translation: This practice, promoting growth, longevity, and strength, is superior. It is the observance of Mandookaparni and the use of Shunti and honey. (92)

sloka: yadyat santarpaṇaṃ śītamavidāhi hitaṃ laghu| annapānaṃ niṣevyaṃ tatkṣatakṣīṇaiḥ sukhārthibhiḥ||93|| yaccoktaṃ yakṣmiṇāṃ pathyaṃ kāsināṃ raktapittinām| tacca kuryādavekṣyāgniṃ vyādhiṃ sātmyaṃ balaṃ tathā||94||
translation: For those seeking pleasure who are debilitated or weak, the appropriate and cool food and drink should be offered. Similarly, one should follow the advice given for treating diseases caused by Kapha, Pitta, and excess bile, after examining the state of the digestive fire and the disease itself.

sloka: upekṣite bhavettasminnanubandho hi yakṣmaṇaḥ| prāgevāgamanāttasya tasmāttaṃ tvarayā jayet||95||
translation: Neglect of a patient can result in disease worsening. Therefore, one should seek treatment without delay. (Verse 95)

sloka: tatra ślokau kṣatakṣayasamutthānaṃ sāmānyapṛthagākṛtim| asādhyayāpyasādhyatvaṃ sādhyānāṃ siddhimeva ca||96|| uktavāñjyeṣṭhaśiṣyāya kṣatakṣīṇacikitsite| tattvārthavidvītarajastamodoṣaḥ[1] punarvasuḥ||97||
translation:
In that context, the arising of the common and distinct forms of kṣhatakṣaya (a disease affecting the spleen) and its being both incurable and curable are stated as the achievement of the desired outcome for the most excellent disciple who has been treated for the diminished spleen and is free from the impurities of rajas and tamas. (96, 97)

References:
[१]. Here, rajas and tamas refer to the two of the three fundamental forces or qualities that constitute matter in Hindu philosophy. Rajas represents activity, movement, and desire, while tamas signifies inertia, darkness, and ignorance.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalapūrite cikitsitasthāne kṣatakṣīṇacikitsitaṃ nāmaikādaśo'dhyāyaḥ||11||
translation: In the treatise written by Agnivesa, when the desired section hasn't been obtained and there is a place for treatment that is filled with firm strength, the name of the eleventh chapter is "The Treatment of the Afflicted and Weakened."

sloka: athāto gulmacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now I will explain the treatment of plant diseases. This is what Bhagavan Atreya said.

sloka: sarvaprajānāṃ pitṛvaccharaṇyaḥ punarvasurbhūtabhaviṣyadīśaḥ|  cikitsitaṃ gulmanibarhaṇārthaṃ provāca siddhaṃ vadatāṃ variṣṭhaḥ||3||
translation: Being the refuge of all beings, Punarvasu, the lord of past, present, and future, who is the best among those who can make things happen, has spoken this verified remedy for the treatment of swelling.

sloka: viṭśleṣmapittātiparisravādvā taireva vṛddhaiḥ paripīḍanādvā|  vegairudīrṇairvihatairadho vā bāhyabhighātairatipīḍanairvā||4||  rūkṣānnapānairatisevitairvā śokena mithyāpratikarmaṇā vā|  viceṣṭitairvā viṣamātimātraiḥ koṣṭhe prakopaṃ samupaiti vāyuḥ||5||
translation: The wind enters the stomach due to an excessive increase of phlegm, bile, and mucus; due to the pressure of these same aged ones; due to violent and irregular movements; due to severe external injuries; or due to eating dry and overly processed foods; or due to incorrect actions taken in response to grief; or due to irregular activities that are beyond appropriate measure.

sloka: kaphaṃ ca pittaṃ ca sa duṣṭavāyuruddhūya  mārgān vinibaddhya tābhyām|  hṛnnābhipārśvodarabastiśūlaṃ karotyatho yāti na baddhamārgaḥ||6||
translation: Disturbing the paths by aggravating bodily humors such as phlegm and bile, and becoming bound in the channels, he causes pain in the region of the heart, navel, flanks, and lower abdomen. Then, he goes not according to the proper path. (Ref: Charaka Samhita, Sutrasthana, Chapter 16, Verse 6)

sloka: pakvāśaye pittakaphāśaye vā sthitaḥ svatantraḥ parasaṃśrayo vā|  sparśopalabhyaḥ paripiṇḍitatvādgulmo yathādoṣamupaiti nāma||7||
translation: Just as a lump of dough, when placed in a place with fermentation, becomes fermented on its own without any external support, similarly the swelling [in the body], depending on its nature, arises.

sloka: bastau ca nā bhyāṃ hṛdi pārśvayorvā sthānāni gulmasya bhavanti pañca| pañcātmakasya prabhavaṃ tu tasya vakṣyāmi liṅgāni cikitsitaṃ ca||8||
translation: I will describe the origin and symptoms of the ailment affecting the one who has five aspects, whose five locations are not in the feet, arms, heart, or sides.

sloka: rūkṣānnapānaṃ viṣamātimātraṃ viceṣṭitaṃ vegavinigrahaśca|  śoko'bhighāto'timalakṣayaśca nirannatā cānilagulmahetuḥ||9||
translation: Fasting on rough food, eating in excessive or insufficient quantities, overexertion, restraining one's movements, experiencing sorrow, being physically assaulted, having a weakened state due to a lack of nourishment, and contracting an illness caused by wind are the nine causes.

sloka: yaḥ sthānasaṃsthānarujāṃ vikalpaṃ viḍvātasaṅgaṃ galavaktraśoṣam|  śyāvāruṇatvaṃ śiśirajvaraṃ ca hṛtkukṣipārśvāṃsaśirorujaṃ ca||10||  karoti jīrṇe'bhyadhikaṃ prakopaṃ bhukte mṛdutvaṃ samupaiti yaśca|  vātāt sa gulmo na ca tatra rūkṣaṃ kaṣāyatiktaṃ kaṭu copaśete||11||
translation: The one who, understanding the transient nature of bodily states, reacts excessively to aging with even more intense aggravation; and who becomes unnecessarily mild when eaten upon - this tumor is not afflicted by rough, astringent, or bitter qualities from wind [located] there.

sloka: kaṭvamlatīkṣṇoṣṇavidāhirūkṣakrodhātimadyārkahutāśasevā|  āmābhighāto  rudhiraṃ ca duṣṭaṃ paittasya gulmasya nimittamuktam||12||
translation: The sharp, bitter, and fiery inflammation of this abscess is said to be caused by its being struck with a blunt object and the flow of blood.

sloka: jvaraḥ pipāsā vadanāṅgarāgaḥ śūlaṃ mahajjīryati bhojane ca|  svedo vidāho vraṇavacca gulmaḥ sparśāsahaḥ paittikagulmarūpam||13||
translation: Fever, thirst, facial complexion changes, severe pain, fatigue that occurs during eating, excessive sweating, burning sensation, wounds, and abdominal lumps are all symptoms of an advanced stage of a disease.

sloka: śītaṃ guru snigdhamaceṣṭanaṃ ca sampūraṇaṃ prasvapanaṃ divā ca|  gulmasya hetuḥ kaphasambhavasya sarvastu diṣṭo nicayātmakasya||14||
translation: The cause of the growth of a plant is the accumulation of the phlegm-dominant constitution, which is cold, heavy, unctuous, stable, and causes sleep both day and night.

sloka: staimityaśītajvaragātrasādahṛllāsakāsārucigauravāṇi|  śaityaṃ rugalpā kaṭhinonnatatvaṃ gulmasya rūpāṇi kaphātmakasya||15||
translation: The six tastes, coldness, heaviness, roughness, and the distinct shape are the qualities of phlegm.

sloka: nimittaliṅgānyupalabhya gulme dvidoṣaje doṣabalābalaṃ ca|  vyāmiśraliṅgānaparāṃstu gulmāṃstrīnādiśedauṣadhakalpanārtham||16||
translation: Upon recognizing the symptoms in a tumor with two faults (dvidoshaje), one should identify and classify three types of tumors with mixed symptoms for the purpose of determining the course of treatment.

sloka: mahārujaṃ dāhaparītamaśmavadghanonnataṃ śīghravidāhi dāruṇam|  manaḥśarīrāgnibalāpahāriṇaṃ tridoṣajaṃ gulmamasādhyamādiśet||17||
translation: Prescribe the intractable lump of wood that is greatly heated, fiery, elevated like stone, swiftly burning, and removes the strength of both the mind and body, and which has the three doshas ( bodily humors), to be a harsh purgative.

sloka: ṛtāvanāhāratayā bhayena virūkṣaṇairvegavinigrahaiśca|  saṃstambhanollekhanayonidoṣairgulmaḥ striyaṃ raktabhavo'bhyupaiti||18||
translation: The tumor (gulma) afflicts a woman, approaching her through excessive appetite, fear, fainting, spasms, and other such maladies caused by the interruption of normal digestion.

sloka: yaḥ spandate piṇḍita eva nāṅgaiścirāt saśūlaḥ samagarbhaliṅgaḥ|  sa raudhiraḥ strībhava eva gulmo māse vyatīte daśame cikitsyaḥ||19||
translation: If a lump (tumor) continues to swell without visible wounds or injuries, resembling the shape of a fruit, and has been present for a long time with symptoms of pain, then it should be considered as a bloody tumor and must be treated medically by the end of the tenth month.

sloka: kriyākramamataḥ siddhaṃ gulmināṃ gulmanāśanam|  pravakṣyāmyata ūrdhvaṃ ca yogān gulmanibarhaṇān||20||
translation: The eradication of unwanted growths (physical or spiritual) is accomplished through the sequential practice (krīyā-kramam) described hereafter

sloka: rūkṣavyāyāmajaṃ gulmaṃ vātikaṃ tīvravedanam|  baddhaviṇmārutaṃ snehairāditaḥ samupācaret||21||
translation: The stiff, pain-causing growth (gulma) that arises from vata (wind), is caused by rough exercise and is sensitive, should be treated with anointments applied from the beginning.

sloka: bhojanābhyañjanaiḥ pānairnirūhaiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ|  snigdhasya bhiṣajā svedaḥ kartavyo gulmaśāntaye||22||
translation: Sweating should be induced by a physician using steady application of food, drink, medicinal procedures, and anointment for the elimination of tumors in a person who is oily (has excessive oiliness/fat in the body).

sloka: srotasāṃ mārdavaṃ kṛtvā jitvā mārutamulbaṇam|  bhittvā vibandhaṃ snigdhasya svedo gulmamapohati||23||
translation: By making the flow of the rivers gentle, overcoming the wind's force, and breaking open the knot of the compact sheath, sweat removes the tumor (of the body).

sloka: snehapānaṃ hitaṃ gulme viśeṣeṇordhvanābhije|  pakvāśayagate bastirubhayaṃ jaṭharāśraye||24||
translation: Placing a warm poultice is beneficial for a swelling in a specific location, as well as for an intestine that has moved to the abdominal cavity.

sloka: dīpte'gnau vātike gulme vibandhe'nilavarcasoḥ|  bṛṃhaṇānyannapānāni snigdhoṣṇāni prayojayet||25||
translation: In a blazing fire, in the windy growth, and in the binding of the luminous wind, one should apply nourishing and warm foods.

sloka: punaḥ punaḥ snehapānaṃ nirūhāḥ sānuvāsanāḥ|  prayojyā vātagulmeṣu kaphapittānurakṣiṇā||26||
translation: Again and again administering of sneha (medicinal oil) is indicated as a preventive measure to protect kapha and pitta in vata-related disorders.

sloka: kapho vāte jitaprāye pittaṃ śoṇitameva vā|  yadi kupyati vā tasya kriyamāṇe cikitsite||27||   yatholbaṇasya doṣasya tatra kāryaṃ bhiṣagjitam|  ādāvante ca madhye ca mārutaṃ parirakṣatā||28||
translation: If the dosha (humor) of kapha is almost subdued and pitta is dominant or if blood becomes aggravated, then, O victorious physician, appropriate measures should be taken to counteract that specific vitiation at the beginning, middle, and end stages; and also protect the vata.

sloka: vātagulme kapho vṛddho hatvā'gnimaruciṃ yadi|  hṛllāsaṃ gauravaṃ tandrāṃ janayedullikhettu tam||29||
translation: If an aged kapha, residing in the tree named vata, were to kill agni's brilliance, causing a burst of laughter, heaviness, and drowsiness, then one should identify that entity.

sloka: śūlānāhavibandheṣu gulme vātakapholbaṇe|  vartayo guṭikāścūrṇaṃ kaphavātaharaṃ hitam||30||
translation: In the sacrificial post's knots and in the grass wound by the gust, grinding and applying the powder is beneficial for removing phlegm and wind.

sloka: pittaṃ vā yadi saṃvṛddhaṃ santāpaṃ vātagulminaḥ|  kuryādvirecyaḥ sa bhavet sasnehairānulomikaiḥ||31||
translation: If the Pitta (bile) becomes excessively high or if there is an inflammation due to wind in the body, then one should induce vomiting with unctuous substances.

sloka: gulmo yadyanilādīnāṃ kṛte samyagbhiṣagjite|  na praśāmyati raktasya so'vasekāt praśāmyati||32||
translation: If, in the treatment of ailments like wind disorder, performed skillfully, the swelling does not subside, then it is pacified by the application of a leech.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇenodite gulme paittike sraṃsanaṃ hitam|  rūkṣoṣṇena tu sambhūte sarpiḥ praśamanaṃ param||33||
translation: In a swelling caused by heat and treated with warmth, its bursting is beneficial; when it arises from intense heat, applying ghee is the supreme cure.

sloka: pittaṃ vā pittagulmaṃ vā jñātvā pakvāśayasthitam|  kālavinnirharet sadyaḥ satiktaiḥ kṣīrabastibhiḥ||34||  payasā vā sukhoṣṇena satiktena virecayet|  bhiṣagagnibalāpekṣī sarpiṣā tailvakena vā||35||
translation: Having identified whether it is bile or a bile-based tumor that has become situated in the digestive tract, one should immediately use astringent decoctions, made from such things as pomegranate, irim seeds, or black myrobalan, to eradicate it. Alternatively, one may choose to induce vomiting using warm, astringent milk. This should be decided based on the strength of the patient and the advice of the physician.

sloka: tṛṣṇājvaraparīdāhaśūlasvedāgnimārdave|  gulmināmarucau cāpi raktamevāvasecayet||36||
translation:
For those with fever, burning sensation, hiccups, and indigestion, as well as for those suffering from emaciation and jaundice, one should apply copper[*] water.

[*] The word used in the verse is "tāmra" which usually means copper or something that has a copper-like color. In this context, it likely refers to actual copper or a copper-infused solution.

sloka: छिन्नमूला विदह्यन्ते न गुल्मा यान्ति च क्षयम्।  रक्तं हि व्यम्लतां याति तच्च नास्ति न चास्ति रुक्॥३७॥
translation: The roots being severed, they are burnt, but the shoots do not go to decay. The redness turns into a state of transformation, which neither exists nor does not exist."

sloka: hṛtadoṣaṃ parimlānaṃ jāṅgalaistarpitaṃ rasaiḥ|  samāśvastaṃ saśeṣārtiṃ sarpirabhyāsayet punaḥ||38||
translation: The one who is free from mental flaws, clarified by the tastes of wilderness plants, and whose distress has been alleviated, should be treated with ghee again.

sloka: raktapittātivṛddhatvāt kriyāmanupalabhya ca|  yadi gulmo vidahyeta śastraṃ tatra bhiṣagjitam||39||
translation: If, due to excessive bile and pitta, a tumor is not perceiving any therapeutic action, then the weapon (i.e., the treatment) that can destroy it is considered to have been wielded by the physician.

sloka: guruḥ kaṭhinasaṃsthāno gūḍhamāṃsāntarāśrayaḥ|  avivarṇaḥ sthiraścaiva hyapakvo gulma ucyate||40||
translation: The teacher is firmly established, with hidden fleshy parts, of uniform complexion, and unyielding; he is called a matured plant (student). (40)

sloka: dāhaśūlārtisaṅkṣobhasvapnanāśāratijvaraiḥ|  vidahyamānaṃ jānīyādgulmaṃ tamupanāhayet||41||
translation: One should recognize a swelling that is being consumed by inflammation, sharp pain, seizure, night-time fever, and chronic illness. It should be treated. (Referring to a symptom of an illness that needs medical attention.)

sloka: vidāhalakṣaṇe gulme bahistuṅge samunnate|  śyāve saraktaparyante saṃsparśe bastisannibhe||42||    nipīḍitonnate stabdhe supte [4] tatpārśvapīḍanāt|  tatraiva piṇḍite śūle sampakvaṃ gulmamādiśet||43||
translation: In a lump characterized by burning sensation, located externally, protruding, blackish in color and extending up to the red part, when pressed, becomes elevated, stiff, and subsides after being pressed; and when a hard mass is felt in the same location, it should be considered as mature for surgical extraction.

sloka: tatra dhānvantarīyāṇāmadhikāraḥ kriyāvidhau|  vaidyānāṃ kṛtayogyānāṃ vyadhaśodhanaropaṇe||44||
translation: In that regard, the authority to perform therapeutic procedures belongs to qualified and competent physicians.

sloka: antarbhāgasya cāpyetat pacyamānasya lakṣaṇam|  hṛtkroḍaśūnatā'ntaḥsthe [5] bahiḥsthe pārśvanirgatiḥ||45||
translation: The sign of the portion (of food) being digested is the emergence on both sides from within the whiteness of the intestines.

sloka: pakvaḥ srotāṃsi saṅkledya vrajatyūrdhvamadho'pi vā|  svayampravṛttaṃ taṃ doṣamupekṣeta hitāśanaiḥ [6] ||46||   daśāhaṃ dvādaśāhaṃ vā rakṣan bhiṣagupadravān|
translation: One who has digested their food should refrain from consuming liquids, whether moving upwards or downwards. They should ignore this naturally occurring gastric problem and instead focus on caring for themselves and managing any medical emergencies for a period of ten or twelve days.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ hitaṃ pānaṃ sarpiṣaḥ saviśodhanam||47||  śuddhasya tiktaṃ sakṣaudraṃ prayoge sarpiriṣyate|48|
translation: Hence, pure ghee is the beneficial drink for consumption and should be properly cleaned. Once it is pure, it will taste bitter and astringent when used in rituals.

sloka: śītalairgurubhiḥ snigdhairgulme jāte kaphātmake||48||  avamyasyālpakāyāgneḥ kuryāllaṅghanamāditaḥ|
translation: When a cold, unctuous tumor arising from an excess of phlegm has appeared, one should initially perform fomentation on the reduced digestive fire (agni).

sloka: mando'gnirvedanā mandā gurustimitakoṣṭhatā||49||   sotkleśā cāruciryasya sa gulmī vamanopagaḥ|
translation: The agni (fire) is weak, experiencing mild sensation; the guru is also slow, with limited storage capacity. Such a person, who is afflicted by hiccups and has an appealing appearance, is called gulmi (a type of medical condition).

sloka: uṣṇairevopacaryaśca kṛte vamanalaṅghane||50||  yojyaścāhārasaṃsargo bheṣajaiḥ kaṭutiktakaiḥ|
translation: One should take medicines that are pungent and astringent in taste, and should also perform vomiting treatment with hot things. The engagement with food should also be regulated.

sloka: sānāhaṃ savibandhaṃ ca gulmaṃ kaṭhinamunnatam||51||  dṛṣṭvā''dau svedayedyuktyā svinnaṃ ca vilayedbhiṣak|
translation: Upon seeing a deep-seated and hardened tumor, the physician should initially sweat it out using proper methods and then cause its dissolution.

sloka: laṅghanollekhane svede kṛte'gnau sampradhukṣite||52||   kaphagulmī pibet kāle sakṣārakaṭukaṃ ghṛtam|
translation: A person suffering from phlegm and bile-related ailments should drink clarified butter that is properly heated in a fire, mixed with a pinch of salt, at the appropriate time.

sloka: sthānādapasṛtaṃ jñātvā kaphagulmaṃ virecanaiḥ||53||   sasnehairbastibhirvā'pi śodhayeddāśamūlikaiḥ|
translation: Having understood that something has departed from its place, one should cleanse the phlegm-related ailment with emetics or, if necessary, with medicated fats and decoctions made from dasamula (a group of ten herbs).

sloka: mande'gnāvanile mūḍhe jñātvā sasnehamāśayam||54||    guṭikācūrṇaniryūhāḥ prayojyāḥ kaphagulminām|
translation: For the ignorant person who kindles a weak fire in the wind, ground and processed medicinal formulations should be applied for kapha and vata disorders (fifty-fourth verse).

sloka: kṛtamūlaṃ mahāvāstuṃ kaṭhinaṃ stimitaṃ gurum||55|| jayetkaphakṛtaṃ gulmaṃ kṣārāriṣṭāgnikarmabhiḥ||
translation: A well-established, large residence that is hard, compact, heavy, and difficult to overcome can be conquered by kapha-removing, alkaline, and agni-stimulating measures.

sloka: doṣaprakṛtigulmartuyogaṃ buddhvā kapholbaṇe||56||   baladoṣapramāṇajñaḥ kṣāraṃ gulme prayojayet|    ekāntaraṃ dvyantaraṃ vā tryahaṃ viśramya vā punaḥ||57||    śarīrabaladoṣāṇāṃ vṛddhikṣapaṇakovidaḥ|
translation: Having understood the nature of the humoral disease along with the season and its development, one who is knowledgeable about the strength and measurement of the dosha should administer kshara treatment in the gulma (abdominal tumor). This should be done either once a day or every other day, after resting for three days. One who knows the growth and reduction of the bodily doshas.

sloka: śleṣmāṇaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhaṃ māṃsakṣīraghṛtāśinaḥ||58||  chittvā chittvā''śayāt kṣāraḥ kṣaratvāta kṣārayatyadhaḥ|
translation: After repeatedly cutting through the phlegm, which is sweet, unctuous, and consumed of meat, curds, and ghee, the chyme (kshara) downwards causes to digest due to its liquid nature.

sloka: mande'gnāvarucau sātmye madye sasnehamaśnatām||59|| prayojyā mārgaśuddhyarthamariṣṭāḥ kaphagulminām||
translation: For promoting unity in a gathering with dim fire and poor fuel, offering (food) mixed with liquor and oil is recommended as a remedy for kapha and gulma ailments.

sloka: laṅghanollekhanaiḥ svedaiḥ sarpiḥpānairvirecanaiḥ||60||  bastibhirguṭikācūrṇakṣārāriṣṭagaṇairapi|       ślaiṣmikaḥ kṛtamūlatvādyasya gulmo na śāmyati||61||    tasya dāho hṛte rakte śaralohādibhirhitaḥ|
translation: The swelling of a person with a suppressed digestive disorder does not subside through sweating, marking, emesis, drinking ghee, purgation, or the administration of drugs such as powders, decoctions, and alkalies. Only when their inflammation is treated by hitting it with sharp instruments like scalpels does it subside.

sloka: auṣṇyāttaikṣṇyācca śamayedagnirgulme kaphānilau||62||   tayoḥ śamācca saṅghāto gulmasya vinivartate|
translation: Fire, with heat and sharpness, can subdue the phlegm and wind in a tumor. Its cessation also leads to the elimination of the tumor's formation.

sloka: dāhe dhānvantarīyāṇāmatrāpi bhiṣajāṃ balam||63||    kṣāraprayoge bhiṣajāṃ kṣāratantravidāṃ balam||
translation: The strength of healers resides in applying alkali even here among the healers of dāhé (a disease) of dhānvantarīṇām

sloka: vyāmiśradoṣe vyāmiśra eṣa eva kriyākramaḥ||64||
translation: In a mixture of virtues and faults, this is indeed the sequence of actions.

sloka: siddhānataḥ pravakṣyāmi yogān gulmanibarhaṇān|
translation: I will expound from settled facts the yoga techniques that destroy the causes of decay.

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalādhānyaviḍaṅgacavyacitrakaiḥ||65||   kalkīkṛtairghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ sakṣīraṃ vātagulmanutiti tryūṣaṇādighṛtam   |
translation: The ghee prepared with a mixture of three kinds of powders - ushana, triphala, and vida, mixed with cavya and citraka, when churned with curd and milk, becomes an effective medicine for digestive disorders.

sloka: एत एव च कल्काः स्युः कषायः पाञ्चमूलिकः  ॥६६॥     द्विपञ्चमूलिको वाऽपि तद्घृतं गुल्मनुत् परमिति त्र्यूषणादिघृतमपरम्
translation: These pillars (kalkah) would be of five-rooted or three-rooted type; the foremost purifier is considered to be the ghee made from cow's milk (tryushanadighritam), while the other one is (aparam) the ghee made from the milk of other animals.

sloka: (ṣaṭpalaṃ vā pibet sarpiryaduktaṃ rājayakṣmaṇi)||67||
translation: One should drink six palmfuls of ghee, as prescribed in the treatment for royal consumption disease (a type of poisoning).

sloka: prasannayā vā kṣīrārthaṃ  surayā dāḍimena vā|  dadhnaḥ sareṇa vā kāryaṃ ghṛtaṃ mārutagulmanut||68||
translation: The purpose of churning either with a pleased woman, or with a sura (fermented liquor) and pomegranate, or with the rennet of a cow, is to produce butter, prompted by the wind-puff.

sloka: hiṅgusauvarcalājājībiḍadāḍimadīpyakaiḥ|  puṣkaravyoṣadhanyākavetasakṣāracitrakaiḥ||69||  śaṭīvacājagandhailāsurasaiśca vipācitam|  śūlānāhaharaṃ sarpirdadhnā cānilagulminām||70||  iti hiṅgusauvarcalādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Ghee prepared with the extracts of Hingusa, Sauvarcala, Bida, Dadima, Pushkara, Vyosha, Dhatura, and Chandana, flavored with the fragrance of Shati, Champra, and Sugandhika, possessed by the power to alleviate the ailments caused by Vata, Pitta, and Kapha.

sloka: hapuṣāvyoṣapṛthvīkācavyacitrakasaindhavaiḥ|  sājājīpippalīmūladīpyakairvipacedghṛtam||71||  sakolamūlakarasaṃ sakṣīradadhidāḍimam|  tat paraṃ vātagulmaghnaṃ śūlānāhavimokṣaṇam||72|| yonyarśograhaṇīdoṣaśvāsakāsārucijvarān|  bastihṛtpārśvaśūlaṃ ca ghṛtametadvyapohati||73||  iti hapuṣādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The ghee prepared with the juices of Kasha, Salmali, Pippali, and sunthi, mixed with the powders of Kolamula, Haridra, Vida, Saindhava, and Sarshapa; that which has a pleasant smell, removes the disorders of the throat, cough, and fever, clears obstructions of the stomach and flanks, and eliminates intestinal worms – this is known as Hapusha ghee.

sloka: pippalyā picuradhyardho dāḍimāddvipalaṃ palam|  dhānyātpañca ghṛtācchuṇṭhyāḥ karṣaḥ kṣīraṃ caturguṇam||74||  siddhametairghṛtaṃ sadyo vātagulmaṃ vyapohati|  yoniśūlaṃ śiraḥśūlamarśāṃsi viṣamajvaram||7 5||  iti pippalyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The ghee (clarified butter) cooked from the upper half of a split pippala (auspicious tree, i.e., Indian bael) fruit, two parts of a ripe date palm fruit, five measures from grain, and sixteen times that of pure ghee, quickly cures diseases like vata (air), gulma (abdominal tumor), yoni shula (pain in the female genital organs), sirashoola (headache), and uneven fever. This is known as the pippalyadi ghrita.

sloka: ghṛtānāmauṣadhagaṇā ya ete parikīrtitāḥ|  te cūrṇayogā vartyastāḥ kaṣāyāste ca gulminām||76||
translation: The powders of these herbs that are mentioned as being in ghee, are effective against diseases.

sloka: koladāḍimagharmāmbusurāmaṇḍāmlakāñjikaiḥ|  śūlānāhaharī peyā bījapūrarasena vā||77||
translation: Prepared from koladā, tamarind, gharmambu, manda and anjikai, the drink made from shoola, naahahari, and filled with the juice of seeds is delicious.

sloka: cūrṇāni mātuluṅgasya bhāvitāni rasena vā|  kuryādvartīḥ saguṭikā gulmānāhārtiśāntaye||78||
translation: The root of mulunga (aka false smoke tree) should be crushed and cooked in its juice to make pellets for the treatment of digestive ailments.

sloka: hiṅgu trikaṭukaṃ pāṭhāṃ hapuṣāmabhayāṃ śaṭīm|  ajamodājagandhe ca tintiḍīkāmlavetasau||79||  dāḍimaṃ puṣkaraṃ dhānyamajājīṃ citrakaṃ vacām|  dvau kṣārau lavaṇe dve ca cavyaṃ caikatra cūrṇayet||80||
translation: Grind together hingu, trikatukam, patha, harita-puspi, abhaya, shati, ajmoda, jagdhnde, tintidika, karamla, dhatri, dhamani, dadima, pushkara, grain, aja, chitraka, vacha, two types of kshara, lavana, and cavya.

sloka: cūrṇametat prayoktavyamannapāneṣvanatyayam|  prāgbhaktamathavā peyaṃ madyenoṣṇodakena vā||81||
translation: This powder should be used in food and drink, whether previously cooked or to be consumed with alcohol or warm water.

sloka: pārśvahṛdbastiśūleṣu gulme vātakaphātmake|  ānāhe mūtrakṛcchre ca śūle ca gudayonije [9] ||82||  grahaṇyarśovikāreṣu plīhni pāṇḍvāmaye'rucau|  urovibandhe hikkāyāṃ kāse śvāse galagrahe||83||
translation: In cases of abdominal pain, flatulence, wind, colic, and indigestion; in symptoms of enlarged spleen, anemia, jaundice, and cough; in afflictions of the sides, chest, and urinary tract; one should attend to and consider the treatments for these conditions.

sloka: bhāvitaṃ mātuluṅgasya cūrṇametadrasena vā|  bahuśo guṭikāḥ kāryāḥ kārmukāḥ syustato'dhikam||84||  iti hiṅgvādicūrṇaṃ guṭikā ca |
translation: The powder of bhavita matulunga, prepared with a sufficient amount of this savory substance, should be made into many pills; doing so will yield even more. (Note: Matulunga is a type of fruit or citrus fruit.)

sloka: mātuluṅgaraso hiṅgu dāḍimaṃ biḍasaindhave|  surāmaṇḍena pātavyaṃ vātagulmarujāpaham||85||
translation: The juice of mātulunga, hingu, and dāḍima, when mixed with bidalasindhava and sura-maṇḍa, should be consumed to alleviate vāta-guḷma-roga.

sloka: śaṭīpuṣkarahiṅgvamlavetasakṣāracitrakān|  dhānyakaṃ ca yavānīṃ ca viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ vacām||86||  sacavyapippalīmūlāmajagandhāṃ sadāḍimām|  ajājīṃ cājamodāṃ ca cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā prayojayet||87||  rasena mātuluṅgasya madhuśuktena vā punaḥ|  bhāvitaṃ guṭikāṃ kṛtvā supiṣṭāṃ kolasammitām||88||
translation: Prepare a mixture of the following: shati, pushkara, honey, munja, barley, venga, salt, licorice, gooseberry,

sloka: gulmaṃ plīhānamānāhaṃ śvāsaṃ kāsamarocakam|  hikkāṃ hṛdrogamarśāṃsi vividhāṃ śiraso rujam||89||  pāṇḍvāmayaṃ kaphotkleśaṃ sarvajāṃ ca pravāhikām|  pārśvahṛdbastiśūlaṃ ca guṭikaiṣā vyapohati||90||
translation: This medicine made from Pandu's ingredients alleviates various disorders such as swelling, emaciation, cough, hiccups, heart pain, and various headaches, as well as the afflictions of the phlegmatic Kapha type, and the pains in the sides, chest, and lower abdomen.

sloka: nāgarārdhapalaṃ piṣṭvā dve pale luñcitasya ca|  tilasyaikaṃ guḍapalaṃ kṣīreṇoṣṇena nā pibet||91||  vātagulmamudāvartaṃ yoniśūlaṃ ca nāśayet|
translation: Having ground two parts of sesame seeds and one part of jaggery, and mixed with warm milk, one should not drink it. This also destroys any abdominal pain caused by wind and menstrual cramps.

sloka: pibederaṇḍajaṃ tailaṃ vāruṇīmaṇḍamiśritam||92||  tadeva tailaṃ payasā vātagulmī pibennaraḥ|  śleṣmaṇyanubale pūrvaṃ hitaṃ pittānuge param||93||
translation: A person should drink sesame oil, mixed with sea water first, when there is weakness of Kapha and then, for the best benefit, drink milk when there is aggravation of Pitta.

sloka: sādhayecchuddhaśuṣkasya laśunasya catuṣpalam|  kṣīrodake'ṣṭaguṇite  kṣīraśeṣaṃ ca nā pibet||94||  vātagulmamudāvartaṃ gṛdhrasīṃ viṣamajvaram|  hṛdrogaṃ vidradhiṃ śothaṃ sādhayatyāśu tatpayaḥ||95||  iti laśunakṣīram |
translation: One should treat with a concoction of four ingredients the impure, dried-up garlic and also the remaining butterfat in eightfold-concentrated milk. That same garlic-infused butter can quickly cure flatulence, arthritis, hiccups, irregular fever, heart disease, and worm infestation.

sloka: tailaṃ prasannā gomūtramāranālaṃ yavāgrajam|  gulmaṃ jaṭharamānāhaṃ pītamekatra sādhayet||96||  iti tailapañcakam |
translation: The fifth part of the oil treatment consists of using clarified butter that is agreeable, cow urine that is pure, barley grains, a growth in the abdomen, and drink all mixed together.

sloka: pañcamūlīkaṣāyeṇa sakṣāreṇa  śilājatu|  pibettasya prayogeṇa vātagulmāt pramucyate||97|| iti śilājatuprayogaḥ |
translation: By drinking the juice of the five-leaved plant and a piece of silver, one is freed from a disorder of the wind. This is the use of a silver ingot.

sloka: vāṭyaṃ pippalīyūṣeṇa mūlakānāṃ rasena vā|  bhuktvā snigdhamudāvartādvātagulmādvimucyate||98||
translation: By consuming the sap of pippali (long pepper) mixed with the juice of mulo (radish) roots, or by having a warm and nourishing meal, one can get relief from vatagulma (a disorder caused by an imbalance in wind and phlegm).

sloka: śūlānāhavibandhārtaṃ svedayedvātagulminam|  svedaiḥ svedavidhāvuktairnāḍīprastarasaṅkaraiḥ||99||
translation: Afflicted by the thrusting pain of thorns and swaying in the wind, (one) should sweat using the sweating methods prescribed in the text, caused by the mingling of the networks of channels.

sloka: bastikarma paraṃ vidyādgulmaghnaṃ taddhi mārutam|  sve sthāne prathamaṃ jitvā sadyo gulmamapohati||100||  tasmādabhīkṣṇaśo gulmā nirūhaiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ|  prayujyamānaiḥ śāmyanti vātapittakaphātmakāḥ||101||  gulmaghnā vividhā diṣṭāḥ siddhāḥ siddhiṣu bastayaḥ|
translation: Know that the function of wind is the foremost in digestion. Having first conquered it in its own place, one promptly eliminates the lump (mass of undigested food). Therefore, the lumps are frequently pacified by constantly applying various medicinal purgatives which have been tested and proven effective in curative properties.

sloka: gulmaghnāni ca tailāni vakṣyante vātarogike||102|| tāni mārutaje gulme pānābhyaṅgānuvāsanaiḥ|  prayuktānyāśu sidhyanti tailaṃ hyanilajitparam [12] ||103||
translation: Oily substances that alleviate gulma (abdominal tumors) are mentioned for those suffering from vataroga (nervous system disorders). When used in the form of drinking, anointing, and fumigation on the gulma affected by vata, they quickly become effective. Indeed, oil is the supreme conqueror of vata.

sloka: nīlinīcūrṇasaṃyuktaṃ pūrvoktaṃ ghṛtameva|  samalāya pradātavyaṃ śodhanaṃ vātagulmine||104||
translation: The ghee previously mentioned, mixed with blue vitriol, should be given for evacuation to a patient with abdominal obstruction caused by air.

sloka: nīlinītrivṛtādantīpathyākampillakaiḥ saha|  śodhanārthaṃ ghṛtaṃ deyaṃ sabiḍakṣāranāgaram||105||
translation: Ghee (clarified butter) mixed with turmeric, camphor, and other cleansing agents should be given.

sloka: nīlinīṃ triphalāṃ rāsnāṃ balāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm|  pacedviḍaṅgaṃ vyāghrīṃ ca palikāni jalāḍhake||106||  tena pādāvaśeṣeṇa ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet|  dadhnaḥ prasthena saṃyojya sudhākṣīrapalena ca||107||  tato ghṛtapalaṃ dadyādyavāgūmaṇḍamiśritam|  jīrṇe samyagviriktaṃ ca bhojayedrasabhojanam||108||  gulmakuṣṭhodaravyaṅgaśophapāṇḍvāmayajvarān|  śvitraṃ plīhānamunmādaṃ ghṛtametadvyapohati||109||  iti nīlinyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Take Trivrit fruit, bitter neem, and bala, as well as vighrii and the fruits of palasha, all crushed and boiled in water. With this residue, cook a prastha (equivalent to 12 oz) of ghee, adding a prastha each of curd and sugarcane juice. Then offer a quarter prastha of this mixture, mixed with salt and black pepper, as a tasty dish. This ghee prepared with these ingredients can help alleviate diseases such as gulma, kushtha, arsha, shotha, pandu, and jwara, as well as vitiligo, splenomegaly, insanity, and consumption. (This completes the recipe for ghee prepared with neem etc.)

sloka: kukkuṭāśca mayūrāśca tittirikrauñcavartakāḥ|  śālayo madirā sarpirvātagulmabhiṣagjitam||110||  hitamuṣṇaṃ dravaṃ snigdhaṃ bhojanaṃ vātagulminām|   samaṇḍavāruṇīpānaṃ pakvaṃ vā dhānyakairjalam||111||
translation: Roosters, peacocks, partridges, and those who maintain herons; barns, wine, ghee, and victory over the wind's blows; wholesome warm liquids, flowing and smooth, are food for those affected by the wind's blows; Aruna-colored drinks or cooked grains with water.

sloka: mande'gnau vardhate gulmo dīpte cāgnau praśāmyati|  tasmānnā nātisauhityaṃ kuryānnātivilaṅghanam||112||
translation: In a weakened fire, the sprout grows; in a blazing fire, it subsides. Therefore, one should not seek excessive familiarity nor should they cross the boundaries (of propriety).

sloka: sarvatra gulme prathamaṃ snehasvedopapādite|  yā kriyā kriyate siddhiṃ sā yāti na virūkṣite||113||
translation: The first action that is performed when a sprout appears everywhere, i.e., the application of fertilizer and sweat, leads to success; it certainly does so if not neglected.

sloka: bhiṣagātyayikaṃ buddhvā pittagulmamupācaret|  vairecanikasiddhena sarpiṣā tiktakena  vā||114||
translation: Having understood that it is a case of bhisaj-atikramana (a type of medical mismanagement causing a wrong treatment), one should administer a pittagulma (a therapeutic emetic) with vairecani siddha (an alkaline metallic compound, such as copper sulfate) or tiktaka sarpis (bitter ghee).

sloka: rohiṇīkaṭukānimbamadhukatriphalātvacaḥ|  karṣāṃśāstrāyamāṇā ca paṭolatrivṛtoḥ pale||115||
translation: The buds of Rohini, bitter orange, and three-leaved caper, when applied to the skin, along with a decoction of patala, triphala, and the inner bark of the tree.

sloka: dve pale ca masūrāṇāṃ sādhyamaṣṭaguṇe'mbhasi|  śṛtāccheṣaṃ ghṛtasamaṃ sarpiṣaśca catuṣpalam||116||  pibet sammūrcchitaṃ tena gulmaḥ śāmyati paittikaḥ|  jvarastṛṣṇā ca śūlaṃ ca bhramo mūrcchā'rucistathā||117||  iti rohiṇyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: One should drink, after being well-mixed, a quantity of ghee equal to the residual portion of two masura beans from water containing eight times its weight. This alleviates abdominal pains, fever, thirst, cramps, dizziness, and fainting, as per Rohini's instructions.

sloka: jale daśaguṇe sādhyaṃ trāyamāṇācatuṣpalam|  pañcabhāgasthitaṃ pūtaṃ kalkaiḥ saṃyojya kārṣikaiḥ||118||
translation: To make the water five times more pure, mix it with four measures of clay and one measure of sadhyah (a type of alkali), when it is being purified.

sloka: rohiṇī kaṭukā mustā trāyamāṇā durālabhā|  kalkaistāmalakīvīrājīvantīcandanotpalaiḥ||119||  rasasyāmalakānāṃ ca kṣīrasya ca ghṛtasya ca|  palāni pṛthagaṣṭāṣṭau dattvā samyagvipācayet||120||
translation: By protecting Rohini, katuka musta, and duralabha tree that are trayamana-treated, and with kalka, malaki, viraaja, icchandana, and utpala, one should separately give eight portions of the pure rasa of malaka fruits and of milk and ghee for proper nourishment.

sloka: pittaraktabhavaṃ gulmaṃ vīsarpaṃ paittikaṃ jvaram|  hṛdrogaṃ kāmalāṃ kuṣṭhaṃ hanyādetadghṛtottamam||121||  iti trāyamāṇādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: This excellent ghee (clarified butter) destroys in this world Pitta (bile), carbuncle, fever caused by pitta, heart disease, and kushta (an eczematous condition); thus it is a protectant ghee.

sloka: rasenāmalakekṣūṇāṃ ghṛtapādaṃ  vipācayet|  pathyāpadaṃ pibetsarpistatsiddhaṃ pittagulmanut||122||  ityāmalakādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The ghee (clarified butter) of the Amalaka fruits should be churned and consumed

sloka: drākṣāṃ madhūkaṃ kharjūraṃ vidārīṃ saśatāvarīm|  parūṣakāṇi triphalāṃ sādhayetpalasammitam||123||  jalāḍhake pādaśeṣe rasamāmalakasya ca|  ghṛtamikṣurasaṃ kṣīramabhayākalkapādikam||124||  sādhayettadghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ śarkarākṣaudrapādikam|  prayogāt pittagulmaghnaṃ sarvapittavikāranut||125||  iti drākṣādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepare a decoction using drākṣā (grapes), madhūka (licorice), kharjūra (date palm), vidārī (potentialy Indian fig), and sashatāvarī (a type of grass), all measured in proportion to the size of a pala (a unit of weight). To this, add jalāḍhaka (a type of salt), āḍhaka (another unit of weight) of pāda (water), and the juice of amalaka (Indian gooseberry), along with ghṛta (ghee), ikṣu-rasa (sugarcane juice), kṣīra (milk), and abhayākala (black salt). Once this is prepared and cooked, it becomes a medication that counteracts pitta (bile) disorders and Pitta-related diseases. This is known as the decoction of grapes and other ingredients.

sloka: vṛṣaṃ samūlamāpothya pacedaṣṭaguṇe jale|  śeṣe'ṣṭabhāge tasyaiva puṣpakalkaṃ pradāpayet||126||  tena siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ śītaṃ sakṣaudraṃ pittagulmanut|  raktapittajvaraśvāsakāsahṛdroganāśanam||127||  iti vāsāghṛtam
translation: By churning the fresh extract of the Soma plant in eight parts of water and offering one-eighth as a residue, a cool, clarified butter is obtained that eliminates diseases caused by Kapha, Pitta, and blood, as well as fever, cough, and heart disease. This is called Vasāghṛta.

sloka: dvipalaṃ trāyamāṇāyā jaladviprasthasādhitam|  aṣṭabhāgasthitaṃ pūtaṃ koṣṇaṃ kṣīrasamaṃ pibet||128||  pibedupari tasyoṣṇaṃ kṣīrameva yathābalam|  tena nirhṛtadoṣasya gulmaḥ śāmyati paittikaḥ||129||
translation: One should drink, kept in a copper vessel, water mixed with a quarter amount of cow's milk, boiled and cooled down to body temperature. Such drinking, as per one's capacity, devoid of impurities, alleviates the Pitta (bile) caused swelling.

sloka: drākṣābhayārasaṃ gulme paittike saguḍaṃ pibet|  lihyātkampillakaṃ vā'pi virekārthaṃ madhudravam||130||
translation: One should drink the fresh juice of grapes, sugarcane, or the Kampa flower, mixed together, as a cleansing practice. (130)

sloka: dāhapraśamano'bhyaṅgaḥ sarpiṣā pittagulminām|  candanādyena tailena tailena madhukasya vā||131||
translation: The soothing of inflammation can be achieved through application of ghee (clarified butter), or using sandalwood paste or sesame oil, or honey as well.

sloka: ye ca pittajvaraharāḥ  satiktāḥ kṣīrabastayaḥ|  hitāste pittagulmibhyo vakṣyante ye ca siddhiṣu||132||
translation: Those who are able to alleviate Pittaja fever, are temperate in eating curd and milk, and speak words that are beneficial, they are said to be capable of preventing Pittagulma (complications due to an imbalance in the bodily humor called pitta).

sloka: śālayo jāṅgalaṃ māṃsaṃ gavyāje payasī ghṛtam|  kharjūrāmalakaṃ drākṣāṃ dāḍimaṃ saparūṣakam||133||  āhārārthaṃ prayoktavyaṃ pānārthaṃ salilaṃ śṛtam|  balāvidārīgandhādyaiḥ pittagulmacikitsitam||134||
translation: Meat from the wild, ghee obtained without milk, fruits like dates and bitter ones, grapes, and raisins are to be used as food. Pure water is to be consumed for quenching thirst. Medicinal substances that alleviate phlegm and bile should be used for maintaining balance of bodily humors.

sloka: āmānvaye pittagulme sāme vā kaphavātike|  yavāgūbhiḥ khaḍairyūṣaiḥ sandhukṣyo'gnirvilaṅghite||135||
translation: In the context of discussing a medical treatment, Agni (the digestive fire) should be stimulated with decoctions made from barley and other ingredients when there is an increase in pitta (bile), kapha (phlegm), or vata (wind) in the body.

sloka: śamaprakopau doṣāṇāṃ sarveṣāmagnisaṃśritau|  tasmādagniṃ sadā rakṣennidānāni ca varjayet||136||
translation: Always protect the fire and avoid its causes, for it controls and suppresses all faults.

sloka: vamanaṃ vamanārhāya pradadyāt kaphagulmine|
translation: One should give emesis to someone who is eligible for it (i.e., has an excess of kapha dosha) to induce vomiting.

sloka: snigdhasvinnaśarīrāya gulme śaithilyamāgate||137||  pariveṣṭya pradīptāṃstu balvajānathavā kuśān|  bhiṣakkumbhe samāvāpya gulmaṃ ghaṭamukhe nyaset||138||
translation: For a body that is moist and emaciated, when the lump becomes loose, wrap heated boluses of barley or darbha grass around it. Placing the swelling into a physician's pot should be done.

sloka: saṅgṛhīto  yadā gulmastadā ghaṭamathoddharet|  vastrāntaraṃ tataḥ kṛtvā bhindyādgulmaṃ  pramāṇavit||139||  vimārgājapadādarśairyathālābhaṃ prapīḍayet|  mṛdnīyādgulmamevaikaṃ na tvantrahṛdayaṃ  spṛśet||140||
translation: When the tumor is firmly held, it should then be lifted up. After that, a space in the clothing should be made and the tumor should be punctured according to what is feasible. Only one tumor should be pressed at a time, not the heart.

sloka: tilairaṇḍātasībījasarṣapaiḥ parilipya ca|    śleṣmagulmamayaḥpātraiḥ sukhoṣṇaiḥ svedayedbhiṣak||141||
translation: The physician should anoint the patient suffering from phlegm-related ailments with sesame, atasi seed, and mustard seeds, and then make them sweat with warm, comfortable vessels.

sloka: savyoṣakṣāralavaṇaṃ daśamūlīśṛtaṃ ghṛtam|  kaphagulmaṃ jayatyāśu sahiṅgubiḍadāḍimam||142||  iti daśamūlīghṛtam|
translation: The decotion of the ten roots, when mixed with salt, ghee, and jaggery, quickly cures kapha-related ailments such as cough. (This is known as Dasamooli Ghrita.)

sloka: bhallātakānāṃ dvipalaṃ pañcamūlaṃ palonmitam|  sādhyaṃ vidārīgandhādyamāpothya salilāḍhake||143||  pādaśeṣe rase tasmin pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ vacām|  viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ hiṅgu yāvaśūkaṃ biḍaṃ śaṭīm||144||  citrakaṃ madhukaṃ rāsnāṃ piṣṭvā karṣasamaṃ bhiṣak|  prasthaṃ ca payaso dattvā ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||145||  etadbhallātakaghṛtaṃ kaphagulmaharaṃ param|     plīhapāṇḍvāmayaśvāsagrahaṇīrogakāsanut||146||  iti bhallātakādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The panchamula of bhallataka, whose measure is determined, when combined with the sap of vidayanga, palonmita, etc., along with pippalI, nAgara, vacA, vaDaiga, saindhava, hiMgu, yAvashUka, biDa, śaṬi, citraka, madhuka, rAsnA, reduced to a powder and mixed with a prastha each of water and ghee, becomes a superior remedy for kapha, vAta, pitta disorders, emaciation, cough, and other diseases. This is called bhallataka ghRita.

sloka: pippalīpippalīmūlacavyacitrakanāgaraiḥ|  palikaiḥ sayavakṣārairghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||147||  kṣīraprasthaṃ ca tat sarpihanti gulmaṃ kaphātmakam|  grahaṇīpāṇḍurogaghnaṃ plīhakāsajvarāpaham||148||  iti kṣīraṣaṭpalakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "One should cook a medicated oil with pippalimoola (roots of Pippali or long pepper), vyaghrakanaka (a type of plant), palika (a type of fruit), and yavakshaara (salt made from barley), adding ghee equivalent to the measure of a prastha (an ancient Indian unit of weight); this removes the kaphadosha-related tumor. It is also helpful in treating diseases like gulma (abdominal lump), Pandu-roga (anemia), and saja-jwara (seasonal fever). Thus, it is called 'kshirashatpala ghritam'."

sloka: trivṛtāṃ triphalāṃ dantīṃ daśamūlaṃ palonmitam|  jale caturguṇe paktvā caturbhāgasthitaṃ rasam||149||  sarpireraṇḍajaṃ tailaṃ kṣīraṃ caikatra sādhayet|  sa siddho miśrakasnehaḥ sakṣaudraḥ kaphagulmanut||150||  kaphavātavibandheṣu kuṣṭhaplīhodareṣu ca|  prayojyo miśrakaḥ sneho yoniśūleṣu cādhikam||151||  iti miśrakaḥ snehaḥ
translation: By cooking separately the three-seeded, three-fruited, toothed *Dashmoola* of a size suitable for a spoonful in four times the amount of water, and then reducing it to one fourth, ghee, oil from eranda seeds, and milk can be combined. This blended ointment, which is also salted and is beneficial in counteracting kapha and phlegm disorders, as well as diseases caused by an imbalance of vata, Pitta, and Kapha, should be used in larger quantities in diseases of the womb and other similar conditions. This is known as blended ointment.

sloka: yaduktaṃ vātagulmaghnaṃ sraṃsanaṃ nīlinīghṛtam|  dviguṇaṃ tadvirekārthaṃ prayojyaṃ kaphagulminām||152||  sudhākṣīradrave cūrṇaṃ trivṛtāyāḥ subhāvitam|  kārṣikaṃ madhusarpibhyāṃ līḍhvā  sādhu viricyate||153||
translation: The oil that is named Nilini, which when used in a quantity twice as much as that of a rice grain, breaks up Kapha-related disorders such as those affecting the throat and is destructive to Vata-related disorders such as those affecting the limbs; when mixed with Sudhaka (a type of sugar syrup), the powder of triple-treated Trivrita (a type of plant), and Karshana (a type of substance), and then cooked with Madhu (honey) and Sarpi (ghee), it becomes suitable for use.

sloka: jaladroṇe vipaktavyā viṃśatiḥ pañca cābhayāḥ|  dantyāḥ palāni tāvanti citrakasya tathaiva ca||154|| aṣṭabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu rasaṃ pūtamadhikṣipet|  dantīsamaṃ guḍaṃ pūtaṃ kṣipettatrābhayāśca tāḥ||155||  tailārdhakuḍavaṃ caiva trivṛtāyāścatuṣpalam|  cūrṇitaṃ palamekaṃ  tu pippalīviśvabheṣajam||156||  tat sādhyaṃ lehavacchīte tasmiṃstailasamaṃ madhu|  kṣipeccūrṇapalaṃ caikaṃ tvagelāpatrakeśarāt||157||  tato lehapalaṃ līḍhvā jagdhvā caikāṃ harītakīm|  sukhaṃ viricyate snigdho doṣaprasthamanāmayam||158||  gulmaṃ śvayathumarśāṃsi pāṇḍurogamarocakam|  hṛdrogaṃ grahaṇīdoṣaṃ kāmalāṃ viṣamajvaram||159||  kuṣṭhaṃ plīhānamānāhameṣā hanyupasevitā|  niratyayaḥ kramaścāsyā dravo māṃsarasaudanaḥ||160||  iti dantīharītakī
translation: On a Jaladrona (a type of tree) twenty-five leaves, each with five veins that are not afraid, and twenty-eight tooth-like parts, similar to Citraka (another type of plant), should be taken. After that, the remaining eighth portion of its juice, which is pure, should be mixed with an equal amount of sugar, free from fear, and the same amount of fine powder of Pippali (long pepper). In a cool liquid medium, add a small amount of this mixture to an equal quantity of sesame oil. Then, consume one part of this mixture along with Haritaki (Terminalia chebula). After consuming it, one will experience a smooth, healthy body free from impurities, and it cures various diseases such as gulma (abdominal tumor), shvayathu (consumption/tuberculosis), marsha (inflammation), pāṇḍuroga (anemia), amarocaka (loss of taste), hridroga (heart disease), grahani dosha (digestive impairment), kamala (jaundice), visamajvara (irregular fever), kushtha (leprosy), plihana (enlarged spleen), arsas (piles), and other ailments. This is the recipe for Dantiharitaki (a type of Ayurvedic medicine).

sloka: siddhāḥ siddhiṣu vakṣyante nirūhāḥ kaphagulminām|  ariṣṭayogāḥ siddhāśca grahaṇyarśaścikitsite||161||
translation: The accomplished ones are mentioned in the attainment of siddhis, the causes in the case of phlegm-related disorders, auspicious planetary conjunctions, and the accomplished ones are to be adopted in the treatment of diseases.

sloka: yaccūrṇaṃ guṭikā yāśca vihitā vātagulminām|  dviguṇakṣārahiṅgvamlavetasāstāḥ kaphe hitāḥ||162||
translation: The powder and pills prescribed by the physician for the treatment of phlegm-related disorders are beneficial when doubled in quantity with turmeric, pippali, and honey.

sloka: ya eva grahaṇīdoṣe kṣārāste kaphagulminām|  siddhā niratyayāḥ śastā dāhastvante praśasyate||163||
translation: Those who are capable of curing the afflictions caused by the faults in the grasping organs are considered praiseworthy and permanently established as the healers of those suffering from kapha and gulma.

sloka: prapurāṇāni dhānyāni jāṅgalā mṛgapakṣiṇaḥ|  kaulattho mudgayūṣaśca pippalyā nāgarasya ca||164||  śuṣkamūlakayūṣaśca bilvasya varuṇasya  ca|  cirabilvāṅkurāṇāṃ ca yavānyāścitrakasya ca||165||
translation: The ancient grains, the plants and animals of the wild, koulatha, mudga, yusha, pippala, arka, bilva, varuna's bilva, long-established sprouts of bilva, and barley of Citraka.

sloka: bījapūrakahiṅgvamlavetasakṣāradāḍimaiḥ|  takreṇa tailasarpirbhyāṃ vyañjanānyupakalpayet||166||
translation: With vinegar, salt, cucumber, and ginger, one should prepare flavorings by churning with butter and buttermilk.

sloka: pañcamūlīśṛtaṃ toyaṃ purāṇaṃ vāruṇīrasam|  kaphagulmī pibetkāle jīrṇaṃ mādhvīkameva vā||167||
translation: One should drink aged, varuni-flavored water, drawn from a fifth root source, at the appropriate time to counteract kapha and gulma.

sloka: yavānīcūrṇitaṃ takraṃ biḍena lavaṇīkṛtam|  pibet sandīpanaṃ vātakaphamūtrānulomanam ||168||
translation: One should drink buttermilk, churned from yava (barley), mixed with salt, which kindles digestive fire and helps in the elimination of wind, phlegm, and feces.

sloka: sañcitaḥ kramaśo gulmo mahāvāstuparigrahaḥ|  kṛtamūlaḥ sirānaddho yadā kūrma ivonnataḥ||169||  daurbalyārucihṛllāsakāsavamyaratijvaraiḥ  |  tṛṣṇātandrāpratiśyāyairyujyate na sa sidhyati||170||
translation:
When a planted creeper, gradually growing, enveloping a large tree,
Establishes its roots and rises up like a tortoise,
And it is bound by weakness, cough, fever, lethargy, and thirst,
Then it does not become successful. (169-170)

sloka: gṛhītvā sajvaraśvāsaṃ vamyatīsārapīḍitam|  hṛnnābhihastapādeṣu śophaḥ karṣati gulminam||171||
translation: Grasping the anxious breathing and stomach pain, one pulls out (using their) hands and feet on the navel; this is how they treat the swelling in a gulma (abdominal tumor).

sloka: raudhirasya tu gulmasya garbhakālavyatikrame|  snigdhasvinnaśarīrāyai dadyāt snehavirecanam||172||
translation: In the case of a splinter in a wound, if there is a delay in the healing process, one should administer ointment to the now become moist and fleshy body.

sloka: palāśakṣārapātre dve dve pātre tailasarpiṣoḥ|  gulmaśaithilyajananīṃ paktvā mātrāṃ prayojayet||173||
translation: In a pair of Palaasha leaf bowls, after preparing a measured quantity of oil and ghee that promotes the loosening of knots (i.e., alleviates stiffness), one should use it.

sloka: prabhidyeta na yadyevaṃ dadyādyoniviśodhanam  |   kṣāreṇa yuktaṃ palalaṃ sudhākṣīreṇa vā punaḥ||174|| ābhyāṃ vā bhāvitān dadyādyonau kaṭukamatsyakān|  varāhamatsyapittābhyāṃ laktakān vā subhāvitān||175||  adhoharaiścordhvaharairbhāvitān vā samākṣikaiḥ|  kiṇvaṃ vā saguḍakṣāraṃ dadyādyoniviśodhanam||176||
translation: If one doesn't cleanse the womb, can it be purified with something mixed with lime or sudha-ksheera (sweetened condensed milk), or both? Or should one use fishes treated with varaha-pitta and matysa-pitta, or lakshaka (a type of pulse) treated with adho-hara (a substance used as purgative) or irdhva-hara (an upward moving substance) or samakshika (a substance causing sneezing), or a mixture of kuñjala (a type of bird) and lime? (This passage describes various methods to purify the womb before conception in Indian medical texts.)

sloka: raktapittaharaṃ kṣāraṃ lehayenmadhusarpiṣā|  laśunaṃ madirāṃ tīkṣṇāṃ matsyāṃścāsyai pradāpayet||177||
translation: One should consume lime (ksāra) mixed with honey and sesame oil, and give garlic, wine, and fish to her.

sloka: bastiṃ sakṣīragomūtraṃ sakṣāraṃ dāśamūlikam|  adṛśyamāne rudhire dadyādgulmaprabhedanam||178||
translation: In the presence of pus, urine, cow dung, and salt, one should administer a medicine that causes emesis if blood is not visible.

sloka: pravartamāne rudhire dadyānmāṃsarasaudanam|  ghṛtatailena cābhyaṅgaṃ pānārthaṃ taruṇīṃ surām||179||
translation: In the flowing blood, one should offer a mixture of meat and broth. Also, massage a young woman with ghee and oil for her to drink the Surā (an alcoholic beverage).

sloka: rudhire'tipravṛtte tu raktapittaharīḥ kriyāḥ|  kāryā vātarugārtāyāḥ sarvā vātaharīḥ punaḥ||180||
translation: In the event of excessive bleeding, all practices that alleviate raktapitta (a type of Pitta disorder) should be employed to relieve vata disorders as well.

sloka: ghṛtatailāvasekāṃśca tittirīṃścaraṇāyudhān|  surāṃ samaṇḍāṃ pūrvaṃ ca pānamamlasya sarpiṣaḥ||181||  prayojayeduttaraṃ vā jīvanīyena sarpiṣā|  atipravṛtte rudhire satiktenānuvāsanam||182||
translation: Anointed with ghee and sesame oil, the arrows and weapons should first be dipped in a mixture of Sura and Madhu. Then, they should be applied with life-sustaining ghee when blood loss is excessive and the wound has turned dry.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  snehaḥ svedaḥ sarpirbastiścūrṇāni bṛṃhaṇaṃ guḍikāḥ|  vamanavirekau mokṣaḥ kṣatajasya ca vātagulmavatām||183||  sarpiḥ satiktasiddhaṃ kṣīraṃ prasraṃsanaṃ nirūhāśca|  raktasya cāvasecanamāśvāsanasaṃśamanayogāḥ||184||
translation:
There, the verses describe:
- The use of powders of rice, flour, ghee, and excretion for swelling.
- The administration of purgatives and emetics for evacuation.
- The application of ghee processed with sugar as a medicated enema for alleviating vata disorders.
- The use of lekhana (scraping) therapy for reducing excess fat.
- Pouring of clarified butter in the mouth for pacifying burning sensation caused by pitta disorders.
- Application of cooling substances and comforting measures to manage blood-related conditions.

sloka: upanāhanaṃ saśastraṃ pakvasyābhyantaraprabhinnasya|  saṃśodhanasaṃśamane pittaprabhavasya gulmasya||185||  snehaḥ svedo bhedo laṅghanamullekhanaṃ virekaśca|  sarpirbastirguṭikāścūrṇamariṣṭāśca sakṣārāḥ||186||
translation: For the pitta-born abscess that is not broken from within, unripe or with weapons; cleansing, calming, oleation, sweating, incision, expression, scattering, and use of medicines in the form of powders, pastes, pills, and decoctions are recommended.

sloka: gulmasyānte dāhaḥ kaphajasyāgre'panītaraktasya|  gulmasya raudhirasya kriyākramaḥ strībhavasyoktaḥ||187||
translation: The burning at the end of a tumor, and before that, the removal of impure blood – this is the procedure for dealing with a tumor, as has been described for achieving femininity.

sloka: pathyānnapānasevā hetūnāṃ varjanaṃ yathāsvaṃ ca|  nityaṃ cāgnisamādhiḥ snigdhasya ca sarvakarmāṇi||188||  heturliṅgaṃ siddhiḥ kriyākramaḥ sādhyatā na yogāśca|  gulmacikitsitasaṅgraha etāvān vyāhṛto'gniveśasya||189||
translation: Avoiding unhealthy food, drink, and service; regularly practicing agnihotra (a Vedic fire ritual); having affectionate attachment to all actions; understanding the causes, signs, accomplishment, and process of yoga - these are the designated means of Agni's worship.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsitasthāne  gulmacikitsitaṃ nāma pañcamo'dhyāyaḥ||5||
translation: In the tantra (treatise) created by Agnivesha, after being edited by Charaka, the fifth chapter titled "Gulma Cikitsita" (Treatment of Gulma).

sloka: athāta unmādacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the cure for madness.\*\* This is what Bhagavan Atreya said.

sloka: buddhismṛtijñānataponivāsaḥ punarvasuḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ śaraṇyaḥ|  unmādahetvākṛtibheṣajāni kāle'gniveśāya śaśaṃsa pṛṣṭaḥ||3||
translation: When asked about the means to control the agitations of the mind, the sage Punarvasu replied: "Buddhi (intellect), smriti (memory), jnana (knowledge), tapas (austerity), and nivasa (residence) are the means for people to seek refuge in and conquer the causes of confusion."

sloka: viruddhaduṣṭāśucibhojanāni pradharṣaṇaṃ devagurudvijānām|  unmādaheturbhayaharṣapūrvo mano'bhighāto viṣamāśca ceṣṭāḥ||4||
translation: Avoiding food that is contradictory, unclean, and impure; harming gods, gurus, and brahmins; causing intoxication, fear, or excitement; mental shock; and unsteady actions.

sloka: tairalpasattvasya malāḥ praduṣṭā buddhernivāsaṃ hṛdayaṃ pradūṣya|  srotāṃsyadhiṣṭhāya manovahāni pramohayantyāśu narasya cetaḥ||5||
translation: The impurities of a person with low spiritual tendencies quickly pollute the mind's intellect and, taking hold of the senses' source, swiftly cause confusion in the man's consciousness. (Translation courtesy: Shri Abhinav Gupta)

sloka: dhīvibhramaḥ sattvapariplavaśca paryākulā dṛṣṭiradhīratā ca|  abaddhavāktvaṃ hṛdayaṃ ca śūnyaṃ sāmānyamunmādagadasya liṅgam||6||  sa mūḍhacetā na sukhaṃ na duḥkhaṃ nācāradharmau kuta eva śāntim|  vindatyapāstasmṛtibuddhisañjño bhramatyayaṃ ceta itastataśca||7||
translation: The deluded-minded one, whose intellect is unsteady and who is overwhelmed by the turbulent senses and unsteady vision; whose speech is unrestrained, and whose heart is empty; such a commonplace, insane person never finds happiness or distress, nor proper conduct. If they wander about in this state, with their memory, intellect, and consciousness impaired, where do they find peace?

sloka: samudbhramaṃ buddhimanaḥsmṛtīnāmunmādamāgantunijotthamāhuḥ| tasyodbhavaṃ pañcavidhaṃ pṛthak tu vakṣyāmi liṅgāni cikitsitaṃ ca||8||
translation: I will describe the five distinct symptoms that indicate the onset of agitation in the intellect and memory

sloka: rūkṣālpaśītānnavirekadhātukṣayopavāsairanilo'tivṛddhaḥ|  cintādijuṣṭaṃ  hṛdayaṃ pradūṣya buddhiṃ smṛtiṃ cāpyupahanti śīghram||9||  asthānahāsasmitanṛtyagītavāgaṅgavikṣepaṇarodanāni|  pāruṣyakārśyāruṇavarṇatāśca jīrṇe balaṃ cānilajasya rūpam||10||
translation: Consuming only meager, cold food and fasting frequently, the wind's form becomes quickly enfeebled; rapidly soiling the heart consumed by worries, it also impairs intellect and memory. Moreover, its strength is lost due to harshness, impatience, reddish discoloration, and shaking of the limbs.

sloka: ajīrṇakaṭvamlavidāhyaśītairbhojyaiścitaṃ pittamudīrṇavegam|  unmādamatyugramanātmakasya hṛdi śritaṃ pūrvavadāśu kuryāt||11||  amarṣasaṃrambhavinagnabhāvāḥ santarjanātidravaṇauṣṇyaroṣāḥ  |  pracchāyaśītānnajalābhilāṣāḥ pītā ca bhāḥ pittakṛtasya liṅgam||12||
translation: One should quickly, as before, alleviate the intensified heat of Pitta (bile) caused by eating unctuous, sour, pungent, salty, and astringent foods, along with symptoms like delirium, restlessness, and inflamed mood, and desires for coolness, shade, water, and annul the craving for food and thirst. These are the signs of an excess of Pitta.

sloka: sampūraṇairmandaviceṣṭitasya soṣmā kapho marmaṇi sampravṛddhaḥ|  buddhiṃ smṛtiṃ cāpyupahatya cittaṃ pramohayan sañjanayedvikāram||13||  vākceṣṭitaṃ mandamarocakaśca nārīviviktapriyatā'tinidrā|  chardiśca lālā ca balaṃ ca bhuṅkte nakhādiśauklyaṃ ca kaphātmakasya||14||
translation: When one is lazy with a lack of vigorous activity, an increase in phlegm in the vital organs occurs, impairing intellect and memory, causing confusion and creating a disorder. Additionally, there is weak and unattractive speech, a strong desire for solitude, excessive sleep, and symptoms such as indigestion, cough, and other kapha-related ailments.

sloka: yaḥ sannipātaprabhavo'tighoraḥ sarvaiḥ samastaiḥ sa ca hetubhiḥ syāt|  sarvāṇi rūpāṇi bibharti tādṛgvirudghabhaiṣajyavidhirvivarjyaḥ||15||
translation: The one who is born from the encounter of terrible poison and is itself extremely fierce, and is the cause for all ailments, should be avoided as the treatment for all forms. (Translation based on the given context)

sloka: devarṣigandharvapiśācayakṣarakṣaḥpitṝṇāmabhidharṣaṇāni|  āgantuheturniyamavratādi mithyākṛtaṃ karma ca pūrvadehe||16||
translation: The act of forcibly approaching devarshis, gandharvas, pitrs, and other supernatural beings, along with the observance of vows and rules, and false attribution of actions, are all declared to be the causes of incoming births.

sloka: amartyavāgvikramavīryaceṣṭo jñānādivijñānabalādibhiryaḥ|  unmādakālo'niyataśca yasya bhūtotthamunmādamudāharettam||17||
translation: The one who is not mortal, whose acts are full of strength and bravery, who is accomplished in knowledge, discrimination, and power, and whose uncontrolled behavior can be traced back to the influence of the elements.

sloka: adūṣayantaḥ puruṣasya dehaṃ devādayaḥ svaistu guṇaprabhāvaiḥ|  viśantyadṛśyāstarasā yathaiva cchāyātapau darpaṇasūryakāntau||18|| āghātakālo hi sa pūrvarūpaḥ prokto nidāne'tha surādibhiśca|  unmādarūpāṇi pṛthaṅnibodha kālaṃ ca gamyān puruṣāṃśca teṣām||19||
translation: When the body of a person is untainted by others, including gods, due to its inherent qualities, they become imperceptible like the reflections of the sun and the moon in a mirror. The stated cause of such an event is described as the time for affliction in the context of etiology, while the madness-like manifestations and the passage of time are to be understood separately for those individuals.

sloka: tatra dvayorapi nijāgantunimittayorunmādayoḥ  samāsavistarābhyāṃ bheṣajavidhimanuvyākhyāsyāmaḥ||24||
translation: We will explain the therapeutic procedure for the two types of madness brought about by attachment to one's own goal and means, using both brief and elaborate methods.

sloka: unmāde vātaje pūrvaṃ snehapānaṃ viśeṣavit|  kuryādāvṛtamārge tu sasnehaṃ mṛdu śodhanam||25||
translation: In the case of poisoning by wind, one who is knowledgeable should administer oleation through a closed passage; gently cleanse when the path is obstructed.

sloka: kaphapittodbhave'pyādau vamanaṃ savirecanam|  snigdhasvinnasya kartavyaṃ śuddhe saṃsarjanakramaḥ||26||
translation: In the initial stage of a disorder arising from an excess of Kapha and Pitta, emesis and purgation should be performed for one with a slimy and well-cooked diet; once cleansed, follow up with a purifying regimen.

sloka: nirūhaṃ snehabastiṃ ca śirasaśca virecanam|  tataḥ kuryādyathādoṣaṃ teṣāṃ bhūyastvamācaret||27||
translation: After determining the cause, applying oil and evacuating the head, one should perform (these tasks) without fault; you should repeat this (procedure) excessively for them.

sloka: hṛdindriyaśiraḥkoṣṭhe saṃśuddhe vamanādibhiḥ|  manaḥprasādamāpnoti smṛtiṃ sañjñāṃ ca vindati||28||
translation: By purifying the heart, the senses, and the mind through emetic and other cleansing processes, one attains mental clarity and gains memory and consciousness.

sloka: śuddhasyācāravibhraṃśe tīkṣṇaṃ nāvanamañjanam|  tāḍanaṃ ca manobuddhidehasaṃvejanaṃ  hitam||29||  yaḥ sakto'vinaye  paṭṭaiḥ saṃyamya sudṛḍhaiḥ sukhaiḥ|  apetalohakāṣṭhādye saṃrodhyaśca tamogṛhe||30||
translation: One who is attached to self-control, restraining the mind and senses with firm and gentle ropes, made of iron-like discipline, and who is not disturbed by the stains caused by the departure from pure conduct; and who has locked the door of the house filled with darkness (of ignorance) by discarding things like wood and stone, what is that - sharp austerity?

sloka: tarjanaṃ trāsanaṃ dānaṃ harṣaṇaṃ sāntvanaṃ bhayam|  vismayo vismṛterhetornayanti prakṛtiṃ manaḥ||31||  pradehotsādanābhyaṅgadhūmāḥ pānaṃ ca sarpiṣaḥ|  prayoktavyaṃ manobuddhismṛtisañjñāprabodhanam||32||  sarpiḥpānādirāgantormantrādiśceṣyate vidhiḥ|33|
translation: The actions of pointing, causing fear, giving, delighting, appeasing, generating fear, and astonishment steer the mind towards its natural state. Massaging the body, inhaling smoke, consuming ghee, and following the ritualistic procedure are meant to stimulate the mind, intellect, memory, and consciousness. The method for regulating the urges of ghee consumption and mantra recitation is also described.

sloka: ataḥ siddhatamānyogāñchṛṇūnmādavināśanān||33||  hiṅgusauvarcalavyoṣairdvipalāṃśairghṛtāḍhakam|  caturguṇe gavāṃ mūtre siddhamunmādanāśanam||34||
translation: Learn from me the supremely potent yogic practices that destroy madness. The churned mixture of cow urine, cow dung, milk, curd, and ghee in equal parts, mixed with four times the quantity of water, is a drink that dispels madness.

sloka: viśālā triphalā kauntī  devadārvelavālukam|  sthirā nataṃ rajanyau dve sārive dve priyaṅgukā||35||  nīlotpalailāmañjiṣṭhādantīdāḍimakeśaram|  tālīśapatraṃ bṛhatī mālatyāḥ kusumaṃ navam||36||  viḍaṅgaṃ pṛśniparṇī ca kuṣṭhaṃ candanapadmakau|  aṣṭāviṃśatibhiḥ kalkairetairakṣasamanvitaiḥ||37||  caturguṇe  jale samyagghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet|
translation: Using thirteen ingredients, including large turmeric.

sloka: apasmāre jvare kāse śoṣe mande'nale kṣaye||38||  vātarakte pratiśyāye tṛtīyakacaturthake|  chardyarśomūtrakṛcchreṣu visarpopahateṣu ca||39||  kaṇḍūpāṇḍvāmayonmādaviṣamehagadeṣu ca|  bhūtopahatacittānāṃ gadgadānāmacesām||40||  śastaṃ strīṇāṃ ca vandhyānāṃ dhanyamāyurbalapradam|  alakṣmīpāparakṣoghnaṃ sarvagrahavināśanam||41||  kalyāṇakamidaṃ sarpiḥ śreṣṭhaṃ puṃsavaneṣu caiti kalyāṇakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: In cases of fainting, fever, cough, weakness, loss of appetite, and in the third or fourth stage of diarrhea. In cases of itching, eye disorders, vomiting, and difficulty in passing urine and stools. In cases of poisoning, mental disorder, epilepsy, and insanity. For those who are tormented by spirits, have disturbed minds, or are stammering and physically weak. This ghee is beneficial for women too - it bestows fortune, longevity, and strength. It destroys poverty, sins, and afflictions caused by planets. This ghee is auspicious and supreme during pregnancy.

sloka: ebhya eva sthirādīni jale paktvaikaviṃśatim||42||  rase tasmin pacet sarpirgṛṣṭikṣīre caturguṇe|  vīrārdramāṣakākolīsvayaṅguptarṣabhardhibhiḥ||43||  medayā ca samaiḥ kalkaistat syāt kalyāṇakaṃ mahat|  bṛṃhaṇīyaṃ viśeṣeṇa sannipātaharaṃ param||44||  iti mahākalyāṇakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: By cooking with them, twenty types of solid substances are prepared in water, ghee melts in curd that has been mixed with four times the amount of milk. With an equal quantity of rice and lentils, along with a bull that is as strong as a lion, and by adding spices, this results in a highly auspicious preparation. This ghee is especially beneficial for increasing strength and eliminating weakness. Thus, this ghee is known as Mahakalyanam.

sloka: jaṭilāṃ pūtanāṃ keśīṃ cāraṭīṃ markaṭīṃ vacām|  trāyamāṇāṃ jayāṃ vīrāṃ corakaṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||45||  vayaḥsthāṃ śūkarīṃ chatrāmaticchatrāṃ palaṅkaṣām|  mahāpuruṣadantāṃ ca kāyasthāṃ nākulīdvayam||46||  kaṭambharāṃ vṛścikālīṃ sthirāṃ cāhṛtya tairghṛtam|  siddhaṃ cāturthakonmādagrahāpasmāranāśanam||47||  mahāpaiśācikaṃ nāma ghṛtametadyathā'mṛtam|  buddhismṛtikaraṃ caiva bālānāṃ cāṅgavardhanam||48||  iti mahāpaiśācikaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Having obtained a hunchbacked, lean, shaven-headed, crooked, monkey-like, speaking woman, young, pig-like, parasol-bearing, very energetic, with matted hair, having large teeth, and two-horned; after binding

sloka: laśunānāṃ śataṃ triṃśadabhayāstryūṣaṇāt palam|  gavāṃ carmamasīprastho dvyāḍhakaṃ kṣīramūtrayoḥ||49||  purāṇasarpiṣaḥ prastha ebhiḥ siddhaṃ prayojayet|  hiṅgucūrṇapalaṃ śīte dattvā ca madhumāṇikām||50||  taddoṣāgantusambhūtānunmādān viṣamajvarān|  apasmārāṃśca hantyāśu pānābhyañjananāvanaiḥ||51||  iti laśunādyaṃ ghṛtamlaśunasyāvinaṣṭasya tulārdhaṃ nistuṣīkṛtam|  tadardhaṃ daśamūlasya dvyāḍhake'pāṃ vipācayet||52||  pādaśeṣe ghṛtaprasthaṃ laśunasya rasaṃ tathā|  kolamūlakavṛkṣāmlamātuluṅgārdrakai rasaiḥ||53||  dāḍimāmbusurāmastukāñjikāmlaistadardhikaiḥ|  sādhayettriphalādārulavaṇavyoṣadīpyakaiḥ||54||  yavānīcavyahiṅgvamlavetasaiśca palārdhikaiḥ|  siddhametat pibecchūlagulmārśojaṭharāpaham||55||  bradhnapāṇḍvāmayaplīhayonidoṣajvarakṛmīn|  vātaśleṣmāmayān sarvānunmādāṃścāpakarṣati||56||  ityaparaṃ laśunādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: One hundred and thirty-two garlic bulbs, a palm's width of cow's hide, two palmfuls of cream, one palmful each of garlic juice and urine, a potful of old ghee, a handful of Hingu powder, a pinch of sugar candy, these when combined and used, can cure various ailments such as poison-induced madness, diarrhea, epilepsy, and diseases caused by the improper digestion of garlic. The remaining half of this should be mixed with the juice of two handfuls of dasamula (ten roots), one palmful each of ghee, garlic paste, kola, kuluttha, triphala, aralu, lavana, vyoshaadi, yavani, nimba, vinegar, bhallataka, and madhuka. This preparation cures diseases like Bradhnapandu (enlargement of abdomen), Amayas (diseases caused due to vitiation of doshas), pliha (spongy swelling in the stomach), jwara (fever), vata, shleshma (phlegm) disorders, and various types of madness. This is another garlic preparation.

sloka: hiṅgunā hiṅguparṇyā ca sakāyasthavayaḥsthayā|  siddhaṃ sarpirhitaṃ tadvadvayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ||57||  kevalaṃ siddhamebhirvā purāṇaṃ pāyayedghṛtam|  pāyayitvottamāṃ mātrāṃ śvabhre rundhyādgṛhe'pi vā||58||  viśeṣataḥ purāṇaṃ ca ghṛtaṃ taṃ pāyayedbhiṣak|  tridoṣaghnaṃ pavitratvādviśeṣādgrahanāśanam||59||  guṇakarmādhikaṃ pānādāsvādāt kaṭutiktakam|  ugragandhaṃ purāṇaṃ syāddaśavarṣasthitaṃ ghṛtam||60||  lākṣārasanibhaṃ śītaṃ taddhi sarvagrahāpaham|  medhyaṃ virecaneṣvagryaṃ prapurāṇamataḥ param||61||  nāsādhyaṃ nāma tasyāsti yat syādvarṣaśatasthitam|  dṛṣṭaṃ spṛṣṭamathāghrātaṃ taddhi sarvagrahāpaham||62||  apasmāragrahonmādavatāṃ śastaṃ viśeṣataḥ|63|
translation: With using cow's urine and cow dung, one should offer pure ghee that is either made by experts or has become pure over time. It should be offered in proper measurement in a vessel or at home, especially the aged ghee which is bitter, pungent, has a strong smell, is thick, yellowish like madhuka fruit, cool, and destroys all grahas (evil spirits). Such ghee is excellent for medicinal purposes and cannot be treated by any medicine if it becomes one hundred years old. It is considered as an ultimate purifier, even if touched or smelled, and is extremely beneficial for those suffering from epilepsy, possession, and mental disorders.

sloka: etānauṣadhayogān vā vidheyatvamagacchati||63||  añjanotsādanālepanāvanādiṣu yojayet|  śirīṣo madhukaṃ hiṅgu laśunaṃ tagaraṃ vacā||64||  kuṣṭhaṃ ca bastamūtreṇa piṣṭaṃ syānnāvanāñjanam|  tadvadvyoṣaṃ haridre dve mañjiṣṭhāhiṅgusarṣapāḥ||65||  śirīṣabījaṃ conmādagrahāpasmāranāśanam|  piṣṭvā tulyamapāmārgaṃ  hiṅgvālaṃ hiṅgupatrikām||66||  vārtiḥ syānmaricārdhāṃśā pittābhyāṃ gośṛgālayoḥ|  tayā'ñjayedapasmārabhūtonmādajvarārditān||67||  bhūtārtānamarārtāṃśca narāṃścaiva dṛgāmaye|  maricaṃ cātape māṃsaṃ sapittaṃ sthitamañjanam||68||  vaikṛtaṃ paśyataḥ kāryaṃ doṣabhūtahatasmṛteḥ|  siddhārthako vacā hiṅgu karañjo devadāru ca||69||  mañjiṣṭhā triphalā śvetā kaṭabhītvak kaṭutrikam|  samāṃśāni priyaṅguśca śirīṣo rajanīdvayam||70||  bastamūtreṇa piṣṭo'yamagadaḥ pānamañjanam|  nasyamālepanaṃ caiva snānamudvartanaṃ tathā||71||  apasmāraviṣonmādakṛtyālakṣmījvarāpahaḥ|  bhūtebhyaśca bhayaṃ hanti rājadvāre ca śasyate||72||  sarpiretena siddhaṃ vā sagomūtraṃ tadarthakṛt|  praseke pīnase gandhairdhūmavartiṃ kṛtāṃ pibet||73||  vairecanikadhūmoktaiḥ śvetādyairvā sahiṅgubhiḥ|  śallakolūkamārjārajambūkavṛkabastajaiḥ||74||  mūtrapittaśakṛllomanakhaiścarmabhireva ca|  sekāñjanaṃ pradhamanaṃ nasyaṃ dhūmaṃ ca kārayet||75||  vātaśleṣmātmake prāyaḥ ...|76|
translation: The use of these herbs is recommended:

sloka: ... paittike tu praśasyate|  tiktakaṃ jīvanīyaṃ ca sarpiḥ snehaśca miśrakaḥ||76||  śītāni cānnapānāni madhurāṇi mṛdūni  ca|  śaṅkhakeśāntasandhau vā mokṣayejjño bhiṣak sirām|  unmāde viṣame caiva jvare'pasmāra eva ca||77||
translation: In the practice of paitrika (therapy with diet and lifestyle), a knowledgeable physician should recommend ghee, which is both bitter-tasting and life-sustaining, when it is mixed with sesame oil. Cool and sweet foods and drinks should also be recommended. Specifically, in cases of fainting, poisoning, fever, epilepsy, and unconsciousness, the wise physician should recommend the cleansing of the blood vessels at the junction of the skull and the neck.

sloka: ghṛtamāṃsavitṛptaṃ vā nivāte sthāpayet sukham|  tyaktvā matismṛtibhraṃśaṃ sañjñāṃ labdhvā pramucyate  ||78||
translation: Having satisfied with ghee and meat, one should easily set (it) down in a place without wind, giving up forgetfulness of the mind and regaining consciousness, (one) is freed.

sloka: āśvāsayet suhṛdvā taṃ vākyairdharmārthasaṃhitaiḥ|  brūyādiṣṭavināśaṃ vā darśayedadbhutāni vā||79||  baddhaṃ sarṣapatailāktaṃ nyasedvottānamātape|  kapikacchvā'thavā taptairlohatailajalaiḥ spṛśet||80||  kaśābhistāḍayitvā vā subaddhaṃ vijane gṛhe|  rundhyācceto hi vibhrāntaṃ vrajatyasya tathā śamam||81||  sarpeṇoddhṛtadaṃṣṭreṇa dāntaiḥ siṃhairgajaiśca tam|  trāsayecchastrahastairvā taskaraiḥ śatrubhistathā||82||  athavā rājapuruṣā bahirnītvā susaṃyatam|  trāsayeyurvadhenainaṃ tarjayanto nṛpājñayā||83||  dehaduḥkhabhayebhyo hi paraṃ prāṇabhayaṃ smṛtam|  tena yāti śamaṃ tasya sarvato viplutaṃ manaḥ||84||
translation:
To calm a bewildered mind, one may
1. Speak words of dharma and artha to a dear friend.
2. Reveal wondrous sights or show something bound,
Covered in sesame oil, or beaten with sticks,
Or anointed with hot iron or oil,
Or tied up securely in an isolated house.
3. Or one may frighten them with serpents, lions, elephants,
Or rogues, enemies, or even the king's men,
Ordered to do so by the king himself.
4. For it is said that fear of death surpasses all other fears,
Thus, through this, a scattered mind attains peace from every side.

sloka: iṣṭadravyavināśāttu mano yasyopahanyate|  tasya tatsadṛśaprāptisāntvāśvāsaiḥ śamaṃ nayet||85||  kāmaśokabhayakrodhaharṣerṣyālobhasambhavān|  parasparapratidvandvairebhireva śamaṃ nayet||86||
translation: The mind of one whose valued resources have been destroyed becomes agitated; they should be calmed and reassured with words that are appropriate. One should bring about calmness towards desires, sorrow, fear, anger, exhilaration, jealousy, and greed, as well as the opposing dispositions towards others. (Verse 85-86)

sloka: buddhvā deśaṃ vayaḥ sātmyaṃ doṣaṃ kālaṃ balābale|  cikitsitamidaṃ kuryādunmāde bhūtadoṣaje||87||
translation: Having understood the place, age, suitability, defect, and time, and one's own strength and weakness, this should be done as a treatment for a deranged state caused by a disturbance of the elements.

sloka: devarṣipitṛgandharvairunmattasya tu buddhimān|  varjayedañjanādīni tīkṣṇāni krūrakarma ca||88||   sarpiṣpānādi tasyeha mṛdu bhaiṣajyamācaret|  pūjāṃ balyupahārāṃśca mantrāñjanavidhīṃstathā||89||   śāntikarmeṣṭihomāṃśca japasvastyayanāni ca|  vedoktān niyamāṃścāpi prāyaścittāni cācaret||90||
translation: A wise person should avoid sharp and cruel actions, such as using collyrium, towards a madman. For him, one should perform mild treatments, offer respect, gifts, and Mantras according to scriptural rules. One should also conduct peaceful rituals, such as funeral rites and fire sacrifices, recite auspicious prayers, follow Vedic regulations, and perform expiatory acts.

sloka: bhūtānāmadhipaṃ devamīśvaraṃ jagataḥ prabhum|  pūjayan prayato nityaṃ jayatyunmādajaṃ bhayam||91||
translation: By regularly and devoutly worshiping the lord of all beings, the god who is the controller of the universe, one conquers the fear arising from delusion.

sloka: rudrasya pramathā nāma gaṇā loke caranti ye|  teṣāṃ pūjāṃ ca kurvāṇa unmādebhyaḥ pramucyate||92||
translation: Those who worship the throngs of Rudra's attendants, the Pishachas, are freed from madness.

sloka: balibhirmaṅgalairhomairoṣadhyagadadhāraṇaiḥ|  satyācāratapojñānapradānaniyamavrataiḥ||93||  devagobrahmaṇānāṃ ca gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca|  āgantuḥ praśamaṃ yāti siddhairmantrauṣadhaistathā||94||
translation: By performing auspicious fire sacrifices with offerings of herbs and plants, by giving knowledge, right conduct, austerity, and charity, and by observing vows, one can appease both the divine and the wise teachers. This is also true for those who are accomplished in mantras and medicinal herbs.

sloka: yaccopadekṣyate kiñcidapasmāracikitsite|  unmāde tacca kartavyaṃ sāmānyāddhetudūṣyayoḥ||95||
translation: In the treatment of fainting, whatever is indicated should be done, as it is common for both the cause and the corrupting factor.

sloka: nivṛttāmiṣamadyo yo hitāśī prayataḥ śuciḥ|  nijāgantubhirunmādaiḥ sattvavān na sa yujyate||96||
translation: The one who, in today's world, is abstinent from spoiled substances, benevolent, engaged in meditation, and pure; and who is not associated with his own intoxicating desires, cannot be united with the unrefined.

sloka: prasādaścendriyārthanāṃ buddhyātmamanasāṃ tathā|  dhātūnāṃ prakṛtisthatvaṃ vigatonmādalakṣaṇam||97||
translation: The serenity of the senses, intellect, and mind, as well as the inherent nature of the elements, indicating the absence of symptoms of insanity.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  unmādānāṃ samutthānaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ sacikitsitam|  nijāgantunimittānāmuktavān bhiṣaguttamaḥ||98||
translation: The best physician has described the symptom's emergence of fainting.

sloka: athātaḥ pramehacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1|| iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, I will explain the means of eliminating the subtle impurities. Thus spoke Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: nirmohamānānuśayo nirāśaḥ punarvasurjñānatapoviśālaḥ|  kāle'gniveśāya sahetuliṅgānuvāca mehāñśamanaṃ ca teṣām||3||
translation: Free from delusion and attachment, dispassionate, and vast in knowledge and austerity, he who is aware of the signs of the approaching fire, should advise calmness and control to them (the people).

sloka: āsyāsukhaṃ svapnasukhaṃ dadhīni grāmyaudakānūparasāḥ payāṃsi|  navānnapānaṃ guḍavaikṛtaṃ ca pramehahetuḥ kaphakṛcca sarvam||4||
translation: The pleasure from eating food and the pleasure from sleep, ordinary village water and various kinds of beverages, new grains and sugar-processed foods – all are causes of phlegm and bile.

sloka: medaśca māṃsaṃ ca śarīrajaṃ ca kledaṃ kapho bastigataṃ pradūṣya| karoti mehān samudīrṇamuṣṇaistāneva pittaṃ paridūṣya cāpi||5|| kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvavakṛṣya bastau dhātūn pramehānanilaḥ karoti|  doṣo hi bastiṃ samupetya mūtraṃ sandūṣya mehāñjanayedyathāsvam||6||
translation: When phlegm, located in the stomach, mixes with bile and corrupts the flesh, meat, and bodily exudations, it produces severe intoxication. After extracting the impurities from the stomach, when the wind element activates the tissues, it causes urine to be produced by cleansing the phlegm that has entered the bladder, just as it should. (5-6)

sloka: sādhyāḥ kaphotthā daśa pittajāḥ ṣaṭ yāpyā na sādhyaḥ pavanāccatuṣkaḥ||  samakriyatvādviṣamakriyatvānmahātyayatvācca yathākramaṃ  te||7||
translation: The ten afflictions caused by kapha are curable, while the six originating from pitta are also treatable. However, the four resulting from vayu are not always curable. They should be treated according to their respective severity. (Ayurvedic text)

sloka: kaphaḥ sapittaḥ pavanaśca doṣā medo'sraśukrāmbuvasālasīkāḥ|  majjā rasaujaḥ piśitaṃ ca dūṣyāḥ[1] pramehiṇāṃ viṃśatireva mehāḥ||8||
translation: The doshas (impurities) of phlegm, bile, and wind, as well as fat, blood, flesh, bones, marrow, and semen are all twenty types of impurities in the urine of those suffering from diabetes.

sloka: jalopamaṃ cekṣurasopamaṃ vā ghanaṃ ghanaṃ copari viprasannam|  śuklaṃ saśukraṃ śiśiraṃ śanairvā lāleva vā vālukayā yutaṃ vā||9||  vidyāt pramehān  kaphajān daśaitān
translation: Learn of the eleven types of phlegm and wind disorders, whether they be water-like, similar to the taste of sugarcane juice, dense, dense with clouds on top, white, tinged with yellow, cool, slowly developing, or resembling sand. (Verse 9)

sloka: kṣāropamaṃ kālamathāpi nīlam|  hāridramāñjiṣṭhamathāpi raktametān pramehān ṣaḍuśanti pittāt||10||
translation: Just as salt is neutralized by bluing, turmeric, and red arsenic, similarly, the six kinds of bile are pacified.

sloka: majjaujasā vā vasayā'nvitaṃ vā lasīkayā vā satataṃ vibaddham|  caturvidhaṃ mūtrayatīha[1] vātāccheṣeṣu dhātuṣvapakarṣiteṣu||11||
translation: Defecating in four ways, either due to being constantly bound by loose stools, mucus, or feces mixed with undigested food, or due to the depletion of bodily tissues.
