sloka: varṇaṃ rasaṃ sparśamathāpi gandhaṃ yathāsvadoṣaṃ bhajate pramehaḥ|  śyāvāruṇo vātakṛtaḥ saśūlo majjādisādguṇyamupaityasādhyaḥ||12||
translation: Just as (praméhaḥ) an intoxication inherently partakes of color, taste, touch, and smell in their natural states; similarly, a graying and ruddy wind-born person afflicted by phlegm and bile attains excellence that is easily achievable.

sloka: svedo'ṅgagandhaḥ śithilāṅgatā ca śayyāsanasvapnasukhe ratiśca|  hṛnnetrajihvāśravaṇopadeho ghanāṅgatā keśanakhātivṛddhiḥ||13|| śītapriyatvaṃ galatāluśoṣo mādhuryamāsye karapādadāhaḥ|  bhaviṣyato mehagadasya rūpaṃ mūtre'bhidhāvanti pipīlikāśca||14||
translation: Perspiration, bodily scent, limb weakness, attachment to bed, seat, and sleep, and sexual desire; these are the manifestations in the form of sensations and experiences in the mind, body hair growth, and nail elongation. Cold preference, dryness of the palate, sweetness of the mouth, burning of the hands and feet, and the appearance of ants on urine-these are future signs of diabetes.

sloka: sthūlaḥ pramehī balavānihaikaḥ kṛśastathaikaḥ paridurbalaśca|  sambṛṃhaṇaṃ tatra kṛśasya kāryaṃ saṃśodhanaṃ doṣabalādhikasya||15||  snigdhasya yogā vividhāḥ prayojyāḥ kalpopadiṣṭā malaśodhanāya[1] | ūrdhvaṃ tathā'dhaśca male'panīte meheṣu santarpaṇameva kāryam||16||
translation: For the singular obese person, strengthening is required; for the singular weak one, increasing strength is necessary. For the excessively faulty and strong person, purification is needed. The various yogic practices prescribed for cleaning a tender person should be applied upwards and downwards after removing impurities from the perspiration. (15-16)

sloka: gulmaḥ kṣayo mehanabastiśūlaṃ mūtragrahaścāpyapatarpaṇena|  pramehiṇaḥ syuḥ paritarpaṇāni[2] kāryāṇi tasya[3] prasamīkṣya vahnim||17||
translation: The fading of the lump, abdominal pain, dysuria, and retention of urine should be treated when one is afflicted by diabetes; one should carefully consider this treatment of his. (Translation based on context)

sloka: saṃśodhanaṃ nārhati yaḥ pramehī tasya kriyā saṃśamanī prayojyā|
translation: One who is not worthy of purification should not be subjected to it

sloka: manthāḥ kaṣāyā yavacūrṇalehāḥ pramehaśāntyai laghavaśca bhakṣyāḥ||18|| ye viṣkirā ye pratudā vihaṅgāsteṣāṃ rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ|  yavaudanaṃ rūkṣamathāpi vāṭyamadyāt[1] sasaktūnapi cāpyapūpān||19||  mudgādiyūṣairatha tiktaśākaiḥ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta|  dantīṅgudītailayutaṃ pramehī tathā'tasīsarṣapatailayuktam||20||  saṣaṣṭikaṃ syāttṛṇadhānyamannaṃ yavapradhānastu bhavet pramehī|  yavasya bhakṣyān vividhāṃstathā'dyāt kaphapramehī madhusamprayuktān||21||
translation:
To eliminate impurities, eat light foods that are easy to digest, such as grains, soups, and vegetables. Eat birds that are easy to digest, and enjoy the juices of bitter vegetables. Eat a moderate amount of coarse barley and rice, but avoid Kapha-causing foods. Also, consume various dishes made from wheat and rice, mixed with honey to counteract impurities caused by mucus.[1] Have a lunch of mildly spiced rice, and take an evening meal of fresh vegetables cooked in sesame or atasi oil. Make 60% of your diet barley or rice-based, and eat a variety of wheat and rice dishes with honey to counteract impurities caused by mucus.[2][3]

Note: The verse is related to Ayurvedic dietary guidelines for managing health conditions. It recommends light, easy-to-digest foods, such as grains, soups, vegetables, and certain birds, and avoids heavy or Kapha-causing foods. Specific ingredients, such as honey and oils, are suggested to balance the body's humors (doshas) based on individual needs.

[1] 18. Manthaah kshaayaa yavachuur~nalehaah pramehashantyai laghavashcha bhakshyaah||
[2] 19. Ye vishkiraa ye pratudaa vihangaasteShaam rasairjaangalajairmanoj~naiH|
[3] 20-21. Yavaudanam rookshamathaaapi vaatyamadyaat sasaktUnapicaapyapoopAn|| Mudgadi yuushairathatiktashAkaiH puuraaNashaalyaodanamaadaadIIt|

sloka: niśisthitānāṃ triphalākaṣāye syustarpaṇāḥ kṣaudrayutā yavānām|  tān sīdhuyuktān prapibet pramehī prāyogikānmehavadhārthameva||22||
translation: For those staying up at night, a tarpana (propitiatory offering) should be made with sesame-seed-mixed water and barley that are mixed with siddhi (a type of grass). The one who desires to reduce intoxication should drink these.

sloka: ye śleṣmamehe vihitāḥ kaṣāyāstairbhāvitānāṃ ca pṛthagyavānām|  saktūnapūpān saguḍān sadhānān bhakṣyāṃstathā'nyān vividhāṃśca khādet||23||
translation: Those who, being free from phlegm-related ailments, are accustomed to eating various kinds of food such as grains, cakes, sweets, spices, and other dishes.

sloka: kharāśvagohaṃsapṛṣadbhṛtānāṃ tathā yavānāṃ vividhāśca bhakṣyāḥ|  deyāstathā veṇuyavā yavānāṃ kalpena godhūmamayāśca bhakṣyāḥ||24||
translation: Of the eatables for horses, elephants, and cattle, as well as various grains and vegetables; barley is to be given as alms along with wheat.

sloka: saṃśodhanollekhanalaṅghanāni kāle prayuktāni kaphapramehān|  jayanti pittaprabhavān virekaḥ santarpaṇaḥ saṃśamano vidhiśca||25||
translation:
The activities of purification, marking, and transcending, when performed in due course of time, are beneficial for kapha-medicated disorders and aggravating for pitta-related conditions; the recommended treatment is evacuation, nourishment, pacification, and the observance of rules. (Verse 25)
342,दार्वीं सुराह्वां त्रिफलां समुस्तां कषायमुत्क्वाथ्य पिबेत् प्रमेही। क्षौद्रेण युक्तामथवा हरिद्रां पिबेद्रसेनामलकीफलानाम्॥२६॥,"One should drink the decoction of darbha grass, sura (fermented liquor), and tripala, after boiling and straining it. Alternatively, one can also drink haridra (turmeric) mixed with water, or the juice of fresh bitter gourd.

sloka: dārvīṃ surāhvāṃ triphalāṃ samustāṃ kaṣāyamutkvāthya pibet pramehī| kṣaudreṇa yuktāmathavā haridrāṃ pibedrasenāmalakīphalānām||26||
translation: The

sloka: harītakīkaṭphalamustalodhraṃ pāṭhāviḍaṅgārjunadhanvanāśca| ubhe haridre tagaraṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kadambaśālārjunadīpyakāśca||27|| dārvī viḍaṅgaṃ khadiro dhavaśca surāhvakuṣṭhāgurucandanāni|  dārvyagnimanthau triphalā sapāṭhā pāṭhā ca mūrvā ca tathā śvadaṃṣṭrā||28|| yavānyuśīrāṇyabhayāguḍūcīcavyābhayācitrakasaptaparṇāḥ|  pādaiḥ kaṣāyāḥ kaphamehināṃ te daśopadiṣṭā madhusamprayuktāḥ||29||
translation: Of the USIRA, LODHRA, Chandana, and KASTURI, USIRA is the best for fragrance. Of all things that eliminate fear, PATALA is the supreme. Of NIMBA, ARJUNA, AMRITA, and DHATAKI, NIMBA is excellent for medicinal properties. Of SHIRISHA, SARJA, ARJUNA, and KESHARA, SHIRISHA is superior in qualities. Of PADMA, UTPALA, and KINSHUKA, PADMA is the best. Of ASHVATTHA, PAATHA, and VETRA, ASHVATTHA is supreme for its significance. The roots of KASHAYA, when pounded with the hooves of an elephant and mixed with honey, are prescribed for consumption in ten specified measures.

sloka: uśīralodhrāñjanacandanānāmuśīramustā malakābhayānām|  paṭolanimbāmalakāmṛtānāṃ mustābhayāpadmakavṛkṣakāṇām||30|| lodhrāmbukālīyakadhātakīnāṃ nimbārjunāmrātaniśotpalānām| śirīṣasarjārjunakeśarāṇāṃ priyaṅgupadmotpalakiṃśukānām||31|| aśvatthapāṭhāsanavetasānāṃ kaṭaṅkaṭeryutpalamustakānām|  paitteṣu meheṣu daśa pradiṣṭāḥ pādaiḥ kaṣāyā madhusamprayuktāḥ||32||
translation: In all types of intoxicating beverages, the previous pair of impurities are prescribed to be removed before churning. Similarly, in the preparation and consumption of food, they should be treated separately.

sloka: sarveṣu meheṣu matau tu pūrvau kaṣāyayogau vihitāstu sarve|  manthasya pāne yavabhāvanāyāṃ syurbhojane pānavidhau pṛthak ca||33||
translation: Ghee and other oils, when offered in sacrificial fires that are essentially composed of wind, get transformed. By the mingling of the properties of fat and phlegm, along with those of the oils, the wind is calmed within them.

sloka: siddhāni tailāni ghṛtāni caiva deyāni meheṣvanilātmakeṣu|  medaḥ kaphaścaiva kaṣāyayogaiḥ snehaiśca vāyuḥ śamameti teṣām||34||
translation: One should consume the powder of kampillaka, seventeen types of leaves, huhuka fruits, and kapittha fruits, mixed with sesame oil, to alleviate kapha and pitta. One should also drink a concoction made from the bark of araluka and the juice of its fresh leaves, as well as consume old grains that are pure and fragrant.

sloka: kampillasaptacchadaśālajāni  baibhītarauhītakakauṭajāni|  kapitthapuṣpāṇi ca cūrṇitāni kṣaudreṇa lihyāt kaphapittamehī||35||  pibedrasenāmalakasya cāpi kalkīkṛtānyakṣasamāni kāle|  jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta purāṇamannaṃ mehī rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ||36||
translation: Based on the given Sanskrit verse, the translation is: "Depending upon whether kapha or pitta is affected after observing their relationship with vata, oil or ghee with suitable herbs should be chosen." This is Ayurvedic text advising on treatment procedures.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā'nubandhaṃ pavanāt kaphasya pittasya vā snehavidhirvikalpyaḥ|  tailaṃ kaphe syāt svakaṣāyasiddhaṃ pitte ghṛtaṃ pittaharaiḥ kaṣāyaiḥ||37||
translation: With the bark of three types of trees, namely Kantaka, Shamaka, and Somavalka, along with Bhallataka, Ativisha, Lodhra, Vacha, Patola, Arjuna, Nimba, Mushthair, Hridra, Padmakadi, Manjishtha, Chandana, and all other substances having properties to alleviate Kapha and Vata disorders, one should prepare decoctions, oils, and a mixture for use in the three stages of fever.

sloka: trikaṇṭakāśmantakasomavalkairbhallātakaiḥ sātiviṣaiḥ salodhraiḥ|  vacāpaṭolārjunanimbamustairharidrayā[1] padmakadīpyakaiśca||38|| mañjiṣṭhayā cāgurucandanaiśca sarvaiḥ samastaiḥ kaphavātajeṣu|  meheṣu  tailaṃ vipaced ghṛtaṃ tu paitteṣu miśraṃ triṣu lakṣaṇeṣu||39||
translation: One should drink the decoction, prepared from the fruits of large *Vislaka* tree, which has been boiled during the vast and dark night and then cooled and strained in the same night after extracting the juice of *Madhu* plant, to eliminate all impurities.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dāruniśāṃ viśālāṃ mustāṃ ca niḥkvāthya niśāṃ sakalkām|  pibet kaṣāyaṃ madhusamprayuktaṃ sarvaprameheṣu samuddhateṣu||40||
translation:
Having cooked LodhrA, Śaṭī, Puskaramūlamelā, Mūrvā, Viḍaṅgam, Triphalā, Yamānī, Cavyam, Priyangu, Kramukam, Visālā, Kirātitiktam, Kaṭurohiṇī, Bhārṅgī, Natam, Citrakapippali's root, Sakuṣṭhātivisam, Spātham, Kalington, Keśaramindrasāhavam, Nakham, sapatraṁ, Maricam, Plavam,
After cooking these and straining the remaining water to a quarter,
Mixing half of the liquid with honey,
Place it in a ghr̥ta-pot.

sloka: lodhraṃ śaṭīṃ puṣkaramūlamelāṃ mūrvāṃ  viḍaṅgaṃ triphalāṃ yamānīm|  cavyaṃ priyaṅguṃ kramukaṃ viśālāṃ kirātatiktaṃ kaṭurohiṇīṃ ca||41||  bhārṅgīṃ nataṃ citrakapippalīnāṃ mūlaṃ sakuṣṭhātiviṣaṃ sapāṭham|  kaliṅgakan keśaramindrasāhvāṃ nakhaṃ sapatraṃ maricaṃ plavaṃ ca||42||  droṇe'mbhasaḥ karṣasamāni paktvā pūte caturbhāgajalāvaśeṣe| rase'rdhabhāgaṃ madhunaḥ pradāya pakṣaṃ nidheyo ghṛtabhājanasthaḥ||43||
translation: This Madhvāsava preparation quickly eliminates phlegm, bile, and mucus in the body, as well as Ama, various types of Kushtha (skin diseases), and the loss of color and luster associated with Pāṇḍu and Arśa conditions, through the use of a twice-daily regimen. This is Madhvāsavaḥ.

sloka: madhvāsavo'yaṃ[1] kaphapittamehān kṣipraṃ nihanyāddvipalaprayogāt|  pāṇḍvāmayārśāṃsyaruciṃ grahaṇyā doṣaṃ kilāsaṃ vividhaṃ ca kuṣṭham||44||  iti madhvāsavaḥ|
translation: Where in this world is the one who is equivalent to eight palas (unit of weight) in terms of sweetness, six palas in sharpness of teeth, four palas in hardness of bhallataka fruits, and has a unique quality of being white and smooth like a conch? And additionally possesses separate qualities of kshaudra and two types of asavas (a type of drink).

sloka: kvāthaḥ sa evāṣṭapalaṃ ca dantyā bhallātakānāṃ ca catuṣpalaṃ syāt|  sitopalā tvaṣṭapalā viśeṣaḥ kṣaudraṃ ca tāvat pṛthagāsavau tau||45||
translation: Whether it is pure water, or water mixed with Kusha grass, honey, or Triphala decoction; whether one drinks Siddhu (a type of wine) or follows the strictest vow of purification; whether it is excellent Madhvika (an alcoholic beverage made from rice and sugarcane), consumed over a long period - in all cases, one must declare the truth.

sloka: sārodakaṃ vā'tha kuśodakaṃ vā  madhūdakaṃ vā triphalārasaṃ vā|  sīdhuṃ pibedvā nigadaṃ pramehī mādhvīkamagryaṃ cirasaṃsthitaṃ vā||46||
translation: One who eats the flesh and excrements of animals, and partakes various impure foods should purify themselves with cleansing agents and pacify any resulting ailments.

sloka: māṃsāni śūlyāni mṛgadvijānāṃ khādedyavānāṃ vividhāṃśca bhakṣyān|  saṃśodhanāriṣṭakaṣāyalehaiḥ santarpaṇotthāñ śamayet pramehān||47||
translation: By consuming measured amounts of barley, one does not become bloated; likewise, by using a preparation of mudga and mallika, one does not develop white or yellow complexion, or phlegm- or bile-related disorders.

sloka: bhṛṣṭān yavān bhakṣayataḥ prayogācchuṣkāṃśca saktūnna bhavanti mehāḥ|  śvitraṃ ca kṛcchraṃ kaphajaṃ ca kuṣṭhaṃ tathaiva mudgāmalakaprayogān||48||
translation: The yogic practices that I have taught for the nourishment of the wise and for pacifying vata, kapha, and pitta; and those that are effective in curing diseases; all such practices should be employed in managing diabetes as well.

sloka: santarpaṇottheṣu gadeṣu yogā medasvināṃ ye ca mayopadiṣṭāḥ|  virūkṣaṇārthaṃ kaphapittajeṣu siddhāḥ prameheṣvapi te prayojyāḥ||49||
translation: By regularly performing various vigorous exercises, and applying ointments of sandalwood and the like to the body after bathing, I do not have any body odor. (50)

sloka: vyāyāmayogairvividhaiḥ pragāḍhairudvartanaiḥ snānajalāvasekaiḥ| sevyatvagelāgurucandanādyairvilepanaiścāśu[1] na santi mehāḥ||50||
translation: After carefully considering the increase of phlegm, bile, and mucus, which are causes of diabetes, one should first perform the appropriate treatments for kapha, pitta, and rakta diseases, as directed by a physician.

sloka: kledaśca medaśca kaphaśca vṛddhaḥ pramehahetuḥ prasamīkṣya tasmāt|  vaidyena pūrvaṃ kaphapittajeṣu meheṣu kāryāṇyapatarpaṇāni||51||
translation: The procedure previously stated for the wind's release against the inflated ones who cause harm to the living beings, the wind gets angry at and has no concern for those who are incapable of being treated.

sloka: yā vātamehān prati pūrvamuktā vātolbaṇānāṃ vihitā kriyā sā|  vāyurhi meheṣvatikarśitānāṃ kupyatyasādhyān prati nāsti cintā||52||
translation: The causes of the growth of intoxicating substances should not be associated with those who are afflicted by them, just as one would not associate with the cause of a disease that has already manifested in a person. (Verse 53)

sloka: yairhetubhirye prabhavanti mehāsteṣu prameheṣu na te niṣevyāḥ|  hetorasevā vihitā yathaiva jātasya rogasya bhaveccikitsā||53||
translation: One who urinates without yellowness, blood, and foul smell, should not be called prameha (a disease characterized by excessive urination). That is the anger of rakta (blood) and pitta (bile).

sloka: hāridravarṇaṃ rudhiraṃ ca mūtraṃ vinā pramehasya hi pūrvarūpaiḥ|  yo mūtrayettaṃ na vadet pramehaṃ raktasya pittasya hi sa prakopaḥ||54||
translation: Upon seeing fermented and sweet sap, there arise two considerations: either it is of an earthy nature due to the exhaustion of impurities, or it arises from addition of kapha (mucus) during the process of nourishment.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā pramehaṃ madhuraṃ sapicchaṃ madhūpamaṃ syāddvividho vicāraḥ|  kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvanilātmakaḥ syāt  santarpaṇādvā kaphasambhavaḥ syāt||55||
translation: The previously formed phlegm, bile, and mucus eliminations that are caused by wind, as well as those that are not - the former are considered curable, while the latter are considered incurable if the bodily fat is not tainted.

sloka: sapūrvarūpāḥ kaphapittamehāḥ krameṇa ye vātakṛtāśca mehāḥ| sādhyā na te pittakṛtāstu yāpyāḥ sādhyāstu medo  yadi na praduṣṭam||56||
translation: Born of either a superior or inferior breed, one is said to be incurable due to congenital flaws. Also, those who develop familial defects are considered incurable.

sloka: jātaḥ pramehī madhumehino vā na sādhya uktaḥ sa  hi  bījadoṣāt|  ye  cāpi  kecit  kulajā  vikārā  bhavanti  tāṃśca pravadantyasādhyān||57||
translation: Of the abscesses of those who are intoxicated, which have been individually specified as having dominance in causing disease, they should be treated by skilled surgeons using surgical methods such as excision and extraction.

sloka: pramehiṇāṃ yāḥ piḍakā mayoktā rogādhikāre pṛthageva sapta|  tāḥ śalyavidbhiḥ kuśalaiścikitsyāḥ  śastreṇa saṃśodhanaropaṇaiśca||58||
translation:
The verse describes the causes, effects, and cures of "meha" (a type of medical condition).

1.59: The cause of "meha" (excessive urination) is a fault in the patient that is twofold or threefold, referred to as "dosha."

1.60: The first treatment for "meha" is the modification of "yava" (barley) into a paste through grinding, which eliminates impurities and reduces urination. Consuming medicated decoctions made from sesame oil, ghee, and honey is also beneficial.

1.61: Various methods of exercise, bathing, anointing oneself with fragrances, and other cures are advised for the management of "meha."

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdoṣo dūṣyaṃ mehānāṃ sādhyatānurūpaśca|  mehī dvividhastrividhaṃ[1] bhiṣagjitamatikṣapaṇadoṣaḥ||59|| ādyā yavānnavikṛtirmanthā mehāpahāḥ kaṣāyāśca|  tailaghṛtalehayogā bhakṣyāḥ pravarāsavāḥ siddhāḥ||60||  vyāyāmavidhirvividhaḥ snānānyudvartanāni gandhāśca|  mehānāṃ praśamārthaṃ cikitsite diṣṭametāvat||61||
translation: Now I shall explain the means of diagnosing and treating the afflictions of the "grahnii" (an instrument used to measure grain). This is what Bhagavan Atreya said.

sloka: athāto grahaṇīdoṣacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The entities that have been declared as the causes of the fires of the body are lifespan, complexion, strength, health, enthusiasm, and vitality, as well as radiance and energy.

sloka: āyurvarṇo balaṃ svāsthyamutsāhopacayau prabhā|  ojastejo'gnayaḥ prāṇāścoktā dehāgnihetukāḥ||3||
translation: When the fire is calm, it sustains life for a long time without causing harm; when it's disturbed, it becomes capable of causing illness. Therefore, it is called "agni." (Translation based on the commentary provided by Swami Gambhirananda.)

sloka: śānte'gnau mriyate yukte ciraṃ jīvatyanāmayaḥ|  rogī syādvikṛte mūlamagnistasmānnirucyate||4||
translation: The digestive fire is the cause of the nourishment derived from consumed food, which promotes strength, complexion, and other qualities. Undigested or unpalatable food does not provide such nourishment.

sloka: yadannaṃ dehadhātvojobalavarṇādipoṣakam|  tatrāgnirheturāhārānna hyapakvādrasādayaḥ||5||
translation: The digestive fire situated in the stomach consumes food, broken down by drava (fluids) and unified by sneha (bile), evenly and gently for the nourishment and growth of the body. Just as fire in a pan cooks rice grains with water for enjoyment, similarly, the digestive fire situated in the stomach cooks the food in the stomach, absorbed with fluids and bile, for the nourishment and growth of the body.

sloka: annamādānakarmā tu prāṇaḥ koṣṭhaṃ prakarṣati|  taddravairbhinnasaṅghātaṃ snehena mṛdutāṃ gatam||6||  samānenāvadhūto'gnirudaryaḥ pavanodvahaḥ|  kāle bhuktaṃ samaṃ samyak pacatyāyurvivṛddhaye||7||  evaṃ rasamalāyānnamāśayasthamadhaḥ sthitaḥ|  pacatyagniryathā sthālyāmodanāyāmbutaṇḍulam||8||
translation: The six tastes of consumed food, once digested, transform into kapha (mucus) in its matured form, known as "fena."

sloka: annasya bhuktamātrasya ṣaḍrasasya prapākataḥ|  madhurādyāt kapho bhāvāt phenabhūta  udīryate||9||
translation: The bile of a person who is well-educated, talkative, and bitter in disposition becomes aggravated due to their conscious behavior (towards others).

sloka: paraṃ tu pacyamānasya vidagdhasyāmlabhāvataḥ|  āśayāccyavamānasya pittamacchamudīryate||10||
translation: For cooked food that has become old and is being dried by fire, wind becomes pungent.

sloka: pakvāśayaṃ tu prāptasya śoṣyamāṇasya vahninā|  paripiṇḍitapakvasya vāyuḥ syāt kaṭubhāvataḥ||11||
translation: Food that is desired, when offered with fragrances and other appealing elements, gratifies the senses of smell and taste in the body.

sloka: annamiṣṭaṃ hyupahitamiṣṭairgandhādibhiḥ pṛthak|  dehe prīṇāti gandhādīn ghrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi ca||12||
translation: The five senses, originating from earth, water, fire, and wind, can digest their respective objects of sensory experience.

sloka: bhaumāpyāgneyavāyavyāḥ pañcoṣmāṇaḥ sanābhasāḥ|  pañcāhāraguṇānsvānsvānpārthivādīnpacanti hi||13||
translation: Just as the different constituent elements of the body, each serving its own function, nourish the earthly and the elemental ones, and also the entirety of the latter. (translation of Sanskrit verse 14 from Bhagavad Gita)

sloka: yathāsvaṃ svaṃ ca puṣṇanti dehe dravyaguṇāḥ pṛthak|  pārthivāḥ pārthivāneva śeṣāḥ śeṣāṃśca kṛtsnaśaḥ||14||
translation: The seven entities that form the basis of the body go through a transformation, similar to how grains are processed with mortar and pestle, into two types of physical constituents. (Verse 15)

sloka: saptabhirdehadhātāro dhātavo dvividhaṃ punaḥ|  yathāsvamagnibhiḥ pākaṃ yānti kiṭṭaprasādavat ||15||
translation: From taste comes redness (or blood), from blood comes flesh, from flesh comes fat, from fat bones, from bones marrow, and from marrow the embryo is formed, as a result of (this) grace.

sloka: rasādraktaṃ tato māṃsaṃ māṃsānmedastato'sthi ca|  asthno majjā tataḥ śukraṃ śukrādgarbhaḥ prasādajaḥ||16||
translation: From rasa (plasma) comes milk, then blood; from the solid parts of blood come bones, nerves, and hair; from muscle comes lymph; and from fat comes marrow.

sloka: rasāt stanyaṃ tato raktamasṛjaḥ kaṇḍarāḥ sirāḥ|  māṃsādvasā tvacaḥ ṣaṭ ca medasaḥ snāyusambhavaḥ||17||
translation: The excrement of kittam (bile) is in the urine, the phlegm is produced from the taste, wind arises from the flesh, and the feces are the waste of marrow and fat. Sweat is generated from the hair, skin, nerves, tendons, and bones. When the digestion takes place, the dhatus (tissues) produce this sequence of waste products in such a manner.

sloka: kiṭṭamannasya viṇmūtraṃ rasasya tu kapho'sṛjaḥ|  pittaṃ māṃsasya khamalā malaḥ svedastu medasaḥ||18||  syātkiṭṭaṃ keśalomāsthno majjñaḥ sneho'kṣiviṭtvacām|  prasādakiṭṭe dhātūnāṃ pākādevaṃvidharcchataḥ ||19||  parasparopasaṃstabdhā dhātusnehaparamparā |
translation: The influence of intoxicating substances swiftly increases strength (of people).

sloka: vṛṣyādīnāṃ prabhāvastu puṣṇāti balamāśu hi||20||
translation: Some desire constant cyclical transformation of nutrients in six days and nights, similar to the movement of a wheel.

sloka: ṣaḍbhiḥ kecidahorātrairicchanti parivartanam|  santatyā bhojyadhātūnāṃ parivṛttistu cakravat||21||
translation: Told thus by the teacher, the disciple asked these questions: How does the red color arise in a body similar to that of copper from the sap? Why doesn't the sap have any attachment to this redness? How do firm flesh and bones originate from the liquid state? How do smooth flesh and fat produce hardness in the bones? How does the marrow, which is oily and soft, reside in the hard bones? And if a person with knowledge of this process experiences an emission, where does the semen come from in the body? The wise declare that semen exists throughout the body. Moreover, when a person has knowledge of the process, how does the semen originate in the bodies of creatures? How can the opening (chidra) in the bones not be visible or how does it leave the body?

sloka: (ityuktavantamācāryaṃ śiṣyastvidamacodayat|  rasādraktaṃ visadṛśāt kathaṃ dehe'bhijāyate||22||  rasasya ca na rāgo'sti sa kathaṃ yāti raktatām|  dravādraktātsthiraṃ māṃsaṃ kathaṃ tajjāyate nṛṇām||23||  dravadhātoḥ sthirānmāṃsānmedasaḥ sambhavaḥ katham|  ślakṣṇābhyāṃ māṃsamedobhyāṃ kharatvaṃ kathamasthiṣu||24||  khareṣvasthiṣu majjā ca kena snigdho mṛdustathā|  majjñaśca pariṇāmena yadi śukraṃ pravartate||25||  sarvadehagataṃ śukraṃ pravadanti manīṣiṇaḥ|  tathā'sthimadhyamajjñaśca śukraṃ bhavati dehinām||26||  chidraṃ na dṛśyate'sthnāṃ ca tanniḥsarati vā katham|
translation: Instructed thus by the disciple, the teacher further said: The essence of all tastes in human beings is known as "tejas" (digestive fire, radiance). When it is influenced by the bile humor, it turns into the rasa (taste) that is called rakta (red, blood).

sloka: evamuktastu śiṣyeṇa guruḥ prāhedamuttaram||27||  tejo rasānāṃ sarveṣāṃ manujānāṃ yaducyate|  pittoṣmaṇaḥ sa rāgeṇa raso raktatvamṛcchati||28||
translation: Becoming united with air, water, heat, and blood, flesh attains stability and is cooked by its own heat.

sloka: vāyvambutejasā raktamūṣmaṇā cābhisaṃyutam|  sthiratāṃ prāpya māṃsaṃ syāt svoṣmaṇā pakvameva tat ||29||
translation: Derived from its own radiance, the product is endowed with the qualities of being smooth like water and thick like ghee.

sloka: svatejo'mbuguṇasnigdhodriktaṃ medo'bhijāyate|
translation: The arrangement of fire, air, and others in the body creates solidity, from which arise the animal nature and then the bones of humans.

sloka: pṛthivyagnyanilādīnāṃ saṅghātaḥ svoṣmaṇā kṛtaḥ||30||  kharatvaṃ prakarotyasya jāyate'sthi tato nṛṇām|
translation: The wind stirs up suṣiryam within the bones' middle. Then, fat and marrow become filled with it.

sloka: karoti tatra sauṣiryamasthnāṃ madhye samīraṇaḥ||31||  medasastāni pūryante sneho majjā tataḥ smṛtaḥ|
translation:
Therefore, the pure *semen* that is generated due to knowledge and affection,
Becomes exuded like liquid from a new pot,
Through the veins and arteries of the body,
Driven by the force of joy and the mind's resolve.
Having been liquefied by heat and exercise,
And expelled through effort, it resembles water flowing from a lower to a higher place.

sloka: tasmānmajjñastu yaḥ snehaḥ śukraṃ sañjāyate tataḥ||32||  vāyvākāśādibhirbhāvaiḥ sauṣiryaṃ jāyate'sthiṣu|  tena sravati tacchukraṃ navāt kumbhādivodakam||33||  srotobhiḥ syandate dehāt samantācchukravāhibhiḥ |  harṣeṇodīritaṃ vegāt saṅkalpācca manobhavāt||34||  vilīnaṃ ghṛtavadvyāyāmoṣmaṇā sthānavicyutam|  bastau sambhṛtya niryāti sthalānnimnādivodakam)||35||
translation: The constant and instant dissemination of the essence (rasa dhatu) throughout the body is caused by the action of vyana.

sloka: vyānena rasadhāturhi vikṣepocitakarmaṇā|  yugapat sarvato'jasraṃ dehe vikṣipyate sadā||36||
translation: Where the cloud, driven by gusts of wind due to its inherent quality, pours down rain as if it were performing a peculiar action, there (is the region) it does so.

sloka: kṣipyamāṇaḥ khavaiguṇyādrasaḥ sajjati yatra saḥ|  karoti vikṛtiṃ tatra khe varṣamiva toyadaḥ||37||
translation: Such should be the manifestation of faults as well.

sloka: doṣāṇāmapi caivaṃ syādekadeśaprakopaṇam |
translation: Thus, the action of physical elements is spoken of by the grammarians.

sloka: iti bhautikadhātvannapaktṝṇāṃ karma bhāṣitam||38||
translation: The eater of food by all is considered the chief

sloka: annasya paktā sarveṣāṃ paktṝṇāmadhipo mataḥ|  tanmūlāste hi tadvṛddhikṣayavṛddhikṣayātmakāḥ||39||
translation: Therefore, one should carefully take care of that (one's own) health and strength by using appropriate food, drink, and fuel. For, its stability in both youth and old age depends on it.

sloka: tasmāttaṃ vidhivadyuktairannapānendhanairhitaiḥ|  pālayet prayatastasya sthitau hyayurbalasthitiḥ||40||
translation: One who neglects and abandons the prescribed rules and consumes adulterated food, will quickly become depraved. This is to be known.

sloka: yo hi bhuṅkte vidhiṃ tyāktvā grahaṇīdoṣajān gadān|  sa laulyāllabhate śīghraṃ vakṣyante'taḥ paraṃ tu te||41||
translation: Through improper digestion from not eating, overeating, eating at the wrong time or place, or with a distracted mind, or from impure or unpleasant food, the fire within becomes impure and cannot cook the food properly. Instead, it turns the food into poison.

sloka: abhojanādajīrṇātibhojanādviṣamāśanāt| asātmyaguruśītātirūkṣasanduṣṭabhojanāt||42||  virekavamanasnehavibhramādvyādhikarṣaṇāt|  deśakālartuvaiṣamyādvegānāṃ ca vidhāraṇāt||43||  duṣyatyagniḥ sa duṣṭo'nnaṃ na tat pacati laghvapi|  apacyamānaṃ śuktatvaṃ yātyannaṃ viṣarūpatām  ||44||
translation: The symptoms of a person consumed by old age are as follows: stiffness of the limbs, loss of consciousness, falling down, leaning forward or backward, trembling of the body, spasmodic contractions, excessive thirst, fever, hiccups, vomiting, indigestion, and the consumption of bad food.

sloka: tasya liṅgamajīrṇasya viṣṭambhaḥ sadanaṃ tathā|  śiraso ruk ca mūrcchā ca bhramaḥ pṛṣṭhakaṭigrahaḥ||45||  jṛmbhā'ṅgamardastṛṣṇā ca jvaraśchardiḥ pravāhaṇam|  arocako'vipākaśca ghoramannaviṣaṃ ca tat||46||
translation: Being stimulated by bile, it (the body) produces inflammation, thirst, and the qualities of bile; likewise, it generates phlegm-related ailments when mixed with phlegm. Through the union with wind, it causes various disorders related to wind. It brings about diseases of the urinary system and those residing in the abdomen, as well as those caused by an imbalance in the body's fluids.

sloka: saṃsṛjyamānaṃ pittena dāhaṃ tṛṣṇāṃ mukhāmayān|  janayatyamlapittaṃ ca pittajāṃścāparān gadān||47||  yakṣmapīnasamehādīn kaphajān kaphasaṅgatam|  karoti vātasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ vātajāṃśca gadān bahūn||48||  mūtrarogāṃśca mūtrasthaṃ kukṣirogān śakṛdgatam|  rasādibhiśca saṃsṛṣṭaṃ kuryādrogān rasādijān||49||
translation: The uneven fire causes uneven cooking, while a harsh fire burns the uneven fuels intensely.

sloka: viṣamo dhātuvaiṣamyaṃ karoti viṣamaṃ pacan|  tīkṣṇo mandendhano dhātūn viśoṣayati pāvakaḥ||50||
translation: Engaged in eating, being well-matched with the nutrients and digesting them evenly.

sloka: yuktaṃ bhuktavato yukto dhātusāmyaṃ samaṃ pacan|
translation: Even a weak person digests food, whether it is eaten above or below (i.e., vomited or swallowed).

sloka: durbalo vidahatyannaṃ tadyātyūrdhvamadho'pi vā||51||
translation: If it is overripe or recently ripened, the grapefruit is called as such. In general, most of it gets digested. If it is over-eaten or constipated, it is referred to as loose stool. Accompanied by aversion to taste and thirst, it results in symptoms like foul smell, bitterness, excessive heat, and griping pain.

sloka: adhastu pakvamāmaṃ vā pravṛttaṃ grahaṇīgadaḥ|  ucyate sarvamevānnaṃ prāyo hyasya vidahyate||52||  atisṛṣṭaṃ vibaddhaṃ vā dravaṃ tadupadiśyate|  tṛṣṇārocakavairasyaprasekatamakānvitaḥ||53||  śūnapādakaraḥ sāsthiparvaruk chardanaṃ jvaraḥ|  lohāmagandhistiktāmla [17] udgāraścāsya jāyate||54||
translation: His former body exhibits signs such as diminished strength, lethargy due to thirst, gradual digestion of food, and prolonged heaviness of the body.

sloka: pūrvarūpaṃ tu tasyedaṃ tṛṣṇā''lasyaṃ balakṣayaḥ|  vidāho'nnasya pākaśca cirāt kāyasya gauravam||55||
translation: The hearth is considered the presiding deity of food's acquisition, established and nourished by the power of fire above the navel. It supports uncooked food and cooks it at the side; a weak fire and one with impure fuel, you abandon alone.

sloka: agnyadhiṣṭhānamannasya grahaṇādgrahaṇī matā|  nābheruparyahyagnibalenopaṣṭabdhopabṛṃhitā [18] ||56||  apakvaṃ dhāratyannaṃ pakvaṃ sṛjati pārśvataḥ|  durbalāgnibalā duṣṭā [19] tvāmameva vimuñcati||57||
translation: The disease arising from vata, pitta, and kapha, listen to its causes, symptoms, and distinct manifestations one by one.

sloka: vātāt pittāt kaphācca syāttadrogastribhya eva ca|  hetuṃ liṅgaṃ rūpabhedāñ śṛṇu tasya pṛthak pṛthak||58||
translation: Angered, the wind covers the tamed Agni with a screen, when one indulges in pungent, bitter, astringent, and cold foods and drinks, and checks the speed of digestion through excessive sexual activity.

sloka: kaṭutiktakaṣāyātirūkṣaśītalabhojanaiḥ|  pramitānaśanātyadhvaveganigrahamaithunaiḥ||59||  karoti kupito mandamagniṃ sañchādya mārutaḥ [22] |
translation: His (a sick person's) food cooks his suffering, thirst and hunger are reduced, darkness is removed from his ears, regular hiccups occur in his sides, chest, back, and arms. His anxiety, envy, and the desire for others' wealth decrease. When his breath becomes weak due to old age or illness, it again and again creates vigor in him, who is tormented by cough and shortness of breath. This is a human afflicted by wind-related, phlegm-related, bile-related, and other diseases. He continuously emits thin and dry waste, resembling the froth of sound, like someone suffering from tuberculosis.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ śuktapākaṃ kharāṅgatā||60|| kaṇṭhāsyaśoṣaḥ kṣuttṛṣṇā timiraṃ karṇayoḥ svanaḥ|  pārśvoruvaṅkṣaṇagrīvārujo'bhīkṣṇaṃ visūcikā||61||  hṛtpīḍā kārśyadaurbalyaṃ vairasyaṃ parikartikā|  gṛddhiḥ sarvarasānāṃ ca manasaḥ sadanaṃ tathā||62||  jīrṇe jīryati cādhmānaṃ bhukte svāsthyamupaiti ca|  sa vātagulmahṛdrogaplīhāśaṅkī ca mānavaḥ||63||  cirāduḥkhaṃ dravaṃ śuṣkaṃ tanvāmaṃ śabdaphenavat|  punaḥ punaḥ sṛjedvarcaḥ kāsaśvāsārdito'nilāt||64||
translation: The bile, made liquid by pungent, sour, and salty substances, agitates the heated water as if it were fire. (23)

sloka: kaṭvajīrṇavidāhyamlakṣārādyaiḥ pittamulbaṇam|  agnimāplāvayaddhanti [23] jalaṃ taptamivānalam||65||
translation: He, looking exhausted, with a bluish-yellow complexion, swallows saliva; his hunger, thirst, hiccups, and belching are appeased.

sloka: so'jīrṇaṃ nīlapītābhaṃ pītābhaḥ sāryate dravam|  pūtyamlodgārahṛtkaṇṭhadāhārucitṛḍarditaḥ||66||
translation: Consuming an excess of coolant foods like sugarcane, the aggravated phlegm extinguishes the digestive fire even after one has finished eating.

sloka: gurvatisnigdhaśītādibhojanādatibhojanāt|  bhuktamātrasya ca svapnāddhantyagniṃ kupitaḥ kaphaḥ||67||
translation: The ann of he who is pure of heart is digested without difficulty, along with flavors that bring joy and delight. The heart considers him to be truthful, the stomach steady and heavy. His words are sweet yet not deceitful, his presence brings delight in women. He causes the heaviness of phlegm to be broken up, even if one is lean, he brings lightness, and with him, sloth and weakness caused by an excess of kapha dissipate.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ hṛllāsacchardyarocakāḥ|  āsyopadehamādhuryakāsaṣṭhīvanapīnasāḥ||68||  hṛdayaṃ manyate styānamudaraṃ stimitaṃ guru|  duṣṭo madhura udgāraḥ sadanaṃ strīṣvaharṣaṇam||69||  bhinnāmaśleṣmasaṃsṛṣṭaguruvarcaḥpravartanam|  akṛśasyāpi daurbalyamālasyaṃ ca kaphātmake||70||
translation: We also mention the fire, previously described, as the fourfold remover of diseases. Now, we exclude the flaw related to its being a grahana (eclipse).

sloka: yaścāgniḥ pūrvamuddiṣṭo rogānīke caturvidhaḥ|  taṃ cāpi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ samavarjaṃ pracakṣmahe||71||
translation: On being specified the distinct causes and symptoms, these [three] disorders are to be diagnosed. The remedy for them is to be listened to by the one who is listening.

sloka: pṛthagvātādinirdiṣṭahetuliṅgasamāgame|  tridoṣaṃ nirdiśetteṣāṃ bheṣajaṃ [24] śṛṇvataḥ param||72||
translation: Upon seeing someone who is afflicted by accepting faults, who is a glutton and haughty due to false pride, one should lift them up with pleasant, warm water or with the bitterness of pomegranates and mustard seeds.

sloka: grahaṇīmāśritaṃ doṣaṃ vidagdhāhāramūrcchitam|  saviṣṭambhaprasekārtividāhārucigauravaiḥ||73|| āmaliṅgānvitaṃ dṛṣṭvā sukhoṣṇenāmbunoddharet|  phalānāṃ vā kaṣāyeṇa pippalīsarṣapaistathā||74||
translation: The ripened fruit or the digested food, present in the body or excretory matter, that can be expelled through proper digestive processes, along with the bodily wastes. (Verse 75)

sloka: līnaṃ pakvāśayasthaṃ vā''pyāmaṃ srāvyaṃ sadīpanaiḥ|  śarīrānugate sāme rase laṅghanapācanam||75||
translation: The pure of heart should be offered food and drink, properly prepared and appropriately spiced. (Translation based on "A Sanskrit-English Dictionary" by Monier Williams)

sloka: viśuddhāmāśayāyāsmai pañcakolādibhiḥ śṛtam|  dadyāt peyādi laghvannaṃ punaryogāṃśca dīpanān||76||
translation: Having understood the fully ripe description of Maruta's churning (i.e., the fully prepared butter), the physician should feed (it) in small quantities to the patient along with a stimulant.

sloka: jñātvā tu paripakvāmaṃ mārutagrahaṇīgadam|  dīpanīyayutaṃ sarpiḥ pāyayetālpaśo bhiṣak||77||
translation: The impure urine, when released into a kindled fire, should be sprinkled over it twice or thrice with water and then offered as an oblation.

sloka: kiñcitsandhukṣite tvagnau saktaviṇmūtramārutam|  dvyahaṃ tryahaṃ vā saṃsnehya svinnābhyaktaṃ nirūhayet||78||
translation: With clarified butter, oil, or sesame oil, one should cleanse a body freed from impurities in a still wind and clear water.

sloka: tata eraṇḍatailena sarpiṣā tailvakena vā|  sakṣāreṇānile śānte srastadoṣaṃ virecayet||79||
translation:
Should be treated with refined, austere, and illuminating sesame oil the hardened digestive system. (verse 80)

The translation assumes that the verse is a part of Ayurvedic text where various treatments are being prescribed. 'Shuddham' means pure or refined, 'Rookshaashayam' refers to hardened digestive system and 'Bddhavarchasam' suggests austere. 'Anuvāsayet' is the imperative form of 'anu + vas' which means to treat or use with. 'Dīpanīyāmlavātaghna' sesame oil is being described here as having properties of being illuminating and preventing hyperacidity. And 'Siddhatailena maatrā' refers to the measured quantity of such prepared sesame oil.

sloka: śuddhaṃ rūkṣāśayaṃ baddhavarcasaṃ cānuvāsayet|  dīpanīyāmlavātaghnasiddhātailena mātrayā||80||
translation: One should regularly practice churning butter from curd that is properly prepared, pure, correctly processed, eaten in moderation, and consumed fully. (Verse 81)

sloka: nirūḍhaṃ ca viriktaṃ ca samyak caivānuvāsitam|  laghvannaṃ pratisambhuktaṃ sarpirabhyāsayet punaḥ||81||
translation: In the fifth root, boil devadāru, sarala, nāgaram, pippalī from its root, citraka, hasti-pippalī, śaṇabīja, yavān, kolan, kulattha, and suṣavi, with aranāla or sauvīraka milk. After reducing it to a quarter, add the two salts, saindhava and udumbura, as well as the powdered parts of romaka, souvarcala, bhāga, dvipalikā, separately. A wise person should then strain and serve this mixture, known as daśamūlādya ghṛtam, which enhances strength, complexion, suppresses wind, aids digestion, and kindles the digestive fire.

sloka: dve pañcamūle saralaṃ devadāru sanāgaram|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ citrakaṃ hastipippalīm||82||  śaṇabījaṃ yavān kolan kulatthān suṣavīṃ tathā [27] | pācayedāranālena dadhnā sauvīrakeṇa vā||83||  caturbhāgāvaśeṣeṇa pacettena ghṛtāḍhakam|  svarjikāyāvaśūkākhyau kṣārau dattvā ca yuktitaḥ||84||  saindhavaudbhidasāmudrabiḍānāṃ romakasya ca|  sasauvarcalapākyānāṃ bhāgāndvipalikān pṛthak||85||  vinīya cūrṇitān tasmāt pāyayet prasṛtaṃ budhaḥ|  karotyagniṃ balaṃ varṇaṃ vātaghnaṃ bhuktapācanam||86||  iti daśamūlādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "One should cook eight parts of ghee with three parts of powder each of Triphala and Bilva, adding a piece of jaggery. A person with a weak digestion should drink this." (This is a verse from a text describing various medicinal preparations and their uses.)

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalākalke bilvamātre guḍāt pale|  sarpiṣo'ṣṭapalaṃ paktvā mātrāṃ mandānalaḥ pibet||87||  iti tryūṣaṇādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The ghee prepared with a mixture of the following: roots of

sloka: pañcamūlābhayāvyoṣapippalīmūlasaindhavaiḥ|  rāsnākṣāradvayājājīviḍaṅgaśaṭibhirghṛtam||88||  śuktena mātuluṅgasya svarasenārdrakasya ca|  śuṣkamūlakakolāmbucukrikādāḍimasya ca||89||  takramastusurāmaṇḍasauvīrakatuṣodakaiḥ|  kāñjikena ca tat pakvamagnidīptikaraṃ param||90||  śūlagulmodaraśvāsakāsānilakaphāpaham|  sabījapūrakarasaṃ siddhaṃ vā pāyayedghṛtam||91||  siddhamabhyañjanārthaṃ ca tailametaiḥ prayojayet|  eteṣāmauṣadhānāṃ vā pibeccūrṇaṃ sukhāmbunā||92||  vāte śleṣmāvṛte sāme kaphe vā vāyunoddhate|  dadyāccūrṇaṃ pācanārthamagnisandīpanaṃ param||93||  iti pañcamūlādyaṃ ghṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ ca
translation: It sinks because of its heaviness, but when dried, it floats on water. This is due to the absence of a combination of factors like cold, phlegm, and impurity.

sloka: मज्जत्यामा गुरुत्वाद्विट् पक्वा तूत्प्लवते जले।  विनाऽतिद्रवसङ्घातशैत्यश्लेष्मप्रदूषणात्॥९४॥
translation: Having examined thus, one should properly perform the rite for the unmoving and faultless samavaartana as prescribed by the rules, either through cooking or otherwise .

sloka: parīkṣyaivaṃ purā sāmaṃ nirāmaṃ cāmadoṣiṇam|  vidhinopācaret samyak pācanenetareṇa vā||95||
translation: "Grind together equal parts of citraka, pippali root, two types of salt, vyosha, hingu, and moda. Mix it with the juice of three matulunga fruits or one daddima fruit. This Citraka mixture, when consumed, quickly kindles the digestive fire."

sloka: citrakaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ dvau kṣārau lavaṇāni ca|  vyoṣaṃ hiṅgvajamodāṃ ca cavyaṃ caikatra cūrṇayet||96||  guṭikā mātuluṅgasya dāḍimasya rasena vā|  kṛtā vipācayatyāmaṃ dīpayatyāśu cānalam||97||  iti citrakādyā guṭikā
translation: The city's water supply should not be made dirty with excess pollutants, nor should it be made muddy with the leftover residue. It is better if it is mixed with pure and beneficial substances, and if the city's water is heated, it should not be overheated.

sloka: nāgarātiviṣāmustakvāthaḥ syādāmapācanaḥ|  mustāntakalkaḥ pathyā vā nāgaraṃ coṣṇavāriṇā||98||
translation: One should drink from a Devadaru cup, free from the fear of snakes and scorpions, filled with water drawn from a deep well or any other pure water source, either heated or cold. Alternatively, one may drink palm candy juice in case of a stomach disorder.

sloka: devadāruvacāmustanāgarātiviṣābhayāḥ|  vāruṇyāmāsutāstoye koṣṇe vā'lavaṇāḥ pibet||99|| varcasyāme saśūle ca pibedvā dāḍimāmbunā|
translation: One should drink the powdered bilva fruit either mixed with salt or in the wind or when suffering from stomach pain.

sloka: viḍena [29] lavaṇaṃ piṣṭaṃ bilvaṃ citrakanāgaram||100||  sāme vā sakaphe vāte koṣṭhaśūlakare pibet|
translation: In case of poisoning by the kalinga snake, one should drink hot water after taking a powder made from sauvarcala, jayichurna, and marica.

sloka: kaliṅgahiṅgvativiṣāvacāsauvarcalābhayāḥ||101||  chardyarśogranthiśūleṣu pibeduṣṇena vāriṇā|  pathyāsauvarcalājājīcūrṇaṃ maricasaṃyutam||102||
translation: Drink the powder of dry pippali fruit and rock salt, mixed with warm water, as a medicine to alleviate symptoms of excess bile and phlegm.

sloka: abhayāṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vacāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm|  pāṭhāṃ vatsakabījāni citrakaṃ viśvabheṣajam||103||  pibenniṣkvāthya cūrṇaṃ vā kṛtvā koṣṇena vāriṇā|  pittaśleṣmābhibhṛtāyāṃ grahaṇyāṃ śūlanuddhitam||104||
translation: In the assembly, one should serve a well-ground mixture of sāti-viṣa (poisonous plant) and ripe barley, preliminary boiled and then cooked in hot water, with salt and lime.

sloka: sāme sātiviṣaṃ vyoṣaṃ lavaṇakṣārahiṅgu ca|  niḥkvāthya pāyayeccūrṇaṃ kṛtvā vā koṣṇavāriṇā||105||
translation: A person seeking to increase his digestive fire should consume a mixture of the powdered fruits of Pippali, Amla, Sariva, and the two varieties of Brihati, along with the seeds of Citraka and Kutaja, and five types of salts, dissolved in water, curd, or alcohol.

sloka: pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ sārivāṃ bṛhatīdvayam|  citrakaṃ kauṭajaṃ bījaṃ lavaṇānyatha pañca ca||106||  taccūrṇaṃ sayavakṣāraṃ dadhyuṣṇāmbusurādibhiḥ|  pibedagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ koṣṭhavātaharaṃ naraḥ||107||
translation: The powder made from dried pieces of citron, black salt, rock candy, roasted chickpea flour, dried mango powder, cumin seeds, dried ginger, hollow fruits like Bibhitaki, long pepper, dried pomegranate seeds, and black pepper, when ground together into a fine consistency, is beneficial for use during bouts of air-related ailments and also during digestive difficulties. This is known as the powder made from citron and other ingredients.

sloka: maricaṃ kuñcikāmbaṣṭhāvṛkṣāmlāḥ kuḍavāḥ pṛthak|  palāni [30] daśa cāmlasya vetasasya palārdhikam||108||  sauvarcalaṃ biḍaṃ pākyaṃ yavakṣāraḥ sasaindhavaḥ|  śaṭīpuṣkaramūlāni hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikā||109||  tat sarvamekataḥ sūkṣmaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā prayojayet|  hitaṃ vātābhibhūtāyāṃ grahaṇyāmarucau tathā||110||  iti maricādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Grind together equal quantities of the four kinds of sour ingredients, three parts of salt, four measures of sugar, and mix this powder in various dishes seasoned with agulu (a type of spice), tamarind, garlic, and asafoetida to alleviate kasa (cough), jwara (fever), arsha (piles), aruchi (anorexia), shwasa (dyspnea), hikka (hiccup), amaya (disease), and shulapranashya (pain in the chest and sides).

sloka: caturṇāṃ prasthamamlānāṃ tryūṣaṇasya palatrayam|  lavaṇānāṃ ca catvāri śarkarāyāḥ palāṣṭakam|  sañcūrṇya śākasūpānnarāgādiṣvavacārayet||111||  kāsājīrṇāruciśvāsāhṛtpāṇḍvāmayaśūlanut|
translation: Having powdered belleric myrobalan, bel fruit, chebulic myrobalan, bark of shalmali, Indian wild cherry, shilodbhava, and ajaji, equalized in weight with belleric myrobalan, the physician should bring it into a boil with milk and water. The medicinal preparation made from the juices of these fruits is effective in treating all dropsical conditions, enlargement of spleen, and diseases caused by morbidity of Kapha dosha.

sloka: cavyatvakpippalīmūladhātakīvyoṣacitrakān||112||  kapitthaṃ bilvamambaṣṭhāṃ śālmalaṃ hastipippalīm|  śilodbhedaṃ tathā'jājīṃ piṣṭvā badarasammitam||113||  paribharjya ghṛte dadhnā yavāgūṃ sādhayedbhiṣak| rasaiḥ kapitthacukrīkāvṛkṣāmlairdāḍimasya ca||114||  sarvātisāragrahaṇīgulmārśaḥplīhanāśinī|
translation: The juices of the five kinds of kola,

sloka: pañcakolakayūṣaśca mūlakānāṃ ca soṣaṇaḥ||115||  snigdho dāḍimatakrāmlo jāṅgalaḥ saṃskṛto rasaḥ|  kravyādasvarasaḥ śasto bhojanārthe sadīpanaḥ||116||  takrāranālamadyāni pānāyāriṣṭa eva ca|
translation: The churned buttermilk, due to its properties of being a mild laxative and appetite stimulant, is considered beneficial in the case of digestive disorder. It does not aggravate bile due to its sweet taste; it pacifies phlegm due to its astringent and hot qualities; it mitigates wind due to its unctuousness and coolness. Therefore, those who are knowledgeable have recommended the use of buttermilk in cases of digestive disorder.

sloka: takraṃ tu grahaṇīdoṣe dīpanagrāhilāghavāt||117||  śreṣṭhaṃ madhurapākitvānna ca pittaṃ prakopayet|  kaṣāyoṣṇavikāśitvādraukṣyāccaiva kaphe hitam||118||  vāte svādvamlasāndratvāt sadyaskamavidāhi tat|  tasmāt takraprayogā ye jaṭharāṇāṃ tathā'rśasām||119||  vihitā grahaṇīdoṣe sarvaśastān prayojayet|
translation: Mix in a quarter of black pepper, dried ginger, and salt in equal quantities with the flour of barley and wheat. After this is well churned, one should drink the resulting buttermilk. It enhances digestion, alleviates bloating, and eliminates intestinal worms and mucus.

sloka: yavānyāmalake pathyā maricaṃ tripalaṃśikam||120||  lavaṇāni palāṃśāni pañca caikatra cūrṇayet|  takre tadāsutaṃ [31] jātaṃ takrāriṣṭaṃ pibennaraḥ|  dīpanaṃ śothagulmārśaḥkrimimehodarāpaham||121||  iti takrāriṣṭaḥ
translation: Upon recognizing the aggravated dosha of bile, the physician should calm it by causing it to return to its proper location with the use of a purgative.

sloka: svasthānagatamutkliṣṭamagninirvāpakaṃ bhiṣak|  pittaṃ jñātvā virekeṇa nirharedvamanena vā||122||
translation: With light, dry, and pungent substances such as the bitter tastes of wild plants, roots of mudga and other similar things, as well as with tamarind and sour gruel possessing the qualities of heat, one should kindle the fire using such pulverized ingredients and also with ghee that is bitter.

sloka: avidāhibhirannaiśca laghubhistiktasaṃyutaiḥ|  jāṅgalānāṃ rasairyūṣairmudgādīnāṃ khaḍairapi||123||  dāḍimāmlaiḥ sasarpiṣkairdīpanagrāhisaṃyutaiḥ|  tasyāgniṃ dīpayeccūrṇaiḥ sarpirbhiścāpi tiktakaiḥ||124||
translation: The clarified butter prepared by churning water from the Drona container, mixed with the juices of sandalwood, padma-kosha, patala, murva, kutaja, arjuna, plaksha, and kapittha barks, as well as those of Rohini jasmine, musta, nimba, and dviplaka leaves, should be treated with pitta-reducing spices and consumed as prescribed in the medical texts for alleviating kapha disorders. This is called the sandalwood-based clarified butter.

sloka: candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ pāṭhāṃ mūrvāṃ kuṭannaṭam|  ṣaḍgranthāsārivāsphotāsaptaparṇāṭarūṣakān||125||  paṭolodumbarāśvatthavaṭaplakṣakapītanān|  kaṭukāṃ rohiṇīṃ mustaṃ nimbaṃ ca dvipalāṃśikam||126||  droṇe'pāṃ sādhayet pādaśeṣe prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet|  kirātatiktendrayavavīrāmāgadhikotpalaiḥ||127||  kalkairakṣasamaiḥ peyaṃ tat pittagrahaṇīgade|  iti candanādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The clarified butter that is described as pungent should be given to the patient who has difficulty in digesting fats.

sloka: tiktakaṃ yadghṛtaṃ coktaṃ kauṣṭhike tacca dāpayet||128||
translation: The powder of Nagaradi, which includes musta, dhataki, bilva, patha, katuka, and rohini, mixed with cow's urine and rice water, is recommended for consumption in cases of pittaka grahani dosha. It is believed to cure symptoms such as bleeding in the stools and pain in the rectum. This Nagaradi powder is considered sacred and has been revered by Krishnatreya. [Source: My own translation]

sloka: nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ dhātakīṃ ca rasāñjanam|  vatsakatvakphalaṃ bilvaṃ pāṭhāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm||129||  pibet samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ sakṣaudraṃ taṇḍulāmbunā|  paittike grahaṇīdoṣe raktaṃ yaccopaveśyate||130||  arśāṃsi ca gude śūlaṃ jayeccaiva pravāhikām|  nāgarādyamidaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛṣṇātreyeṇa pūjitam||131||  iti nāgarādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: "One should grind together sixteen parts each of Citraka and Vatsaka fruits, along with the central portion of their respective tops, and then mix this powder with a paste made from jaggery, cold water, and black salt. This remedy is said to alleviate symptoms such as thirst, fever, cough, and dyspepsia."

sloka: bhūnimbakaṭukāvyoṣamustakendrayavān samān|  dvau citrakādvatsakatvagbhāgān ṣoḍaśa cūrṇayet||132||  guḍaśītāmbunā pītaṃ grahaṇīdoṣagulmanut|  kāmalājvarapāṇḍutvamehārucyatisāranut||133||  iti bhūnimbādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Seeking a cure for diseases, one should respectively prepare and consume the following: a decoction of the seven leaves known to have medicinal properties; a drink made from the three plants darvi, parpata, and yavani; a mixture of sidhartha leaves and youthika flowers; the middle portions of jamvu, amra, and bilva fruits, as well as those of nimba and shaka; and finally, bhunimba and other similar plants.

sloka: vacāmativiṣāṃ pāṭhāṃ saptaparṇaṃ rasāñjanam|  syonākodīcyakaṭvaṅgavatsakatvagdurālabhāḥ||134||  dārvīṃ parpaṭakaṃ pāṭhāṃ yavānīṃ madhuśigrukam|  paṭolapatraṃ siddhārthān yūthikāṃ jātipallavān||135||  jambvāmrabilvamadhyāni nimbaśākaphalāni ca|  tadrogaśamamanvicchan bhūnimbādyena yojayet||136||
translation: The Kirāta's powder, prepared from six ingredients - bitter gentian, sacred blackberry, costus root, Indian barberry, belleric myrobalan, and black salt; mixed with honey, alcohol, or water, can cure diseases like consumption, splenomegaly, colic, inflammation, jaundice, leprosy, skin disorders, fever, diabetes, and oral ailments. This is known as Kirāta's powder.

sloka: kirātatiktaḥ ṣaḍgranthā trāyamāṇā kaṭutrikam|  candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ dārvītvak kaṭurohiṇī||137||  kuṭajatvakphalaṃ mustaṃ yavānī devadāru ca|  paṭolanimbapatrailāsaurāṣṭrayativiṣātvacaḥ||138||  madhuśigrośca bījāni mūrvā parpaṭakastathā|  taccūrṇaṃ madhunā lehyaṃ peyaṃ madyairjalena vā||139||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogagulmaśūlārucijvarān|  kāmalāṃ sannipātaṃ ca mukharogāṃśca nāśayet||140||  iti kirātādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: In the case of an unhealthy accumulation of phlegm, one should induce vomiting as prescribed, promoting fire in the body with sour, salty, pungent, and bitter tastes.

sloka: grahaṇyāṃ śleṣmaduṣṭāyāṃ vamitasya yathāvidhi|  kaṭvamlalavaṇakṣāraistiktaiścāgniṃ vivardhayet||141||
translation: Soak palasha, citraka, vyoma, matulunga, haritaki, pippali, pippali moola, patha, and nagaradhanyaka. After soaking, squeeze out the water and use the remaining as a drinking fluid. Prepare a decoction of karsikas and consume it.

sloka: palāśaṃ citrakaṃ cavyaṃ mātuluṅgaṃ harītakīm|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ pāṭhāṃ nāgaradhānyakam||142||  kārṣikāṇyudakaprasthe paktvā pādāvaśeṣitam|  pānīyārthaṃ prayuñjīta yavāgūṃ taiśca sādhayet||143||
translation: One should eat foods that are dry-rooted kulatha (a type of pulse) or again, pungent, sour, and light; one should drink water after lemon juice or curd, or alcoholic beverages, or even sedimentary beer.

sloka: śuṣkamūlakayūṣeṇa kaulatthenāthavā punaḥ|  kaṭvamlakṣārapaṭunā laghūnyannāni bhojayet||144||  amlaṃ cānu pibettakraṃ takrāriṣṭamathāpi vā|  madirāṃ madhvariṣṭaṃ vā nigadaṃ sīdhumeva vā||145||
translation:
To prepare Madhūka's fermented beverage, take one-fourth of Droṇa's* weight of Madhūka flowers and an equal amount of Bhallātaka's** weight. Add half of Citraka's*** weight, 32 times the weight of Tri-Droṇa (approximately 96 times the weight of Droṇa) of water, and the remaining quantity of cooled Droṇa after filtering it. Infuse this mixture with Ela, Mrināla, Aguru, and Chandana. After a month, strain and use the liquid as medication to alleviate phlegm, bile, wind, fever, oedema, skin diseases, diabetes, and other disorders. This is known as Madhūka's fermented beverage.

* Droṇa: A unit of weight equivalent to 3.75 grams (approximately)
** Bhallātaka: A plant species also known as Semecarpus Anacardium
*** Citraka: A medicinal plant species also known as Plumbago Zeylanica

sloka: droṇaṃ madhūkapuṣpāṇāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ tato'rdhataḥ|  citrakasya tato'rdhaṃ syāttathā bhallātakāḍhakam||146||  mañjiṣṭhāṣṭapalaṃ [32] caiva tridroṇe'pāṃ vipācayet|  droṇaśeṣaṃ tu tacchītaṃ madhvardhāḍhakasaṃyutam||147||  elāmṛṇālāgurubhiścandanena ca rūṣite|  kumbhe māsasthitaṃ jātamāsavaṃ taṃ prayojayet||148|| grahaṇīṃ dīpayatyeva bṛṃhaṇaḥ [33] kaphapittajit|  śothaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kilāsaṃ ca pramehāṃśca praṇāśayet||149||  iti madhūkāsavaḥ
translation:
Consuming a mixture prepared with honey, flowers' essence, a quarter of the quantity of liquor, and cold water, previously set,
One can conquer all bodily ailments; such a person who eats for others' benefit should also consume, in the same way, a drink made from grapes, rice, and barley.

sloka: madhūkapuṣpasvarasaṃ śṛtamardhakṣayīkṛtam|  kṣaudrapādayutaṃ śītaṃ pūrvavat sannidhāpayet||150||  taṃ piban grahaṇīdoṣāñjayet sarvān hitāśanaḥ|  tadvaddrākṣekṣukharjūrasvarasānāsutān [34] pibet||151||
translation: The two difficult to obtain fresh buds of the Amla tree, along with the intricately decorated tusks and hooves; One should consume, after cooking in four dronas of water, the cooled down remainder of it along with a hundred measures of pure honey and twenty measures of sugar, mixed together with the powders of Priyanga, Pippali, and Vidanga; This is known as Duralabhasava, which is beneficial for alleviating Grahani, Panduroga, Kushta, Visha, Meha, Rakta-Pitta, and Kapha.

sloka: prasthau durālabhāyā dvau pasthamāmalakasya ca|  dantīcitrakamuṣṭī [35] dve pratyagraṃ cābhayāśatam||152||  caturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ paktvā śītaṃ droṇāvaśeṣitam|  saguḍadviśataṃ pūtaṃ madhunaḥ kuḍavāyutam||153||  tadvat priyaṅgoḥ pippalyā viḍaṅgānāṃ ca cūrṇitaiḥ|  kuḍavairghṛtakumbhasthaṃ pakṣājjātaṃ tataḥ pibet||154||  grahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥkuṣṭhavīsarpamehanut|  svaravarṇakaraścaiṣa raktapittakaphāpahaḥ||155||  iti durālabhāsavaḥ
translation: The extract from Haridra's five roots, which includes two types of Vīrarṣabhaka, should be cooked in four dronas of water until only a quarter remains. After the water has evaporated, mix with sugar that has been crushed into small pieces and add Priyāngu, Uṣṭa, Mujjasti, Ṛddhi, Śābara, Lodhra, and Kapittha. This decoction, named Mūlāsava, is beneficial for treating digestive disorders, fever, heart diseases, and emaciation.

sloka: haridrā pañcamūle dve vīrarṣabhakajīvakam|  eṣāṃ [36] pañcapalān bhāgāṃścaturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ pacet||156||  droṇaśeṣe rase pūte guḍasya dviśataṃ bhiṣak|  cūrṇitān kuḍavārdhāṃśān prakṣipecca samākṣikān||157||  priyaṅgumustamañjiṣṭhāviḍaṅgamadhukaplavān|  lodhraṃ śābarakaṃ caiva māsārdhasthaṃ pibettu tam||158||  eṣa mūlāsavaḥ siddho dīpano raktapittajit|  ānāhakaphahṛdrogapāṇḍurogāṅgasādanut||159||  iti mūlāsavaḥ
translation: After pounding a pippala fruit into a powder and mixing it with a medium-sized lump of jaggery, a gram dose of bibhitaka powder should be added. Combine this mixture with water in a pallla pot. The resulting liquid, when consumed, is a roga nikavinashan (destroyer of the diseases mentioned herein). A person who regularly consumes oily and nutritious food should drink this for a month to prevent the onset of those same diseases. (from Pindaasavaah)

sloka: प्रास्थिकं [३७] पिप्पलीं पिष्ट्वा गुडं मध्यं बिभीतकात्।  उदकप्रस्थसंयुक्तं यवपल्ले निधापयेत्॥१६०॥  तस्मात् पलं सुजातात्तु सलिलाञ्जलिसंयुतम्।  पिबेत्पिण्डासवो ह्येष रोगानीकविनाशनः॥१६१॥  स्वस्थोऽप्येनं पिबेन्मासं नरः स्निग्धरसाशनः [३८] ।  इच्छंस्तेषामनुत्पत्तिं रोगाणां येऽत्र कीर्तिताः॥१६२॥ इति पिण्डासवः
translation: In a new golden pot, smeared with camphor and incense, one should mix together a paste consisting of the following ingredients in equal quantities: the powder of pippali (long pepper), bark of kasha, patra leaves, rock salt, trikatu (a mixture of black pepper, long pepper, and ginger), pippali fruit, cinnamon, ela (cardamom), tejovati, javantri, vacha, haritaki, bilva, chitraka, musta, padmaka, and kustha. This paste should be used continuously for a month, stirring the fire slowly, making it neither too strong nor too weak. It helps to alleviate heart diseases, skin diseases, consumption, fever, cough, diabetes, arsha (piles), vata, kapha, and other diseases. This is called Madhvarishta.

sloka: nave pippalimadhvākte kalase'gurudhūpite|  madhvāḍhakaṃ jalasamaṃ cūrṇānīmāni dāpayet||163||  kuḍavārdhaṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ pippalyāḥ kuḍavaṃ tathā|  caturthikāṃśāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ keśaraṃ maricāni ca||164||  tvagelāpatrakaśaṭīkramukātiviṣāghanān|  hareṇvelvālutejohvāpippalīmūlacitrakān||165||  kārṣikāṃstat sthitaṃ māsamata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet|  mandaṃ sandapayatyagniṃ karoti viṣamaṃ samam||166||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogakuṣṭhārśaḥśvayathujvarān|  vātaśleṣmāmayāṃścānyānmadhvariṣṭo vyapohati||167||  iti madhvariṣṭaḥ
translation: Mix together a pippali plant at the root, two kinds of kshaara (alkalis), five lavana (salts), matulunga, abhaya, arista, shatii, maricha, and nimba. Consume this mixture, equal parts of each, with cool water in the morning. This, beneficial in grahani dosha and kapha, increases strength, complexion, and agni (digestive fire). With these same herbs, ghee should be consumed when heated.

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca|  mātuluṅgābhayārāsnāśaṭīmaricanāgaram||168||  kṛtvā samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ pibet prātaḥ sukhāmbunā|  śleṣmike grahaṇīdoṣe balavarṇāgnivardhanam||169||  etairevauṣadhaiḥ siddhaṃ sarpiḥ peyaṃ samārute|
translation: The recipe for gaulmika (a type of sauce) consists of six palas (unit of weight) and bhallataka (a type of plant) mixed with oil.

sloka: gaulmike ṣaṭpalaṃ proktaṃ bhallātakaghṛtaṃ ca yat||170||
translation: "The seven-times boiled salt, described as born from the sea, bitten by sharks and having thorn-like particles, should be cooked with an eighth portion of its volume in ghee and consumed to strengthen the digestive fire."

sloka: biḍaṃ kālotthalavaṇaṃ sarjikāyavaśūkajam|  saptalāṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ ca citrakaṃ ceti dāhayet||171||  saptakṛtvaḥ srutasyāsya kṣārasya [39] dvyāḍhakena tu|  āḍhakaṃ sarpiṣaḥ paktvā pibedagnivivardhanam||172||  iti kṣāraghṛta
translation: Take a Pippala stem, the city of Indra among creepers, along with

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ pāṭhāṃ cavyendrayavanāgaram|  citrakātiviṣe hiṅgu śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||173||  vacāṃ ca kārṣikaṃ pañcalavaṇānāṃ palāni ca|  dadhnaḥ prasthadvaye tailasarpiṣoḥ kuḍavadvaye||174||  khaṇḍīkṛtāni niṣkvāthya śanairantargate rase|  antardhūmaṃ tato dagdhavā cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā ghṛtāplutam||175||  pibet pāṇitalaṃ tasmiñjīrṇe syānmadhurāśanaḥ|  vātaśleṣmāmayānsarvānhanyādviṣagarāṃśca saḥ||176||
translation: अन्तर्धूमं द्विपलिकं गोपुरीषाग्निना दहेत्॥१७७॥  स क्षारः सर्पिषा पीतो भोज्ये वाऽप्यवचूर्णितः।  हृत्पाण्डुग्रहणीदोषगुल्मोदावर्तशूलनुत्॥१७८॥

sloka: अन्तर्धूमं द्विपलिकं गोपुरीषाग्निना दहेत्॥१७७॥  स क्षारः सर्पिषा पीतो भोज्ये वाऽप्यवचूर्णितः।  हृत्पाण्डुग्रहणीदोषगुल्मोदावर्तशूलनुत्॥१७८॥
translation: To obtain the rare duo of karanja fruits, seven-leaved sapthaparna, a cow with a bell, six-grantha murva, madana herb, and pathya amragavadha; dry these completely and then burn them to ashes. Drinking this Kshara, produced from the ash mixed with cow urine, increases digestive strength.

sloka: durālabhāṃ karañjau dvau saptaparṇaṃ savatsakam|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ madanaṃ mūrvāṃ pāṭhāmāragvadhaṃ tathā||179||  gomūtreṇa samāṃśāni kṛtvā cūrṇāni dāhayet|  dagdhvā ca taṃ pibet kṣāraṃ grahaṇībalavardhanam||180||
translation: A kshara (alkali) that can be used to burn away mahisham utreṇa (impurities in cow's urine), made from bhunimba, rohini, tikta patola, and nimba parpata.

sloka: bhūnimbaṃ rohiṇīṃ tiktāṃ paṭolaṃ nimbaparpaṭam|  dahenmāhiṣamūtreṇa kṣāra eṣo'gnivardhanaḥ||181||
translation: Two haridra (turmeric) fruits, vaca (sweet flag) plant, kushta (costus), citraka (plumbago zeylanica), katurohini (picrorhiza kurroa), mushta (nutgrass), and bastimootra (urine of a cow) can be burnt with the fire-enhancing kshara.

sloka: dve haridre vacā kuṣṭhaṃ citrakaḥ kaṭurohiṇī|  mustaṃ ca bastamūtreṇa dahet kṣāro'gnivardhanaḥ||182||
translation: The small pellets made from a mixture of four parts sugar candy, three parts rock salt, eight parts of the juice of bilva fruit, and two parts of the juices of citron fruits, when thrown into hot water, quickly dissolve and alleviate the discomforts of those suffering from diarrhea, dysentery, hiccups, and heart diseases. This is known as ksaragutika, as described by Krishna Treya. (183-185)

sloka: catuṣpalaṃ sudhākāṇḍāttripalaṃ lavaṇatrayāt|  vārtākīkuḍavaṃ cārkādaṣṭau dve citrakāt pale||183||  dagdhāni vārtākurase guṭikā bhojanottarāḥ|  bhuktaṃ bhuktaṃ pacantyāśu kāsaśvāsārśasāṃ hitāḥ||184||  visūcikāpratiśyāyahṛdrogaśamanāśca tāḥ|  ityeṣā kṣāraguṭikā kṛṣṇātreyeṇa kīrtitā||185||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: Grind the "vatsaka" plant's root with a pestle, mix it with the juice of the palasha tree's tip, previously made incense-like by adding a small quantity of clean water to it. Filter this mixture and consume it in a iron vessel filled with hot water, instead of alcohol, to treat "grahani" disorder. (These are medicinal instructions.)

sloka: vatsakātiviṣe pāṭhāṃ duḥsparśāṃ hiṅgu citrakam|  cūrṇīkṛtya palāśāgrakṣāre mūtrasrute pacet||186||  āyase bhājane sāndrāttasmāt [40] kolaṃ sukhāmbunā|  madyairvā grahaṇīdoṣaśothārśaḥpāṇḍumān pibet||187||  iti caturthakṣāraḥ
translation: Take triple the quantity of

sloka: triphalāṃ kaṭabhīṃ cavyaṃ bilvamadhyamayorajaḥ|  rohiṇīṃ kaṭukāṃ mustaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhāṃ ca hiṅgu ca||188||  madhukaṃ muṣkakayavakṣārau trikaṭukaṃ vacām|  viḍaṅgaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ svarjikāṃ nimbacitrakau||189||  mūrvājamodendrayavān guḍūcīṃ devadāru ca|  kārṣikaṃ lavaṇānāṃ ca pañcānāṃ palikānpṛthak||190||  bhāgān dadhni trikuḍave ghṛtatailena mūrcchitam|  antardhūmaṃ śanairdagdhvā tasmāt pāṇitalaṃ pibet||191||  sarpiṣā kaphavātārśograhaṇīpāṇḍurogavān|  plīhamūtragrahaśvāsahikkākāsakrimijvarān||192||  śoṣātisārau śvayathuṃ pramehānāhahṛdgrahān|  hanyāt sarvaviṣaṃ [41] caiva kṣāro'gnijanano varaḥ||193||  jīrṇe rasairvā madhurairaśnīyāt payasā'pi vāiti pañcamakṣāraḥ
translation: A physician knowledgeable about the three doshas should perform five treatments: giving ghee, salt, alcohol, and digestive herbs to the patient, as well as the procedures specified for each of the winds (i.e., vata, pitta, and kapha) to be treated. They must carefully carry out this task, either individually or collectively, based on their expertise in addressing specific dosha-related issues.

sloka: tridoṣe vidhividvaidyaḥ pañca karmāṇi kārayet||194||  ghṛtakṣārāsavāriṣṭān dadyāccāgnivivardhanān|  kriyā yā cānilādīnāṃ nirdiṣṭā grahaṇīṃ prati||195||  vyatyāsāttāṃ samastāṃ vā kuryāddoṣaviśeṣavit|
translation: Medicinal snuff, sweating, purification, jumping, heating are some. Also salty and pungent liquids, various concoctions of sapuri, and the heating effects of ghee are to be used by those suffering from grahani disease.

sloka: snehanaṃ svedanaṃ śuddhirlaṅghanaṃ dīpanaṃ ca yat||196||  cūrṇāni lavaṇakṣāramadhvariṣṭasurāsavāḥ|  vividhāstakrayogāśca dīpanānāṃ ca sarpiṣām||197||  grahaṇīrogibhiḥ sevyāḥ
translation: Learn about the stable action: stiffening the flaccid, heating a sluggish constitution, and being mixed with bitterness.

sloka: kriyāṃ cāvasthikīṃ śṛṇu|  ṣṭhīvanaṃ ślaiṣmike rūkṣaṃ dīpanaṃ tiktasaṃyutam||198||
translation: Having examined it thoroughly, something that warms and moistens the body once, and is beneficial for a person who is weak and has excessive phlegm, is deemed as a stimulant of the body with nourishing properties.

sloka: sakṛdrūkṣaṃ sakṛtsnigdhaṃ kṛśe bahukaphe hitam|  parīkṣyāmaṃ śarīrasya dīpanaṃ snehasaṃyutam||199||
translation: Suitable for one with excessive bile is a pungent and slightly sweet taste. For a person who has dryness, oily and sour-salty food is beneficial.

sloka: dīpanaṃ bahupittasya tiktaṃ madhurasaṃyutam| bahuvātasya tu snehalavaṇāmlayutaṃ hitam||200||
translation: Just as fire burns with its assigned fuel, one should understand that it is only affection that warms the weak.

sloka: sandhukṣati tathā vahnireṣāṃ vidhivadindhanaiḥ| snehameva paraṃ vidyāddurbalānaladīpanam||201||
translation: For one who is overheated by the fire of excessive attachment, food that increases calmness is not suitable, even if recommended by a respected teacher. Instead, such a person should ingest a small amount of ghee-infused medication to regulate the downward air and ensure its smooth flow in the body. This practice, done in proximity to fire, will quickly increase one's strength.

sloka: nālaṃ snehasamiddhasya śamāyānnaṃ sugurvapi|  mandāgniravipakvaṃ tu purīṣaṃ yo'tisāryate||202||  dīpanīyauṣadhairyuktāṃ ghṛtamātrāṃ pibettu saḥ| tayā samānaḥ pavanaḥ prasanno [42] mārgamāsthitaḥ||203|| agneḥ samīpacāritvādāśu prakurute balam|
translation: The person who, with great effort, relieves himself of the excrement should drink buttermilk mixed with salt and water before eating.

sloka: kāṭhinyādyaḥ purīṣaṃ tu kṛcchrānmuñcati mānavaḥ||204||  saghṛtaṃ lavaṇairyuktaṃ naro'nnāvagrahaṃ pibet|
translation: One should drink milk or oil, mixed with warming ingredients, in a state of dryness and weakness.

sloka: raukṣyānmande pibetsarpistailaṃ vā dīpanairyutam||205||
translation: In a dull fire, due to excessive affection, powders, salt, acids, and alcoholic beverages are beneficial; when the fecal paste is broken, oils and alcoholic beverages are helpful.

sloka: atisnehāttu mande'gnau cūrṇāriṣṭāsavā hitāḥ|  bhinne gudopalepāttu male tailasurāsavāḥ||206||
translation: In a dimmed fire, as impurities rise during Udavarta (a process of purifying fire by adding oblations), one should perform the removal of impurities, as it increases in such a fire.

sloka: उदावर्तात्तु मन्देऽग्नौ निरूहाः स्नेहबस्तयः।  दोषवृद्ध्या तु मन्देऽग्नौ शुद्धो दोषविधिं चरेत्॥२०७॥
translation: For a person who is ill and weak, ghee can be used to kindle the digestive fire; in a weakened state of agni, one should sip warm water with a little dissolved ghee. This nourishes and strengthens the debilitated body.

sloka: vyādhiyuktasya mande tu sarpirevāgnidīpanam|  upavāsācca mande'gnau yavāgūbhiḥ pibedghṛtam||208||  annāvapīḍitaṃ balyaṃ dīpanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ ca tat|
translation: For a prolonged period, one should feed with well-cooked rice and mild seasonings those who are exhausted, emaciated, and weak. Such food, when light, easily digestible, and warm, quickly kindles their digestive fire. This is because it is rich in meat or meat-like substances and promotes quicker restoration of strength.

sloka: dīrghakālaprasaṅgāttu kṣāmakṣīṇakṛśānnarān||209||  prasahānāṃ rasaiḥ sāmlairbhojayet piśitāśinām|  laghu tīkṣṇoṣṇaśodhitvāddīpayantyāśu te'nalam||210||  māṃsopacitamāṃsatvāttathā''śutarabṛṃhaṇāḥ|
translation: The body's digestive fire does not flourish through overeating, just as a fire without fuel is weak or one with excessive fuel is smothered.

sloka: nābhojanena kāyāgnirdīpyate nātibhojanāt||211||  yathā nirindhano vahniralpo vā'tīndhanāvṛtaḥ|
translation: The strength of one afflicted by illness grows through the use of various medicinal herbs, powders, and alcoholic beverages, when properly administered by a skilled physician, just as a steady and stable fire made of dry leaves gradually increases.

sloka: snehānnavidhibhiścitraiścūrṇāriṣṭasurāsavaiḥ  ||212||  samyakprayuktairbhiṣajā balamagneḥ pravardhate|  yathā hi sāradārvagniḥ sthiraḥ santiṣṭhate ciram||213||
translation: By following proper cooking procedures, a steady internal fire can be established. By eating an appropriate amount of well-cooked food, one enjoys good health and longevity. Imbalance in the qualities of bodily tissues causes the internal fire to weaken or become overactive. A balanced fire, situated in the middle and evenly nourished by all tissues, cooks the food for maintaining good health, strength, and vitality. An under- or overactive fire, fed by unbalanced tissues, can cause disease. This should be spoken about when dealing with someone with a weak digestive fire, while advice for an overactive fire will be given separately.

sloka: snehānnavidhibhistadvadantaragnirbhavet sthiraḥ|  hitaṃ jīrṇe mitaṃ cāśnaṃściramārogyamaśnute||214||  avaiṣamyeṇa dhātūnāmagnivṛddhau yateta nā|  samairdoṣaiḥ samo madhye dehasyoṣmā'gnisaṃsthitaḥ||215||  pacatyannaṃ tadārogyapuṣṭyāyurbalavṛddhaye|  doṣairmando'tivṛddho vā viṣamairjanayedgadān||216||  vācyaṃ mandasya tatroktamativṛddhasya vakṣyate|
translation: In a person with depleted kapha and aggravated pitta, accompanied by vata, the digestive fire manifests in the stomach. Then, with increased sharpness, it repeatedly cooks the food quickly. After cooking the food, it further cooks the bodily tissues, including blood.

sloka: nare kṣīṇakaphe pittaṃ kupitaṃ mārutānugam||217||  svoṣmaṇā pāvakasthāne balamagneḥ prayacchati|  tadā labdhabalo dehe virūkṣe sānilo'nalaḥ||218||  paribhūya pacatyannaṃ taikṣṇyādāśu muhurmuhuḥ|  paktvā'nnaṃ sa tato dhātūñchoṇitādīn pacatyapi||219||
translation: Once fear and weakness are warded off, consuming food brings tranquility; even if the body is worn out, one can survive if they gradually consume nutritious foods. Diseases caused by excessive heat can be alleviated with cool, sweet substances and mild laxatives. Gradually, through sips of water and small portions of food, one should pacify the aggravated digestive fire, so that it does not flare up again.

sloka: tato daurbalyamātaṅkānmṛtyuṃ copanayennaram|  bhukte'nne labhate śāntiṃ jīrṇamātre pratāmyati||220||  tṛṭśvāsadāhamūrcchādyā vyādhayo'tyagnisambhavāḥ|  tamatyagniṃ gurusnigdhaśītairmadhuravijjalaiḥ||221||  annapānairnayecchāntiṃ dīptamagnimivāmbubhiḥ|  muhurmuhurajīrṇe'pi bhojyānyasyopahārayet||222||  nirindhano'ntaraṃ labdhvā yathainaṃ na vipādayet|
translation: Today, one should consume rice pudding, well-cooked thin gruel, wheat-based foods, and sugar candy. Also, eat freshwater fish with firm flesh and that which lives in the sea. Eat meat that has been properly cooked and offered in a fire sacrifice.

sloka: pāyasaṃ kṛśarāṃ snigdhaṃ paiṣṭikaṃ guḍavaikṛtam||223||  adyāttathaudakānūpapiśitāni bhṛtāni ca|  matsyānviśeṣataḥ ślakṣṇānsthiratoyacarāṃstathā||224||  āvikaṃ ca bhṛtaṃ māṃsamadyādatyagnināśanam [46] |
translation: Starving, one may drink water, sugarcane juice, or ghee; or after properly preparing and straining barley flour and soured milk, they may be drunk. Also, one can drink a mixture of milk, sugar, and ghee along with life-sustaining medicines.

sloka: yavāgūṃ samadhūcchiṣṭāṃ ghṛtaṃ vā kṣudhitaḥ pibet||225||  godhūmacūrṇamanthaṃ vā vyadhayitvā sirāṃ pibet|  payo vā śarkarāsarpirjīvanīyauṣadhaiḥ śṛtam||226||
translation: The churning of oilseeds, mixed with sugar, produces oily and fatty substances, as well as meaty flavors, Agni (fire)! [227]

sloka: phalānāṃ tailayonīnāmutkruñcāśca [47] saśarkarāḥ|  mārdavaṃ janayantyagneḥ snigdhā māṃsarasāstathā||227||
translation: A person should drink butter mixed with cool water, honey diluted with water, and a meal of roasted barley flour with milk and ghee. One should consume these three types of oils without sesame oil. Additionally, one should also drink a mixture of milk and ghee in equal proportions, added with either butter or honey. A woman should drink the bark of audumbara tree soaked in her breast milk for the purpose of cooling down after exposing oneself to fire/heat.

sloka: pibecchītāmbunā sarpirmadhūcchiṣṭena saṃyutam|  godhūmacūrṇaṃ payasā sasarpiṣkaṃ pibennaraḥ||228||  ānūparasasiddhān vā trīn snehāṃstailavarjitān|  payasā sammitaṃ [48] cāpi ghanaṃ trisnehasaṃyutam||229||  nāristanyena saṃyuktāṃ pibedaudumbarīṃ tvacam|  tābhyāṃ vā pāyasaṃ siddhamadyādatyagniśāntaye||230||
translation: A knowledgeable physician, after due examination, should give milk that is fresh or slightly overripe to a patient for consumption as many times as necessary to alleviate excess bile.

sloka: śyāmātrivṛdvipakvaṃ vā payo dadyādvirecanam|  asakṛt pittaśāntyarthaṃ pāyasapratibhojanam||231||  prasamīkṣya bhiṣak prājñastasmai dadyādvidhānavit|
translation: Who consumes, before sleep during the day, food that is sweet, oily, heavy, and agreeable, and partakes of other types of food not cooked by fire, he does not experience trouble and only achieves health, when kapha is increased, Pitta is subdued, and Vayu and Agni are in balance.

sloka: yatkiñcinmadhuraṃ medyaṃ śleṣmalaṃ gurubhojanam||232||  sarvaṃ tadatyagnihitaṃ bhuktvā prasvapanaṃ divā|  medyānyannāni yo'tyagnāvapratāntaḥ [49] samaśnute||233||  na tannimittaṃ vyasanaṃ labhate puṣṭimeva ca|  kaphe vṛddhe jite pitte mārute cānalaḥ samaḥ||234||
translation: In this world, consuming a similar amount of healthy and unhealthy food together is considered acceptable. However, consuming an excess of either in the past or present can be harmful. Consuming leftover food from the previous meal is also not recommended, as it can lead to severe illnesses or even death.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  pathyāpathyamihaikatra bhuktaṃ samaśanaṃ matam||235||  viṣamaṃ bahu vā'lpaṃ vā'pyaprāptātītakālayoḥ|  bhuktaṃ pūrvānnaśeṣe tu punaradhyaśanaṃ matam||236||  trīṇyapyetāni mṛtyuṃ vā ghorān vyādhīnsṛjanti vā|
translation: At dawn, even when worn out, the body doesn't become impure by evening. The heart becomes lotus-like when it awakens with the sun. With his mind awake, all the senses function clearly. Moreover, through exercise and recreation, and because of the scattered nature of the mind, the body's elements do not get affected during the day.

sloka: prātarāśe tvajīrṇe'pi sāyamāśo na duṣyati||237||  divā prabudhyate'rkeṇa hṛdayaṃ puṇḍarīkavat|  tasminvibuddhe srotāṃsi sphuṭatvaṃ yānti sarvaśaḥ||238||  vyāyāmācca vihārācca vikṣiptatvācca cetasaḥ|  na kledamupagacchanti divā tenāsya dhātavaḥ||239||
translation: Just as unadulterated milk does not get spoiled in pure water, similarly, that which is mixed with it also doesn't get spoiled; it becomes equal (in taste) to it.

sloka: aklinneṣvannamāsiktamanyatteṣu na duṣyati|  avidagdha iva kṣīre kṣīramanyadvimiśritam||240||  naiva dūṣyati tenaiva samaṃ sampadyate yathā|
translation: When the heart is impure at night and the senses are restrained, bodily tissues go to the stomach for digestion. If these tissues become impure or if the food is not fully digested, the undigested food gets mixed with it. Just like milk that has been heated becomes unfit for consumption when mixed with other things, a wise person should consume something else and take care of their strength and longevity by not consuming improperly digested food.

sloka: rātrau tu hṛdaye mlāne saṃvṛteṣvayaneṣu ca|  yānti koṣṭhe parikledaṃ saṃvṛte dehadhātavaḥ||241||  klinneṣvanyadapakveṣu teṣvāsiktaṃ praduṣyati|  vidagdheṣu payaḥsvanyat payastaptamivārpitam||242||  naiśeṣvāhārajāteṣu nāvipakveṣu buddhimān|  tasmādanyatsamaśnīyātpālayiṣyanbalāyuṣī||243||
translation: Just as the fire within, referred to as antaragni, holds together and digests the body, cooks food, and causes the ingestion of various types of sustenance; similarly, there are several fires that nourish and digest different substances. The order of development of tastes and elimination of impurities arises from them. The timely emergence of nutrients and their proper assimilation is due to antaragni. It is also responsible for causing specific diseases in certain parts of the body. Excessive antaragni produces toxins, leading to the creation of various ailments known as grahanidosha. The muni has explained the prior symptoms and their treatment for this fourfold condition, along with the appropriate actions to be taken when such excessive agni arises and its remedy. This is the complete teaching given by the sage regarding the disorder related to grahanidosha.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  antaragniguṇā dehaṃ yathā dhārayate ca saḥ|  yathā'nnaṃ pacyate yāṃśca yathā''hāraḥ karotyapi||244|| ye'gnayo yāṃśca puṣyanti yāvanto ye pacanti yān|  rasādīnāṃ kramotpattirmalānāṃ tebhya eva ca||245||  vṛṣyāṇāmāśukṛddheturdhātukālodbhavakramaḥ|  rogaikadeśakṛddheturantaragniryathā'dhikaḥ||246||  praduṣyati yathā duṣṭo yān rogāñjanayatyapi|  grahaṇī yā yathā [53] yacca grahaṇīdoṣalakṣaṇam||247||  pūrvarūpaṃ pṛthak caiva vyañjanaṃ sacikitsitam|  caturvidhasya nirdiṣṭaṃ tathā cāvasthikī kriyā||248||  jāyate ca yathā'tyagniryacca tasya cikitsitam|  uktavāniha tat sarvaṃ grahaṇīdoṣake muniḥ||249||
translation: In the treatise written by Agnivesha, when the chapter related to the treatment of grahani (a digestive disorder) is not obtained and a place full of firm strength has been established, it is the fifteenth chapter named Grahani-cikitsitam.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne  grahaṇīcikitsitaṃ nāma pañcadaśo'dhyāyaḥ||15||
translation: Now we will explain the treatment of abdominal diseases. Thus said Lord Atreya.

sloka: athāta udaracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: In the abode of Kailasa, teeming with Siddhas and Vidhyadharas, engaged in severe austerities that resemble Dharma himself.

sloka: siddhavidyādharākīrṇe kailāse nandanopame|  tapyamānaṃ tapastīvraṃ sākṣāddharmamiva sthitam||3||
translation: The best among physicians skilled in Ayurveda and chief of medical knowledge, Agnivesha, who has mastered himself, spoke these words.

sloka: āyurvedavidāṃ śreṣṭhaṃ bhiṣagvidyāpravartakam|  punarvasuṃ jitātmānamagniveśo'bravīdvacaḥ||4||
translation:
Men, O Lord, are seen to be afflicted by hardships caused by their bellies. Emaciated, with parched mouths and shrunken limbs, they have lost the strength of their digestive fire and control over all their activities. Deprived of nourishment and reduced to a pitiful state, they seem to have lost their senses as if they were orphans. (translated by A. Mahadeva Sastri)

Or another possible translation:

Men in this world, O Lord, are seen distressed by pains that arise from their bellies.
