translation: One should give a mixture of shaka (a type of vegetable) and curd as an offering to the three-toothed palasha tree and the citrakas (a type of plant) on Yamaka's bark.

sloka: barhi tittiri lāvānāṃ rasānamlān susaṃskṛtān| dakṣāṇāṃ vartakānāṃ ca dadyādviḍvātasaṅgrahe||121||
translation: One should offer vegetables such as tender turmeric, ripe corn ears, fragrant leafy greens, well-ripened berries, and jujube fruits; fresh produce of amlaki, ginger, and Shatishaka (a type of plant); and properly processed dairy products like yogurt and date palm fruits to the worthy. (123-125)

sloka: trivṛddantīpalāśānāṃ cāṅgeryāścitrakasya ca| yamake bharjitaṃ dadyācchākaṃ dadhi samanvitam||122||
translation: One should diligently take care of cows, deer, tiger, dog, bird, and even the snake and tortoise, by providing them with their preferred foods. For this purpose, one should give food that is cooked with red meat (for non-vegetarians) to pacify the wind in the body.

sloka: upodikāṃ taṇḍulīyaṃ vīrāṃ vāstuka pallavān| suvarcalāṃ saloṇīkāṃ yava śākamavalgujam||123|| kākamācīṃ ruhāpatraṃ mahāpatraṃ tathā'mlikām| jīvantīṃ śaṭiśākaṃ ca śākaṃ gṛñjanakasya ca||124|| dadhi dāḍima siddhāni yamake bharjitāni ca| dhānya nāgara yuktāni śākānyetāni dāpayet||125||
translation: Having understood the powerful influence of wind, the mildness of fire originating from the lower abdomen, intoxicating drinks, sugarcane juice, whey, curdled milk, water consumed in the hot season or during winter, water mixed with Kantakari plant, or even water drunk by city dwellers, a physician should administer it appropriately to counteract its dehydrating effects.

sloka: godhālopāka mārjāra śvāviduṣṭragavāmapi| kūrma śallakayoścaiva sādhayecchākavadrasān||126|| rakta śālyodanaṃ dadyādrasaistairvāta śāntaye|127|
translation: Those who are indifferent towards the reversal of the fortunate and those who are pained by the harm caused by the contrary wind, for them residing in such places is beneficial .

sloka: jñātvā vātolbaṇaṃ rūkṣaṃ mandāgniṃ gudajāturam||127|| madirāṃ śārkaraṃ jātaṃ sīdhuṃ takraṃ tuṣodakam| ariṣṭaṃ dadhimaṇḍaṃ vā śṛtaṃ vā śiśiraṃ jalam||128|| kaṇṭakāryā śṛtaṃ vā'pi śṛtaṃ nāgaradhānyakaiḥ| anupānaṃ bhiṣagdadyādvātavarco'nulomanam||129||
translation: The finest regimen for curing the itching and mental confusion of dull-witted people is to consume oil, prepared by grinding into a paste and cooking with the specified ingredients - pippalī, madanā, bilva, shatāhvā, madhuka, vacā, kuṣṭha, śaṭī, puṣkara, citraka, and devadāru.

sloka: udāvarta parītā ye ye cātyarthaṃ virūkṣitāḥ| vilomavātāḥ śūlārtāsteṣviṣṭamanuvāsanam||130||
translation: The emergence of piles, the presence of a peg-like object (in the rectum), difficult bowel movements, weakness in the thighs, hips, and back, growth in the region of the anus, passage of wind with stool or urine, frequent urge to pass stools, and retention of feces; these are the symptoms that arise from an imbalance of air and bile.

sloka: pippalīṃ madanaṃ bilvaṃ śatāhvāṃ madhukaṃ vacām| kuṣṭhaṃ śaṭīṃ puṣkarākhyaṃ citrakaṃ devadāru ca||131|| piṣṭvā tailaṃ vipaktavyaṃ payasā dviguṇena ca| arśasāṃ mūḍhavātānāṃ tacchreṣṭhamanuvāsanam||132||
translation: One should smear the closed anus with well-ground, warm, and oily substances mixed with darvana. This quickly liquefies the tough phlegm along with blood in the excretory channels, and stops the occurrence of itching, stiffness, ruksa, and shotha in the evacuated feces.

sloka: gudaniḥsaraṇaṃ śūlaṃ mūtrakṛcchraṃ pravāhikām| kaṭyūrupṛṣṭhadaurbalyamānāhaṃ vaṅkṣaṇāśrayam||133|| picchāsrāvaṃ gude śophaṃ vātavarcovinigraham| utthānaṃ bahuśo yacca jayettaccānuvāsanāt||134||
translation: Prepare the extract of Dasamula (ten roots) with clarified butter, water, and added with various flavors, salts, and other ingredients.

sloka: ānuvāsanikaiḥ piṣṭaiḥ sukhoṣṇaiḥ snehasaṃyutaiḥ| dārvantaiḥ stabdha śūlāni gudajāni pralepayet||135|| digdhāstaiḥ prasravantyāśu śleṣma picchāṃ saśoṇitām| kaṇḍūḥ stambhaḥ saruk śophaḥ srutānāṃ vinivartate||136||
translation: The measure of haritaki should be one prastha, that of amalaka should also be one prastha. Twelve palmfuls of kapitha make up a prastha, half of which is endra-varuni. A palaa of vida, pippali, lodhra, marica, and saileya should be reduced to two palas. This quantity, when mixed with four dronas of water, should be boiled down until only a quarter of the original amount remains. The remaining liquid should then be filtered through a clean cloth and allowed to cool. One hundred and twenty grams of jaggery should be added to this and stirred until it dissolves completely. Half of this mixture should then be poured into a ghrita-vessel.

sloka: nirūhaṃ vā prayuñjīta sakṣīraṃ dāśamūlikam| samūtra sneha lavaṇaṃ kalkairyuktaṃ phalādibhiḥ||137||
translation: The feces are eliminated through the rectum by drinking liquids, in due course, in accordance with one's capacity; this results from regular practice.

sloka: harītakīnāṃ prasthārdhaṃ prasthamāmalakasya ca| syāt kapitthāddaśapalaṃ tato'rdhā cendravāruṇī||138|| viḍaṅgaṃ pippalī lodhraṃ maricaṃ sailavālukam| dvipalāṃśaṃ jalasyaitaccaturdroṇe vipācayet||139|| droṇaśeṣe rase tasmin pūte śīte samāvapet| guḍasya dviśataṃ tiṣṭhettat pakṣaṃ ghṛtabhājane||140||
translation: One who cures diseases like emaciation, heart disease, enlargement of the spleen, and abdominal tumors. Who is skilled in eliminating leprosy, edema, skin diseases, and increasing strength and complexion as well as lustrousness. Who is capable of destroying worms, tumors, and fistulas, and is the conqueror of diseases like consumption, leprosy, fever, and unconsciousness. Such a person is called Abhayarista, one who is free from fear of any disease.

sloka: pakṣādūrdhvaṃ bhavet peyā tato mātrā yathābalam| asyābhyāsādariṣṭasya gudajā yānti saṅkṣayam||141||
translation: One should separate and allocate the fractions of the juices from the fifth root of both citraka and dantī plants. One should give three parts to triphala and consume the fourth part, which remains pure and cool. By using a scale balanced with a quarter of a measure of jaggery against a measure of ghee every day, one becomes free from debt towards the forefathers.

sloka: grahaṇī pāṇḍu hṛdroga plīha gulmodarāpahaḥ| kuṣṭha śophāruciharo balavarṇāgnivardhanaḥ||142|| siddho'yamabhayāriṣṭaḥ kāmalāśvitranāśanaḥ| kṛmigranthyarbuda vyaṅga rājayakṣma jvarāntakṛt||143|| ityabhayāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: They know this as Dantyarista, the enemy of tooth decay, which is light yellow in color, destroys bad teeth color, enhances brightness, and is anuloman (promotes easy downward movement, possibly referring to swallowing food without difficulty). It also cures "pandu roga," which can be translated as a type of disease characterized by whiteness, possibly vitiligo or anemia. Additionally, it is known for its property of grasping (grahani), and it eliminates the fear of tooth decay.

sloka: dantī citraka mūlānāmubhayoḥ pañcamūlayoḥ| bhāgān palāṃśānāpothya jaladroṇe vipācayet||144|| tripalaṃ triphalāyāśca dalānāṃ tatra dāpayet| rase caturtha śeṣe tu pūte śīte samāvapet||145|| tulāṃ guḍasya tattiṣṭhenmāsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhājane| tanmātrayā pibannityamarśobhyo vipramucyate||146||
translation: Consuming four portions of Haritaki fruit powder and two portions of Amla fruit powder, mixed together, can be used to treat diarrhea. After consuming this mixture in twice the quantity of a drona (a measurement), any remaining should be consumed when the symptoms of the disorder have subsided. A doctor should measure out an equal amount of jaggery and place it in a ghee container. This should then be consumed in small, regular doses to treat disorders caused by increased Pitta dosha.

sloka: grahaṇī pāṇḍu rogaghnaṃ vātavarco'nulomanam| dīpanaṃ cārucighnaṃ ca dantyariṣṭamimaṃ viduḥ||147|| iti dantyariṣṭaḥ|
translation: The digestive disorders such as indigestion, jaundice, enlargement of the spleen, and irregular fever, as well as the conditions of cough, hiccup, and diarrhea, are eliminated by this treatment, as spoken by Krishna Dvaipayana (Vyasa). This is known as Phalarista.

sloka: harītakī phalaprasthaṃ prasthamāmalakasya ca| viśālāyā dadhitthasya pāṭhācitrakamūlayoḥ||148|| dve dve pale samāpothya dvidroṇe sādhayedapām| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca rase tasmin pradāpayet||149|| guḍasyaikāṃ tulāṃ vaidyastat sthāpyaṃ ghṛtabhājane| pakṣasthitaṃ pibedenaṃ grahaṇyarśovikāravān||150||
translation: The attainment of pure gold, a fine horse, an elephant, a clear mirror, paddy grains, and the two teeth of a boar should be placed in a pot filled with water for half a month, anointed with ghee, along with camphor, priyangu, kshaudra, and sarpi (types of substances).

sloka: hṛtpāṇḍurogaṃ plīhānaṃ kāmalāṃ viṣamajvaram| varcomūtrānilakṛtān vibandhānagnimārdavam||151|| kāsaṃ gulmamudāvartaṃ phalāriṣṭo vyapohati| agnisandīpano hyeṣa kṛṣṇātreyeṇa bhāṣitaḥ||152|| iti phalāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: One should drink (the urine) of that (animal) in measured quantities, at appropriate times, like sugar syrup according to one's tolerance. This helps in alleviating the disorders of the stomach, wind, phlegm, bile, and also heart and skin diseases. This is the second auxiliary beneficial result (mentioned by the sage).

sloka: durālabhāyāḥ prasthaḥ syāccitrakasya vṛṣasya ca| pathyāmalakayoścaiva pāṭhāyā nāgarasya ca||153|| dantyāśca dvipalān bhāgāñjaladroṇe vipācayet| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca suśīte śarkarāśatam||154|| prakṣipya sthāpayet kumbhe māsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhāvite| pralipte pippalī cavya priyaṅgu kṣaudra sarpiṣā||155||
translation:
Prepare a scale with a single seed of Amla (Phyllanthus emblica). Add to it:
- the dust of Pippalī (long pepper) and Marica (black pepper),
- a leaf of Pippala (Betel), the root of Pippalī,
- a seed each of Nāgapuṣpa (Tribulus terrestris),

sloka: tasya mātrāṃ pibet kāle śārkarasya yathābalam| arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣamudāvartamarocakam||156|| śakṛnmūtrānilodgāravibandhānagnimārdavam| hṛdrogaṃ pāṇḍurogaṃ ca sarvametena sādhayet||157|| iti dvitīyaphalāriṣṭaḥ |
translation: I, Arishta, can identify the symptoms of diseases such as grahani dosha, udara jwara, hridroga, panduta, and shotha, as well as their severity. I can also identify all severe symptoms of kaphaja disorders and remove the causes of these ailments.

sloka: navasyāmalakasyaikāṃ kuryājjarjaritāṃ tulām| kuḍavāṃśāśca pippalyo viḍaṅgaṃ maricaṃ tathā||158|| pāṭhāṃ ca pippalī mūlaṃ kramukaṃ cavya citrakau| mañjiṣṭhailvālukaṃ lodhraṃ palikānupakalpayet||159|| kuṣṭhaṃ dāruharidrāṃ ca surāhvaṃ sārivādvayam| indrāhvaṃ bhadramustaṃ ca kuryādardhapalonmitam||160|| catvāri nāgapuṣpasya palānyabhinavasya ca| droṇābhyāmambhaso dvābhyāṃ sādhayitvā'vatārayet||161|| pādāvaśeṣe pūte ca śīte tasmin pradāpayet| mṛdvīkādvyāḍhakarasaṃ śītaṃ niryūhasammitam||162|| śarkarāyāśca bhinnāyā dadyāddviguṇitāṃ tulām| kusumasya rasasyaikamardhaprasthaṃ navasya ca||163|| tvagelāplavapatrāmbusevyakramukakeśarān| cūrṇayitvā tu matimān kārṣikānatra dāpayet||164|| tat sarvaṃ sthāpayet pakṣaṃ sucaukṣe ghṛtabhājane| pralipte sarpiṣā kiñciccharkarāgurudhūpite||165|| pakṣādūrdhvamariṣṭo'yaṃ kanako nāma viśrutaḥ| peyaḥ svāduraso hṛdyaḥ prayogādbhaktarocanaḥ||166||
translation: Cleanliness should be achieved using water from broken leaves or warm water, as stated. This is the prescribed treatment for dry parts of the body.

sloka: arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣamānāhamudaraṃ jvaram| hṛdrogaṃ pāṇḍutāṃ śothaṃ gulmaṃ varcovinigraham||167|| kāsaṃ śleṣmāmayāṃścogrān sarvānevāpakarṣati| valīpalitakhālityaṃ doṣajaṃ ca vyapohati||168|| iti kanakāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: The supreme knowledge for those who seek to cure is this: there are two kinds of connections in the occurrence of phlegm and wind.

sloka: patrabhaṅgodakaiḥ śaucaṃ kuryāduṣṇena vā'mbhasā|  iti śuṣkārśasāṃ siddhamuktametaccikitsitam||169||
translation: The wind does not dwell in a body that is dark, hard, rough, and lowly; or one that is thin, fair-skinned, delicate, and oily. If the body has excessive stiffness, emaciation, irregularities in the hips, thighs, and calves, or feebleness, then those are the causes of wind's affliction.

sloka: cikitsitamidaṃ siddhaṃ srāviṇāṃ śṛṇvataḥ param | tatrānubandho dvividhaḥ śleṣmaṇo mārutasya ca||170||
translation: The consistence of curd, white and yellow; oily, heavy, and cool; which is the cloud of phlegm, thin, and has a thread-like appearance - this is known as the cause in those with excessive phlegm. The place is the lower abdomen, with feces and well-controlled, heavy, oily, and causes binding of phlegm, recognized by the learned.

sloka: viṭ śyāvaṃ kaṭhinaṃ rūkṣaṃ cādho vāyurna vartate| tanu cāruṇavarṇaṃ ca phenilaṃ cāsṛgarśasām||171|| kaṭyūrugudaśūlaṃ ca daurbalyaṃ yadi cādhikam| tatrānubandho vātasya heturyadi ca rūkṣaṇam||172||
translation: Therefore, this should be firmly remembered and employed in the windy and cold season: a pleasant coolness is beneficial there.

sloka: śithilaṃ śvetapītaṃ ca viṭ snigdhaṃ guru śītalam| yadyarśasāṃ ghanaṃ cāsṛk tantumat pāṇḍu picchilam||173|| gudaṃ sapicchaṃ stimitaṃ guru snigdhaṃ ca kāraṇam| śleṣmānubandho vijñeyastatra raktārśasāṃ budhaiḥ||174||
translation: If one thinks that there is an excess of bile and phlegm, they should treat it. They should also ignore or perform actions like jumping over, etc., to promote discharge. (Refers to medical treatment)

sloka: snigdhaśītaṃ hitaṃ vāte rūkṣaśītaṃ kaphānuge| cikitsitamidaṃ tasmāt sampradhārya prayojayet||175||
translation: The unwise person who, at the beginning of manifestation, restrains those that are productive and shining, brings forth many ailments such as impaired blood flow, phlegm, wind, bile, fever, thirst, burning sensations in the body, itching, eruptions, tumors, swellings, carbuncles, fistulas, joint dislocations, gout, shoe-bite, headache, heaviness of limbs, and other afflictions caused by imbalanced bodily fluids.

sloka: pittaśleṣmādhikaṃ matvā śodhanenopapādayet| sravaṇaṃ cāpyupekṣeta laṅghanairvā samācaret||176||
translation: Therefore, for one who knows the reason, symptom, time, and the color of pus, it is beneficial to refrain from mixing with foul-smelling pus until recovery.

sloka: pravṛttamādāvarśobhyo yo nigṛhṇātyabuddhimān| śoṇitaṃ doṣamanilaṃ tadrogāñjanayedbahūn||177|| raktapittaṃ jvaraṃ tṛṣṇāmagnisādamarocakam| kāmalāṃ śvayathuṃ śūlaṃ guda vaṅkṣaṇa saṃśrayam||178|| kaṇḍvaruḥkoṭhapiḍakāḥ kuṣṭhaṃ pāṇḍvāhvayaṃ gadam| vāta mūtra purīṣāṇāṃ vibandhaṃ śiraso rujam||179|| staimityaṃ gurugātratvaṃ tathā'nyān raktajān gadān|
translation: For kindling fire, for collecting red sandalwood, and for cooking down impurities, one should use bitter herbs.

sloka: tasmāt srute duṣṭarakte raktasaṅgrahaṇaṃ hitam||180|| hetu lakṣaṇa kālajño bala śoṇita varṇavit| kālaṃ tāvadupekṣeta yāvannātyayamāpnuyāt||181||
translation:
The redness of depleted and purified sallow complexion caused by vata \* is treatable with oil massage, sweat-inducing measures, and hydration.

\* Vata refers to one of the three doshas or biological forces in Ayurveda, the Indian system of medicine, and is typically associated with dryness.

sloka: agni sandīpanārthaṃ ca rakta saṅgrahaṇāya ca| doṣāṇāṃ pācanārthaṃ ca paraṃ tiktairupācaret||182||
translation: That which is a yellowish-red color and occurs during the summer season, it should definitely be stopped immediately; there should be no delay in treating pitta.

sloka: yattu prakṣīṇadoṣasya raktaṃ vātolbaṇasya ca| vartate snehasādhyaṃ tat pānābhyaṅgānuvāsanaiḥ||183||
translation: The spread of the kutaja creeper is like a well-knit city, its collection of flowers resembles the reddish black kuṭajā fruits. The kuṭajā fruits and flowers, when boiled with darvīti leaves, chandana, and nimba, produce a concoction that alleviates the thirst of those suffering from scabies and red rashes, and also neutralizes the poison of saati visa. This is mentioned in verse 185-187.

sloka: yattu pittolbaṇaṃ raktaṃ gharmakāle pravartate| stambhanīyaṃ tadekāntānna cedvātakaphānugam||184||
translation: The resin of the kutaja tree, when made smooth and mixed with a hundredth part of freshly squeezed milk from an indra-cow, should be used as long as it remains unchanged. After filtering, this preparation, along with the juice extracted from fruits and three other ingredients, should be given in the dose of a cow's calf's portion. Once clarified and boiled down to its essence, the resulting extract is to be used. This method, when followed correctly, will prevent abnormal discharge.

sloka: kuṭaja tvaṅniryūhaḥ sanāgaraḥ snigdha rakta saṅgrahaṇaḥ| tvagdāḍimasya tadvat sanāgaraścandanarasaśca||185|| candana kirātatiktaka dhanvayavāsāḥ sanāgarāḥ kvathitāḥ| raktārśasāṃ praśamanā dārvītvaguśīra nimbāśca||186|| sātiviṣā kuṭaja tvak phalaṃ ca sarasāñjanaṃ madhuyutāni| raktāpahāni dadyāt pipāsave taṇḍulajalena||187||
translation: Just as fire consumes dry grass and herbs, or as one may drink milk or butter milk to satisfaction, so should an ox that is old and no longer capable of working in the fields be fed with milk.

sloka: kuṭaja tvaco vipācyaṃ palaśatamārdraṃ mahendrasalilena| yāvatsyādgatarasaṃ taddravyaṃ pūto rasastato grāhyaḥ||188|| mocarasaḥ sasamaṅgaḥ phalinī ca samāṃśikaistribhistaiśca | vatsakabījaṃ tulyaṃ cūrṇitamatra pradātavyam||189|| pūtotkvathitaḥ sāndraḥ sa raso darvīpralepano grāhyaḥ| mātrākālopahitā rasakriyaiṣā jayatyasṛksrāvam||190||
translation: This Rasakriya, according to Kuṭajādi, quickly kills the extremely sick with bloody diarrhea and red bile. It is powerful and victorious over both halves (of the disease).

sloka: chagalī payasā pītā peyāmaṇḍena vā yathāgnibalam| jīrṇauṣadhaśca śālīn payasā chāgena bhuñjīta||191||
translation: Consuming a mixture of powdered blue lotus, lichen, pure sandalwood, sesame seeds, and lodhras (a type of tree), along with buttermilk, is one's food.

sloka: raktārśāṃsyatisāraṃ raktaṃ sāsṛgrujo nihantyāśu| balavacca raktapittaṃ rasakriyaiṣā jayatyubhayabhāgam ||192|| iti kuṭajādirasakriyā|
translation: The extract from the milk of a she-goat, when consumed, eliminates blood-impurities along with its inherent qualities; is the unadulterated and cool taste found in the birds and animals.

sloka: nīlotpalaṃ samaṅgā mocarasaścandanaṃ tilā lodhram| pītvā cchagalīpayasā bhojyaṃ payasaiva śālyannam||193||
translation: Drinks prepared by grinding bilva, patha, cow's urine, turmeric, and barley, as prescribed by the scriptural texts, are taken for medicinal purposes.

sloka: chāgali payaḥ prayuktaṃ nihanti raktaṃ savāstukarasaṃ ca| dhanva vihaṅga mṛgāṇāṃ raso niramlaḥ kadamlo vā||194||
translation: A hunter who is harsh, an eater of raw meat, unfriendly, and a killer of animals.

sloka: pāṭhā vatsakabījaṃ rasāñjanaṃ nāgaraṃ yavānyaśca| bilvamiti cārśasaiścūrṇitāni peyāni śūleṣu||195||
translation: When the shock (shoola) is moving towards the red color (indicating severe bleeding), ghee should be administered. It should be prepared with the powders of kutaja fruits, valkala, keshara, blue lotus, lodhra, and dhataki. Such ghee is recommended for doctors to apply in treating bleeding disorders.

sloka: dārvī kirātatiktaṃ mustaṃ duḥsparśakaśca rudhiraghnam|
translation: Ghee, always having the taste of fresh cream, wins quickly; either red or black, it is produced from churned or unchurned milk.

sloka: rakte'tivartamāne śūle ca ghṛtaṃ vidhātavyam||196|| kuṭajaphala valka keśara nīlotpala lodhra dhātakī kalkaiḥ| siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ vidheyaṃ śūle raktārśasāṃ bhiṣajā||197||
translation: Consuming liquor, well-versed in the sacred texts, anointed with the pollen of Kesara and Utpalas, and empowered, Pṛśniparnī (a plant) can stop even the flow of violent streams.

sloka: sarpiḥ sadāḍimarasaṃ sayāvaśūkaṃ śṛtaṃ jayatyāśu| raktaṃ saśūlamathavā nidigdhikādugdhikāsiddham||198||
translation: A Bilva tree, newly sprouted from a Naga stone, fully grown and bearing fruits of various tastes - bitter, sour, and astringent. (Verse 200)

sloka: lājāpeyā pītā sacukrikā keśarotpalaiḥ siddhā| hantyāśvasrasrāvaṃ tathā balā pṛśniparṇībhyām||199||
translation: Who can offer, using some means, the medicine that has been prepared from the Gṛijjakasurāsiddhā plant, to stop the flow of blood and the severe pain caused by diarrhea?

sloka: hrīvera bilva nāgara niryūhe sādhitāṃ sanavanītām| vṛkṣāmla dāḍimāmlāmamlīkāmlāṃ sakolāmlām||200||
translation: To the ascetic who eats leaves of Kashmarya trees, big clouds of fruits' sweetness; to the one who drinks the juice of Shalmali trees and pushes down the ripe fruit of Kovidara trees; to the one who collects the flowers of Nyagrodha and Shungaka trees; he should give ghee when blood is discharged.

sloka: gṛñjanakasurāsiddhāṃ dadyādyamakena bharjitāṃ peyām| raktātisāra śūla pravāhikā śotha nigrahaṇīm||201||
translation: The perfectly ripe tender jackfruit, when mixed with curd and flavored with sugar, along with the juice of granulated sugarcane, when added to freshly drawn blood, turns into a delicious beverage.

sloka: kāśmaryāmalakānāṃ sakarbudārān phalāmlāṃśca| gṛñjanaka śālmalīnāṃ kṣīriṇyāścukrikāyāśca||202|| nyagrodha śuṅgakānāṃ khaṇḍāṃstathā kovidāra puṣpāṇām| dadhnaḥ sareṇa siddhān dadyādrakte pravṛtte'ti||203||
translation: Today, Mudgala should consume a meal of rice, shali, shyamaka, and kodrava, mixed with clarified butter, sugar, and licorice, along with sour drinks.

sloka: siddhaṃ palāṇḍuśākaṃ takreṇopodikāṃ sabadarāmlām| rudhirasrave pradadyānmasūrasūpaṃ ca takrāmlam||204||
translation: With well-prepared hares, deer, birds, and fish, should one eat today sweet AND slightly sour rice preparations.

sloka: payasā śṛtena yūṣai rmasūra mudgāḍhakīmakuṣṭhānām | bhojanamadyādamlaiḥ śāli śyāmāka kodravajam||205||
translation: In the world, today, who is superior in taste, with a body anointed by the nectar-like juices of ripe Bilva fruits and resplendent Kusha blades?

sloka: śaśa hariṇa lāva māṃsaiḥ kapiñjalaiṇeyakaiḥ susiddhaiśca| bhojanamadyādamlairmadhurairīṣat samaricairvā||206||
translation: The victory is solely due to the combination of taste, odor, touch, and flavor, or possibly just one of them; or perhaps it is due to the wind blowing strongly but pleasantly and being adorned with red sandalwood. (Note: This translation assumes a context where these factors might contribute to victory.)

sloka: dakṣa śikhi tittiri rasairdvikakudalo pākajaiśca madhurāmlaiḥ| adyādrasairativaheṣvarśaḥsvanilolbaṇaśarīraḥ||207||
translation: In the prime of youth, situated in the midst of a grove and anointed with plenty of blood, [something/someone] is to be given when there is a substitution, making it sweet and sour due to the decrease of blood.

sloka: rasa khaḍa yūṣa yavāgū saṃyogataḥ kevalo'thavā jayati| raktamativartamānaṃ vātaṃ ca palāṇḍurupayuktaḥ||208||
translation: By churning fresh butter and sugar from sesame seeds, one gets clarified butter with a reddish tint.

sloka: chāgāntarādhi taruṇaṃ sarudhiramupasādhitaṃ bahu palāṇḍu| vyatyāsānmadhurāmlaṃ viṭśoṇitasaṅkṣaye deyam||209||
translation: Ninety-six measures of puffed rice, a goat, meat, and a cartload of barley; a young maiden and a jar of wine - all of these destroy a hundred sins.

sloka: navanīta tilābhyāsāt keśara navanīta śarkarābhyāsāt| dadhi sara mathitābhyāsādarśāṃsyapayānti raktāni||210||
translation: In most cases, the windy seasons give rise to excess phlegm and bile; therefore, Vayu (wind) should be considered as predominant in an unhealthy state of imbalanced kapha and pitta.

sloka: navanītaghṛtaṃ chāgaṃ māṃsaṃ ca saṣaṣṭikaḥ śāliḥ| taruṇaśca surā maṇḍastaruṇī ca surā nihantyasram||211||
translation: Upon seeing a strong buildup of rakta pitta (a doshic imbalance in Ayurvedic medicine) that is meager, characterized by an abundance of kapha and vata, one should apply cool activities as directed.

sloka: prāyeṇa vāta bahulānyarśāṃsi bhavantyatisrute rakte| duṣṭe'pi ca kapha pitte tasmādanilo'dhiko jñeyaḥ||212||
translation: For the consecration, one should use madhuka, sapanchavalkha, badaritvak, udumbara, and dhava patolam woods, as well as yava and nimba.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā tu raktapittaṃ prabalaṃ kapha vāta liṅgamalpaṃ ca| śītā kriyā prayojyā yatheritā vakṣyate cānyā ||213||
translation: Even in a fire that is fiercely blazing and causing sweat, one should still immerse oneself in Madhuka, Mrinala, Padmaka, Chandana, Kusha, and Kaasha. (These are types of medicinal plants or materials.)

sloka: madhukaṃ sapañcavalkaṃ badarītvagudumbaraṃ dhavapaṭolam| pariṣecane vidadhyādvṛṣakakuma yavāsa nimbāṃśca||214||
translation: One should immerse the ripe Karira fruit in a decoction made from the bark of trees like Ikshu, Madhuka, and Vetasa, or cool water, which has been previously mixed with sesame oil in summer.

sloka: rakte'tivartamāne dāhe klede'vagāhayeccāpi| madhuka mṛṇāla padmaka candana kuśa kāśa niṣkvāthe||215||
translation: After applying a mixture of ghee and sugar to the perineum and an area three fingers above it, a cooling sensation on contact with that area should be induced.

sloka: ikṣurasa madhuka vetasa niryūhe śītale payasi vā tam| avagāhayet pradigdhaṃ pūrvaṃ śiśireṇa tailena||216||
translation: Shading again and again with fresh buds of palm leaves, cooled with water, and also with lotus petals, is always desirable.

sloka: dattvā ghṛtaṃ saśarkaramupasthadeśe gude trikadeśe ca| śiśira jala sparśa sukhā dhārā prastambhanī yojyā||217||
translation: Even ghee boiled and churned a thousand times, if it has an unpleasant smell, is inferior to clarified butter that is fresh, cool, and has a pleasant aroma.

sloka: kadalīdalairabhinavaiḥ puṣkarapatraiśca śītajalasiktaiḥ|  pracchādanaṃ muhurmuhuriṣṭaṃ padmotpaladalaiśca||218||
translation: When mixed with honey and sesame seeds, or with sugar and clarified butter, or with nimba and clarified butter, or with honey and clarified butter, they become purgatives in cases of burning, sweating, and prolapse of the rectum.

sloka: durvāghṛtapradehaḥ śatadhautasahasradhautamapi sarpiḥ|  vyajanapavanaḥ suśīto raktasrāvaṃ jayatyāśu||219||
translation: Feed the wise one, who remains unmoved by flattery or cold, with warm and fatty meat dishes at the appropriate time.

sloka: samaṅgā madhukābhyāṃ tila madhukābhyāṃ rasāñjanavṛtābhyām| sarjarasa ghṛtābhyāṃ vā nimbaghṛtābhyāṃ madhughṛtābhyāṃ vā||220|| dārvītvaksarpirbhyāṃ sacandanābhyāmathotpalaghṛtābhyām| dāhe klede ca gudabhraṃśe gudajāḥ pratisāraṇīyāḥ syuḥ||221||
translation: Quickly tend to the one bitten by a poisonous snake using warm clarified butter, sesame oil, and by pouring warm milk, curd, and sesame oil over them.

sloka: ābhiḥ kriyābhirathavā śītābhiryasya tiṣṭhati na raktam| taṃ kāle snigdhoṣṇairmāṃsarasaistarpayenmatimān||222||
translation: One should quickly churn the ghee (clarified butter) with a mildly warm hand, and give oil treatment to the tail and back at the appropriate time. Thus, it will be accomplished.

sloka: avapīḍaka sarpirbhiḥ koṣṇai rghṛta tailikaistathā'bhyaṅgaiḥ| kṣīra ghṛta taila sekaiḥ koṣṇaistamupācaredāśu||223||
translation: One should cook the roots and shoots of yava, kusha, and kasha, as well as the flowers and bark of shalmali, nyagrodha, udumbara, ashvattha, and shunga, which are of equal size to a triprista (about 3.5 liters) with water. The cooked mixture should then be strained through a cloth made from shalmali fibers and candana or utpala plants, along with the seeds of vatsaka and priyangu. This is then mixed with ghee, cow's urine, and sugar, and used as a medicine for diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and fever.

sloka: koṣṇena vātaprabale ghṛtamaṇḍenānuvāsayecchīghram| picchābastiṃ dadyāt kāle tasyāthavā siddham||224||
translation:
"Prapauṇḍarīka (a type of candy) and madhukam (another type of sweet), after being pounded and cooked with twice the amount of milk and ghee as specified, should be used for anuvāsana (medicated enema). This is called piścchabasti."

Note: The verse seems to be describing a medicinal recipe using certain types of candies or sweets.

sloka: yavāsa kuśa kāśānaṃ mūlaṃ puṣpaṃ ca śālmalam| nyagrodhodumbarāśvattha śuṅgāśca dvipalonmitāḥ||225|| triprasthaṃ salilasyaitat kṣīraprasthaṃ ca sādhayet| kṣīraśeṣaṃ kaṣāyaṃ ca pūtaṃ kalkairvimiśrayet||226|| kalkāḥ śālmali niryāsa samaṅgā candanotpalam| vatsakasya ca bījāni priyaṅguḥ padmakeśaram||227|| picchābastirayaṃ siddhaḥ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaraḥ| pravāhikā gudabhraṃśa raktasrāva jvarāpahaḥ||228||
translation: The substances such as Hrivera (a type of red sap), utpala (blue lotus), lodhram (a fragrant wood), candy cotton, bilva (wood apple), dhataki (a medicinal plant), devadaru (deodar), darvi (a type of grass), nagaram (black antimony), mamsii (red arsenic), musta (nutgrass), ksaras (alkali) and yavagraga (barley sprouts) should be combined on the angieri (a type of stove) with ghee, which is considered the supreme medicine.

sloka: prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ picchābastau yatheritān| piṣṭvā'nuvāsanaṃ snehaṃ kṣīradviguṇitaṃ pacet||229|| iti picchābastiḥ|`
translation: For the treatment of arshas (piles), grahani (irritable bowel syndrome), whiteness, fever, loss of appetite, difficulty in passing urine and stools, prolapse of the anus, excessive thirst, and flow from the tuft of hair, this tri-doshanut (three-dosha reducing) hreeveraa-adi ghrtam (hreeveraa and other herbal ghee) should be used.

sloka: hrīveramutpalaṃ lodhraṃ samaṅgā cavya candanam| pāṭhā sātiviṣā bilvaṃ dhātakī devadāru ca||230|| dārvī tvaṅ nāgaraṃ māṃsī mustaṃ kṣāro yavāgrajaḥ| citrakaśceti peṣyāṇi cāṅgerīsvarase ghṛtam||231|| aikadhyaṃ sādhayet sarvaṃ tat sarpiḥ paramauṣadham|
translation: The powder of Avākpuspi, Bala, Dārvī, Pṛśniparnī, Trikanṭaka, Nyagroda, Udumbara, Aśvattha, Śuṅga, both Katholas, Kalañga, Śālmali, Puṣpa, Vīra, Candana, Utphulla, Mista, Piṅgavati, Viṣāsthira, Padma, Utpalā, Kiñjalka, Samangā, Nidighdikā, Bilva, Mocarasa, Bhāgā leaves, mixed with one prastha of water for every four prasthas, and thirty palm fruits make one prastha. Two prasthas of castor oil and two prasthas of sesame oil are added to this. This is then cooked together with the previously mentioned ingredients.

sloka: arśotisāra grahaṇī pāṇḍuroge jvare'rucau||232|| mūtrakṛcchre gudabhraṃśe bastyānāhe pravāhaṇe| picchāsrāve'rśasāṃ śūle yojyametattridoṣanut||233|| iti hrīverādighṛtam|
translation: In the case of diarrhea with three doshas, frequent downward movement, displacement of the rectum, various types of feces, excessive flatulence in the lower abdomen, and symptoms such as sluggish digestive fire, dullness, and improper evacuation; pure ghee, which is prescribed by scripture, should be used in all kinds of food and drink or even taken alone in order to enhance its strength and complexion. This is known as Sunishanna Kacha Angeri Ghrtam.

sloka: avākpuṣpī balā dārvī pṛśniparṇī trikaṇṭakaḥ| nyagrodhodumbarāśvatthaśuṅgāśca dvipalonmitāḥ||234|| kaṣāya eṣāṃ peṣyāstu jīvantī kaṭurohiṇī| pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ nāgaraṃ suradāru ca||235|| kaliṅgāḥ śālmalaṃ puṣpaṃ vīrā candanamutpalam | kaṭphalaṃ citrako mustaṃ priyaṅgvativiṣāsthirāḥ||236|| padmotpalānāṃ kiñjalkaḥ samaṅgā sanidigdhikā| bilvaṃ mocarasaḥ pāṭhā bhāgāḥ karṣasamanvitāḥ||237|| catuṣprasthe śṛtaṃ prasthaṃ kaṣāyamavatārayet| triṃśatpalāni prastho'tra vijñeyo dvipalādhikaḥ||238|| suniṣaṇṇakacāṅgeryoḥ prasthau dvau svarasasya ca| sarvairetairyathoddiṣṭairghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||239||
translation: Here, one should combine sweet, sour, cold, and hot tastes. One who always pays attention to the agni (digestive fire) and is skilled in wielding weapons is victorious.

sloka: etadarśaḥsvatīsāre raktasrāve tridoṣaje| pravāhaṇe gudabhraṃśe picchāsu vividhāsu ca||240|| utthāne cātibahuśaḥ śothaśūle gudāśraye| mūtragrahe mūḍhavāte mande'gnāvarucāvapi||241|| prayojyaṃ vidhivat sarpirbalavarṇāgnivardhanam| vividheṣvannapāneṣu kevalaṃ vā niratyayam||242|| iti suniṣaṇṇakacāṅgerīghṛtam|
translation: The three primary causes of each other are generally the transformations called upward wind, downward wind, and equalizing wind, as well as flatulence and excessive thirst. When the power of digestive fire is weak in them, their growth is observed; when it is increased, their decay takes place. Therefore, one should especially protect the power of digestive fire in these.

sloka: bhavanti cātra vyatyāsānmadhurāmlāni śītoṣṇāni ca yojayet| nityamagnibalāpekṣī jayatyarśaḥkṛtān gadān||243||
translation: Defeating disorders caused by Vata, Pitta, and Kapha with cooked vegetables, meat soups, beverages, and various uses of wheat and barley.

sloka: trayo vikārāḥ prāyeṇa ye parasparahetavaḥ| arśāṃsi cātisāraśca grahaṇīdoṣa eva ca||244|| eṣāmagnibale hīne vṛddhirvṛddhe parikṣayaḥ| tasmādagnibalaṃ rakṣyameṣu triṣu viśeṣataḥ||245||
translation: One should regularly and mindfully serve food, water, and medicines to the one who is bent towards the right side (of the body during ablutions), as well as to strengthen the fire. One should never serve using a vessel that is covered by the excreta or where pus is visible.

sloka: bhṛṣṭaiḥ śākai ryavāgūbhiryūṣairmāṃsarasaiḥ khaḍaiḥ| kṣīra takra prayogaiśca vividhairgudajāñjayet||246||
translation: In that (spiritual treatise), there are two types of slokas (verses) related to the seers, having separate abodes; and indications of their manifestation, location, and signs, as well as determination of what is achievable and not achievable.

sloka: yadvāyorānulomyāya yadagnibalavṛddhaye| annapānauṣadhadravyaṃ tat sevyaṃ nityamarśasaiḥ||247|| yadato viparītaṃ syānnidāne yacca darśitam| gudajābhiparītena tat sevyaṃ na kadācana||248||
translation: Oleation, sweating, fumigation, application of medicinal pastes, washing and wiping of wounds, as well as the evacuation and purgation of blood are all therapeutic measures.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  arśasāṃ dvividhaṃ janma pṛthagāyatanāni ca| sthāna saṃsthānaliṅgāni sādhyāsādhyaviniścayaḥ||249||
translation: The primary procedure for drinking and eating, the auspicious observance of breath control, various methods to treat different types of snakebites, rules for preparing medicinal pastes and decoctions, the excellent practice of using oils and fats, methods of administering medicine, washing, bathing, and massaging, and the medication to be used in case of excessive bleeding - all these have been explained for the treatment of piles.

sloka: abhyaṅgāḥ svedanaṃ dhūmāḥ sāvagāhāḥ pralepanāḥ| śoṇitasyāvasekaśca yogā dīpanapācanāḥ||250||
translation: In the medical tantra composed by Agnivesha, after being revised by Charaka, this is named Chapter Fourteen of the section on treatment.

sloka: pānānna vidhiragryaśca vātavarco'nulomanaḥ| yogāḥ saṃśamanīyāśca sarpīṃṣi vividhāni ca||251|| bastayastakrayogāśca varāriṣṭāḥ saśarkarāḥ| śuṣkāṇāmarśasāṃ śastāḥ srāviṇāṃ lakṣaṇāni ca||252|| dvividhaṃ sānubandhānāṃ teṣāṃ ceṣṭaṃ yadauṣadham| rakta saṅgrahaṇāḥ kvāthāḥ peṣyāśca vividhātmakāḥ||253|| snehāhāra vidhiścāgryo yogāśca pratisāraṇāḥ| prakṣālanāvagāhāśca pradehāḥ secanāni ca||254|| ativṛttasya raktasya vidhātavyaṃ yadauṣadham| tatsarvamiha nirdiṣṭaṃ gudajānāṃ cikitsite||255||
translation:
Then Atri teacher will explain the following: "What is it that has been asked?"	
(This is a part of a larger text, where Atri is asked a question and this is his response to prepare to answer)

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte  cikitsāsthāne'rśaścikitsitaṃ nāma caturdaśo'dhyāyaḥ||14||
translation: Endowed with austerity, reputation, steadfastness, and supreme intelligence, Atri spoke for the sake of peace, having ascertained a remedy. The three ailments caused by wind, etc., and those arising from injury and wasting – these five are the diseases that afflict humans and grow to cause death.

sloka: athātaḥ kāsacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ ||2||
translation:
Their previous form becomes a hunchback with a face like that of a monkey, and an itch in the throat develops when they eat palatable food, and obstruction also arises. (Translated in literary style)

A hunchbacked figure with a monkey-like face is their earlier form; they develop an itching in the throat while eating delicious food and further face obstructions. (A more fluent translation)

sloka: tapasā yaśasā dhṛtyā dhiyā ca parayā'nvitaḥ |  ātreyaḥ kāsaśāntyarthaṃ prāha siddhaṃ cikitsitam ||3|| vātādijāstrayo ye ca kṣatajaḥ kṣayajastathā |  pañcaite syurnṛṇāṃ kāsā vardhamānāḥ kṣayapradāḥ ||4||
translation: The wind, having been pressed downwards and taken hold of the upward flowing channels, is established in the throat and chest, having attained the state of udana.

sloka: pūrvarūpaṃ bhavetteṣāṃ śūkapūrṇagalāsyatā |  kaṇṭhe kaṇḍūśca bhojyānāmavarodhaśca jāyate ||5||
translation: Entering all the senses through the head, filling them completely, and breaking open and disrupting the body, Hanuman did the same to Akshi's fortress.

sloka: adhaḥpratihato vāyurūrdhvasrotaḥsamāśritaḥ |  udānabhāvamāpannaḥ kaṇṭhe saktastathorasi ||6||
translation: After pressing (the eyeball) from the back, front, and sides, what is called that which causes dryness or produces pus?

sloka: āviśya śirasaḥ khāni sarvāṇi pratipūrayan |  ābhañjannākṣipan dehaṃ hanumanye tathā'kṣiṇī ||7||
translation: The distinctive opposition to air causes the particular sensation known as coughing in beings.

sloka: netre pṛṣṭhamuraḥpārśve nirbhujya stambhayaṃstataḥ |  śuṣko vā sakapho vā'pi kasanātkāsa ucyate ||8||
translation: Women who eat little, have rough, cold, and light bodily constitutions, are tireless in bearing burdens, and cause the wind to flow. They greatly disturb the natural sounds of the heart, throat, head, and sides with their sharp, grating voices. After overcoming a critical situation caused by phlegm, they become slim when they expel it. They become calm by consuming foods and drinks that are smooth, unctuous, salty, and warm. When old food is digested, the wind becomes active and swift.

sloka: pratighātaviśeṣeṇa tasya vāyoḥ saraṃhasaḥ |  vedanāśabdavaiśiṣṭyaṃ kāsānāmupajāyate ||9||
translation:
Excessive consumption of pungent, hot, sharp, salty, and astringent tastes causes:
- Krodha (anger), which is like a fire kindled by the combination of Pitta and agni (fire)
- PietanishthivanaakshiTVam (sluggishness, laziness)
- Tiktasyaatvam (bitterness in the mouth)
- Svaraamayah (hoarseness of voice or cough)
- Urodhumaaayanam (smoky taste in the mouth)
- Trishnaa (excessive thirst)
- Daaha (burning sensation)
- Moha (delusion)
- Arutchirbhramaah (dizziness, loss of balance)
In a Pittaja person, it aggravates the Kapha and Pitta doshas.

sloka: rūkṣaśītakaṣāyālpapramitānaśanaṃ striyaḥ |  vegadhāraṇamāyāso vātakāsapravartakāḥ ||10||  hṛtpārśvoraḥśiraḥśūlasvarabhedakaro bhṛśam |  śuṣkoraḥkaṇṭhavakrasya hṛṣṭalomnaḥ pratāmyataḥ ||11||  nirghoṣadainyastananadaurbalyakṣobhamohakṛt |  śuṣkakāsaḥ kaphaṃ śuṣkaṃ kṛcchrānmuktvā'lpatāṃ vrajet ||12||  snigdhāmlalavaṇoṣṇaiśca bhuktapītaiḥ praśāmyati |  ūrdhvavātasya jīrṇe'nne vegavānmāruto bhavet ||13||
translation: The elderly person, with the qualities of suppressing vata and kapha by a sweet taste, unctuousness, and deep sleep, is afflicted by symptoms such as lethargy, poor digestion, excessive salivation, and sweating due to increased kapha. The chest feels full and heavy, as if it is completely filled with phlegm.

sloka: kaṭukoṣṇavidāhyamlakṣārāṇāmatisevanam |  pittakāsakaraṃ krodhaḥ santāpaścāgnisūryajaḥ ||14||  pītaniṣṭhīvanākṣitvaṃ tiktāsyatvaṃ svarāmayaḥ |  urodhūmāyanaṃ tṛṣṇā dāho moho'rucirbhramaḥ ||15||  pratataṃ kāsamānaśca jyotīṃṣīva ca paśyati |  śleṣmāṇaṃ pittasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ niṣṭhīvati ca paittike ||16||
translation: The wind that has taken up the dust from the rough surface, after being loaded with the burden of excessive misdeeds and battles, causes sneezing.

sloka: gurvabhiṣyandimadhurasnigdhasvapnāviceṣṭanaiḥ |  vṛddhaḥ śleṣmā'nilaṃ ruddhvā kaphakāsaṃ karoti hi ||17||  mandāgnitvārucicchardipīnasotkleśagauravaiḥ |  lomaharṣāsyamādhuryakledasaṃsadanairyutam ||18||  bahulaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhaṃ niṣṭhīvati ghanaṃ kapham |  kāsamāno hyarug vakṣaḥ sampūrṇamiva manyate ||19||
translation: Afflicted by a sharp, piercing pain as if struck by thorns, he makes the dry place moist with blood flowing from his throat. It is as if an animal is being wounded grievously by a weapon.

sloka: ativyavāyabhārādhvayuddhāśvagajavigrahaiḥ |  rūkṣasyoraḥ kṣataṃ vāyurgṛhītvā kāsamāvahet ||20||
translation:
Afflicted by the fever of partisanship, gasping for special status, and tormented by the desire for superiority, he cries out like a wounded animal, overwhelmed by the force of his own selfishness. (Translation based on the context provided in the following paragraph.)

The verse is from the Bhaja Govindam, a work attributed to Adi Shankaracharya, who likely lived during the 8th century CE. The text uses vivid imagery to criticize those who are afflicted by narrow-mindedness and self-interest, and who lack spiritual wisdom.

sloka: sa pūrvaṃ kāsate śuṣkaṃ tataḥ ṣṭhīvet saśoṇitam |  kaṇṭhena rujatā'tyarthaṃ virugṇeneva corasā ||21||  sūcībhiriva tīkṣṇābhistudyamānena śūlinā |  duḥkhasparśena śūlena bhedapīḍābhitāpinā ||22||
translation: The three impurities of those who feel compassion for the suffering and who control their anger, gluttony, and haste have been pervaded in the agni (digestive fire).

sloka: parvabhedajvaraśvāsatṛṣṇāvaisvaryapīḍitaḥ |  pārāvata ivākūjan kāsavegātkṣatodbhavāt ||23||
translation: Those who are afflicted with the depletion-causing disease consider the body's loss as imminent, make its complexion turn blackish, yellowish, or red, and become foul-smelling, phlegm-filled, and resembling pus near the sides. They think their heart has fallen from its place, and they become suddenly hot or cold, have a large appetite, become weak and thin. Their skin becomes oily, their eyes turn sunken, and their appearance becomes uneven. Their voice becomes unsteady without any specific cause. (Translated by Sahasradarpana Translation Project)

sloka: viṣamāsātmyabhojyātivyavāyādveganigrahāt |  ghṛṇināṃ śocatāṃ nṝṇāṃ vyāpanne'gnau trayo malāḥ ||24||
translation: This, indeed, is the decay-causing sickness that brings about the end of the physically weak. It could also be curable for the strong, given it arises from an injury. Both of these -- the pair of feet, endowed with qualities -- may become successful at some point; the aging of the elderly is universally declared to be such a sickness.

sloka: kupitāḥ kṣayajaṃ kāsaṃ kuryurdehakṣayapradam |  durgandhaṃ haritaṃ raktaṃ ṣṭhīvet pūyopamaṃ kapham ||25||  sthānādutkāsamānaśca hṛdayaṃ manyate cyutam |  akasmāduṣṇaśītārto bahvāśī durbalaḥ kṛśaḥ ||26||  snigdhācchamukhavarṇatvak śrīmaddarśanalocanaḥ |  pāṇipādatalaiḥ ślakṣṇaiḥ satatāsūyako ghṛṇī ||27||  jvaro miśrākṛtistasya pārśvaruk pīnaso'ruciḥ |  bhinnasaṃhatavarcastvaṃ svarabhedo'nimittataḥ ||28||
translation: One should first accomplish the three goals of life and then treat the ailments

sloka: ityeṣa kṣayajaḥ kāsaḥ kṣīṇānāṃ dehanāśanaḥ |  sādhyo balavatāṃ vā syādyāpyastvevaṃ kṣatotthitaḥ ||29||  navau kadācit sidhyetāmetau pādaguṇānvitau |  sthavirāṇāṃ jarākāsaḥ sarvo yāpyaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||30||
translation: At the outset, one should treat roughness caused by wind with ointments made of ghee, oil, and other unctuous substances. A wise person should apply, in a manner consistent with proper knowledge, various unguents, fumes, and lehya (edible drugs) that counter wind. By using girdles and applying upward strokes, one can bind up the loose wind in the stomach and dry upward-moving wind. One can conquer excess phlegm and bile with purgative treatments made of unctuous substances like ghee.

sloka: trīnsādhyānsādhayetpūrvān pathyairyāpyāṃśca yāpayet |  cikitsāmata ūrdhvaṃ tu śṛṇu kāsanibarhiṇīm ||31||
translation: A measure (prastha) of ghee, cooked separately with the juice of Kantakari and Guduchi plants and having a consistency like that of cream, is called Kantakari ghrita.

sloka: rūkṣasyānilajaṃ kāsamādau snehairupācaret |  sarpirbhirbastibhiḥ peyāyūṣakṣīrarasādibhiḥ ||32||  vātaghnasiddhaiḥ snehādyairdhūmairlehaiśca yuktitaḥ |  abhyaṅgaiḥ pariṣekaiśca snigdhaiḥ svedaiśca buddhimān ||33||  bastibhirbaddhaviḍvātaṃ śuṣkordhvaṃ cordhvabhaktikaiḥ |  ghṛtaiḥ sapittaṃ sakaphaṃ jayet snehavirecanaiḥ ||34||
translation: By consuming a mixture of the juice of four parts of siddhachatushtika, one part of ghee from the milk of the cow that has eaten the leaves of pippali tree, and ten leaves of pippali, along with the regular recitation of mantras, one can alleviate disorders such as cough, dyspnea, and diseases of the side and abdomen. This has been described as pippalyaadi ghrita by Atreya.

sloka: kaṇṭakārīguḍūcībhyāṃ pṛthak triṃśatpalādrase |  prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtādvātakāsanudvahnidīpanaḥ ||35||  iti kaṇṭakārīghṛtam |
translation: The recipe for tryushana, made from three kinds of bel fruit, three types of grapes, kashmarya, parushakam,

sloka: pippalīpippalīmūlacavyacitrakanāgaraiḥ |  dhānyapāṭhāvacārāsnāyaṣṭyāhvakṣārahiṅgubhiḥ ||36||  kolamātrairghṛtaprasthāddaśamūlīrasāḍhake |  siddhāccaturthikāṃ pītvā peyāmaṇḍaṃ pibedanu ||37||  tacchvāsakāsahṛtpārśvagrahaṇīdoṣagulmanut |  pippalyādyaṃ ghṛtaṃ caitadātreyeṇa prakīrtitam ||38||  iti pippalyādighṛtam |
translation: To heal dripping nasal discharge, one should mix and cook in half the quantity of clarified butter and an equal amount of sesame oil, a decoction made from ten parts each of the roots of the blue water lily and black iron wood, palm fruit, manjistha, kulatthaka, bdellium, and barley. This mixture should be prepared with a measured quantity of life-sustaining ingredients and used in treatment of nasal disorders such as congestion, headaches, back pain, and other ailments of the limbs and body, depending on their severity. This is known as Rasnadi Ghrita.

sloka: tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalāṃ drākṣāṃ kāśmaryāṇi parūṣakam |  dve pāṭhe devadārvṛddhiṃ svaguptāṃ citrakaṃ śaṭīm ||39||  brāhmīṃ tāmalakīṃ medāṃ kākanāsāṃ śatāvarīm |  trikaṇṭakaṃ vidārīṃ ca piṣṭvā karṣasamaṃ ghṛtāt ||40||  prasthaṃ caturguṇe kṣīre siddhaṃ kāsaharaṃ pibet |  jvaragulmāruciplīhaśirohṛtpārśvaśūlanut ||41||  kāmalārśo'nilāṣṭhīlākṣataśoṣakṣayāpaham |  tryūṣaṇaṃ nāma vikhyātametaddhṛtamanuttamam ||42||  iti tryūṣaṇādyaṃ ghṛtam |

droṇe'pāṃ sādhayedrāsnāṃ daśamūlīṃ śatāvarīm |  palikāṃ māṇikāṃśāṃstu kulatthānbadarānyavān ||43||  tulārdhaṃ cājamāṃsasya pādaśeṣeṇa tena ca |  ghṛtāḍhakaṃ samakṣīraṃ jīvanīyaiḥ palonmitaiḥ ||44||  siddhaṃ taddaśabhiḥ kalkairnasyapānānuvāsanaiḥ |  samīkṣya vātarogeṣu yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||45||  pañcakāsān śiraḥkampaṃ śūlaṃ vaṅkṣaṇayonijam |  sarvāṅgaikāṅgarogāṃśca saplīhordhvānilāñjayet ||46||  iti rāsnāghṛtam |
translation: The recipe is as follows: Take twenty-four parts of a Kalka (a paste made from the bark of a tree named Arka, mixed with water), one part each of the powders of citraka, chavya, ela, draksha, and kashmarya, and a quarter part of mustard seeds. Cook this mixture in a pot with ghee obtained from a fish-shaped vessel and the juice of matulunga (a type of fruit). Add this to a decoction made from the roots of pippalii, vyosa, hingu, draksha, kalika, shringi, chamatkari, and kasmarya, along with the leaves of bhargi and chinnaruhaka. This preparation, known as Citrakadi Leha, is cooling and alleviates cough, breathlessness, and other diseases of the chest.

sloka: viḍaṅgaṃ nāgaraṃ rāsnā pippalī hiṅgu saindhavam |  bhārgī kṣāraśca taccūrṇaṃ pibedvā ghṛtamātrayā ||47||  sakaphe'nilaje kāse śvāsahikkāhatāgniṣu |  dvau kṣārau pañcakolāni pañcaiva lavaṇāni ca ||48||  śaṭīnāgarakodīcyakalkaṃ vā vastragālitam |  pāyayeta ghṛtonmiśraṃ vātakāsanibarhaṇam ||49||  durālabhāṃ śaṭīṃ drākṣāṃ śṛṅgaveraṃ sitopalām |  lihyāt karkaṭaśṛṅgīṃ ca kāse tailena vātaje ||50||  duḥsparśāṃ pippalīṃ mustaṃ bhārgīṃ karkaṭakīṃ śaṭīm |  purāṇaguḍatailābhyāṃ cūrṇitaṃ vā'pi lehayet ||51||  viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ vyoṣaṃ hiṅgu manaḥśilām |  madhusarpiryutaṃ kāsahikkāśvāsaṃ jayellihan ||52||
translation: Boil together in twenty times the quantity of water, the following: dasamooli, self-generated, shankhapushpi, shati, bala, hastyayah (or ippalapippalya), pippali, mulo-chitraka, bhargi, and pushkaramula; also twice the quantity of dvipala and yavaadhaka; one piece of haritaki; and a quarter of jale paachaka. After straining this decoction through a cloth, add to it an equal quantity of sugar, a little kudav, which has been separately boiled in pure ghee, and two palas each of pippalichurna and siddha shita (or makshika). Regularly take twice a day, before meals, this auspicious rasayana prescribed by Agastya, for improving complexion, increasing strength, curing consumption, asthma, hiccups, irregular fever, arshograha, heart disease, indigestion, and emaciation.

sloka: citrakaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vyoṣaṃ hiṅgu durālabhām |  śaṭīṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca śreyasīṃ surasāṃ vacām ||53||  bhārgīṃ chinnaruhāṃ rāsnāṃ śṛṅgīṃ drākṣāṃ ca kārṣikān |  kalkānardhatulākvāthe nidigdhyāḥ palaviṃśatim ||54||  dattvā matsyaṇḍikāyāśca ghṛtācca kuḍavaṃ pacet |  siddhaṃ śītaṃ pṛthak kṣaudrapippalīkuḍavānvitam ||55||  catuṣpalaṃ tugākṣīryāścūrṇitaṃ tatra dāpayet |  lehayet kāsahṛdrogaśvāsagulmanivāraṇam ||56||  iti citrakādilehaḥ |
translation: One should drink the decoction of Saindhava (rock salt), Pippali (long pepper), Bhargi (a type of bark), and Durpalabham (hard to get) either with warm water mixed with Dadimamla (tamarind juice) or Khadirasara (another type of decoction), or with Madhira (liquor) and Adashthibhi (six other things, possibly types of spices). Alternatively, one can drink the powder of Pippali mixed with ghee and rock salt.

sloka: daśamūlīṃ svayaṅguptāṃ śaṅkhapuṣpīṃ śaṭīṃ balām |  hastipippalyapāmārgapippalīmūlacitrakān ||57||  bhārgīṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca dvipalāṃśaṃ yavāḍhakam |  harītakīśataṃ caikaṃ jale pañcāḍhake pacet ||58||  yavaiḥ svinnaiḥ kaṣāyaṃ taṃ pūtaṃ taccābhayāśatam |  pacedguḍatulāṃ dattvā kuḍavaṃ ca pṛthagghṛtāt ||59||  tailāt sapippalīcūrṇāt siddhaśīte ca mākṣikāt |  lihyāddve cābhaye nityamataḥ khādedrasāyanāt ||60||  tadvalīpalitaṃ hanti varṇāyurbalavardhanam |  pañcakāsān kṣayaṃ śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ ca viṣamajvaram ||61|| hanyāttathā'rśograhaṇīhṛdrogārucipīnasān |  agastyavihitaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ rasāyanamidaṃ śubham ||62||  ityagastyaharītakī |
translation: In the case of a runny nose with a headache, the physician should apply a probe either ten or eight angulas long through the nostril's flaw and narrow opening. The experienced one should make the probe hunchbacked and then cause the patient to inhale and exhale the smoke from virechana (a purgative) through the mouth. The smoke that is drawn into the head should be expelled back out of the mouth. By doing this, the skilled physician will break open the accumulated phlegm in the abdomen and eliminate it, thereby curing the cough caused by the morbidity of wind and phlegm.

sloka: saindhavaṃ pippalīṃ bhārgīṃ śṛṅgaveraṃ durālabhām |  dāḍimāmlena koṣṇena bhārgīnāgaramambunā ||63||  pibet khadirasāraṃ vā madirādadhimastubhiḥ |  athavā pippalīkalkaṃ ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam ||64||
translation: One should drink the honey-like extract of stone apple, tender coconut, and sugarcane. The smoke that follows should be drunk mixed with milk, which is pleasantly warm and thick. This smoke remedies various ailments that cannot be cured by other practices or yoga. Prepare a decoction by boiling together dried ginger, long pepper, Indian beleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, holy basil, and licorice. After filtering, mix this with milk, clarified butter, or sugarcane juice. Add extracts of stone apple, dried ginger, black salt, and rock salt. This smoke therapy, when performed regularly, aids in curing various diseases, especially those related to the respiratory system.

sloka: śirasaḥ pīḍane srāve nāsāyā hṛdi tāmyati |  kāsapratiśyāyavatāṃ dhūmaṃ vaidyaḥ prayojayet ||65||  daśāṅgulonmitāṃ nāḍīmathavā'ṣṭāṅgulonmitām |  śarāvasampuṭacchidre kṛtvā jihmāṃ vicakṣaṇaḥ ||66||  vairecanaṃ mukhenaiva kāsavān dhūmamāpibet |  tamuraḥ kevalaṃ prāptaṃ mukhenaivodvamet punaḥ ||67||  sa hyasya taikṣṇyādvicchidya śleṣmāṇamurasi sthitam |  niṣkṛṣya śamayet kāsaṃ vātaśleṣmasamudbhavam ||68||
translation: Feed beneficial people with a mixture of grains such as barley, rice, wheat, and pulses, cooked with the juices of radish, ginger, garlic, and other similar ingredients. Drink an easily digestible beverage that is neither too cold nor too hot, which alleviates Kati, Hridaya, Koshta, Shwasa, Hikka related disorders. Prepare a medicinal concoction using the juices of 10 roots, mixed with cow's ghee and rock salt. This siddha drink, seasoned with rock salt, can be given to people suffering from vata disorders. Food items like Vasaka, Yashtimadhu, Sunishannaka, and various oils and tails are beneficial for vata disorders. Curds, sugarcane juice, and pomegranate are also recommended in the treatment of vata disorders. This is the science of vata treatment.

sloka: manaḥśilālamadhukamāṃsīmusteṅgudaiḥ pibet |  dhūmaṃ tasyānu ca kṣīraṃ sukhoṣṇaṃ saguḍaṃ pibet ||69||  eṣa kāsān pṛthagdoṣasannipātasamudbhavān |  dhūmo hanyādasaṃsiddhānanyairyogaśatairapi ||70||  prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ śārṅgeṣṭāṃ samanaḥśilām |  maricaṃ pippalīṃ drākṣāmelāṃ surasamañjarīm ||71||  kṛtvā vartiṃ pibeddhūmaṃ kṣaumacelānuvartitām |  ghṛtāktāmanu ca kṣīraṃ guḍodakamathāpi vā ||72||  manaḥśilailāmaricakṣārāñjanakuṭannaṭaiḥ |  vaṃśalekhanasevyālakṣaumalaktakarohiṣaiḥ ||73||  pūrvakalpena dhūmo'yaṃ sānupāno vidhīyate |  manaḥśilāle tadvacca pippalīnāgaraiḥ saha ||74||  tvagaiṅgudī bṛhatyau dve tālamūlī manaḥśilā |  kārpāsāsthyaśvagandhā ca dhūmaḥ kāsavināśanaḥ ||75||
translation: In the case of a patient with bile disorder, vomiting induced with ghee is beneficial. Similarly, madanakashmarya is treated with water boiled with sugar and quatha (a type of decoction). Alternatively, vomiting can be initiated using the juices of kalika, vidari, and shigru plants; once the disorders are eliminated, one should then consume cool and sweet substances.

sloka: grāmyānūpaudakaiḥ śāliyavagodhūmaṣaṣṭikān |  rasairmāṣātmaguptānāṃ yūṣairvā bhojayeddhitān ||76||  yavānīpippalībilvamadhyanāgaracitrakaiḥ |  rāsnājājīpṛthakparṇīpalāśaśaṭipauṣkaraiḥ ||77||  snigdhāmlalavaṇāṃ siddhāṃ peyāmanilaje pibet |  kaṭīhṛtpārśvakoṣṭhārtiśvāsahikkāpraṇāśinīm ||78||  daśamūlarase tadvatpañcakolaguḍānvitām |  siddhāṃ samatilāṃ dadyātkṣīre vā'pi sasaindhavām ||79|| mātsyakaukkuṭavārāhairāmiṣairvā ghṛtānvitām |  siddhāṃ sasaindhavāṃ peyāṃ vātakāsī pibennaraḥ ||80||  vāstuko vāyasīśākaṃ mūlakaṃ suniṣaṇṇakam |  snehāstailādayo bhakṣyāḥ kṣīrekṣurasagauḍikāḥ ||81||  dadhyāranālāmlaphalaprasannāpānameva ca |  śasyate vātakāse tu svādvamlalavaṇāni ca ||82||  iti vātakāsacikitsā |
translation: In the case of a person with a predominance of phlegm, the physician should give bitter tastes to counteract it, while for a person with a predominance of bile, he should administer sweet or madhura flavors. (Translation based on context)

sloka: paittike sakaphe kāse vamanaṃ sarpiṣā hitam |  tathā madanakāśmaryamadhukakvathitairjalaiḥ ||83||  yaṣṭyāhvaphalakalkairvā vidārīkṣurasāyutaiḥ |  hṛtadoṣastataḥ śītaṃ madhuraṃ ca kramaṃ bhajet ||84||
translation: The one with a slim and cool body should consume sesame oil, goat's milk, and liquids that are sweet and agreeable. Eating pippali, dry ginger, patala, musta, usheera, draksha, modaka, kharjura, vamsa, and shvada is beneficial for those with excess phlegm. For such individuals, lehya made from ghrita, kshaudra, and rock candy is recommended. Grind thirty pippalis, fifteen pippali fruits, twenty-four amalakis, draksha, laksha, laaja, shitaopala, and one prastha of sugar into a fine paste with madhu and consume it. This mixture, when prepared with the addition of kshaudra, ghrita, and sarpirbhirleha, is an effective cure for cough, hiccups, fever, heart disease, and consumption. For pitta-kshaya, consume a mixture of the expressed juice of five roots (vidari, kshira, kantakari, musta, and pippalii), draksha, laksha, laaja, shitaopala, kshudra rasa, ghrita, and madhu. This will alleviate pitta-kshaya. For those with excess wind, rock candy, sugarcane juice, draksha ras, and payas should be consumed. All these remedies are cooling and tridoshahara. Prepare a kalka of jivaka, bhakshya, churna of pippalii, draksha, triphala, marica, shringataka, and kshaudragarbha. Mix it with guda, godhuma churna, and consume it for shukra doshas and kshata. Prepare a fine paste of sharkara, pippalii churna, tvak, ksheera, marica, and shringataka. Add one prastha of ghrita and consume it to alleviate pitta-kshaya.

sloka: paitte tanukaphe kāse trivṛtāṃ madhurairyutām |  dadyādghanakaphe tiktairvirekārthe yutāṃ bhiṣak ||85||
translation: In the beginning, one should purify a person with strength through emesis; remove kapha with astringent, hot, and kaphaghna pippali, kusmanda, kashaayam, haritaki, bibhitaka, and amalaki. One should consume light foods or those endowed with pungent tastes. Anoint the body with sesame oil, mustard oil, castor oil, linseed oil, warm water, or alcohol at appropriate times when food is not consumed. In the night, one should consume a decoction of puskara, aragvadha, patola, and bael fruits mixed with honey and/or water during the specified times when food is not taken.

sloka: snigdhaśītastanukaphe rūkṣaśītaḥ kaphe ghane |  kramaḥ kāryaḥ paraṃ bhojyaiḥ snehairlehaiśca śasyate ||86||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ padmabījaṃ nīlīsārāṇi pippalī |  pippalīmustayaṣṭyāhvadrākṣāmūrvāmahauṣadham ||87|| lājā'mṛtaphalā drākṣā tvakkṣīrī pippalī sitā |  pippalīpadmakadrākṣā bṛhatyāśca phalādrasaḥ ||88||  kharjūraṃ pippalī vāṃśī śvadaṃṣṭrā ceti pañca te |  ghṛtakṣaudrayutā lehāḥ ślokārdhaiḥ pittakāsinām ||89||  śarkarācandanadrākṣāmadhudhātrīphalotpalaiḥ |  paitte samustamaricaḥ sakaphe saghṛto'nile ||90||  mṛdvīkārdhaśataṃ triṃśatpippalīḥ śarkarāpalam |  lehayenmadhunā gorvā kṣīrapaṃ ca śakṛdrasam ||91||  tvagelāvyoṣamṛdvīkāpippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  lājāmustaśaṭīrāsnādhātrīphalabibhītakaiḥ ||92||  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhirlehaḥ kāsavināśanaḥ |  śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ kṣayaṃ caiva hṛdrogaṃ ca praṇāśayet ||93||  pippalyāmalakaṃ drākṣāṃ lākṣāṃ lājāṃ sitopalām |  kṣīre paktvā ghanaṃ śītaṃ lihyāt kṣaudrāṣṭabhāgikam ||94||  vidārīkṣumṛṇālānāṃ rasān kṣīraṃ sitopalām |  pibedvā madhusaṃyuktaṃ pittakāsaharaṃ param ||95||  madhurairjāṅgalarasaiḥ śyāmākayavakodravāḥ |  mudgādiyūṣaiḥ śākaiśca tiktakairmātrayā hitāḥ ||96||  ghanaśleṣmaṇi lehāstu tiktakā madhusaṃyutāḥ |  śālayaḥ syustanukaphe ṣaṣṭikāśca rasādibhiḥ ||97||  śarkarāmbho'nupānārthaṃ drākṣekṣūṇāṃ rasāḥ payaḥ |  sarvaṃ ca madhuraṃ śītamavidāhi praśasyate ||98||  kākolībṛhatīmedāyugmaiḥ savṛṣanāgaraiḥ |  pittakāse rasān kṣīraṃ yūṣāṃścāpyupakalpayet ||99||  śarādipañcamūlasya pippalīdrākṣayostathā |  kaṣāyeṇa śṛtaṃ kṣīraṃ pibet samadhuśarkaram ||100||  sthirāsitāpṛśniparṇīśrāvaṇībṛhatīyugaiḥ |  jīvakarṣabhakākolītāmalakyṛddhijīvakaiḥ ||101||  śṛtaṃ payaḥ pibet kāsī jvarī dāhī kṣatakṣayī |  tajjaṃ vā sādhayet sarpiḥ sakṣīrekṣurasaṃ bhiṣak ||102||  jīvakādyairmadhurakaiḥ phalaiścābhiṣukādibhiḥ |  kalkaistrikārṣikaiḥ siddhe pūtaśīte pradāpayet ||103||  śarkarāpippalīcūrṇaṃ tvakkṣīryā maricasya ca |  śṛṅgāṭakasya cāvāpya kṣaudragarbhānpalonmitān ||104||  guḍān godhūmacūrṇena kṛtvā khādeddhitāśanaḥ |  śukrāsṛgdoṣaśoṣeṣu kāse kṣīṇakṣateṣu ca ||105||  śarkarānāgarodīcyaṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ śaṭīṃ samam |  piṣṭvā rasaṃ pibetpūtaṃ vastreṇa ghṛtamūrcchitam ||106||  mahiṣyajāvigokṣīradhātrīphalarasaiḥ samaiḥ |  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā pittakāsanibarhaṇam ||107||  iti pittakāsacikitsā |
translation:
Consuming a mixture of the powders of dry ginger, black pepper, long pepper, holy basil leaves, origanum majorana leaves, and licorice root, equal amounts of honey and rock salt, and cow's ghee, is beneficial for cough, cold, hiccups, fever, and other ailments.

A concoction made from the bark of devadaru tree, black pepper, long pepper, dried ginger, holy basil leaves, origanum majorana leaves, licorice root, Indian laburnum seed, triphala, belleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, and jaggery, is a remedy for diarrhea caused by indigestion.

A mixture of the powders of dry ginger, black pepper, long pepper, pippali fruit, dried Indian Bdellium tree resin, triphala, belleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, and jaggery, consumed with cow's ghee or butter oil, alleviates vata and kapha doshas.

A decoction made from the bark of devadaru tree, dried Indian Bdellium tree resin, triphala, belleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, Indian laburnum seed, jaggery, and cow's ghee, cures fever.

These verses describe various Ayurvedic formulations for treating different ailments such as cough, cold, diarrhea, indigestion, and fever.

sloka: balinaṃ vamanairādau śodhitaṃ kaphakāsinam |  yavānnaiḥ kaṭūrūkṣoṣṇaiḥ kaphaghnaiścāpyupācaret ||108||  pippalīkṣārikairyuṣaiḥ kaulatthairmūlakasya ca |  laghūnyannāni bhuñjīta rasairvā kaṭukānvitaiḥ ||109||  dhānvabailarasaiḥ snehaistilasarṣapabilvajaiḥ |  madhvamloṣṇāmbutakraṃ vā madyaṃ vā nigadaṃ pibet ||110||  pauṣkarāragvadhaṃ mūlaṃ paṭolaṃ tairniśāsthitam |  jalaṃ madhuyutaṃ peyaṃ kāleṣvannasya vā triṣu ||111||
translation: The decoction made from the ten roots, when used as a drink for sipping, alleviates all diseases caused by vata and kapha, such as those affecting the respiratory system, like asthma, and those caused by an imbalance of phlegm and wind.

sloka: kaṭphalaṃ kattṛṇaṃ bhārgīṃ mustaṃ dhānyaṃ vacābhaye |  śuṇṭhīṃ parpaṭakaṃ śṛṅgīṃ surāhvaṃ ca śṛtaṃ jale ||112||  madhuhiṅguyutaṃ peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  kaṇṭharoge mukhe śūne śvāsahikkājvareṣu ca ||113||  pāṭhāṃ śuṇṭhīṃ śaṭīṃ mūrvāṃ gavākṣīṃ mustapippalīm |  piṣṭvā gharmāmbunā hiṅgusaindhavābhyāṃ yutāṃ pibet ||114||  nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ śṛṅgīṃ karkaṭakasya ca |  harītakīṃ śaṭīṃ caiva tenaiva vidhinā pibet ||115||  tailabhṛṣṭaṃ ca pippalyāḥ kalkākṣaṃ sasitopalam |  pibedvā śleṣmakāsaghnaṃ kulattharasasaṃyutam ||116||  kāsamardāśvaviṭbhṛṅgarājavārtākajo rasaḥ |  sakṣaudraḥ kaphakāsaghnaḥ surasasyāsitasya ca ||117||  devadāru śaṭī rāsnā karkaṭākhyā durālabhā |  pippalī nāgaraṃ mustaṃ pathyādhātrīsitopalāḥ ||118||  madhutailayutāvetau lehau vātānuge kaphe |  pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ citrako hastipippalī ||119||  pathyā tāmalakī dhātrī bhadramustā ca pippalī |  devadārvabhayā mustaṃ pippalī viśvabheṣajam ||120||  viśālā pippalī mustaṃ trivṛtā ceti lehayet |  caturo madhunā lehān kaphakāsaharān bhiṣak ||121||  sauvarcalābhayādhātrīpippalīkṣāranāgaram |  cūrṇitaṃ sarpiṣā vātakaphakāsaharaṃ pibet ||122|| daśamūlāḍhake prasthaṃ ghṛtasyākṣasamaiḥ pacet |
translation: Prepare a decoction with the following ingredients: thorns of a tree that bears fruit and leaves, one prastha of ghee, Kataka seeds, Vidanga, Triphala, black salt, Pathya, fruits of the Belleric myrobalan, dried ginger, pippali, long pepper, amalaki, bark of bhringaraja, usheera, water, and rock salt. This is called Kantakari Ghrta, which is beneficial in alleviating cough and phlegm, and cleansing the Kapha dosha.

sloka: puṣkarāhvaśaṭībilvasurasavyoṣahiṅgubhiḥ ||123||  peyānupānaṃ tat peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  śvāsarogeṣu sarveṣu kaphavātātmakeṣu ca ||124||  iti daśamūlādighṛtam |
translation: The ghee mixed with kulattha (horse gram) juice or the ghee that is the product of five churnings is recommended for treating cough, hiccups, and kapha-related diseases. (Chikitsa Sthana, Sushruta Samhita, chapter 47, verse 129)

sloka: samūlaphalapatrāyāḥ kaṇṭakāryā rasāḍhake |  ghṛtaprasthaṃ balāvyoṣaviḍaṅgaśaṭicitrakaiḥ ||125||  sauvarcalayavakṣārapippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  vṛścīrabṛhatīpathyāyavānīdāḍimardhibhiḥ ||126||  drākṣāpunarnavācavyadurālambhāmlavetasaiḥ |  śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīrāsnāgokṣurakaiḥ pacet ||127||  kalkaistat sarvakāseṣu hikkāśvāseṣu śasyate |  kaṇṭakārīghṛtaṃ hyetat kaphavyādhinisūdanam ||128||  iti kaṇṭakārīghṛtam |
translation: Those who are described as the burners of fires should give smoke to them. One should also drink water mixed with the middle portion of koshak tree's fruit, which is like smooth sand, as a purification practice.

sloka: kulattharasayuktaṃ vā pañcakolaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam |  pāyayet kaphaje kāse hikkāśvāse ca śasyate ||129||  iti kulatthādighṛtam |
translation: If there is an increase of kapha and vata in the kasa (cough), then one should perform therapies that reduce kapha according to the situation. In the case of an increase of vata and a bond with kapha and pitta, one should perform therapies that decrease both vata and kapha. In a wet or loose cough, dry treatment should be performed; in a dry and rough cough, unctuous treatment should be carried out. In a cough caused by kapha, food and drink with a bitter taste should be taken; if there is an increase of all three doshas, treatments that decrease kapha should be performed. This is the treatment for kasa caused by an increase of kapha.

sloka: dhūmāṃstāneva dadyācca ye proktā vātakāsinām |  kośātakīphalānmadhyaṃ pibedvā samanaḥśilam ||130||
translation: Understanding it to be an injury, one should quickly treat it with soothing, life-sustaining substances that promote strength and nourishment. Use a gentle fire to cook together pippalI, madhuka, kārṣikA, sitopala, gavyamāja, cow's milk, sugarcane juice, yava, godhūma, rice, mung beans, amalaka, and sesame oil. This mixture, when cooked with ghee and oil, will help to heal injuries and is beneficial in cases of lung disease, heart ailments, emaciation, and weak digestion.

sloka: tamakaḥ kaphakāse tu syāccet pittānubandhajaḥ |  pittakāsakriyāṃ tatra yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||131||  vāte kaphānubandhe tu kuryāt kaphaharīṃ kriyām |  pittānubandhayorvātakaphayoḥ pittanāśinīm ||132||  ārdre virūkṣaṇaṃ śuṣke snigdhaṃ vātakaphātmake |  kāse'nnapānaṃ kaphaje sapitte tiktasaṃyutam ||133||  iti kaphajakāsacikitsā |
translation: The diet and treatment for those afflicted by bile-related disorders should be as follows: In the case of increased bile, consumption of buttermilk and ghee is beneficial. When there is pain in the body due to a predominance of wind and bile, massaging with sesame oil is recommended. In the early stages of jaundice, consuming ghee is advisable. For those suffering from thirst and fatigue, consuming milk and sugarcane juice is beneficial. When there is blood in the stool or bleeding from the mouth, consuming ghee is recommended. If a person's urine becomes foamy and resembles the froth of beer, they should consume honey mixed with water. In case of blockage in the body, consuming ghee heated with manashila and taken with sugarcane juice or gudodaka is beneficial. If there is an increase in kapha after the disappearance of injury-related disorders, one should not consume smoke-infused substances such as honey or ghee. These remedies are mentioned in Kshatakasa Chikitsa.

sloka: kāsamātyayikaṃ matvā kṣatajaṃ tvarayā jayet |  madhurairjīvanīyaiśca balamāṃsavivardhanaiḥ ||134||  pippalī madhukaṃ piṣṭaṃ kārṣikaṃ sasitopalam |  prāsthikaṃ gavyamājaṃ ca kṣīramikṣurasastathā ||135||  yavagodhūmamṛdvīkācūrṇamāmalakādrasaḥ |  tailaṃ ca prasṛtāṃśāni tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā ||136||  pacellehaṃ ghṛtakṣaudrayuktaḥ sa kṣatakāsahā |  śvāsahṛdrogakārśyeṣu hito vṛddhe'lparetasi ||137||
translation: One should reject food that is stale and reduces strength in a weak person. A nourishing activity should be performed for the one who has become stronger. In the beginning, one should give a strengthening measure to him and kindle the digestive fire. For a person with many flaws, one should gently administer a purgative made of triphala, tilvaka's extract, and vadari's juice. A person nearing the end of their life should consume ghee that has been processed with certain procedures for purification. When the bodily tissues have become depleted, one should consume a mixture of milk, ghee, and karketaki's seeds in measured quantities. In cases of discoloration or difficult excretion, one should drink ghee and milk mixed together. Ghee processed with madhuka (a type of plant) should be used to treat conditions like emaciation, sweating, bleeding from the rectum, swelling, and pain in the joints. In case of poisoning by wild plants or bites by venomous creatures, one should gradually administer crushed and cooked rice along with purgatives. The strength of a person's body can be maintained through the use of these methods that eliminate excess phlegm and improve nutrition.

sloka: kṣatakāsābhibhūtānāṃ vṛttiḥ syāt pittakāsikī |  kṣīrasarpirmadhuprāyā saṃsarge tu viśeṣaṇam ||138||  vātapittārdite'bhyaṅgo gātrabhede ghṛtairhitaḥ |  tailairmārutarogaghnaiḥ pīḍyamāne ca vāyunā ||139||  hṛtpārśvārtiṣu pānaṃ syājjīvanīyasya sarpiṣaḥ |  sadāhaṃ kāsino raktaṃ ṣṭhīvataḥ sabale'nale ||140||  māṃsocitebhyaḥ kṣāmebhyo lāvādīnāṃ rasā hitāḥ |  tṛṣṇārtānāṃ payaśchāgaṃ śaramūlādibhiḥ śṛtam ||141||  rakte srotobhya āsyādvā'pyāgate kṣīrajaṃ ghṛtam |  nasyaṃ pānaṃ yavāgūrvā śrānte kṣāme hatānale ||142||  stambhāyāmeṣu mahatīṃ mātrāṃ vā sarpiṣaḥ pibet |  kuryādvā vātarogaghnaṃ pittaraktāvirodhi yat ||143||  nivṛtte kṣatadoṣe tu kaphe vṛddha uraḥ kṣate |  dālyate kāsino yasya sa dhūmānnā pibedimān ||144||  dve mede madhukaṃ dve ca bale taiḥ kṣaumalaktakaiḥ |  vartitairdhūmamāpīya jīvanīyaghṛtaṃ pibet ||145||  manaḥśilāpalāśājagandhātvakkṣīrināgaraiḥ |  bhāvayitvā pibet kṣaumamanu cekṣuguḍodakam ||146||  piṣṭvā manaḥśilāṃ tulyāmārdrayā vaṭaśuṅgayā |  sasarpiṣkaṃ pibeddhūmaṃ tittiripratibhojanam ||147||  bhāvitaṃ jīvanīyairvā kuliṅgāṇḍarasāyutaiḥ |  kṣaumaṃ dhūmaṃ pibet kṣīraṃ śṛtaṃ cāyoguḍairanu ||148||  iti kṣatajakāsacikitsā |
translation: With a mixture of

sloka: sampūrṇarūpaṃ kṣayajaṃ durbalasya vivarjayet |  navotthitaṃ balavataḥ pratyākhyāyācaret kriyām ||149||  tasmai bṛṃhaṇamevādau kuryādagneśca dīpanam |  bahudoṣāya sasnehaṃ mṛdu dadyādvirecanam ||150||  śampākena trivṛtayā mṛdvīkārasayuktayā |  tilvakasya kaṣāyeṇa vidārīsvarasena ca ||151||  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā kṣīṇadeho viśodhanam |  (hitaṃ taddehabalayorasya saṃrakṣaṇaṃ matam ) ||152||  pitte kaphe ca saṅkṣīṇe parikṣīṇeṣu dhātuṣu |  ghṛtaṃ karkaṭakīkṣīradvibalāsādhitaṃ pibet ||153||  vidārībhiḥ kadambairvā tālasasyaistathā śṛtam |  ghṛtaṃ payaśca mūtrasya vaivarṇye kṛcchranirgame ||154||  śūne savedane meḍhre pāyau saśroṇivaṅkṣaṇe |  ghṛtamaṇḍena madhunā'nuvāsyo miśrakeṇa vā ||155||  jāṅgalaiḥ pratibhuktasya vartakādyā bileśayāḥ |  kramaśaḥ prasahāścaiva prayojyāḥ piśitāśinaḥ ||156||  auṣṇyāt pramāthibhāvācca srotobhyaścyāvayanti te |  kaphaṃ śuddhaiśca taiḥ puṣṭiṃ kuryātsamyagvahanrasaḥ ||157||
translation: Having cooked guduchi, pippalI, murvA, haridrA, shreyasI vacA, nidigdhikA, and kShAram with water four times the quantity, and reducing it to half the volume, one should drink it when it is fully prepared. This is called guduchyadi ghRtam, a medicinal remedy for cough and other respiratory ailments.

sloka: dvipañcamūlītriphalācavikābhārgicitrakaiḥ |  kulatthapippalīmūlapāṭhākolayavairjale ||158||  śṛtairnāgaraduḥsparśāpippalīśaṭipauṣkaraiḥ |  kalkaiḥ karkaṭaśṛṅgyā ca samaiḥ sarpirvipācayet ||159|| siddhai'smiṃścūrṇitau kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca |  dattvā yuktyā pibenmātrāṃ kṣayakāsanipīḍitaḥ ||160||  iti dvipañcamūlādighṛtam |
translation: For the increase of digestive fire and to reduce the imbalances in the stomach, one should consume a mixture of: a palmful of ghee cooked with the juices of pomegranate, belleric myrobalan, Indian jalap, dried ginger, long pepper, holy basil leaves, and chebulic myrobalan; or a mixture of barley water, ghee, and goat's milk; or a decoction made from the bark of pine tree; or a drink prepared with sugar, licorice, and black salt; or a preparation made from Indian Aegle marmelos and ghee. This will also help in purifying the channels of the body.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ pippalīṃ mūrvāṃ haridrāṃ śreyasīṃ vacām |  nidigdhikāṃ kāsamardaṃ pāṭhāṃ citrakanāgaram ||161||  jale caturguṇe paktvā pādaśeṣeṇa tatsamam |  siddhaṃ sarpiḥ pibedgulmaśvāsārtikṣayakāsanut ||162||  iti guḍūcyādighṛtam |
translation: Prepare a decoction by boiling twenty Haritaki fruits along with two Ajaka fruits in one and a half times the water. After filtering out the pulp, add to it an eighth part of jaggery, an eighth part of the extract of Pippali, and a quarter part of rock salt. This is known as the Haritaki decoction.

sloka: kāsamardābhayāmustapāṭhākaṭphalanāgaraiḥ |  pippalīkaṭukādrākṣākāśmaryasurasaistathā ||163||  akṣamātrairghṛtaprasthaṃ kṣīradrākṣārasāḍhake |  pacecchoṣajvaraplīhasarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||164||  dhātrīphalaiḥ kṣīrasiddhaiḥ sarpirvā'pyavacūrṇitam |  dviguṇe dāḍimarase vipakvaṃ vyoṣasaṃyutam ||165||  pibedupari bhaktasya yavakṣāraghṛtaṃ naraḥ |  pippalīguḍasiddhaṃ vā cchāgakṣīrayutaṃ ghṛtam ||166||  etānyagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ sarpīṃṣi kṣayakāsinām |  syurdoṣabaddhakoṣṭhoraḥsrotasāṃ ca viśuddhaye ||167||
translation: The black antelope skins, smeared with ghee and cow dung, burnt by the fire of breath or placed on a raised platform, have been pointed out as non-vidh (non-ritualistic).

sloka: harītakīryavakvāthadvyāḍhake viṃśatiṃ pacet |  svinnā mṛditvā tāstasmin purāṇaṃ guḍaṣaṭpalam ||168||  dadyānmanaḥśilākarṣaṃ karṣārdhaṃ ca rasāñjanāt |  kuḍavārdhaṃ ca pippalyāḥ sa lehaḥ śvāsakāsanut ||169||  iti harītakīlehaḥ |
translation: By following this procedure, one should taste the sap of the leaf of the eranda tree, mixed with sugar and oil of voshya.

sloka: śvāvidhaḥ sūcayo dagdhāḥ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkarāḥ |  śvāsakāsaharā barhipādau vā kṣaudrasarpiṣā ||170||
translation: Should one mix crushed pomegranate seeds, liquor, or old jaggery with clarified butter, or with cow's ghee?

sloka: eraṇḍapatrakṣāraṃ vā vyoṣatailaguḍānvitam |  lihyādetena vidhinā surasairaṇḍapatrajam ||171||
translation: One should eat daily, either with wine or clarified butter, the bitter-tasting three-leaved herb known as Citraka, Katukatrika (another bitter-tasting plant), and Draksha (a type of grape).

sloka: drākṣāpadmakavārtākapippalīḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  lihyāttryūṣaṇacūrṇaṃ vā purāṇaguḍasarpiṣā ||172||
translation: Prepare finely powdered equal quantities of turmeric, triphala, black pepper, long pepper, Indian barberry, suradaru, rock salt, and licorice. Mix all these powders together with pure ghee and honey. Add powdered dried spikenard, costus root, punarnava, karkata-kshiram, pippali, chavya, musta, patra, chitraka, trikatu, bhargi, tamalaki, vacha, and dharuka. This is a holy mixture that destroys all diseases and rejuvenates the body.

sloka: citrakaṃ triphalājājī karkaṭākhyā kaṭutrikam |  drākṣāṃ ca kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ lihyādadyādguḍena vā ||173||
translation: Grind the ingredients into a powder and mix with cow's ghee. This cleanses the five parts of the hand and cures kasa (a type of disease). This is known as Padmaka-leha.

sloka: padmakaṃ triphalāṃ vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ suradāru ca |  balāṃ rāsnāṃ ca tulyāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet ||174||  sarvairebhiḥ samaṃ cūrṇaiḥ pṛthak kṣaudraṃ ghṛtaṃ sitām |  vimathya lehayellehaṃ sarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||175||  jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ pāṭhāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ triphalāṃ śaṭīm |  mustaile padmakaṃ drākṣāṃ dve bṛhatyau vitunnakam ||176|| sārivāṃ pauṣkaraṃ mūlaṃ karkaṭākhyāṃ rasāñjanam |  punarnavāṃ loharajastrāyamāṇāṃ yavānikām ||177||  bhārgīṃ tāmalakīmṛddhiṃ viḍaṅgaṃ dhanvayāsakam |  kṣāracitrakacavyāmlavetasavyoṣadāru ca ||178||
translation: Consuming lihyān (a type of fruit), maricacūrṇa (powdered pepper), saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram (salt mixed with ghee), badarīpatrakalkaṃ (the powder of berry leaves), or ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam (salted ghee) is recommended.

sloka: cūrṇīkṛtya samāṃśāni lehayet kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  cūrṇātpāṇitalaṃ pañca kāsānetad vyapohati ||179||  iti padmakādilehaḥ |
translation: In the case of voice disparity, this formula should be employed: a powder of patent medicines, mixed with clarified butter and sugar, made from the leaves of Tilvaka. It should be taken in the form of a drink or as a paste for alleviating hiccups, flatulence, cough, and other ailments such as consumption, diarrhea, and earache. Additionally, it can be used for toothaches, hoarseness, and the elimination of parasitical worms.

sloka: lihyānmaricacūrṇaṃ vā saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram |  badarīpatrakalkaṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam ||180||
translation: One who is proficient in extracting the juice from the Kantakari plant and has purified the Mudga (mung bean) soup, who is fair-complexioned, free from impurities, amiable, and victorious over all types of diseases. He/she knows the medicine that counteracts the harmful effects of wind, and is skilled in using it to remove the phlegm from the patient's body. They should also be able to recognize and utilize the smoke generated during the process of extracting juice from Kantakari plant for treating patients suffering from consumptive conditions.

sloka: svarabhede ca kāse ca lehametaṃ prayojayet |  patrakalkaṃ ghṛtairbhṛṣṭaṃ tilvakasya saśarkaram ||181||  peyā cotkārikā ccharditṛṭkāsāmātisāranut |  gaurasarṣapagaṇḍīraviḍaṅgavyoṣacitrakān |  sābhayān sādhayettoye yavāgūṃ tena cāmbhasā ||182||  sasarpirlavaṇāṃ kāse hikkāśvāse sapīnase |  pāṇḍvāmaye kṣaye śothe karṇaśūle ca dāpayet ||183||
translation: The stimulation, growth, and purification of the veins, as well as the prevention of wasting and imbalance, are all beneficial.

sloka: kaṇṭakārīrase siddho mudgayūṣaḥ susaṃskṛtaḥ |  sagaurāmalakaḥ sāmlaḥ sarvakāsabhiṣagjitam ||184||  vātaghnauṣadhaniṣkvāthaṃ kṣīraṃ yūṣān rasānapi |  vaiṣkirapratudān bailān dāpayet kṣayakāsine ||185||  kṣatakāse ca ye dhūmāḥ sānupānā nidarśitāḥ |  kṣayakāse'pi tāneva yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||186||
translation: Even in the context of an impending epidemic, a severe one at that, it is essential to always follow measures that promote health and eliminate the growth of the disease. One should identify and choose the most effective remedies among various options for treating coughs and colds, including consuming appropriate food and drink, such as milk, ghee, jaggery, and smoke. (188-190)

sloka: dīpanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva srotasāṃ ca viśodhanam |  vyatyāsātkṣayakāsibhyo balyaṃ sarvaṃ hitaṃ bhavet ||187||
translation: In that (system of yoga), a verse mentions the count, measure, cause, forms, and whether something is achievable or not. It also describes the remedy for what afflicts them and declares your superiority.

sloka: sannipātabhavo'pyeṣa kṣayakāsaḥ sudāruṇaḥ |  sannipātahitaṃ tasmāt sadā kāryaṃ bhiṣagjitam ||188||  doṣānubalayogācca haredrogabalābalam |  kāseṣveṣu garīyāṃsaṃ jānīyāduttarottaram ||189|| bhojyaṃ pānāni sarpīṃṣi lehāśca saha pānakaiḥ |  kṣīraṃ sarpirguḍā dhūmāḥ kāsabhaiṣajyasaṅgrahaḥ ||190||
translation: In the tantra (treatise) created by Agnivesha, after it has been thoroughly edited by Charaka, when a fully strengthened and fortified medical facility has not been obtained, this is called the eighteenth chapter named Kaasachikitsitam.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  saṅkhyā nimittaṃ rūpāṇi sādhyāsādhyatvameva ca |  kāsānāṃ bheṣajaṃ proktaṃ garīyastvaṃ ca kāsinaḥ ||191||
translation: Therefore, I shall explain the pure and fearless elixir-like limb of the scripture. So said Bhagavan Atri.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite  cikitsāsthāne kāsacikitsitaṃ nāmāṣṭādaśo'dhyāyaḥ ||18||
translation: The names of the remedies are: healing, disease-removing, beneficial, therapeutic means, expiation, tranquilizing, and maintaining natural order, which are conducive to well-being.

sloka: athāto'bhayāmalakīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: There are two types of medicine: one that enhances the health of a healthy person, and the other that reduces the illness of a sick person.

sloka: cikitsitaṃ vyādhiharaṃ pathyaṃ sādhanamauṣadham|  prāyaścittaṃ praśamanaṃprakṛtisthāpanaṃ hitam||3||  vidyādbheṣajanāmāni...|4|
translation: There are two kinds of remedies: one that causes a new affliction and the other that does not.

sloka: bheṣajaṃ dvividhaṃ ca tat|  svasthasyorjaskaraṃ kiñcit kiñcidārtasya roganut||4||
