translation: That which increases the strength of a healthy person is called vrysa (virile); it is also called rasayana in general. For the most part, this is considered to be the second best means for suppressing diseases. The word "prayaH" here indicates a special meaning, i.e., both uses of the word have a similar meaning.

sloka: abheṣajaṃ ca dvividhaṃ bādhanaṃ sānubādhanam||
translation: One who is long-lived, has a good memory, intelligence, and good health, is young and handsome, possesses radiance, majesty, strength in the body and senses, eloquence, devotion, and luster does not acquire these through medicinal preparations. These are the results obtained by those who are truly virtuous.

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ yattu tadvṛṣyaṃ tadrasāyanam||5|| prāyaḥ prāyeṇa rogāṇāṃ dvitīyaṃ praśamematam|  prāyaḥśabdoviśeṣārtho hyubhayaṃ hyubhayārthakṛt||6||
translation:
The one who immediately brings joy through the birth of offspring,
Who is like a swift and powerful horse easily overcoming females,
Who is greatly loved by women, making them subservient to him,
Who causes even withered seeds to sprout and be fruitful,
Who is like a tree with many branches and leaves, respected and honored by all,
And who enables one to attain immortality and prosperity after death,
Gaining fame, wealth, strength, and nourishment. //9-12//

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ|  prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param||7||  vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt|  lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam||8||
translation: There are two types of medicines declared for strengthening a healthy person. One that counters the harmful effects of ailments is said to be useful for therapeutic purposes. Moreover, the medicine that acts as a rejuvenator and enhancer of strength is also considered as an effective measure in the beginning.

sloka: apatyasantānakaraṃ yat sadyaḥ sampraharṣaṇam|  vājīvātibalo yenayātyapratihataḥ striyaḥ||9||  bhavatyatipriyaḥ strīṇāṃ yena yenopacīyate|  jīryato'pyakṣayaṃ śukraṃ phalavadyena dṛśyate||10||  prabhūtaśākhaḥ śākhīva yena caityo yathā mahān|  bhavatyarcyobahumataḥ prajānāṃ subahuprajaḥ||11||  santānamūlaṃ yeneha pretya cānantyamaśnute|  yaśaḥ śriyaṃ balaṃ puṣṭiṃ vājīkaraṇameva tat||12||
translation: That which is considered a cure is, in fact, the opposite of a medicine. I will declare that as something to be avoided, not used, as a medicine.

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ tvetaddvividhaṃ proktamauṣadham|  yadvyādhinirghātakaraṃ vakṣyate taccikitsite||13||  cikitsitārtha etāvān vikārāṇāṃ yadauṣadham|  rasāyanavidhiścāgre vājīkaraṇameva ca||14||
translation: The wise know the use of medicines to be of two kinds: one for household consumption and the other for exposure to wind and sun. (Verse 16)

sloka: abheṣajamiti jñeyaṃ viparītaṃ yadauṣadhāt|  tadasevyaṃ niṣevyaṃ tu pravakṣyāmi yadauṣadham||15||
translation: The procedure for constructing a hermitage is first described for one who is about to enter household life, namely, for kings, veterinarians, Brahmins, the virtuous, and those performing religious duties. It should be built in a peaceful and auspicious location, either in the eastern or northern direction, and should be equipped with necessary provisions.

sloka: rasāyanānāṃ dvividhaṃ prayogamṛṣayo viduḥ|  kuṭīprāveśikaṃ caiva vātātapikameva ca||16||
translation: She who is endowed with proper dimensions, triangular-shaped and having sharp eyes, pleasing to the mind, residing in a secluded place, liked by respectable women and physicians, and is devoid of any faults and menstruation.

sloka: kuṭīprāveśikasyādau vidhiḥ samupadekṣyate|  nṛpavaidyadvijātīnāṃ sādhūnāṃpuṇyakarmaṇām||17||  nivāse nirbhaye śaste prāpyopakaraṇe pure|  diśi pūrvottarasyāṃ ca subhūmau kārayet kuṭīm||18||
translation: Having established determination, memory, and strength, a resolute and focused person should discard mental impurities and contemplate benevolence towards all beings during the auspicious time of Udagayana, on the bright fortnight, when the tithi and nakshatra are also favorable.

sloka: vistārotsedhasampannāṃ trigarbhāṃ sūkṣmalocanām|  ghanabhittimṛtusukhāṃ suspaṣṭāṃ manasaḥ priyām||19||  śabdādīnāmaśastānāmagamyaṃ strīvivarjitām|  iṣṭopakaraṇopetāṃ sajjavaidyauṣadhadvijām||20||
translation: After worshipping the deities and making a circumambulation of the dvijatis (twice-born), and having paid obeisance to the devas, cows, and brahmanas, one should then enter the hut. Having purified himself in that hut, becoming happy and gaining strength, he should then make use of the rejuvenating elixir - I shall describe that method of purification.

sloka: athodagayane śukle tithinakṣatrapūjite|  muhūrtakaraṇopete praśastekṛtavāpanaḥ||21||  dhṛtismṛtibalaṃ kṛtvā śraddadhānaḥ samāhitaḥ|  vidhūya mānasān doṣān maitrīṃ bhūteṣu cintayan||22||
translation: A creature, who is afflicted with phlegm and sweat, should drink in the morning, during three consecutive nights, a preparation made of

sloka: devatāḥpūjayitvā'gre dvijātīṃśca pradakṣiṇam|  devagobrāhmaṇān kṛtvā tatastāṃ praviśetkuṭīm||23||  tasyāṃ saṃśodhanaiḥ śuddhaḥ sukhī jātabalaḥ punaḥ|  rasāyanaṃ prayuñjīta tatpravakṣyāmiśodhanam||24||
translation: Having known his body to be pure, one should prepare an alchemical treatment for him, who recognizes the harmony of his age and constitution. (The verse is a recommendation for medical treatment based on the individual's unique physical condition.)

sloka: harītakīnāṃ cūrṇāni saindhavāmalake guḍam|  vacāṃ viḍaṅgaṃ rajanīṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||25||  pibeduṣṇāmbunā jantuḥsnehasvedopapāditaḥ|  tena śuddhaśarīrāya kṛtasaṃsarjanāya ca||26||  trirātraṃ yāvakaṃ dadyāt pañcāhaṃvā'pi sarpiṣā|  saptāhaṃ vā purāṇasya yāvacchuddhestu varcasaḥ||27||
translation: Learn of Haritaki, with five tastes, warm, without impurities, auspicious, that which removes defects, light, and that which enhances digestion. It is life-giving, nutritious, beneficial, stabilizes aging, and is the supreme eliminator of all diseases, and increases intellect and strength.

sloka: śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ tu taṃ jñātvā rasāyanamupācaret|  vayaḥprakṛtisātmyajño yaugikaṃ yasya yadbhavet||28||
translation: Diseases such as leprosy, tumors, abscesses, emaciation, tuberculosis, piles, disorders of the spleen, jaundice, consumption, fever, insanity, epilepsy, loss of appetite, cough, diabetes, vomiting, gout, and debility.

sloka: harītakīṃ pañcarasāmuṣṇāmalavaṇāṃ śivām|  doṣānulomanīṃ laghvīṃvidyāddīpanapācanīm||29||  āyuṣyāṃ pauṣṭikīṃ dhanyāṃ vayasaḥ sthāpanīṃ parām|  sarvarogapraśamanīṃbuddhīndriyabalapradām||30||
translation: One should quickly overcome the various obstructions of the flow, the coating of the heart and chest, as well as the confusion of memory and intellect, caused by not having digested the bitter harita leaves. Those emaciated due to fasting, weakened by thirst and heat, should serve these plants, which are devoid of fear. One should recognize those qualities and actions in the harita plant that are spoken of as being opposite to its bitterness. (34-36)

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ gulmamudāvartaṃ śoṣaṃ pāṇḍvāmayaṃmadam|  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ purāṇaṃ viṣamajvaram||31||  hṛdrogaṃ saśirorogamatīsāramarocakam|  kāsaṃ pramehamānāhaṃ plīhānamudaraṃ navam||32||  kaphaprasekaṃ vaisvaryaṃ vaivarṇyaṃ kāmalāṃ krimīn|  śvayathuṃ tamakaṃ chardiṃ klaibyamaṅgāvasādanam||33||
translation: Learn, then, about the medicinal properties of haritaki and bhishagamala fruits through such actions.

sloka: srotovibandhān vividhān pralepaṃ hṛdayorasoḥ|  smṛtibuddhipramohaṃ ca jayecchīghraṃ harītakī||34||  (ajīrṇino rūkṣabhujaḥ strīmadyaviṣakarśitāḥ|  severannābhayāmete kṣuttṛṣṇoṣṇārditāścaye)||35||  tān guṇāṃstāni karmāṇi vidyādāmalakīṣvapi|  yānyuktāni harītakyā vīryasya tu viparyayaḥ||36||
translation: Of all plants, the earth is the foremost, and the best of mountains is Himavat; one should therefore acquire ripe fruits from them at the proper time. They are full of vigor and rich in juice, nourished by the rays of the sun and the moon, as well as water. I will explain the use and effects of such fruits.

sloka: ataścāmṛtakalpāni vidyāt karmabhirīdṛśaiḥ|  harītakīnāṃ śasyāni bhiṣagāmalakasya ca||37||
translation: The shares of the roots of the five [plants], measured by a dashapala (a unit of measurement), are: fifty haritaki fruits, and nine times that amount of raw sugar.

sloka: oṣadhīnāṃ parā bhūmirhimavāñ śailasattamaḥ|  tasmātphalāni tajjāni grāhayetkālajāni tu||38||  āpūrṇarasavīryāṇi kāle kāle yathāvidhi|  ādityapavanacchāyāsalilaprīṇitāni ca||39||  yānyajagdhānyapūtīni nirvraṇānyagadāni ca|  teṣāṃ prayogaṃ vakṣyāmi phalānāṃ karma cottamam||40||
translation: Learn to recognize the following five plants: (1) the great tree whose bark has a pungent smell, (2) the fifth family of dogs' teeth (perhaps referring to a type of plant with five-petaled flowers), (3) the fruit of the Bilva tree, (4) the Agnimantha plant, (5) the Shyonaka plant, (6) the Goshavari or Kantakari plant, (7) the two varieties of Shalmali tree, (8) the root of the black colocasia, (9) the Jivanti plant, and (10) the leaves of the sefika gram. Properly prepare a quantity of each of these five kinds of plants equal to a tenth of the water to be used.

sloka: pañcānāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ bhāgān daśapalonmitān|  harītakīsahasraṃ ca triguṇāmalakaṃ navam||41||
translation: One should consume only a tenth portion of the remaining pure [food] after removing with a curved instrument all the unripe, impure fruits and flowers like haritaki, pippala, shankhapushpi, plava, musta, vidanga, chandan, guru, madhuka, hridra, vacha, kankasya, along with a quarter of fine powder of costus root and an amount of sugar equal to the weight of a hundred white conch shells. To this, two parts of oil and three parts of ghee should be added.

sloka: vidārigandhāṃ bṛhatīṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ nidigdhikām|  vidyādvidārigandhādyaṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāpañcamaṃ gaṇam||42||  bilvāgnimanthaśyonākaṃ kāśmaryamatha pāṭalām|  punarnavāṃ śūrpaparṇyau balāmeraṇḍameva ca||43||  jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ saśatāvarīm|  śarekṣudarbhakāśānāṃ śālīnāṃ mūlameva ca||44||  ityeṣāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ pañcānāmupakalpayet|  bhāgān yathoktāṃstatsarvaṃ sādhyaṃ daśaguṇe'mbhasi||45||
translation: The audumbar pot needs to be heated with a gentle fire, and once it's understood that everything has been properly cooked, it should be cooled down with a measure of kshaudra. The entire measure of kshaudra should then be mixed in a ghrita vessel, and at the appropriate time, this quantity should be used. One should not neglect to eat one's meal in the prescribed measure; with six measures of water, food is considered digested when it becomes old (or stale).

sloka: daśabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu pūtaṃ taṃ grāhayedrasam|  harītakīśca tāḥ sarvāḥ sarvāṇyāmalakāni ca||46||  tāni sarvāṇyanasthīni phalānyāpothya kūrcanaiḥ|  vinīya tasminniryūhe cūrṇānīmānidāpayet||47||  maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ pippalyāḥ śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ plavasyaca|  mustānāṃ saviḍaṅgānāṃ candanāguruṇostathā||48||  madhukasya haridrāyā vacāyāḥ kanakasya ca|  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalān kṛtvā sūkṣmailāyāstvacastathā||49||  sitopalāsahasraṃ ca cūrṇitaṃtulayā'dhikam|  tailasya dvyāḍhakaṃ tatra dadyāttrīṇi ca sarpiṣaḥ||50||
translation: The followers of Vaikhana and Valakhilya, as well as other ascetics who are wealthy in tapas, after consuming this elixir, have become freed from old age, regained their youth, became free from fatigue, sluggishness, and fear, and achieved a composed state.

sloka: sādhyamaudumbare pātre tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā|  jñātvālehyamadagdhaṃ ca śītaṃ kṣaudreṇa saṃsṛjet||51||  kṣaudrapramāṇaṃ snehārdhaṃ tat sarvaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  tiṣṭhetsammūrcchitaṃ tasya mātrāṃ kāle prayojayet||52||  yā noparundhyādāhāramekaṃ mātrā jarāṃprati|  ṣaṣṭikaḥ payasā cātra jīrṇe bhojanamiṣyate||53||
translation: Those who are endowed with wisdom, memory, and strength, if they practice severe austerities and celibacy with utmost dedication, should engage in this Brahma-rasayana for the pursuit of long life, youthfulness, and fulfillment of desires. (Brahmaraasayanam)

sloka: vaikhānasā vālakhilyāstathā cānye tapodhanāḥ|  rasāyanamidaṃ prāśyababhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||54||  muktvā jīrṇaṃ vapuścāgryamavāpustaruṇaṃ vayaḥ|  vītatandrāklamaśvāsā nirātaṅkāḥ samāhitāḥ||55||
translation: Here is the divine Brahma rasāyana, worshipped by great sages. One who uses it becomes free from disease, long-lived, and possesses immense strength. They are loved by people, successful in their goals, and shine like the sun and moon. They possess virtue, knowledge of the Vedas, and good character. Like the earth supported by the wind, they become firm and pure, without impurities or unevenness in their body. (This is the second Brahma rasāyana.)

sloka: medhāsmṛtibalopetāścirarātraṃ tapodhanāḥ|  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryaṃ ceruścātyantaniṣṭhayā||56||  rasāyanamidaṃ brāhmamāyuṣkāmaḥ prayojayet|  dīrghamāyurvayaścāgryaṃ kāmāṃśceṣṭān samaśnute||57||  (iti brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Of the bilva, agnimantha, shyonaaka, kashamarya, patala, and the two types of brhati, as well as the shringi, tamalakii, draksha, jivanti, pippali, shvadamshtraa, vidari, vrishamoolani, kaakolee, kaakanaasikaa, musta, punarnava, meda, saila, utpala, when their measured portions are combined with 100 portions of amalaka, five should be given in the palasha tree on the new moon day.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ brāhmaṃ maharṣigaṇasevitam|  bhavatyarogo dīrghāyuḥ prayuñjāno mahābalaḥ||59|| kāntaḥ prajānāṃsiddhārthaścandrādityasamadyutiḥ|  śrutaṃ dhārayate sattvamārṣaṃ cāsya pravartate||60||  dharaṇīdharasāraśca vāyunā samavikramaḥ|  sa bhavatyaviṣaṃ cāsya gātre sampadyate viṣam||61||  (iti dvitīyaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Having understood these various medicinal herbs, one should extract the essence; free from impurities, mix it with sesame oil and ghee. After grinding this mixture into a paste with 12 palas of water, give half a pala of it to a clean fish in a pot. Add six palas of honey and offer four palas of curd, one pala each of licorice, ela, patra, and keshara. This is called the Chyavanaprasa Rasayana, the ultimate rejuvenating therapy.

sloka: bilvo'gnimanthaḥ śyonākaḥ kāśmaryaḥ pāṭalirbalā|  parṇyaścatasraḥ pippalyaḥ śvadaṃṣṭrā bṛhatīdvayam||62||  śṛṅgī tāmalakī drākṣā jīvantī puṣkarāguru|  abhayā cāmṛtā ṛddhirjīvakarṣabhakau śaṭī||63||  mustaṃ punarnavā medā sailā candanamutpalam|  vidārī vṛṣamūlāni kākolī kākanāsikā||64||  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgāñchatānyāmalakasya ca|  pañca dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ jaladroṇe vipācayet||65||
translation: A single entity is specially declared to be a remover of fatigue and anxiety. It promotes the growth of the weak, the aged, and children. It preserves the voice and rids the body of diseases affecting the head and heart, wind, bile, and phlegm, as well as the impurities of thirst, urine, and excrement.

sloka: jñātvā gatarasānyetānyauṣadhānyatha taṃ rasam|  taccāmalakamuddhṛtya niṣkulaṃ tailasarpiṣoḥ||66||  paladvādaśake bhṛṣṭvā dattvā cārdhatulāṃ bhiṣak|  matsyaṇḍikāyāḥ pūtāyā lehavatsādhu sādhayet||67||  ṣaṭpalaṃ madhunaścātra siddhaśīte pradāpayet|  catuṣpalaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ pippalīdvipalaṃ tathā||68||  palamekaṃ nidadhyācca tvagelāpatrakeśarāt|  ityayaṃ cyavanaprāśaḥ paramukto rasāyanaḥ||69||
translation:
One who consumes this (medicine) after appropriately determining its measure, instead of eating food, becomes youthful again despite aging. Through its use, one acquires increased intellect, memory, complexion, health, longevity, strength, and radiance in women; one also gains a pleasant voice and a fragrant smell. Even someone who is old and infirm can regain their former bodily appearance by using this (medicine), leaving behind the form caused by aging and bearing the appearance of youth.
(This is from Cyavana Prashah.)

sloka: kāsaśvāsaharaścaiva viśeṣeṇopadiśyate|  kṣīṇakṣatānāṃ vṛddhānāṃ bālānāṃcāṅgavardhanaḥ||70||  svarakṣayamurorogaṃ hṛdrogaṃ vātaśoṇitam|  pipāsāṃ mūtraśukrasthān doṣāṃścāpyapakarṣati||71||
translation: Just as immortality and enjoyment are found among the gods, similarly in the past, the great sages, who were devoted to the elixir of life, attained a lifespan of thousands of years without aging, weakness, natural decay, or death. One who properly follows the method of consuming the elixir of life does not merely obtain long life, but also achieves the auspicious destination and imperishable state revered by the gods and rishis.

sloka: asya mātrāṃprayuñjīta yoparundhyānna bhojanam|  asya prayogāccyavanaḥsuvṛddho'bhūtpunaryuvā||72||  medhāṃ smṛtiṃ kāntimanāmayatvamāyuḥprakarṣaṃ balamindriyāṇām|  strīṣu praharṣaṃ paramagnivṛddhiṃ varṇaprasādaṃpavanānulomyam||73|| rasāyanasyāsya naraḥ prayogāllabheta jīrṇo'pi kuṭīpraveśāt|  jarākṛtaṃ rūpamapāsya sarvaṃ bibharti rūpaṃ navayauvanasya||74|| (iti cyavanaprāśaḥ)|
translation: In this Abhayamalaki, the six Yogas are mentioned; one's lifespan is sustained by the elixirs of which those are accomplished.

sloka: bhavanticātra yathā'marāṇāmamṛtaṃ yathā bhogavatāṃsudhā|  tathā'bhavanmaharṣīṇāṃ rasāyanavidhipurā||78|| na jarāṃ na ca daurbalyaṃ nāturyaṃ nidhanaṃ na ca|  jagmurvarṣasahasrāṇi rasāyanaparāḥ purā||79||  na kevalaṃ dīrghamihāyuraśnute rasāyanaṃ yovidhivanniṣevate|  gatiṃ sa devarṣiniṣevitāṃ śubhāṃ prapadyate brahma tatheti cākṣayam||80||
translation: In the medical tantra composed by Agnivesha, in the section on treatment that has been revised by Charaka, the first chapter of this section is named 'Abhayamala' (Fearless Medicine).

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  abhayāmalakīye'smin ṣaḍyogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāmāyuryairanuvartate||81||
translation: Therefore, we will explain the science of rejuvenation (prāṇakāmīya) starting from the root (pāda) related to rasa (taste or mercury). This is according to what has been said by Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthānerasāyanādhyāye'bhayāmalakīyo nāma rasāyanapādaḥ prathamaḥ||1||
translation: The same method as before should be followed to cook a vessel containing bhallataka oil, mixed with a quarter of fresh butter and milk, along with one hundred times of grinding. (This is known as the method for preparing bhallataka oil.)

sloka: athātaḥ prāṇakāmīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The preparation method of bhallataka (a tree species) is described as follows: its oil, sap, resin, candy, juice, ghee, bark, and ablution - all are mentioned.

sloka: bhallātakatailapātraṃ sapayaskaṃ madhukena kalkenākṣamātreṇa śatapākaṃ kuryāditi samānaṃ pūrveṇa||15||  (iti bhallātakatailam)|
translation: Here, sharp and glowing like fires, Bhallataka fruits are found that have the properties of being rejuvenating when used as prescribed. Of these, there are ten uses described. One who knows the nature and effects of diseases should apply these uses appropriately. (translated from Sanskrit)

sloka: bhallātakasarpiḥ bhallātakakṣīraṃ bhallātakakṣaudraṃ guḍabhallātakaṃ bhallātakayūṣaḥ bhallātakatailaṃ bhallātakapalalaṃ bhallātakasaktavaḥ bhallātakalavaṇaṃbhallātakatarpaṇam iti bhallātakavidhānamuktaṃ bhavati||16||
translation: There is no such disease as kapha, nor any bondage. One who does not kill a bhallataka tree, which enhances intellect, quickly, has neither merit nor longevity (19). In the past, sages like Cyavana, who desired life and pleasure, became long-lived by using these auspicious elixirs after their bodies had become old and worn out (20). Those who seek longevity and pleasure should carefully follow, as prescribed, the procedure for preparing the elixir of bhallataka, which leads to Brahmaloka, and also practice brahmana tapas, brahmacharya, and atma-dhyana (21-22).

sloka: bhavanticātra  bhallātakāni tīkṣṇāni pākīnyagnisamānica| bhavantyamṛtakalpāni prayuktāni yathāvidhi||17||  ete daśavidhāstveṣāṃ prayogāḥparikīrtitāḥ|  rogaprakṛtisātmyajñastān prayogān prakalpayet||18||
translation: The sage Kapila has described the compositions of rasāyana (rejuvenation therapy) that promote well-being, in the seventy-third verse.

sloka: kaphajo na sa rogo'sti na vibandho'sti kaścana|  yaṃ na bhallātakaṃ hanyācchīghraṃ medhāgnivardhanam||19||  (iti bhallātakavidhiḥ)|  prāṇakāmāḥ purā jīrṇāścyavanādyā maharṣayaḥ|  rasāyanaiḥ śivairetairbabhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||20||  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryamadhyātmadhyānameva ca|  dīrghāyuṣo yathākāmaṃ sambhṛtya tridivaṃ gatāḥ||21||  tasmādāyuḥprakarṣārthaṃ prāṇakāmaiḥsukhārthibhiḥ|  rasāyanavidhiḥ sevyo vidhivatsusamāhitaiḥ||22||
translation: In the medical treatise composed by Agnivesha, after being revised by Charaka, in the section on pharmacology, the second chapter is named "Prana-Kamisha," which deals with elixirs.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  rasāyanānāṃ saṃyogāḥ siddhābhūtahitaiṣiṇā|  nirdiṣṭāḥ prāṇakāmīye saptatriṃśanmaharṣiṇā ||23||
translation: Now, I will explain the means to attain the elixir of life. Thus spoke Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye prāṇakāmīyo nāma rasāyanapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: Here, in the past, Vasishtha, Vishvamitra, Angirasa, Jamadagni, Bharadvaja, Bhrigu, and others of their kind have engaged in this elixir of knowledge (rasayana). Acting with deliberation, they became free from fatigue, disease, and fear of old age. For as long as they desired, they performed austerities and gained great power from it. Brahma created this elixir of knowledge over the course of a thousand years, which has the ability to suppress aging and illness in the intelligent. (This is called Amalakayasam Brahmarasayanam.)

sloka: athātaḥ karapracitīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃvyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The great sages of the past established themselves through austerity, celibacy, meditation, tranquility, and proper lifespan with the administration of rejuvenation. Indeed, no rejuvenation occurs for those who are not disciplined in other worldly activities.

sloka: bhavanticātra  etadrasāyanaṃ pūrvaṃ vasiṣṭhaḥkaśyapo'ṅgirāḥ| jamadagnirbharadvājo bhṛguranye ca tadvidhāḥ||4||  prayujya prayatā muktāḥ śramavyādhijarābhayāt| yāvadaicchaṃstapastepustatprabhāvānmahābalāḥ||5||  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ cakre brahmā vārṣasahasrikam|  jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ buddhīndriyabalapradam||6||  (ityāmalakāyasaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: A cow should reside in the middle of the herd, following a yearly cycle of giving milk, while meditating on Savitri and controlling his senses.

sloka: tapasā brahmacaryeṇa dhyānena praśamena ca|  rasāyanavidhānena kālayuktena cāyuṣā||7||  sthitā maharṣayaḥ pūrvaṃ nahikiñcidrasāyanam|  grāmyānāmanyakāryāṇāṃ sidhyatyaprayatātmanām||8||
translation: At the end of the year, on the Paushi or Maghi or Phalguni day, if one observes a three-day fast and enters the grove of amalaki trees on the third day of the bright fortnight, climbs the well-fruited tree, plucks the fruit with his hand and stands there repeating the mantra "Brahmaamritaagamat," then for that moment he becomes immortal. He finds the amalaki fruits to be as sweet as nectar and as soft as sugar. As long as one eats these fruits, they will remain youthful for thousands of years. By befriending them, one becomes similar to the immortals. Furthermore, Lakshmi and Vedamargi (the embodiment of speech and knowledge) will themselves come and reside in him (Kevalamalakarasayanam).

sloka: saṃvatsaraṃ payovṛttirgavāṃ madhye vaset sadā|  sāvitrīṃ manasā dhyāyan brahmacārī yatendriyaḥ||9||
translation: The juice of Triphala, the urine of a cow, salt, cengee lemon juice, and kishuka juice should be sequentially mixed. The pointed leaves of iron rust should be made red by treating them with these. Once identified, they should be ground into fine particles. These powders should be mixed with honey and sugarcane juice and kept in a pot smeared with ghee for a year.

sloka: saṃvatsarānte pauṣīṃ vā māghīṃ vā phālgunīṃ tithim|  tryahopavāsī śuklasya praviśyāmalakīvanam||10||  bṛhatphalāḍhyamāruhya drumaṃ śākhāgataṃ phalam|  gṛhītvā pāṇinā tiṣṭhejjapan brahmāmṛtāgamāt||11||  tadā hyavaśyamamṛtaṃ vasatyāmalake kṣaṇam|  śarkarāmadhukalpāni snehavanti mṛdūni ca||12||  bhavantyamṛtasaṃyogāttāni yāvanti bhakṣayet|  jīvedvarṣasahasrāṇi tāvantyāgatayauvanaḥ||13||  sauhityameṣāṃ gatvā tu bhavatyamarasannibhaḥ|  svayaṃ cāsyopatiṣṭhante śrīrvedā vāk ca rūpiṇī||14||  (iti kevalāmalakarasāyanam)|
translation: A wise person should donate ghee and sugar while ritually reciting the month's name at the beginning of each month, and at the end of the year. In the morning, one should have a satisfying meal according to their strength, and this has been declared as the usage of iron.

sloka: triphalāyā rase mūtre gavāṃ kṣāre ca lavaṇe|  krameṇaceṅgudīkṣāre kiṃśukakṣāra eva ca||15||  tīkṣṇāyasasya patrāṇi vahnivarṇāni sādhayet |  caturaṅguladīrghāṇi tilotsedhatanūni ca||16|| jñātvā tānyañjanābhāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet|  tāni cūrṇāni madhunā rasenāmalakasya ca||17||  yuktāni lehavat kumbhe sthitāni ghṛtabhāvite|  saṃvatsaraṃ nidheyāni yavapalle tathaivaca||18||
translation: Such is the elephant's noble nature, unshaken by beatings, fear, old age, or death; wise, famous, eloquent, accomplished in scriptures, and wealthy, a person who uses this method with equal treatment towards all becomes capable of increasing their lifespan and eliminating all diseases. (This is called the alchemy of metals.)

sloka: dadyādāloḍanaṃ māse sarvatrāloḍayan budhaḥ|  saṃvatsarātyaye tasya prayogo madhusarpiṣā||19||  prātaḥ prātarbalāpekṣī sātmyaṃ jīrṇe ca bhojanam|  eṣa eva ca lauhānāṃ prayogaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ||20||
translation: Of the three portions that are of the nature of Indra among fishes, named Brāhmī, of excellent luster; of pippalyō (a type of grain), of lavana (salt), of hema (gold), of śaṅkha-puṣpī (conch-flower, a type of plant), and of visha (poison); two portions consisting of gold should be given, and for the portion of poison, sesame seeds should be given; for ghee, a handful should be offered, and ghee that is abundant is praised when used in the sacrificial offering of old food.

sloka: nābhighātairna cātaṅkairjarayāna ca mṛtyunā|  sa dhṛṣyaḥ syādgajaprāṇaḥ sadā cātibalendriyaḥ||21||  dhīmān yaśasvī vāksiddhaḥ śrutadhārī mahādhanaḥ|  bhavet samāṃ prayuñjāno naro lauharasāyanam||22||  anenaiva vidhānena hemnaśca rajatasyaca|  āyuḥprakarṣakṛtsiddhaḥ prayogaḥ sarvaroganut||23||  (iti lauhādirasāyanam)|
translation: This is the renowned elixir of Indra, which, when taken, removes aging and disease. It enhances memory, intellect, and wisdom. It bestows longevity, good health, wealth, and clarity of voice and complexion. It gives immense strength, subdues all tasks, and wards off poverty, poison, and grey hair. It cures diseases such as leprosy, abdominal tumors, enlarged spleen, jaundice, old age, and irregular fever. It also eliminates diseases that affect intellect and memory, as well as strong winds (such as those causing flatulence). (This is known as the elixir of Indra.)

sloka: aindrī matsyākhyako brāhmī vacā brahmasuvarcalā|  pippalyo lavaṇaṃ hema śaṅkhapuṣpī viṣaṃghṛtam||24||  eṣāṃ triyavakān bhāgān hemasarpirviṣairvinā|  dvau yavau tatra hemnastu tilaṃ dadyādviṣasyaca||25||  sarpiṣaśca palaṃ dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ prayojayet|  ghṛtaprabhūtaṃ sakṣaudraṃ jīrṇe cānnaṃpraśasyate||26||
translation:
The juice of manduka-parna, when mixed with milk and the powder of madhu-kas's root, as well as the sap of guduchi along with its flowers, when combined with shankha-pushpi - all these are rejuvenating substances that promote longevity, cure diseases, improve strength, complexion, and voice. Particularly, shankha-pushpi is highly medicinal. (Translated by Ganguli)

Note: The Sanskrit verse appears to be describing various herbal concoctions for medicinal purposes, but I don't have the original context or source of this verse. Therefore, my translation may not be 100% accurate.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ smṛtimedhākaraṃ param|  āyuṣyaṃ pauṣṭikaṃ dhanyaṃ svaravarṇaprasādanam||27||  paramojaskaraṃ caitat siddhamaindraṃ rasāyanam|  nainat prasahate kṛtyā nālakṣmīrna viṣaṃ na ruk||28||  śvitraṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ jaṭharāṇi gulmāḥ plīhā purāṇo viṣamajvaraśca|  medhāsmṛtijñānaharāśca rogāḥ śāmyantyanenātibalāśca vātāḥ||29||  (ityaindraṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: Seeking the properties of the elixir, one should prepare a concoction with eight, seven, or ten pippalii fruits, processed with honey and ghee, in equal quantities. In the first part of the day, after consuming a third each on three separate occasions, the fruits should be treated with turmeric and ghee.

sloka: maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ svarasaḥ prayojyaḥ kṣīreṇa yaṣṭīmadhukasya cūrṇam| raso guḍūcyāstu samūlapuṣpyāḥ kalkaḥ prayojyaḥ khalu śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ||30||  āyuḥpradānyāmayanāśanāni balāgnivarṇasvaravardhanāni|  medhyāni caitāni rasāyanāni medhyā viśeṣeṇa caśaṅkhapuṣpī||31||  (itimedhyarasāyanāni)|
translation: Mixed with honey and possessing the qualities of a rejuvenating potion, it is used to conquer cough, fever, loss of appetite, thirst, hiccups, stiffness of the neck, diseases of the throat, worm infestation, anemia, disorders of the stomach, swelling, and flatulence (from Pippali Rasayana).

sloka: pañcāṣṭau sapta daśa vā pippalīrmadhusarpiṣā|  rasāyanaguṇānveṣī samāmekāṃ prayojayet||32||  tisrastisrastu pūrvāhṇe bhuktvā'gre bhojanasya ca|  pippalyaḥ kiṃśukakṣārabhāvitā ghṛtabharjitāḥ||33||
translation: Over the course of ten days, one should gradually increase the quantity of milk by a peepal leaf's worth each day, and then decrease it in the same manner on the following ten days. One should consume a mixture of curd and ghee when the previous portion has been digested. This method, which uses a thousand peepal leaves, is a means of enhancing taste. Coarsely ground peepal leaves should be consumed by those of medium strength, while finely ground ones should be given to those of weaker strength along with any necessary medicines.

sloka: prayojyā madhusammiśrā rasāyanaguṇaiṣiṇā|  jetuṃ kāsaṃ kṣayaṃ śoṣaṃ śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ galāmayān||34||  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ pāṇḍutāṃ viṣamajvaram|  vaisvaryaṃ pīnasaṃ śophaṃ gulmaṃ vātabalāsakam||35||  (iti pippalīrasāyanam)|
translation: The best among the Dasapappala trees is recognized as having six mentions, while the one praised three times is considered inferior, even with strength. The large-sized, deep-voiced, longevity-granting, and obesity-reducing pippalina plant is called a rejuvenating elixir. (This is known as the growth-promoting elixir of pippalina.)

sloka: kramavṛddhyā daśāhāni daśapaippalikaṃ  dinam|  vardhayet payasā sārdhaṃ tathaivāpanayetpunaḥ||36||  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  pippalīnāṃ sahasrasya prayogo'yaṃrasāyanam||37||  piṣṭāstā balibhiḥ sevyāḥ śṛtā madhyabalairnaraiḥ|  cūrṇīkṛtā hrasvabalairyojyā doṣāmayān prati||38||
translation: Upon completion of one's life span, by consuming twice daily for a year, a preparation made from two ingredients - Madhu and Sarpi (honey and ghee), along with four Amalaki fruits, and then consuming the Triphala decoction, one can live for a hundred years, free from old age and disease. (This is known as the Triphala Rasayana.)

sloka: daśapaippalikaḥ śreṣṭho madhyamaḥ ṣaṭprakīrtitaḥ|  prayogo yastriparyantaḥ sa kanīyān sacābalaiḥ||39||  bṛhaṇaṃ svaryamāyuṣyaṃ plīhodaravināśanam|  vayasaḥ sthāpanaṃ medhyaṃ pippalīnāṃ rasāyanam||40||  (iti pippalīvardhamānaṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: With a newly coated triphala-infused vessel, one should drink every day for a period of time, this kshaudra-infused water, mixed with clarified butter that is abundantly used and recommended when the vessel becomes old. Thus, one can live for a hundred years, free from old age and disease. (This is known as Triphala Rasayana).

sloka: jaraṇānte'bhayāmekāṃ prāgbhuktād dve bibhītake|  bhuktvā tu madhusarpirbhyāṃ catvāryāmalakāni ca||41||  prayojayan samāmekāṃ triphalāyā rasāyanam|  jīvedvarṣaśataṃ pūrṇamajaro'vyādhireva ca||42||  (iti triphalārasāyanam)|
translation: The elixir prepared with honey, cow's ghee, Pippali, Kaudra ghee, triple-fermented, and pure sugar is complete. (This is known as Triphala Rasayana.)

sloka: traiphalenāyasīṃ pātrīṃ kalkenālepayennavām|  tamahorātrikaṃ lepaṃ pibetkṣaudrodakāplutam||43||  prabhūtasnehamaśanaṃ jīrṇe tatra praśasyate|  ajaro'ruk samābhyāsājjīveccaiva samāḥ śatam||44||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Through year-long use of Triphala, it becomes a giver of longevity, intelligence, memory, strength, and remover of old age and disease, superior to gold and comparable to honey and ghee in its excellence. (This is called Triphala Rasayana.)

sloka: madhukena tugākṣīryā pippalyā kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  triphalā sitayā cāpi yuktā siddhaṃ rasāyanam||45||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: The preparation that is free from bitterness and astringency, not too hot or cold, and derived from four substances - gold, silver, copper, and iron - can eliminate phlegm, bile, and wind; when refined with appropriate processes and made palatable, it greatly enhances potency through the individual or combined action of these substances.

sloka: sarvalauhaiḥ suvarṇena vacayāmadhusarpiṣā|  viḍaṅgapippalībhyāṃ ca triphalā lavaṇena ca||46||  saṃvatsaraprayogeṇa medhāsmṛtibalapradā|  bhavatyāyuḥpradā dhanyājarāroganibarhaṇī||47||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: If a substance is thrown into water and then retrieved, it should be thrown again in seven days according to the previously mentioned method. It should be mixed with powdered metals and consumed with milk to achieve long, happy life.

sloka: anamlaṃ ca kaṣāyaṃ ca kaṭu pāke śilājatu|  nātyuṣṇaśītaṃ dhātubhyaścaturbhyastasyasambhavaḥ||48||  hemnaśca rajatāttāmrādvarāt kṛṣṇāyasādapi|  rasāyanaṃ tadvidhibhistadvṛṣyaṃ tacca roganut||49||  vātapittakaphaghnaiśca niryūhaistat subhāvitam|  vīryotkarṣaṃ paraṃ yāti sarvairekaikaśo'pi vā||50||
translation: The one who is capable of alleviating old age and disease, strengthening the body, improving intellect and memory, and being blessed, should use curd mixed with rice. This practice should be followed for seven days, three days, or a week, as directed. The measurement of this mixture is classified into three types: half, one-third, and a handful.

sloka: prakṣiptoddhṛtamapyenat punastat prakṣipedrase|  koṣṇe saptāhametena vidhinā tasya bhāvanā||51||  pūrvoktena vidhānena lohaiścūrṇīkṛtaiḥ saha|  tat pītaṃ payasā dadyāddīrghamāyu sukhānvitam||52||
translation: I will describe the distinguishing feature of gold from others. The mountains, heated by the sun, release oozing streams that are initially sandy and rough, then become gradually softer, smooth, and less impure. This liquid, when further processed, turns into a substance that is sweet at first but becomes bitter and cool upon solidification. Silver, on the other hand, yields a liquid that is sour, white, cool, and slightly sweet after processing. Copper produces a liquid with a pungent taste, turning hot and pungent upon solidification. Iron, when heated, releases a liquid similar to aloewood, pungent, salty, and bitter, which becomes hard and more pungent when cooled. Among all these, iron is considered the most excellent due to its unique properties.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ dehadārḍhyakaraṃ param|  medhāsmṛtikaraṃ dhanyaṃ kṣīrāśī tat prayojayet||53||  prayogaḥ saptasaptāhāstrayaścaikaśca saptakaḥ|  nirdiṣṭastrividhastasya paro madhyo'varastathā||54||  palamardhapalaṃ karṣo mātrā tasya tridhā matā |
translation: All are associated with the smell of cow urine and are used in various actions. In the use of mercurial compounds,

sloka: jāterviśeṣaṃ savidhiṃ tasya vakṣyāmyataḥ param||55|| hemādyāḥ sūryasantaptāḥ sravanti giridhātavaḥ|  jatvābhaṃ mṛdumṛtsnācchaṃ yanmalaṃ tacchilājatu||56||  madhuraśca satiktaśca japāpuṣpanibhaśca yaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sa suvarṇasya nisravaḥ ||57||  rūpyasya kaṭukaḥ śvetaḥ śītaḥ svādu vipacyate|  tāmrasya barhikaṇṭhābhastiktoṣṇaḥ pacyate kaṭu ||58||  yastu guggulukābhāsastiktako lavaṇānvitaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sarvaśreṣṭhaḥ sa cāyasaḥ ||59||
translation: In the use of lithics and other such tools, one should always avoid those teachers who lack heat (i.e., enthusiasm or knowledge). For, due to their being directly opposed to the ultimate goal, the act of splitting stone is seen in the world as something forbidden for them. The waters, buttermilk, tastes, dew, and various impurities - these are suitable to be used for anointing the goddess (i.e., the linga) after being carefully considered for their purpose.

sloka: gomūtragandhayaḥ sarve sarvakarmasu yaugikāḥ|  rasāyanaprayogeṣu paścimastu viśiṣyate ||60||  yathākramaṃ vātapitte śleṣmapitte kaphe triṣu|  viśeṣataḥ praśasyante malā hemādidhātujāḥ ||61||
translation: There is no incurable disease on earth that cannot be overcome by the use of silājatu at the proper time and in accordance with the prescribed methods, it gives abundant vitality to a healthy person. (Shilajatursam)

sloka: śilājatuprayogeṣu vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  varjayet sarvakālaṃ tu kulatthān  parivarjayet||62||  te hyatyantaviruddhatvādaśmano bhedanāḥ param|  loke dṛṣṭāstatasteṣāṃ prayogaḥpratiṣidhyate||63||  payāṃsi takrāṇi rasāḥ sayūṣāstoyaṃ samūtrā vividhāḥ kaṣāyāḥ|  āloḍanārthaṃ girijasya śastāste te prayojyāḥ prasamīkṣyakāryam||64||
translation: The verse describes the combination of ten and six ingredients, as identified by the great sage (maharishi), in making the alchemical preparation "rasayana."

sloka: na so'sti rogo bhuvi sādhyarūpaḥ śilāhvayaṃ yaṃ na jayet prasahya|  tat kālayogairvidhibhiḥ prayuktaṃ svasthasya corjāṃ vipulāṃ dadāti||65||  (iti śilājaturasāyanam)|
translation: In the tantra (treatise) composed by Agnivesha, after its revision by Charaka, in the section on Rasayana (rejuvenation therapy), there is a third chapter named Karapraciteeya.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  karapracitike pāde daśa ṣaṭ ca maharṣiṇā|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāṃ saṃyogāḥ samudāhṛtāḥ||66||
translation: Now, I will explain the section on mercury that is originating from Ayurveda. So says Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye karapracitīyo nāma rasāyanapādastṛtīyaḥ||3||
translation: Having heard the words of the lord of the gods, all the sages were pleased and praised the best among the celestials. They also delighted in and approved of his words. (Translation by Aryan Bhai)

sloka: athāta āyurvedasamutthānīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The power of the divine medicinal plants that exists is not something that can be endured by ordinary people. Only those with self-disciplined minds can withstand and utilize it. By standing in one's own duty, all prosperity will be obtained through their influence. Indeed, these medicinal plants can be effectively used and accessed by both ascetics and householders who are focused and self-controlled. (translated by Parthasarathy Seshadri)

sloka: tacchrutvā vibudhapativacanamṛṣayaḥ sarva evāmaravaramṛgbhistuṣṭuvuḥ prahṛṣṭāśca tadvacanamabhinananduśceti||5||
translation: As for those who are endowed with the qualities of the field and mediocre in their actions, the scripture dictates that one should approach or utilize those who are mild and brave among them. However, for those who seek pleasure and are unable to do so, a course of action prescribed by medical science is recommended instead. (Translation based on "The Bhagavad Gita" translated by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada)

sloka: bhavanti cātra  divyānāmoṣadhīnāṃ yaḥ prabhāvaḥ sa bhavadvidhaiḥ| śakyaḥ soḍhumaśakyastu syāt soḍhumakṛtātmabhiḥ||8||  oṣadhīnāṃ prabhāveṇa tiṣṭhatāṃ sve ca karmaṇi|  bhavatāṃ nikhilaṃ śreyaḥ sarvamevopapatsyate||9||  vānaprasthairgṛhasthaiśca prayatairniyatātmabhiḥ|  śakyā oṣadhayo hyetāḥ sevituṃ viṣayābhijāḥ||10||
translation: Of the juices of barley, wheat, rice, sugarcane, utpala (a type of lotus), mrdvika (a type of grass), vida (a type of plant), citraka (a type of plant), shataavari, jongka (a type of plant), naagabala (a type of plant), dvaarada (a type of tree), triphala, kantakari (a type of plant), ikshu (sugarcane), sharamoola (a type of plant), shriparnya (a type of tree), and tinospora, each should be individually consumed in proper measured quantities. The measure of each is four times that of milk or gavyam (clarified butter).

sloka: yāstu kṣetraguṇaisteṣāṃ madhyamena ca karmaṇā|  mṛduvīryatarāstāsāṃ vidhirjñeyaḥ sa eva tu||11||  paryeṣṭuṃ tāḥ prayoktuṃ vā ye'samarthāḥ sukhārthinaḥ|  rasāyanavidhisteṣāmayamanyaḥ praśasyate||12||
translation: The ghee and sesame oil should be churned in their respective vessels. One should extract the combined product all at once, which is easily achieved if done properly. In the case of well-ground, purified cereals, one should donate its essence according to one's ability; similarly, for freshly prepared sugar, one should give a measure of one prastha (equivalent to around 1.25 liters). One should establish and then offer, along with pippali and tuga, the vessels filled with sugar and milk that have been properly shaken.

sloka: balyānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ bṛṃhaṇīyāśca yā daśa|  vayasaḥ sthāpanānāṃ ca khadirasyāsanasya ca||13||  kharjūrāṇāṃ madhūkānāṃ mustānāmutpalasya ca|  mṛdvīkānāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ vacāyāścitrakasya ca||14||  śatāvaryāḥ payasyāyāḥ pippalyā joṅgakasya ca|  ṛdhdyā nāgabalāyāśca dvāradāyā dhavasya ca||15||  triphalākaṇṭakāryośca vidāryāścandanasya ca|  ikṣūṇāṃ śaramūlānāṃ śrīparṇyāstiniśasya ca||16||  rasāḥ pṛthak pṛthaggrāhyāḥ palāśakṣāra eva ca|  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgān payo gavyaṃ caturguṇam||17||
translation: In a clean, earthen pot during the rainy season, fill it halfway with clarified butter. One should then add to it the amount of water equivalent to that of a full agnihotra measurement. Mix together powders of gold, copper, iron, crystal, pearl, coral, and silver, each a sixteenth of the water measure. After discarding the impurities, one should consume this mixture with milk and ghee in small portions, day after day.

sloka: dve pātre tilatailasya dve ca gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  tat sādhyaṃ sarvamekatra susiddhaṃ snehamuddharet||18||  tatrāmalakacūrṇānāmāḍhakaṃ śatabhāvitam |  svarasenaiva dātavyaṃ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca||19||  śarkarācūrṇapātraṃ ca prasthamekaṃ pradāpayet|  tugākṣīryāḥ sapippalyāḥ sthāpyaṃ sammūrcchitaṃ ca tat||20||
translation: It is the best antidote for all diseases, enhances longevity and complexion, improves digestive fire, intellect, strength of senses. It also increases vigor and gives color and tone to voice. Moreover, it stops the growth of ugliness and calms down all speech-related ailments.

sloka: sucaukṣe mārtike kumbhe māsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhāvite|  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya tata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet||21||  hematāmrapravālānāmayasaḥ sphaṭikasya ca|  muktāvaidūryaśaṅkhānāṃ cūrṇānāṃ rajatasya ca||22||  prakṣipya ṣoḍaśīṃ mātrāṃ vihāyāyāsamaithunam|  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā||23||
translation: The attainment of desired goals, youth, popularity, and fame in the world—this Brahminical excellence of great heroism should be properly utilized by those who desire it. (Indroktarasayanam, chapter 2, verse 26)

sloka: sarvarogapraśamanaṃ vṛṣyamāyuṣyamuttamam|  sattvasmṛtiśarīrāgnibuddhīndriyabalapradam||24||  paramūrjaskaraṃ caiva varṇasvarakaraṃ tathā|  viṣālakṣmīpraśamanaṃ sarvavācogatapradam||25||
translation: For the able, healthy, and disciplined, entering a hut is beneficial in an instant. However, for those who prefer solar or wind heat, the former method is superior and more difficult. If alchemy is disturbed, diseases will arise. Therefore, it is recommended to administer appropriate medicines to them separately, abandoning alchemy.

sloka: siddhārthatāṃ cābhinavaṃ vayaśca prajāpriyatvaṃ ca yaśaśca loke|  prayojyamicchadbhiridaṃ yathāvadrasāyanaṃ brāhmamudāravīryam||26||  (itīndroktarasāyanamaparam)|
translation: A truthful, calm, and self-controlled person; who is free from anger, alcohol, and lust; non-violent, effortless, and peaceful, speaking pleasing words; devoted to constant repetition of mantras, cleanliness, and patience; engaged in regular charity and austerities; respecting elders, gods, Brahmins, teachers, and the elderly; always practicing compassion, equanimity in waking and dream states, drinking only milk and ghee; aware of time, place, and circumstances; wise, egoless; leading a disciplined life without confusion; serving the wise and the revered elders; knowledgeable about dharma shastras and engaged in lifelong learning; such is the ideal person.

sloka: samarthānāmarogāṇāṃ dhīmatāṃ niyatātmanām|  kuṭīpraveśaḥ kṣaṇināṃ paricchadavatāṃ hitaḥ||27||  ato'nyathā tu ye teṣāṃ sauryamārutiko vidhiḥ|  tayoḥ śreṣṭhataraḥ pūrvo vidhiḥ satusuduṣkaraḥ||28||  rasāyanavidhibhraṃśājjāyeran vyādhayo yadi|  yathāsvamauṣadhaṃ teṣāṃ kāryaṃ muktvā rasāyanam||29||
translation: One who uses these means possessed of such qualities surely enjoys all the properties of the elixir as described. (Quoted from "Achara Rasayana")

sloka: satyavādinamakrodhaṃ nivṛttaṃ madyamaithunāt|  ahiṃsakamanāyāsaṃ praśāntaṃ priyavādinam||30||  japaśaucaparaṃ dhīraṃ dānanityaṃ tapasvinam|  devagobrāhmaṇācāryaguruvṛddhārcane ratam||31||  ānṛśaṃsyaparaṃ nityaṃ nityaṃ karuṇavedinam |  samajāgaraṇasvapnaṃ nityaṃ kṣīraghṛtāśinam||32||  deśakālapramāṇajñaṃ yuktijñamanahaṅkṛtam|  śastācāramasaṅkīrṇamadhyātmapravaṇendriyam||33||  upāsitāraṃ vṛddhānāmāstikānāṃ jitātmanām|  dharmaśāstraparaṃ vidyānnaraṃ nityarasāyanam||34||
translation:
The body and mind of a creature can never be free from faults; they are only temporarily pacified by the properties of medicines. Yogic practices, which prolong life and alleviate aging and disease, become effective only for those who have purified minds and bodies through diligent practice. This should not be spoken to those with impure minds and hearts, nor should servitude be offered to those outside of the twice-born class where it does not exist. (translated by M. Monier-Williams)
935,ये रसायनसंयोगा वृष्ययोगाश्च ये मताः।  यच्चौषधं विकाराणां सर्वं तद्वैद्यसंश्रयम्॥३९॥  प्राणाचार्यं बुधस्तस्माद्धीमन्तं वेदपारगम्।  अश्विनाविव देवेन्द्रः पूजयेदतिशक्तितः॥४०॥,"The teacher of the breath, the intellectually advanced, the one well-versed in the Vedas, and endowed with great power – such a one should worship the Ashvins, who are considered the cause of the formation of merging of rasa (taste, essence) and vrishya (virility-enhancing), and also the source of all medicinal herbs that counteract disorders.

sloka: guṇairetaiḥ samuditaiḥ prayuṅkte yo rasāyanam|  rasāyanaguṇān sarvān yathoktān sa samaśnute||35||  (ityācārarasāyanam)|
translation: The Asvins are remembered as the divine healers and the charioteers of the yajna (sacrificial ritual); with their assistance, the head of the yajna is restored and rejuvenated.

sloka: yathāsthūlamanirvāhya doṣāñchārīramānasān|  rasāyanaguṇairjanturyujyate na kadācana||36||  yogā hyāyuḥprakarṣārthā jarāroganibarhaṇāḥ|  manaḥśarīraśuddhānāṃ sidhyanti prayatātmanām||37||  tadetanna bhavedvācyaṃ sarvameva hatātmasu|  arujebhyo'dvijātibhyaḥ śuśrūṣā yeṣu nāsti ca||38||
translation: With dislodged teeth, sight lost, Bhaga's portion (genitals) amputated, and cured by those very weapons, the moon, afflicted by the royal fever, has been seized. And upon being struck by Soma, the moon, once again, becomes happy.

sloka: ye rasāyanasaṃyogā vṛṣyayogāśca ye matāḥ|  yaccauṣadhaṃ vikārāṇāṃ sarvaṃ tadvaidyasaṃśrayam||39||  prāṇācāryaṃ budhastasmāddhīmantaṃ vedapāragam|  aśvināviva devendraḥ pūjayedatiśaktitaḥ||40||
translation: The sage Bharadvaja, who desires progeny, an elderly man now and deformed, who has lost his natural color and voice, along with other numerous deeds, has become greatly venerable by the great-souled Indras and others. By them, hymns, mantras, various sacrificial rituals, and smoke are arranged for him by the twice-born.

sloka: aśvinau devabhiṣajau yajñavāhāviti smṛtau|  yajñasya hi śiraśchinnaṃ punastābhyāṃ samāhitam||41||
translation: In the morning, Indra and the Ashvins partake in the Soma offering together. The worshipful one also enjoys with the Ashvins during the Sautramani ritual. Indra and the Ashvins, as well as the two Asvins, are usually praised by the dvijas in the recitation of the Vedic mantras. No other deities are praised in this manner in the Vedic texts.

sloka: praśīrṇā daśanāḥ pūṣṇo netre naṣṭe bhagasya ca|  vajriṇaśca bhujastambhastābhyāmeva cikitsitaḥ||42||  cikitsitaśca śītāṃśurgṛhīto rājayakṣmaṇā|  somābhipatitaścandraḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaḥ sukhī||43||
translation: The Ashwins, who are immortal, constant associates of the wise gods, should be worshiped with careful attention. How much more so should physicians, who remove suffering from humans caused by death, disease, and old age, be worshiped, as they possess strength in this regard? A self-controlled, intelligent, knowledgeable dvija (twice-born) who is respectful toward all living beings should be considered a spiritual preceptor and be respected.

sloka: bhārgavaścyavanaḥ kāmī vṛddhaḥ san vikṛtiṃ gataḥ|  vītavarṇasvaropetaḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaryuvā||44||  etaiścānyaiśca bahubhiḥ karmabhirbhiṣaguttamau|  babhūvaturbhṛśaṃ pūjyāvindrādīnāṃmahātmanām||45||  grahāḥ stotrāṇi mantrāṇi tathā nānāhavīṃṣi ca|  dhūmrāśca  paśavastābhyāṃ prakalpyante dvijātibhiḥ||46||
translation: Upon completion of studies, a healer is called the second birth; attains the title of physician, not in previous birth. Whether it be brahminical or martial virtue, knowledge alone definitely pervades. Therefore, a physician is remembered as twice-born. One who does not contemplate, nor cry out, nor performs unrighteous deeds, such a wise person, seeking longevity, respects the teacher as the self.

sloka: prātaśca savane somaṃ śakro'śvibhyāṃ sahāśnute|  sautrāmaṇyāṃ ca bhagavānaśvibhyāṃ saha modate||47||  indrāgnī cāśvinau caiva stūyante prāyaśo dvijaiḥ|  stūyante vedavākyeṣu na tathā'nyā hi devatāḥ||48||
translation: A person, who after being approached as a physician, does not treat a patient whether he has previously sought treatment or not, there is no expiation for him in this world. Desiring to protect all patients from afflictions, just like his own sons, a doctor truly observes the supreme duty (dharma).

sloka: ajarairamaraistāvadvibudhaiḥ sādhipairdhruvaiḥ|  pūjyete prayatairevamaśvinaubhiṣajāviti||49||  mṛtyuvyādhijarāvaśyairduḥkhaprāyaiḥ sukhārthibhiḥ|  kiṃ punarbhiṣajo martyaiḥ pūjyāḥ syurnātiśaktitaḥ||50||  śīlavānmatimān yukto dvijātiḥ śāstrapāragaḥ|  prāṇibhirguruvat pūjyaḥ prāṇācāryaḥ sa hi smṛtaḥ||51||
translation: The Vedas, revealed by the great sages for the pursuit of Dharma and Artha, indicate an eternal reality; one who is engrossed in earning wealth through medical practice does not fully engage with it. Those who carry out medical treatment, trade, or commerce to earn a living, they worship a mere handful of wealth, abandoning a large amount. One who cuts the bonds of Vaivasvatas (sons of Vivasvan) while being tortured by cruel means and grants life, liberates himself from their control.

sloka: vidyāsamāptau bhiṣajo dvitīyā jātirucyate|  aśnute vaidyaśabdaṃ hi na vaidyaḥ pūrvajanmanā||52||  vidyāsamāptau brāhmaṃ vā sattvamārṣamathāpi vā|  dhruvamāviśati jñānāttasmādvaidyo dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ||53|| nābhidhyāyenna cākrośedahitaṃ na samācaret|  prāṇācāryaṃ budhaḥ kaścidicchannāyuranitvaram||54||
translation: न हि जीवितदानाद्धि दानमन्यद्विशिष्यते॥६१॥  परो भूतदया धर्म इति मत्वा चिकित्सया।  वर्तते यः स सिद्धार्थः सुखमत्यन्तमश्नुते॥६२॥

sloka: cikitsitastu saṃśrutya yovā'saṃśrutya mānavaḥ|  nopākaroti vaidyāya nāsti tasyeha niṣkṛtiḥ||55||  bhiṣagapyāturān sarvān svasutāniva yatnavān|  ābādhebhyo hi saṃrakṣedicchan dharmamanuttamam||56||
translation: In that place, the divine Amareśvara spoke to the chaste ascetics (brahmacārins) who have achieved great spiritual attainments (siddhas), regarding the origin of Ayurveda, the auspicious description of divine herbs, and the qualities of the elixir of life that grants longevity; all of this was revealed in connection with the origin of Ayurveda.

sloka: dharmārthaṃ cārthakāmārthamāyurvedo maharṣibhiḥ|  prakāśito dharmaparairicchadbhiḥ sthānamakṣaram||57||  nārthārthaṃ nāpi kāmārthamatha bhūtadayāṃ prati|  vartate yaścikitsāyāṃ sa sarvamativartate||58||  kurvate ye tu vṛttyarthaṃ cikitsāpaṇyavikrayam|  te hitvākāñcanaṃ rāśiṃ pāṃśurāśimupāsate||59||  dāruṇaiḥ kṛṣyamāṇānāṃ gadairvaivasvatakṣayam|  chittvā vaivasvatān pāśān jīvitaṃ yaḥ prayacchati||60||
translation: In the treatise composed by Agnivesha, after being edited by Charaka, in the section on therapeutics in the fourth chapter of the Ayurveda textbook, titled "Nāmarasāyana."

sloka: न हि जीवितदानाद्धि दानमन्यद्विशिष्यते॥६१॥  परो भूतदया धर्म इति मत्वा चिकित्सया।  वर्तते यः स सिद्धार्थः सुखमत्यन्तमश्नुते॥६२॥
translation: Now, I will explain the means of union, which is the first step in the ritual preparation (of a horse sacrifice). So said Bhagavan Atri.

sloka: tatra ślokau  āyurvedasamutthānaṃ divyauṣadhividhiṃ śubham|  amṛtālpāntaraguṇaṃ siddhaṃ ratnarasāyanam||63||  siddhebhyo brahmacāribhyo yaduvācāmareśvaraḥ|  āyurvedasamutthāne tat sarvaṃ samprakāśitam||64||
translation: The self-realized person should always seek to cultivate horse-like qualities; for him, duty and wealth, as well as pleasure and fame, become attached (to his nature).

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsitasthāne rasāyanādhyāye āyurvedasamutthānīyo nāmarasāyanapādaścaturthaḥ||4||
translation:
This (etad) is the resting place for the son, as well as these good qualities and daughter-in-law-supporting. The best among things that bring joy is horse sacrifice. 
950,(सङ्घातो हीन्द्रियार्थानां स्त्रीषु नान्यत्र विद्यते)।  स्त्र्याश्रयो हीन्द्रियार्थो यः स प्रीतिजननोऽधिकम्।  स्त्रीषु प्रीतिर्विशेषेण स्त्रीष्वपत्यं प्रतिष्ठितम्॥६॥,"The sensory pleasure derived from objects, which is not found elsewhere, resides in women. The one who partakes in this sensory pleasure with women is considered to be an intense source of happiness and the progeny becomes established in women. (Translation of Manu Smriti 2.6)

sloka: athātaḥ saṃyogaśaramūlīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Dharma and artha reside in women, as do beauty, youth, and adornments. The woman who is obedient, educated, and most virtuous, who is revered by society, is considered the most worthy. Through various forms of devotion and divine coincidence, such a woman is established in the world. (Translation based on Swami Gambhirananda's translation of Vidyasagara's commentary)

sloka: vājīkaraṇamanvicchet puruṣo nityamātmavān|  tadāyattau hi dharmārthau prītiśca yaśa eva ca||3||
translation: Upon attaining whom, qualities such as physical appearance and strengths flourish; whose paramour is the one who possesses excellent attributes of age, beauty, and speech.

sloka: putrasyāyatanaṃ hyetadguṇāścaite sutāśrayāḥ| vājīkaraṇamagryaṃ ca kṣetraṃ strī yā praharṣiṇī||4||  iṣṭā hyokaikaśo'pyarthā paraṃ prītikarā smṛtāḥ|  kiṃ punaḥ strīśarīre ye saṅghātena pratiṣṭhitāḥ||5||
translation: Entering quickly into the heart, whether by destiny or actions, those that are equally balanced in their thinking; those that are of a similar nature and are capable of being controlled, those that are pleasing to one's beloveds, and those that have become like bonds to all of the senses due to their qualities.

sloka: (saṅghāto hīndriyārthānāṃ strīṣu nānyatra vidyate)|  stryāśrayo hīndriyārtho yaḥ sa prītijanano'dhikam|  strīṣu prītirviśeṣeṇa strīṣvapatyaṃ pratiṣṭhitam||6||
translation: By which a person, detached from the world, is considered to be engrossed in the feminine. Without which one's body does not retain its form, as if empty without the senses. Upon seeing whom, one is not overwhelmed by sorrow, fear, or agitation. Attaining which, one becomes extremely delighted. Constantly rushing towards which with intense eagerness. And even after reaching it many times, still never feels satisfied.

sloka: dharmārthau strīṣu lakṣmīśca strīṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ|  surūpā yauvanasthā yā lakṣaṇairyā vibhūṣitā||7||  yā vaśyā śikṣitā yā ca sā strī vṛṣyatamā matā|   nānābhaktyā tu lokasya daivayogācca yoṣitām||8||
translation: That woman, most fertile of his, diverse in nature are the human beings, of equal lineage and also fertile, see her delightful and free from disturbances.

sloka: taṃ taṃ prāpya vivardhante naraṃ rūpādayo guṇāḥ|  vayorūpavacohāvairyā yasya paramāṅganā||9||
translation: A healthy man, who desires offspring, should approach a woman who has bathed and is pure. Like a tree that bears no fruit, with only one branch, offering no shade, yielding no results, and having an unpleasant smell, a childless man who is without support, resembling a barren lake, with the appearance of a post, and bereft of all sensory abilities, should be considered as such. A man devoid of activity, who has no offspring, should also be regarded in the same way.

sloka: praviśatyāśu hṛdayaṃ daivādvā karmaṇo'pi vā|  hṛdayotsavarūpā yā yā samānamanaḥśayā||10||  samānasattvā yā vaśyā yā yasya prīyate priyaiḥ|  yā pāśabhūtā sarveṣāmindriyāṇāṃ parairguṇaiḥ||11||
translation: Having many forms, many mouths, many deeds, having many eyes, all-knowing, possessing a large number of qualities, prolific, praised as "having many branches," providing happiness, strength, prosperity, growth, fame, well-being, and nourishment to the world, bringing satisfaction along with offspring, one should desire for such offspring who possess these qualities and are endowed with them. Always engaged in increasing one's prowess and fulfilling one's desires, attain happiness, prosperity, and growth of virility through such offspring.

sloka: yayā viyukto nistrīkamaratirmanyate jagat|  yasyā ṛte śarīraṃ nā dhatte śūnyamivendriyaiḥ||12||  śokodvegāratibhayairyāṃ dṛṣṭvā nābhibhūyate|  yāti yāṃ prāpya visrambhaṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣyatyatīva yām||13||  apūrvāmiva yāṃ yāti nityaṃ harṣātivegataḥ|  gatvā gatvā'pi bahuśo yāṃ tṛptiṃ naiva gacchati||14||
translation: I will explain further about the preparation of medicinal decoction. The ingredients are: the roots of Vaajika, Kasha, Arka, and Shatavari plants, the fruit of Payasya, the stinging nettle plant, Jivanti, Jivaka, Meda, Vira, and Charishva; the resin of Gokshura; and the root of Punarnava. The quantities are: three Palas each of Vaajika, Kasha, Arka, Payasya, Jivanti, Jivaka, Meda, and Vira; two Palas of Charishva and Gokshura resin; and one Pala of Punarnava root.

sloka: sā strī vṛṣyatamā tasya nānābhāvā hi mānavāḥ|  atulyagotrāṃ vṛṣyāṃ ca prahṛṣṭāṃ nirupadravām||15||
translation: The physician should prepare a quarter of the juice from cloud-like jujube, and press out separately the juices of madhuka, draksha, phalgugani, and pippalii. He should protect the self's madhukas and split open the amalaka fruits, extracting their juice separately. The physician should give a measure of ghee and a measure of thickened milk, treat the remaining ghee and mix it with well-strained sugar. He should make a powder of sharkara, tugaraka, ela, kesara, each in measures of four and eight prasthas. He should also make a powder of twaga, leka, and kesharas, each in measures of half and one prastha. The physician should prepare two measures of madhu with the help of kudava vessels.

sloka: śuddhasnātāṃ vrajennārīmapatyārthī nirāmayaḥ|  acchāyaścaikaśākhaśca niṣphalaśca yathā drumaḥ||16||  aniṣṭagandhaścaikaśca nirapatyastathā naraḥ|  citradīpaḥ saraḥ śuṣkamadhāturdhātusannibhaḥ||17||  niṣprajastṛṇapūlīti mantavyaḥ puruṣākṛtiḥ|  apratiṣṭhaśca nagnaśca śūnyaścaikendriyaśca nā||18||  mantavyo niṣkriyaścaiva yasyāpatyaṃ na vidyate|
translation: Just as fire kindles the pieces of dry wood, similarly this aphrodisiac is the supreme means for increasing virility and strength. With this, a strong man may metaphorically 'mount' his wife (in sexual intercourse). (from Brimhani Gutika)

sloka: bahumūrtirbahumukho bahuvyūho bahukriyaḥ||19||  bahucakṣurbahujñāno bahvātmā ca bahuprajaḥ|  maṅgalye'yaṃ praśasyo'yaṃ dhanyo'yaṃ vīryavānayam||20||  bahuśākho'yamiti ca stūyate nā bahuprajaḥ|  prītirbalaṃ sukhaṃ vṛttirvistāro vipulaṃ  kulam||21||  yaśo lokāḥ sukhodarkāstuṣṭiścāpatyasaṃśritāḥ|  tasmādapatyamanvicchan guṇāṃścāpatyasaṃśritān||22||  vājīkaraṇanityaḥ syādicchan kāmasukhāni ca|  upabhogasukhān siddhān vīryāpatyavivardhanān||23||
translation: To protect the seeds, cultivate nine varieties of grains such as medaka, sadhye kudavonmita, adding a prastha of ghee in the juice of that plant, a dashaguṇa of milk, a prastha each of the juices of vidari andiksu, and a prastha of honey and ashvagandha.

sloka: vājīkaraṇasaṃyogān pravakṣyāmyata uttaram| śaramūlekṣumūlāni kāṇḍekṣuḥ sekṣuvālikā||24||  śatāvarī payasyā ca vidārī kaṇṭakārikā|  jīvantī jīvako medā vīrā carṣabhako balā||25||  ṛddhirgokṣurakaṃ rāsnā sātmaguptā punarnavā|  eṣāṃ tripalikān bhāgān  māṣāṇāmāḍhakaṃ navam||26||
translation: Having cooked the offering with a soft fire, one should carefully place ghee and, separately, sugar, curd, and kshaudra. Then, one should offer a portion of each of the four ingredients along with a portion of pippali fruit. After adding the initial portion, one should then offer the food. (This is) the ritual for extracting the finest and most potent sperm.

sloka: vipācayejjaladroṇe caturbhāgaṃ ca śeṣayet|  tatra peṣyāṇi madhukaṃ drākṣā phalgūni pippalī||27||  ātmaguptā madhukāni kharjūrāṇi śatāvarī|  vidāryāmalakekṣūṇāṃ rasasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ dadyāt kṣīradroṇaṃ ca tadbhiṣak|  sādhayedghṛtaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaṃ yojayet punaḥ||29||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāścūrṇaiḥ prasthonmitaiḥ pṛthak|  palaiścaturbhirmāgadhyāḥ palena maricasya ca||30||  tvagelākeśarāṇāṃ ca cūrṇairardhapalonmitaiḥ|  madhunaḥ kuḍavābhyāṃ ca dvābhyāṃ tatkārayedbhiṣak||31||
translation: Prepare a mixture of sugar, grain similar in size to a barleycorn, curds, milk, and ghee. Cook this with six parts of wheat flour until it becomes neither overcooked nor too soft. Add it to a kukkuta (a type of bird, possibly chicken) in a broth that is warm, scented, and sweet-tasting. This mixture, when consumed, will be invigorating, nutritious, and strength-enhancing.

sloka: palikā gulikāstyānāstā  yathāgni prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo bṛṃhaṇo balavardhanaḥ||32||  anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī liṅgaṃ samarpayet|33| (iti bṛṃhaṇīguṭikā)
translation: With this (strength), a horse-like man is set in motion; the mark of a bird's crest is considered as such, i.e., a distinguishing feature of those possessing strength, beauty, and good voice. A man becomes vigorous through that (combination of strength, beauty, and good voice).

sloka: māṣāṇāmātmaguptāyā bījānāmāḍhakaṃ navam||33||  jīvakarṣabhakau vīrāṃ medāmṛddhiṃ śatāvarīm|  madhukaṃ cāśvagandhāṃ ca sādhyet kuḍavonmitām||34||  rase tasmin ghṛtaprasthaṃ gavyaṃ daśaguṇaṃ payaḥ|  vidārīṇāṃ rasaprasthaṃ prasthamikṣurasasya ca||35||
translation: Prepare a mixture of one Uttara-Fana ghee and sixteen Palas of pure, filtered, and sour gruel. This is a superior, nutritious, and energizing rasayana (tonic). (from Vrishyamahisharasa)

sloka: dattvā mṛdvagninā sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ sarpirnidhāpayet|  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||36||  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalāṃstatra pippalyāścāvapet palam| palaṃ pūrvamato līḍhvā tato'nnamupayojayet||37||  ya icchedakṣayaṃ śukraṃ śephasaścottamaṃ balam|38| (iti vājīkaraṇaṃ ghṛtam)
translation: In the curds, let the tittiri bird drink the taste of the titttiri, and in the chicken, the chicken's taste. Let the swan drink only the barhin's taste in the barhin, and in the duck, the duck's taste. One should prepare tastes in the new sap of sesame that are sweet, pleasant-smelling, and strength-enhancing, according to one's own nature. (Other aphrodisiac tastes)

sloka: śarkarā māṣavidalāstugākṣīrī payo ghṛtam||38||  godhūmacūrṇaṣaṣṭhāni sarpiṣyutkārikāṃ pacet|  tāṃ nātipakvāṃ mṛditāṃ kaukkuṭe madhure rase||39||  sugandhe prakṣipeduṣṇe yathā sāndrībhavedrasaḥ|  eṣa piṇḍaraso vṛṣyaḥ pauṣṭiko balavardhanaḥ||40||
translation: The one who, after going to a Chataka bird's feeding place and drinking its collected water, does not experience limpness or loss of semen at night.

sloka: anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī  liṅgaṃ samarpayet| śikhitittirihaṃsānāmevaṃ piṇḍaraso mataḥ|  balavarṇasvarakaraḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||41||  (iti vājīkaraṇapiṇḍarasāḥ [2] )
translation: One who has consumed a measure of barley gruel mixed with ghee, and drinks milk in the night after finishing sixty such meals, is said to be staying awake throughout the night. (This refers to an ascetic practice known as Vrishyamasha Yoga.)

sloka: ghṛtaṃ māṣān sabastāṇḍān sādhayenmāhiṣe rase|  bharjayettaṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ phalāmlaṃ navasarpiṣi||42||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktaṃ dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  eṣa vṛṣyaśca balyaśca bṛṃhaṇaśca rasottamaḥ||43||  (iti vṛṣyamāhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: He who never dozes off during the nights, with a steady and unflinching gaze, satisfied after consuming cockerel meat, and smeared with the fat of a crocodile. (This is from the text "Vrishya's Use of Cockerel".)

sloka: caṭakāṃstittirirase tittirīn kaukkuṭe rase|  kukkuṭān bārhiṇarase hāṃse bārhiṇameva ca||44||  navasarpiṣi santaptān phalāmlān kārayedrasān|  madhurān vā yathāsātmyaṃ gandhāḍhyān balavardhanān||45||  (ityanye vṛṣyarasāḥ)
translation: Having extracted the liquid essence of fish and mixed it with clarified butter, one should consume; similarly, only those adept in the vow of Hansabarhini should consume such mixtures. (End of the section on the essence of Vrishyaanda)

sloka: tṛptiṃ caṭakamāṃsānāṃ gatvā yo'nupibet payaḥ|  na tasya liṅgaśaithilyaṃ syānna śukrakṣayo niśi||46||  (iti vṛṣyamāṃsam)
translation: When in a pure, clean body, the flow of vital fluid (semen) is not controlled at the appropriate time, then the person becomes lustful. That augmentation is conducive to strength. Therefore, purification should be performed according to one's capacity. For, efforts aimed at controlling the vital fluid do not bear fruit when the body is impure, just as attempts to clean a dirty cloth are futile.

sloka: māṣayūṣeṇa yo bhuktvā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  payaḥ pibati rātriṃ sa kṛtsnāṃ jāgarti vegavān||47||  (iti vṛṣyamāṣayogaḥ)
translation: In that [text], the field of horse-powering, consisting of a wife and other inherent qualities; the ten virtues and five types of union, which promote heroism and offspring, are mentioned in the foot of the Sarmauliya tree as promoting strength and nourishment.

sloka: na nā svapiti rātriṣu nityastabdhena śephasā|  tṛptaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsānā bhṛṣṭānāṃ nakraretasi||48||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsaprayogaḥ)
translation: Now I will explain the process of churning butter from curd. This is according to what has been said by Bhagavan Atri.

sloka: niḥsrāvya matsyāṇḍarasaṃ bhṛṣṭaṃ sarpiṣi bhakṣayet|  haṃsabarhiṇadakṣāṇāmevamaṇḍāni bhakṣayet||49||  (iti vṛṣyo'ṇḍarasaḥ)
translation: Having churned the milk that is full of water and made it devoid of water, one should take the separated cream and mix it with cow's milk. This is to be used for nourishing seeds, grains, the roots of plants like ऋddhīvṛkṣa, kakola, elephant apple, licheni, madhuka, śatāvarī, vidāra, drākṣā, kharjūra, and for making medicinal powders out of the pulses such as tuṅgaka, śālī, ṣaṣṭikas, godhūma.

sloka: bhavataścātra  srotaḥsu śuddheṣvamale śarīre vṛṣyaṃ yadā nā  mitamatti kāle|  vṛṣāyate tena paraṃ manuṣyastadbṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva balapradaṃ ca||50||  tasmāt purā śodhanameva kāryaṃ balānurūpaṃ na hi vṛṣyayogāḥ|  sidhyanti dehe maline prayuktāḥ kliṣṭe  yathā vāsasi rāgayogāḥ||51||
translation: One should churn the sandalwood to obtain a large quantity of its fragrant paste, which is comparable to honey and sugar in sweetness. When used in a fire, along with a diet of milk and fatty foods, it results in the birth of many worthy offspring, even for an aged person. (This is from "Sixty Precepts for the Wife," a text on householder duties.)

sloka: tatra ślokau  vājīkaraṇasāmarthyaṃ kṣetraṃ strī yasya caiva yā|  ye doṣā nirapatyānāṃ guṇāḥ putravatāṃ ca ye||52||  daśa pañca ca saṃyogā vīryāpatyavivardhanāḥ|  uktāste śaramūlīye pāde puṣṭibalapradāḥ||53||
translation: He who is skilled in caring for cuckoos, knows the proper time for hawks and is a doctor to both tortoises and serpents; who also knows the remedy of administering the fat of a boar, the oil from a cow, and the powders of sixty-four medicinal plants and licorice.

sloka: athāta āsiktakṣīrikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: With these [ingredients], cakes and rice dishes, as well as various other snacks, are to be prepared. By using these for consumption, a man's lustfulness will rise up to the level of that of a stallion, as much as he desires, even if he is with his wife. (From Vrishya-pūpalikādiyogaḥ)

sloka: āsiktakṣīramāpūrṇamaśuṣkaṃ śuddhaṣaṣṭikam|  udūkhale  samāpothya pīḍayet kṣīramarditam||3||  gṛhītvā taṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ gavyena payasā saha|  bījānāmātmaguptāyā dhānyamāṣarasena ca||4||  balāyāḥ śūrpaparṇyośca jīvantyā jīvakasya ca [2] |  ṛddhyarṣabhakakākolīśvadaṃṣṭrāmadhukasya ca||5||  śatāvaryā vidāryāśca drākṣākharjūrayorapi|  saṃyuktaṃ mātrayā vaidyaḥ sādhayettatra cāvapet||6||  tugākṣīryāḥ samāṣāṇāṃ śālīnāṃ ṣaṣṭikasya ca|  godhūmānāṃ ca cūrṇāni yaiḥ sa sāndrībhavedrasaḥ||7||
translation: Procure, with due measure, a hundred dates, licorice, asphaltum, muntingia tree fruit, and madhuka tree fruit. Mix this with an equal quantity of pure water and ghee, each measured in a prastha. Purify yourself and your utensils, and consume this mixture. (verses 14-15)

sloka: sāndrībhūtaṃ ca kuryāt prabhūtamadhuśarkaram|  guli(ṭi)kā badaraistulyāstāśca sarpiṣi bharjayet||8||  tā yathāgni prayuñjānaḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśanaḥ|  paśyatyapatyaṃ vipulaṃ vṛddho'pyātmajamakṣayam||9||  (ityapatyakarī ṣaṣṭikādiguṭikā)
translation: One who daily consumes a mixture of fresh curd and sugar candy, sweetened with sugar, in addition to drinking cow's urine and consuming sesame seeds, will through this practice, find strength even in old age and rejoice in having many offspring and youthfulness. (Quoted from "The Secret of Increasing Offspring")

sloka: caṭakānāṃ sahaṃsānāṃ dakṣāṇāṃ śikhināṃ tathā|  śiśumārasya nakrasya bhiṣak śukrāṇi saṃharet||10||  gavyaṃ sarpirvarāhasya kuliṅgasya vasāmapi|  ṣaṣṭikānāṃ ca cūrṇāni cūrṇaṃ godhūmakasya  ca||11||
translation: A wise man should prepare a meal for six people using the following ingredients in the specified quantities: 100 Pala (approximately 3.2 liters) of milk, enough sugar to make it sweet, five Kharjuri fruits (sugar palm fruits), two Masa (black gram) seeds, 100 Shatavari roots (asparagus roots), five Kharjura fruits (dates), five Madhuka fruits (Madhuca indica fruits), five Mrudvika fruits (Randia dumetorum fruits), and five Ajada fruits (Strychnos potatorum fruits). The remaining portion of the milk should be used to prepare one Prastha (approximately 0.4 liters) of Kshira (condensed milk). This meal, when consumed with sugar, is considered to be highly nutritious and invigorating. (End of Vrishyaksheeram)

sloka: ebhiḥ pūpalikāḥ kāryāḥ śaṣkulyo vartikāstathā|  pūpā dhānāśca vividhā bhakṣyāścānye pṛthagvidhāḥ||12||  eṣāṃ prayogādbhakṣyāṇāṃ stabdhenāpūrṇaretasā|  śephasā vājivadyāti yāvadicchaṃ striyo naraḥ||13||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikādiyogāḥ)
translation: The two months of Shravana, jujube, honey, grapes, long pepper, and the universal medicine, pippali;

sloka: ātmaguptāphalaṃ māṣān kharjūrāṇi śatāvarīm|  śṛṅgāṭakāni mṛdvīkāṃ sādhayet prasṛtonmitam||14||  kṣīraprasthaṃ jalaprasthametat prasthāvaśeṣitam|  śuddhena vāsasā pūtaṃ yojayet prasṛtaistribhiḥ||15||
translation: With a clear intellect, one should mix together in a clean new pot, filled with cool, clarified butter, the churned cream that is like the autumn moon, free of defects and tinged with saffron, sugar, and camphor. After consuming a small quantity of this sweet liquid, along with sixty quantities of the rice-based dish, a man becomes strong and virile. (The practice of making oneself virile through the consumption of cow's milk products.)

sloka: śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ sarpiṣo'bhinavasya ca|  tat pāyayeta sakṣaudraṃ ṣaṣṭikānnaṃ ca bhojayet||16||  jarāparīto'pyabalo yogenānena vindati|  naro'patyaṃ suvipulaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||17||  (ityapatyakaraḥ svarasaḥ)
translation: Consuming a rice pudding made with milk equivalent to the moon's rays, enriched with ghee, containing sixty-six ingredients and mixed with sugar and honey can make one fertile. (This is the ritual of consuming sixty-six ingredient rice pudding.)

sloka: kharjūrīmastakaṃ māṣān payasyāṃ ca śatāvarīm|  kharjūrāṇi madhūkāni mṛdvīkāmajaḍāphalam||18||  palonmitāni matimān [4] sādhayet salilāḍhake|  tena pādāvaśeṣeṇa kṣīraprasthaṃ vipācayet||19||  kṣīraśeṣeṇa tenādyād ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  saśarkareṇa saṃyoga eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ smṛtaḥ||20||  (iti vṛṣyakṣīram)
translation: Having heated up the ghee, mixed with copper sulfate, and combined it with sixty-four finely ground pieces of ghee, one should cook small cakes. Having eaten these Vrishya cakes, a person will be able to go the speed of a horse and have the strength of an elephant, (as per the description of Vrishya Pūpalikās)

sloka: jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ śrāvaṇīdvayam|  kharjūraṃ madhukaṃ drākṣāṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||21||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ vidārīṃ ca navaṃ sarpiḥ payo jalam|  siddhaṃ ghṛtāvaśeṣaṃ taccharkarākṣaudrapādikam||22||  ṣaṣṭikānnena saṃyuktamupayojyaṃ yathābalam|  vṛṣyaṃ balyaṃ ca varṇyaṃ ca kaṇṭhyaṃ bṛṃhaṇamuttamam||23||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtam)
translation: With these practices, he becomes strong and accomplished in valor, powerful, and possessing a fine physique. He is exhilarated, like a horse in its eighth year, and is capable in courting women. Also, whatever pleasing to the mind, such as beautiful groves, riverbanks, mountains, desired women, ornaments, fragrant garlands, and dear friends, are all appropriate for him here. (translated by Sreejita Bertilsson)

sloka: dadhnaḥ saraṃ śaraccandrasannibhaṃ doṣavarjitam|  śarkarākṣaudramaricaistugākṣīryā ca buddhimān||24||  yuktyā yuktaṃ sasūkṣmailaṃ nave kumbhe [5] śucau paṭe|  mārjitaṃ prakṣipecchīte ghṛtāḍhye ṣaṣṭikaudane||25||  pibenmātrāṃ rasālāyāstaṃ bhuktvā ṣaṣṭikaudanam [6] |  varṇasvarabalopetaḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||26||  (vṛṣyo dadhisaraprayogaḥ)
translation: In the work "Agnivesha Tantra" and its revised version "Caraka Pratisamskrita," in the section on therapies , specifically in the second chapter named "Asiktakshiriko," the following verse is found: "Yogah parikirtitah ashtau vatyakamaish te prayojyah." It means: "The eight forms of yoga mentioned [in this text] should be employed by those seeking virility."

sloka: candrāṃśukalpaṃ payasā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  śarkarāmadhusaṃyuktaṃ prayuñjāno vṛṣāyate||27||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ ṣaṣṭikaudanaprayogaḥ)
translation: Now we will explain the portion relating to the procedure for sowing Maasha (black gram) seeds, as was said by Bhagvan Atri.

sloka: tapte sarpiṣi nakrāṇḍaṃ tāmracūḍāṇḍamiśritam|  yuktaṃ ṣaṣṭikacūrṇena sarpiṣā'bhinavena ca||28|| paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedvāruṇīmaṇḍapo naraḥ|  ya icchedaśvavadgantuṃ prasektuṃ gajavacca yaḥ||29||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation: A wise man should milk a cow that is well-fed, has four teats, is of the same color as its hide, alive and healthy. It can be a Rohini or a Krishna with an upward horn or even one that gives excellent sweet milk, like the Arjuna plant. The milk from such a cow, consumed either boiled or unboiled, mixed with sugar, salt, or ghee, is considered the best source of nourishment.

sloka: bhavataścātra  etaiḥ prayogairvidhivadvapuṣmān vīryopapanno [7] balavarṇayuktaḥ|  harṣānvito vājivadaṣṭavarṣo bhavet samarthaśca varāṅganāsu||30|| yadyacca kiñcinmanasaḥ priyaṃ syādramyā vanāntāḥ pulināni śailāḥ|  iṣṭāḥ striyo bhūṣaṇagandhamālyaṃ priyā vayasyāśca tadatra yogyam [8] ||31||
translation: With rice flour, ghee, sugar, and salt, separately prepare milk that is enriched with nutrients and promotes strength. If one desires to make the semen inexhaustible, this should be used as a substitute in the form of a mixture with ground gram, jaggery, and sendha namak.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  āsiktakṣīrike pāde ye yogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  aṣṭāvapatyakāmaiste prayojyāḥ pauruṣārthibhiḥ||32||  ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne vājīkaraṇādhyāye āsiktakṣīriko nāma vājīkaraṇapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: One who extracts from meda (buttermilk) the living microorganisms in payasya (butter milk), the gritty kantakarika (sand particles), the teeth of a dog, and the ksirika (cream or curdled milk), as well as the masa (beans), godhuma (wheat), sasi (barley), and shashtikas (rice) found in it;

sloka: athāto māṣaparṇabhṛtīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The buttermilk, born of her own form, is churned with her circles (arms). Through this, the act of giving birth to a child is accomplished, mixed with ghee and curd.

sloka: māṣaparṇabhṛtāṃ dhenuṃ gṛṣṭiṃ puṣṭāṃ catuḥstanīm|  samānavarṇavatsāṃ ca jīvadvatsāṃ ca buddhimān||3||  rohiṇīmathavā kṛṣṇāmūrdhvaśṛṅgīmadāruṇām|  ikṣvādāmarjunādāṃ vā sāndrakṣīrāṃ ca dhārayet||4||  kevalaṃ tu payastasyāḥ śṛtaṃ vā'śṛtameva vā|  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhiryuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||5||
translation: Consuming thirty leaves of the supure Pippal tree, steeped in oil and clarified butter, mixed with sugar and flowing like a stream of milk, quenches one's thirst. After drinking an appropriate amount, if one then consumes sixty grams of a mixture made from rice, cow ghee, and sweetened condensed milk, they will not see any unresolved bodily waste or urine the next morning. (This is known as the Pippali yoga.) Additionally, chewing on sugarcane mixed with the juice of shvadamstraa (a type of plant) that has been split open and combined with four times the amount of ghee makes one virile. (This is known as the Virshya payasa yoga.)

sloka: śukralairjīvanīyaiśca bṛṃhaṇairbalavardhanaiḥ|  kṣīrasañjananaiścaiva payaḥ siddhaṃ pṛthak pṛthak||6||  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  paryāyeṇa prayoktavyamicchatā śukramakṣayam||7||
translation:
The lump should be made of ripe fruits that are juicy, flavorful, and agreeable. Similarly, for roasted barley and powdered sesame and urad dal, the lump should be made separately. Only a small portion of ghee is needed when it is mixed with milk. After cooking, one should eat these balls in large quantities to increase semen. (Translation by Sridhar Krishnaswami)

Note: This passage describes a recipe for "vrisyapulpali," a type of food ball that is said to increase semen and sexual vitality. It comes from the ancient Indian medical text, the Susruta Samhita.

sloka: medāṃ payasyāṃ jīvantīṃ vidārīṃ kaṇṭakārikām|  śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kṣīrikāṃ māṣān godhūmāñchāliṣaṣṭikān||8||  payasyardhodake paktvā  kārṣikānāḍhakonmite|  vivarjayet payaḥśeṣaṃ tat pūtaṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā||9||  yuktaṃ saśarkaraṃ pītvā vṛddhaḥ saptatiko'pi vā|  vipulaṃ labhate'patyaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||10||
translation: The butter churned from the heart of Shatavari, when cooked in milk with ten times its quantity of sugar, jaggery, and black pepper, becomes the supreme aphrodisiac. (This is known as Shatavari ghee.)

sloka: maṇḍalairjātarūpasya tasyā eva payaḥ śṛtam|  apatyajananaṃ siddhaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram||11||
translation: The one who regularly consumes, as a daily habit, an admixture of honey and sesame or clarified butter, will never become fat. (Vrsyamadhukayoga)
