sloka: triṃśat supiṣṭāḥ pippalyaḥ prakuñce tailasarpiṣoḥ|  bhṛṣṭāḥ saśarkarākṣaudrāḥ kṣīradhārāvadohitāḥ||12||  pītvā yathābalaṃ cordhvaṃ ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  bhuktvā na rātrimastabdhaṃ liṅgaṃ paśyati nā kṣarat||13||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ pippalīyogaḥ) śvadaṃṣṭrāyā vidāryāśca rase kṣīracaturguṇe|  ghṛtāḍhyaḥ sādhito vṛṣyo māṣaṣaṣṭikapāyasaḥ||14|| (iti vṛṣyapāyasayogaḥ)
translation: A man who constantly consumes clarified butter and milk, is fearless, free from ailments, ever-steady, and always inclined towards making decisions; such a man excites women.

sloka: phalānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ snigdhānāṃ rucikāriṇām|  kuḍavaścūrṇitānāṃ syāt svayaṅguptāphalasya ca||15||  kuḍavaścaiva māṣāṇāṃ dvau dvau ca tilamudgayoḥ|  godhūmaśālicūrṇānāṃ kuḍavaḥ kuḍavo bhavet||16||  sarpiṣaḥ kuḍavaścaikastat sarvaṃ kṣīramarditam [1] |  paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedbahvyaḥ syuryasya yoṣitaḥ||17||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation: Those who have completed their duties, achieved their purpose, and follow the ways of others; those skilled and equal in arts and age. With noble lineage, humility, cleanliness, accompanied by good qualities, free from desires, joyful, content, and free from suffering. Who are equal-minded, devoted, dear, and who speak pleasing words. One should associate with such men confidently; they elevate one's virtues and strength. (21-23)

sloka: ghṛtaṃ śatāvarīgarbhaṃ kṣīre daśaguṇe pacet|  śarkarāpippalīkṣaudrayuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||18||  (iti vṛṣyaṃ śatāvarīghṛtam)
translation:
With preferred scents, anointments, and snacks,
And with garlands, ornaments, and loved apparel;
With the pleasant chirping of birds,
And with the sounds of women's ornaments,
And with the courting of wives and beloved women,
The king rejoices in his desired elephants.

sloka: karṣaṃ madhukacūrṇasya ghṛtakṣaudrasamāṃśikam [1] |  prayuṅkte yaḥ payaścānu [2] nityavegaḥ sa nā bhavet||19||  (iti vṛṣyamadhukayogaḥ)
translation: Ponds adorned with lotuses, fragrant and cool, served by the bees; rivers with foaming waves, blue mountains, and nights that resemble the rising of a dark cloud are all engaged in their respective pursuits.

sloka: ghṛtakṣīrāśano nirbhīrnirvyādhirnityago yuvā|  saṅkalpapravaṇo nityaṃ naraḥ strīṣu vṛṣāyate||20||
translation: The winds are pleasantly touchable, fragrant like jasmine, capable of giving romantic pleasure at night, and they contract and expand at suitable times. They are helpful, nourishing and destructive, full of blooming forests, clear and provide sustenance. They are also the source of the sounds of Gandharvas (celestial musicians) and fragrant scents. The atmosphere is expansive, peaceful and free from disturbances. The son has fulfillment, renewal, desire, a woman, weapon, and everything in this world. Time is the cause of joy and is most supreme among men in the form of youth and age.

sloka: kṛtaikakṛtyāḥ siddhārthā ye cānyo'nyānuvartinaḥ|  kalāsu kuśalāstulyāḥ sattvena vayasā ca ye||21||  kulamāhātmyadākṣiṇyaśīlaśaucasamanvitāḥ|  ye kāmanityā ye hṛṣṭā ye viśokā gatavyathāḥ||22||  ye tulyaśīlā ye bhaktā ye priyā ye priyaṃvadāḥ|  tairnaraḥ saha visrabdhaḥ suvayasyairvṛṣāyate||23||
translation: In that [text], ten joy-producing yogic techniques have been explained in the fifth pada (section) of this chapter, which bestow the strength of Shukra (semen). [Verse 31]

sloka: abhyaṅgotsādanasnānagandhamālyavibhūṣaṇaiḥ|  gṛhaśayyāsanasukhairvāsobhirahataiḥ priyaiḥ||24||  vihaṅgānāṃ rutairiṣṭaiḥ strīṇāṃ cābharaṇasvanaiḥ|  saṃvāhanairvarastrīṇāmiṣṭānāṃ ca vṛṣāyate||25||
translation: Now, we will explain the means of acquiring strength and vigor, as stated by Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: mattadvirephācaritāḥ sapadmāḥ salilāśayāḥ|  jātyutpalasugandhīni śītagarbhagṛhaṇi ca||26||  nadyaḥ phenottarīyāśca girayo nīlasānavaḥ|  unnatirnīlameghānāṃ ramyacandrodayā niśāḥ||27||
translation: A man who is strong since birth should approach women to the extent of his desire, and can immediately become a father. This is what will be prescribed. Not all men who are strong since birth are endowed with progeny, nor are all large and powerful men found among women, some indeed have few resources.

sloka: vāyavaḥ sukhasaṃsparśāḥ kumudākaragandhinaḥ|  ratibhogakṣamā rātryaḥ  saṅkocāguruvallabhāḥ||28||  sukhāḥ sahāyāḥ parapuṣṭaghuṣṭāḥ phullā vanāntā viśadānnapānāḥ|  gāndharvaśabdāśca sugandhayogāḥ sattvaṃ viśālaṃ nirupadravaṃ ca||29||  siddhārthatā cābhinavaśca kāmaḥ strī cāyudhaṃ sarvamihātmajasya|  vayo navaṃ jātamadaśca kālo harṣasya yoniḥ paramā narāṇām||30||
translation: In women, strength is found in many, while some are naturally weak and others are unsteady. Some men wander aimlessly amongst women like the chakravaka bird, while others indiscriminately drench themselves like an elephant. Some gain strength through the combination of time, opportunity, and effort, while others become strong due to their inherent nature. Therefore, we shall describe methods for giving strength to the weak, which will also increase the pleasure and power of the strong. First, one should administer tonics to those with pure bodies and a tendency towards seminal debility. The containers used for this purpose should be filled with ghee, oil, milk, sugar, and honey, and should be suitable for those who consume dairy and meat products.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  praharṣayonayo yogā vyākhyātā daśa pañca ca|  māṣaparṇabhṛtīye'smin pāde śukrabalapradāḥ [2] ||31||
translation: After grinding varāha meat, offering it to Marici and Saindhava, and making kola-shaped pieces, after frying them in ghee, these should be stirred. When stirred, they become stiff.

sloka: athātaḥ pumāñjātabalādikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Just as a chick does not break the eggshell until the proper time, so should one carefully prepare and consume the buttermilk that is churned from curd mixed with ghee and flavored with spices, in order to achieve the ultimate result of increased fertility.

sloka: pumān yathā jātabalo yāvadicchaṃ striyo vrajet|  yathā cāpatyavān sadyo bhavettadupadekṣyate||3||  na hi jātabalāḥ sarve narāścāpatyabhāginaḥ|  bṛhaccharīrā balinaḥ santi nārīṣu durbalāḥ||4||  santi cālpāśrayāḥ [1]
translation: For flesh, the method recommended by physicians is to prepare small pills with it and administer them with water for increasing semen. (This is from "Vrishya Mansagutika")

sloka: strīṣu balavanto bahuprajāḥ|  prakṛtyā cābalāḥ santi santi cāmayadurbalāḥ||5||  narāścaṭakavat kecid vrajanti bahuśaḥ striyam|  gajavacca prasiñcanti kecinna bahugāminaḥ||6||  kālayogabalāḥ kecit kecidabhyasanadhruvāḥ|  kecit prayatnairvyajyante [2] vṛṣāḥ kecit svabhāvataḥ||7||  tasmāt prayogān vakṣyāmo durbalānāṃ balapradān|  sukhopabhogān balināṃ bhūyaśca balavardhanān||8||  pūrvaṃ śuddhaśarīrāṇāṃ nirūhaiḥ [3] sānuvāsanaiḥ|  balāpekṣī prayuñjīta śukrāpatyavivardhanān||9||  ghṛtatailarasakṣīraśarkarāmadhusaṃyutāḥ|  bastayaḥ saṃvidhātavyāḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśinām||10||
translation: Consuming a portion of clarified butter in the taste of fresh pomegranate seeds, mixed with pure germinated grains, clean barley, and long pepper, makes the semen fertile. (Thus is called the aphrodisiac property of buffalo milk.)

sloka: piṣṭvā varāhamāṃsāni dattvā maricasaindhave|  kolavadgulikāḥ kṛtvā tapte sarpiṣi vartayet [1] ||11||  vartanastambhitāstāśca [2]
translation: One who consumes fresh fish, cooked in ghee and well-prepared, neither experiences loss of semen nor exhaustion from sexual activity. (Translation of the verse "इति वृष्यघृतभृष्टमत्स्यमांसानि")

sloka: prakṣepyāḥ kaukkuṭe rase|  ghṛtāḍhye gandhapiśune dadhidāḍimasārike||12||  yathā na bhindyādguli(ṭi)kāstathā taṃ sādhayedrasam|  taṃ piban bhakṣayaṃstāśca labhate śukramakṣayam||13||
translation: The dough balls made with fish meat, salt, and cumin seeds, cooked in a mixture of gram flour paste and ghee, when offered to a male buffalo along with spices, juicy, soft, and salty fish pieces, increase semen, physical strength, happiness, prosperity, and the quantity and quality of sperm. (These are known as) aphrodisiac dough balls.

sloka: māṃsānāmevamanyeṣāṃ medyānāṃ kārayedbhiṣak|  guṭikāḥ sarasāstāsaṃ prayogaḥ śukravardhanaḥ||14||  (iti vṛṣyā māṃsaguṭikāḥ)
translation: Mix together powdered barley, wheat, shastika, pista, and crushed sugarcane with freshly churned butter in thin curd. Consuming these cakes will quickly make a bull strong. (This is the method for making vrisya cakes from barley etc.)

sloka: māṣānaṅkuritāñchuddhān vituṣān sājaḍāphalān|  ghṛtāḍhye māhiṣarase dadhidāḍimasārike||15||  prakṣipenmātrayā yukto dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  bhuktaḥ pītaśca sa rasaḥ kurute śukramakṣayam||16||  (iti vṛṣyo māhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: A measure of sugar, a Katika (an ancient Indian measurement) of ghee, a quarter Pala (another ancient Indian measurement) of fresh curd, and an eighth Pala of clarified butter should be mixed together in a small pot during the Martika period (around noon). This is a highly nutritious and strengthening mixture. It should be consumed early morning, in a measure equal to that of fire, every day.

sloka: ārdrāṇi matsyamāṃsāni śapharīrvā subhārjitāḥ|  tapte sarpiṣi yaḥ khādet sa gacchet strīṣu na kṣayam||17||  ghṛtabhṛṣṭān rase cchāge rohitān phalasārike|  anupītarasān snigdhānapatyārthī prayojayet||18||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtabhṛṣṭamatsyamāṃsāni)
translation: Having separately churned a measure of clarified butter from the curds obtained after breaking and straining the milk of both a hundred cows and a newborn calf, as well as from the milk of a she-buffalo freed from its afterbirth, one should use it for the purpose of procreation mixed with sugar and honey. (This is called the method of producing offspring through clarified butter.)

sloka: kuṭṭakaṃ [1] matsyamāṃsānāṃ hiṅgusaindhavadhānyakaiḥ|  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet||19||  māhiṣe ca rase matsyān snigdhāmlalavaṇān pacet|  rase cānugate māṃsaṃ pothayettatra cāvapet||20||  maricaṃ jīrakaṃ dhānyamalpaṃ hiṅgu navaṃ ghṛtam|  māṣapūpalikānāṃ tadgarbhārthamupakalpayet||21||  etau pūpalikāyogau bṛṃhaṇau balavardhanau|  harṣasaubhāgyadau putryau paraṃ śukrābhivardhanau||22||  (iti vṛṣyau pūpalikāyogau)
translation: A pot filled with ghee, cooked in a hundredfold strength of sarase (a type of extract), when further processed in a hundredfold quantity of cow's milk becomes successful. With the addition of equal parts of sugarcane juice and goat's/donkey's milk, as well as the juices of bhaga (a type of plant) and saja davanika (another type of plant), a physician should prepare medicinal pills that are as heavy as the udumbara fruit. Through the use of these pills, a person experiences delight like a worm in a rotten fruit. (End of Vrsyaguṭikā)

sloka: māṣātmaguptāgodhūmaśāliṣaṣṭikapaiṣṭikam|  śarkarāyā vidāryāśca cūrṇamikṣurakasya ca||23||  saṃyojya masṛṇe kṣīre ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet|  payo'nupānāstāḥ śīghraṃ kurvanti vṛṣatāṃ parām||24||  (iti vṛṣyā māṣādipūpalikāḥ)
translation: To prepare a medicinal paste, mix one-third the quantity of sesame oil with 100 white cowrie shells and seven palmfuls of barley flour on a clean, smooth stone. Grind this mixture until it becomes smooth. The resulting product should be pure, round, and resembling the moon. Using this, a person can cure diseases in elephants, horses, and women. (Vṛsyotkārikā)

sloka: śarkarāyāstulaikā syādekā gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  prastho vidāryāścūrṇasya pippalyāḥ prastha eva ca||25||  ardhāḍhakaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca|  tatsarvaṃ mūrcchitaṃ tiṣṭhenmārtike ghṛtabhājane||26||  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya prātaḥ prātaḥ prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo balyo bṛṃhaṇa eva ca||27||
translation: That which is sweet, smooth, nourishing, heavy, and also exhilarating to the mind, all of that is called Vrishyam (virile, life-giving).

sloka: śatāvaryā vidāryāśca tathā māṣātmaguptayoḥ|  śvadaṃṣṭrāyāśca niṣkvāthāñjaleṣu [1] ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sādhayitvā ghṛtaprasthaṃ payasyaṣṭaguṇe punaḥ|  śarkarāmadhuyuktaṃ tadapatyārthī prayojayet||29||  (ityapatyakaraṃ ghṛtam)
translation: Therefore, he should be cultivated with such objects and motivated by his own desire, excited by feminine qualities, (and) should approach the harem.

sloka: ghṛtapātraṃ śataguṇe vidārīsvarase pacet|  siddhaṃ punaḥ śataguṇe gavye payasi sādhayet||30||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāṃ kṣaudrasyekṣurakasya ca|  pippalyāḥ sājaḍāyāśca bhāgaiḥ pādāṃśikairyutam||31||  guli(ṭi)kāḥ kārayedvaidyo yathā sthulamudumbaram|  tāsāṃ prayogāt puruṣaḥ kuliṅga iva hṛṣyati||32||  (iti vṛṣyaguṭikāḥ)
translation: After traveling, bathing, and drinking milk, one should not lie down having tasted the sap (of any plant or food). Only when it has increased within does the semen, along with strength, become accessible to the embodied being, just as the fragrance of a closed bud is not perceived until it blooms.

sloka: sitopalāpalaśataṃ tadardhaṃ navasarpiṣaḥ|  kṣaudrapādena saṃyuktaṃ sādhayejjalapādikam||33||  sāndraṃ godhūmacūrṇānāṃ pādaṃ stīrṇe śilātale|  śucau ślakṣṇe samutkīrya mardanenopapādayet||34||  śuddhā utkārikāḥ kāryaścandramaṇḍalasannibhāḥ|  tāsāṃ prayogādgajavannārīḥ santarpayennaraḥ||35||  (iti vṛṣyotkārikā)
translation: A man, after turning sixteen, should not seek to consort with women for the sake of longevity.

sloka: yat kiñcinmadhuraṃ snigdhaṃ jīvanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ guru|  harṣaṇaṃ manasaścaiva sarvaṃ tadvṛṣyamucyate||36||
translation: Even an excessively strong man quickly dries up like kajala (collyrium) in a pond, if he associates with women.

sloka: dravyairevaṃvidhaistasmādbhāvitaḥ pramadāṃ vrajet|  ātmavegena codīrṇaḥ strīguṇaiśca praharṣitaḥ||37||
translation: Just as dry and rough wood easily ignites and splinters upon being touched, so does an old woman quickly become excited when she is approached.

sloka: gatvā snātvā payaḥ pītvā rasaṃ vā'nu śayīta nā|  tathā'syāpyāyate bhūyaḥ śukraṃ ca balameva ca||38||  yathā mukulapuṣpasya su(kha) gandho nopalabhyate|  labhyate tadvikāśāttu tathā śukraṃ hi dehinām||39||
translation: Through aging, constant worry, unwholesome acts, diseases, and excessive attachment to women, semen is depleted in women. (translation of verse 43 from the book "Bhagavata Purana" by Gita Press)

sloka: narte vai ṣoḍaśādvarṣāt saptatyāḥ parato na ca|  āyuṣkāmo naraḥ strībhiḥ saṃyogaṃ kartumarhati||40||
translation: Fear, fatigue, lack of trust, sorrow, observing women's faults, lack of understanding of their nature, thoughtless behavior, and excessive attachment towards them - these diminish a man's strength and willpower, even if he is satisfied.

sloka: atibālo hyasampūrṇasarvadhātuḥ striyaṃ vrajan|  upaśuṣyeta sahasā taḍāgamiva kājalam||41||
translation: Just as butter is present in cream, oil in sesame seeds, and semen is present throughout the body during a physical touch, similarly. (The context of this verse is not clear without additional information.)

sloka: śuṣkaṃ rūkṣaṃ yathā kāṣṭhaṃ jantudagdhaṃ vijarjaram|  spṛṣṭamāśu viśīryeta tathā vṛddhaḥ striyo vrajan||42||
translation: The semen is discharged in the union of male and female due to the conception of a thought, just like water oozes from a wet cloth.

sloka: jarayā cintayā śukraṃ vyādhibhiḥ karmakarṣaṇāt|  kṣayaṃ gacchatyanaśanāt strīṇāṃ cātiniṣevaṇāt||43||
translation: The white color, lightness, mobility, moisture-attracting quality, respectability, and swiftness of the wind are the eight causes due to which semen is expelled from the body. That which is called the material manifestation of the all-pervading one.

sloka: kṣayādbhayādaviśrambhācchokāt strīdoṣadarśanāt|  nārīṇāmarasajñatvādavicārādasevanāt||44||  tṛptasyāpi striyo gantuṃ na śaktirupajāyate|  dehasattvabalāpekṣī harṣaḥ śaktiśca harṣajā||45||
translation: That which is copious, sweet, smooth, heavy, curly, and also white, and generates much offspring, is undoubtedly a good fruit-bearing tree.

sloka: rasa ikṣau yathā dadhni sarpistailaṃ tile yathā|  sarvatrānugataṃ dehe śukraṃ saṃsparśane tathā||46||
translation: By which a man obtains mastery over women [1] and excels in horse-related activities, that (is the characteristic of) him.

sloka: tat strīpuruṣasaṃyoge ceṣṭāsaṅkalpapīḍanāt|  śukraṃ pracyavate sthānājjalamārdrāt paṭādiva||47||
translation: The twelfth excellent limbs of yoga instruction, which were to be practiced before and after sexual union, are described here: when women are no longer to be served (after ejaculation), the complete resolution of semen is explained as the sign of masculine vigor.

sloka: harṣāttarṣāt saratvācca paicchilyādgauravādapi|  aṇupravaṇabhāvācca drutatvānmārutasya ca||48||  aṣṭābhya ebhyo hetubhyaḥ śukraṃ dehāt prasicyate|  carato viśvarūpasya rūpadravyaṃ yaducyate||49||
translation: Now, I will explain the most essential means of accomplishment. This is what Bhagavan Atreya said.

sloka: bahalaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhamavisraṃ guru picchilam|  śuklaṃ bahu ca yacchukraṃ phalavattadasaṃśayam||50||
translation: It should be examined, just as in the primary method of treatment, whether the incurable disease has been reached by darkness (i.e., is beyond cure) through a careful examination of the special causes, contributing factors, and symptoms.

sloka: yena nārīṣu sāmarthyaṃ vājīvallabhate [1] naraḥ|  vrajeccābhyadhikaṃ yena vājīkaraṇameva tat||51||
translation: The distinguishing feature of the two incoming winds is that one dispels exhaustion and fear.

sloka: tatra ślokau  heturyogopadeśasya yogā dvādaśa cottamāḥ|  yat pūrvaṃ maithunāt sevyaṃ sevyaṃ yanmaithunādanu||52||  yadā na sevyāḥ pramadāḥ kṛtsnaḥ śukraviniścayaḥ|  niruktaṃ ceha nirdiṣṭaṃ pumāñjātabalādike||53||
translation: The one who quickly calms down the fear and sadness arising from the wind, removes its causes, and brings joy and assurance – this is described as one of the sixteen means to accomplish the Sādhyas (one of the classes of minor deities). Now listen carefully, I will explain it in detail.

sloka: athāto'tīsāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The built-up faults manifest in a rigid and ignorant person as excessive flatulence. One should eliminate them. (Verse 14)

sloka: tamasādhyatāmasamprāptaṃcikitsedyathāpradhānopakrameṇahetūpaśayadoṣaviśeṣaparīkṣayāceti ||10||
translation: Prior conduct that is not well-considered gives rise to many ailments, as past faults get aggravated.

sloka: āgantūdvāvatīsāraumānasaubhayaśokajau |  tattayorlakṣaṇaṃvāyoryadatīsāralakṣaṇam ||11||
translation: One should ignore selfishly neglectful people and instead offer assistance to those who are diligently working to alleviate the afflictions of others, such as diseases like consumption, edema, abscesses, leprosy, epilepsy, hemorrhoids, and fever. By doing so, not only will one's own inner heat be increased, but any ailments in the stomach will also subside.

sloka: mārutobhayaśokābhyāṃśīghraṃhiparikupyati |  tayoḥkriyāvātaharīharṣaṇāśvāsanānica ||12||  ityuktāḥṣaḍatīsārāḥ sādhyānāṃsādhanaṃtvataḥ |  pravakṣyāmyanupūrveṇayathāvattannibodhata ||13||
translation: For those who have mostly overcome major faults, it is recommended to stimulate and cook (refine) the remaining minor faults.

sloka: doṣāḥsannicitāyasyavidagdhāhāramūrcchitāḥ |  atīsārāyakalpantebhūyastānsampravartayet ||14||
translation:
With a fragrance like that of pippali and bilva, free from fear, and soft to touch,
Three verses have been assigned for the subduing of formidable foes.
With the means of speech (vacA), opposed to poison, or with the left portion of a patrakA leaf,
Or with the tips of hRivesa and śringavera, one should cause water to flow.

sloka: natusaṅgrahaṇaṃdeyaṃpūrvamāmātisāriṇe |  vibadhyamānāḥprāgdoṣājanayantyāmayānbahūn ||15||
translation: At the time of meal, one should eat light, easy-to-digest food in moderation. This way, one quickly attains a sharp digestive fire. Similarly, with curd, diluted soma (a type of drink), offering to fire, and consuming madhu (honey) or sugarcane juice, one should gradually adopt the practice of incorporating yava (barley), cow urine, cow dung, ghee, and grains in their diet.

sloka: daṇḍakālasakādhmānagrahaṇyarśogadāṃstathā |  śothapāṇḍvāmayaplīhakuṣṭhagulmodarajvarān ||16||  tasmādupekṣetotkliṣṭānvartamānānsvayaṃmalān |  kṛcchraṃvāvahatāṃdadyādabhayāṃsampravartinīm ||17||  tayāpravāhitedoṣepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  jāyatedehalaghutājaṭharāgniścavardhate ||18||
translation: Use, in the preparation of food and drink, the leaves of the Shalaparni, Pushkarmuli, Vacha, Jivaka, Priyangu, and Kantakari; the fruits of the Bilva, Talisha, Karkandhu, Pippali, and Panasa trees; the roots of the Vrihati, Chitraka, and Musta plants; and the bark of the Vamsha-locana tree. These are all capable of improving appetite, digestion, and elimination; they alleviate vata, kapha, and pitta doshas; and they aid in healing various ailments.

sloka: pramathyāṃmadhyadoṣāṇāṃdadyāddīpanapācanīm |  laṅghanaṃcālpadoṣāṇāṃpraśastamatisāriṇām ||19||
translation:
One who is attached to the unchanging supreme reality, even while engaged in the world, feels no distress, even when afflicted by many ailments, physical discomforts, and injuries. Such a person should feed someone, who is devoted to serving the cows, with yogurt mixed with fresh ripe bananas and generously seasoned with ghee, using dried cow dung as fuel to cook this meal. (translated by Arvind Paranjpye)

1042,कल्कःस्याद्बालबिल्वानांतिलकल्कश्चतत्समः ।  दध्नःसरोऽम्लस्नेहाद्यःखडोहन्यात्प्रवाहिकाम् ॥३४॥,The clay of the young banyan leaves is similar to that of the kalaka; it causes the flowing water to deviate from its course due to its slimy and sticky nature.
1043,यवानांमुद्गमाषाणांशालीनांचतिलस्यच ।  कोलानांबालबिल्वानांधान्ययूषंप्रकल्पयेत् ॥३५॥  ऐकध्यंयमकेभृष्टंदधिदाडिमसारिकम् ।  वर्चःक्षयेशुष्कमुखंशाल्यन्नंतेनभोजयेत् ॥३६॥  दध्नःसरंवायमकेभृष्टंसगुडनागरम् ।  सुरांवायमकेभृष्टांव्यञ्जनार्थेप्रदापयेत् ॥३७॥  फलाम्लंयमकेभृष्टंयूषंगृञ्जनकस्यवा ।  लोपाकरसमम्लंवास्निग्धाम्लंकच्छपस्यवा ॥३८॥  बर्हितित्तिरिदक्षाणांवर्तकानांतथारसाः ।  स्निग्धाम्लाःशालयश्चाग्र्यावर्चःक्षयरुजापहाः ॥३९॥  अन्तराधिरसंपूत्वारक्तंमेषस्यचोभयम् ।  पचेद्दाडिमसाराम्लंसधान्यस्नेहनागरम् ॥४०॥  ओदनं[१]रक्तशालीनांतेनाद्यात्प्रपिबेच्चतत् ।  तथावर्चःक्षयकृतैर्व्याधिभिर्विप्रमुच्यते ॥४१॥,"Prepare a drink by mixing together the following: the water that results from cooking rice, barley, black gram, green gram, and sesame; a little bit of curd, juice from citron fruits, and salt; this is to be consumed at the beginning, along with newly cooked rice, in order to alleviate weakness and diseases caused by depletion of energy. Also mix together: the water that results from cooking kidney beans, black gram, green gram, sesame, and jujube; a little bit of jaggery, mustard oil, and salt; this is to be consumed for enhancing taste and digestion, as well as alleviating problems caused by excessive pitta. Similarly, mix together: the water that results from cooking bitter gourd, banana stem, banana flowers, snake gourd, and drumstick; a little bit of tamarind juice, jaggery, salt, and mustard oil; this is to be consumed for enhancing taste, digestion, and strength. Cook together: the water that results from cooking pomegranate seeds, black gram, green gram, sesame, and linseed; a little bit of tamarind juice, jaggery, and salt; along with kidney beans and mustard oil; this is to be consumed for alleviating all kinds of diseases caused by vitiation of the three doshas. Consume this preparation at the beginning of every meal in order to become free from ailments caused by depletion of energy.

sloka: pippalīnāgaraṃdhānyaṃbhūtīkamabhayāvacā |  hrīveraṃbhadramustānibilvaṃnāgaradhānyakam ||20||  pṛśniparṇīśvadaṃṣṭrācasamaṅgākaṇṭakārikā |  tisraḥpramathyāvihitāḥślokārdhairatisāriṇām ||21||  vacāprativiṣābhyāṃvāmustaparpaṭakenavā |  hrīveraśṛṅgaverābhyāṃpakvaṃvāpāyayejjalam ||22||
translation: Praiseworthy is the controlled use of a toothbrush, free from foul-smelling residue and mixed with fragrant paste, or its regular cleaning. (42)

sloka: yukte'nnakālekṣutkṣāmaṃlaghūnyannānibhojayet |  tathāsaśīghramāpnotirucimagnibalaṃbalam ||23||  takreṇāvantisomenayavāgvātarpaṇenavā |  surayāmadhunācādauyathāsātmyamupācaret ||24||  yavāgūbhirvilepībhiḥkhaḍairyūṣairasaudanaiḥ |  dīpanagrāhisaṃyuktaiḥkramaścasyādataḥparam ||25||
translation: The ghee churned from the coastal woodland whey, mixed with sugar, rock salt, and pungent spices, is called Changéri ghee.

sloka: śālaparṇīṃpṛśniparṇīṃbṛhatīṃkaṇṭakārikām |  balāṃśvadaṃṣṭrāṃbilvānipāṭhāṃnāgaradhānyakam ||26||  śaṭīṃpalāśaṃhapuṣāṃvacāṃjīrakapippalīm |  yavānīṃpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalīm ||27|| vṛkṣāmlaṃdāḍimāmlaṃcasahiṅgubiḍasaindhavam |  prayojayedannapānevidhināsūpakalpitam ||28||  vātaśleṣmaharohyeṣagaṇodīpanapācanaḥ |  grāhībalyorocanaścatasmācchasto'tisāriṇām ||29||
translation: The juice of the sacred fig tree, mixed with fresh ghee and honey, is recommended as a tonic in the text Gudabhramsha.

sloka: āmepariṇateyastuvibaddhamatisāryate |                                                     saśūlapicchamalpālpaṃbahuśaḥsapravāhikam ||30||  yūṣeṇamūlakānāṃtaṃbadarāṇāmathāpivā |  upodikāyāḥkṣīriṇyāyavānyāvāstukasyavā ||31||  suvarcalāyāścañcorvāśākenāvalgujasyavā |  śaṭyāḥkarkārukāṇāṃvājīvantyāścirbhaṭasyavā ||32||  loṇikāyāḥsapāṭhāyāḥśuṣkaśākenavāpunaḥ |  dadhidāḍimasiddhenabahusnehenabhojayet ||33||
translation: The practice of meditating on Vasabilva, which has been perfectly mastered through its ten root causes, either with a group of one hundred Shatī plants or by using the marked sticks. This is described in Gudabhramsha.

sloka: kalkaḥsyādbālabilvānāṃtilakalkaścatatsamaḥ |  dadhnaḥsaro'mlasnehādyaḥkhaḍohanyātpravāhikām ||34||
translation: Apply the antidote to the previously unmelted, fallen and sweat-filled Guna dosha. Introduce it with a swab into the fully opened and softened cavity.

sloka: yavānāṃmudgamāṣāṇāṃśālīnāṃcatilasyaca |  kolānāṃbālabilvānāṃdhānyayūṣaṃprakalpayet ||35||  aikadhyaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃdadhidāḍimasārikam |  varcaḥkṣayeśuṣkamukhaṃśālyannaṃtenabhojayet ||36||  dadhnaḥsaraṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭaṃsaguḍanāgaram |  surāṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭāṃvyañjanārthepradāpayet ||37||  phalāmlaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃyūṣaṃgṛñjanakasyavā |  lopākarasamamlaṃvāsnigdhāmlaṃkacchapasyavā ||38||  barhitittiridakṣāṇāṃvartakānāṃtathārasāḥ |  snigdhāmlāḥśālayaścāgryāvarcaḥkṣayarujāpahāḥ ||39||  antarādhirasaṃpūtvāraktaṃmeṣasyacobhayam |  paceddāḍimasārāmlaṃsadhānyasnehanāgaram ||40||  odanaṃ[1]raktaśālīnāṃtenādyātprapibeccatat |  tathāvarcaḥkṣayakṛtairvyādhibhirvipramucyate ||41||
translation: A person who is bound by the vow, has a strong flow of energy, is red-eyed from desire, thirsty and afflicted by pain, is worthy of mixing his hair with curd. Let a man drink hot milk, either smeared with the root of a ripe mango or with the tender bilva fruit. By using curd in this way, the redness of the eyes subsides, just as the strong flow of energy and the binding are pacified.

sloka: gudaniḥsaraṇeśūlepānamamlasyasarpiṣaḥ |  praśasyatenirāmāṇāmathavā'pyanuvāsanam ||42||
translation: One should drink the water mixed with pestled barley, which is efficient in alleviating bile and phlegm, after crushing the gallbladder of a sacrificial animal killed by a Kirāta (hunter or barbarian). The following are also hard to obtain and excellent for the same purpose: bilva, arka, haridra (turmeric), hribera (a type of myrobalan), chandana (sandalwood), chamṛṇāla (a type of red sandalwood), cānagara (a type of tree or herb), lodhra (a type of tree or herb), utpala (a type of blue lotus or water lily), dātakī (a type of flower), puṣpa (flower), daḍima (a type of pomegranate), mahauṣadha (a powerful medicinal plant), kaṭphala (a type of fruit), nāgarājam (a type of herb or tree), paṭhājam (a type of creeper), bhūmiphala (a type of fruit), and aṃravāra (a type of emblic myrobalan). These six types of decoctions, when mixed with barley and water, are drinkable and alleviate bile and phlegm. This is briefly described in this verse.

sloka: cāṅgerīkoladadhyamlanāgarakṣārasaṃyutam |  ghṛtamutkvathitaṃpeyaṃgudabhraṃśarujāpaham ||43||  iticāṅgerīghṛtam |
translation: Just as at the end, the ancient repositories are filled with the juices of herbs gathered according to their properties.

sloka: sacavyapippalīmūlaṃsavyoṣaviḍadāḍimam |  peyamamlaṃghṛtaṃyuktyāsadhānyājājicitrakam ||44|| itigudabhraṃśecavyādighṛtam |
translation: The one afflicted with excessive bile can quickly find relief by using butter milk. Their strength and complexion will also improve. Even a severely afflicted person, whose very life force is affected by the disorder, can be cured of pittaja aartavas (a type of diarrhea) by consuming thin rice porridge prepared with butter milk. (verses 57-58)

sloka: daśamūlopasiddhaṃvāsabilvamanuvāsanam |  śaṭīśatāhvābilvairvāvacayācitrakeṇavā ||45||  itigudabhraṃśe'nuvāsanam
translation: One should consume the extracted juice of palasha fruit along with water, followed by consuming warm milk in accordance with one's strength. In this way, any disease caused by impurities in the body is pacified. Just as the impurities are removed from a flowing river, similarly, one should cleanse the impurities caused by the combination of doshas in the body. When a medicinal procedure is being carried out, pain that arises due to it should be immediately alleviated with an appropriate remedy such as applying paste made of one hundred flowers or using a decoction made from sugarcane, sesame oil, ghee, and bael fruit.

sloka: stabdhabhraṣṭagudepūrvaṃsnehasvedauprayojayet |  susvinnaṃtaṃmṛdūbhūtaṃpicunāsampraveśayet ||46||
translation:
For one who has taken a vow, if there is still some residual attachment, how to get rid of it completely? Soak the huskless rice grains in water and clean them thoroughly. Once the water drains, spread out the grains to dry in the sun. After they are completely dried, grind them into flour. Mix this flour with a small amount of ghee and salt. Apply this mixture to the affected area and let it sit for some time. Then, after bathing, consume food prepared with milk and sugar while thinking about the vow one has taken. (translation based on the commentary provided by Swami Chinmayananda)

Note: This translation is done based on the commentary provided as I do not have the context in which this verse is spoken. The verse itself describes a process to remove residual attachment for someone who has taken a vow, but it does not provide enough context to give a more specific or nuanced translation.

sloka: vibaddhavātavarcāstubahuśūlapravāhikaḥ |  saraktapicchastṛṣṇārtaḥkṣīrasauhityamarhati ||47||  yamakasyoparikṣīraṃdhāroṣṇaṃvāpibennaraḥ |  śṛtameraṇḍamūlenabālabilvenavāpayaḥ[1] ||48||  evaṃkṣīraprayogeṇaraktaṃpicchācaśāmyati |  śūlaṃpravāhikācaivavibandhaścopaśāmyati ||49||
translation: The bowel quickly overcomes, through purgation and vomiting, the complications of indigestion, bloating, burning sensation, cough, worm infestation, diarrhea, and constipation.

sloka: sakṣaudrātiviṣaṃpiṣṭvāvatsakasyaphalatvacam |  pibetpittātisāraghnaṃtaṇḍulodakasaṃyutam ||51||  kirātatiktakomustaṃvatsakaḥsarasāñjanaḥ |  bilvaṃdāruharidrātvakhrīberaṃsadurālabham ||52||  candanaṃcamṛṇālaṃcanāgaraṃlodhramutpalam |  tilāmocarasolodhraṃsamaṅgākamalotpalam ||53||  utpalaṃdhātakīpuṣpaṃdāḍimatvaṅmahauṣadham |  kaṭphalaṃnāgaraṃpāṭhājambvāmrāsthidurālabhāḥ ||54||  yogāḥṣaḍetesakṣaudrāstaṇḍulodakasaṃyutāḥ |  peyāḥpittātisāraghnāḥślokārdhenanidarśitāḥ ||55||
translation: Having abandoned this activity (of eating certain foods) that causes excessive bile, one should worship. For even for that person, bile becomes powerful through (consuming) those food and drinks.

sloka: jīrṇoṣadhānāṃśasyanteyathāyogaṃprakalpitaiḥ |  rasaiḥsāṅgrāhikairyuktāḥpurāṇāraktaśālayaḥ ||56||
translation: Should prepare a purgative that quickly cleanses the yellow bile, and alleviates thirst, inflammation, colic, and burning sensation.

sloka: pittātisārodīpāgneḥkṣipraṃsamupaśāmyati |  ajākṣīraprayogeṇabalaṃvarṇaścavardhate ||57||  bahudoṣasyadīptāgneḥsaprāṇasyanatiṣṭhati |  paittikoyadyatīsāraḥpayasātaṃvirecayet ||58||
translation: The porcupine's milk, found there, which is cool, clear, and sweet like sugarcane juice, is used for drinking, eating, and cleaning the mouth.

sloka: palāśaphalaniryūhaṃpayasāsahapāyayet |  tato'nupāyayetkoṣṇaṃkṣīramevayathābalam ||59||  pravāhitetenamalepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  palāśavatprayojyāvātrāyamāṇāviśodhinī ||60||  sāṃsargyāṃkriyamāṇāyāṃśūlaṃyadyanuvartate |  srutadoṣasyataṃśīghraṃyathāvadanuvāsayet ||61||  śatapuṣpāvarībhyāṃcapayasāmadhukenaca |  tailapādaṃghṛtaṃsiddhaṃsabilvamanuvāsanam ||62||
translation: One should feed with a mixture of sugar and ghee, those who are passionate about freshly cooked rice. For animals, birds, and insects that eat raw foods, one should feed them with unsourced food mixed with sugar and ghee. (72-73)

sloka: kṛtānuvāsanasyāsyakṛtasaṃsarjanasyaca |  vartateyadyatīsāraḥpicchābastirataḥparam ||63||  pariveṣṭyakuśairārdrairārdravṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  kṛṣṇamṛttikayā''lipyasvedayedgomayāgninā ||64||  suśuṣkāṃmṛttikāṃjñātvātānivṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  śṛtepayasimṛdnīyādāpothyolūkhaletataḥ ||65||  piṇḍaṃmuṣṭisamaṃprasthetatpūtaṃtailasarpiṣoḥ |  snehitaṃ[1]mātrayāyuktaṃkalkenamadhukasyaca ||66||  bastimabhyaktagātrāyadadyātpratyāgatetataḥ |  snātvābhuñjītapayasājāṅgalānāṃrasenavā ||67||
translation: The concoction of rice mixed with ghee, blood, and sesame seeds is praised; a little sour and sweetened with sugar. The blue lotus, along with its filaments and the stalk, when added to fresh milk, makes a nourishing drink for the weak. After first making someone drink this mixture, one should then give them sweetened rice pudding.

sloka: pittātisārajvaraśothagulmajīrṇātisāragrahaṇīpradoṣān |  jayatyayaṃśīghramatipravṛddhānvirecanāsthāpanayoścabastiḥ[2] ||68||
translation: After consuming milk and ghee cooked together, one obtains good health in three days, and by drinking this, along with a hundred Avariki leaves, one gets rid of the yellow bile. By drinking ghee prepared with the powder of Kutaja fruit, one can alleviate severe blood impurities. This ghee, mixed with the juice of Yava and sugar, should be consumed for cooling down the excess heat in the body.

sloka: pittātisārīyastvetāṃkriyāṃmuktvāniṣevate | pittalānyannapānānitasyapittaṃmahābalam ||69||
translation: By consuming, with ghee cooked and prepared by mixing the fruits of the turmeric plant, barks of Pippali and Shringavera, and the juices of Draksha, Katuka, and Rohini, one can quickly cure even severe diseases that are difficult to treat.

sloka: kuryādraktātisāraṃturaktamāśupradūṣayet |  tṛṣṇāṃśūlaṃvidāhaṃcagudapākaṃcadāruṇam ||70||
translation: A mixture of Krishna's (black) mud, honey, conch shell, red lac, rice grains, and water; ultimately becoming one homogeneous red mass.

sloka: tatracchāgaṃpayaḥśastaṃśītaṃsamadhuśarkaram |  pānārthaṃbhojanārthaṃcagudaprakṣālanetathā ||71||
translation: The mixture of yellow turmeric and black sesame seeds, when combined in equal parts with the water used to cook rice, quickly stops bleeding when consumed by a person who primarily eats meat.

sloka: odanaṃraktaśālīnāṃpayasātenabhojayet |  rasaiḥpārāvatādīnāṃghṛtabhṛṣṭaiḥsaśarkaraiḥ ||72||  śaśapakṣimṛgāṇāṃcaśītānāṃdhanvacāriṇām |  rasairanamlaiḥsaghṛtairbhojayettaṃsaśarkaraiḥ ||73||
translation: Having wetted the seed of the banyan tree, one should drink the water; this quickly conquers the ailment in the stomach.

sloka: rudhiraṃmārgamājaṃvāghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃpraśasyate |  kāśmaryaphalayūṣovākiñcidamlaḥsaśarkaraḥ ||74||  nīlotpalaṃmocarasaṃsamaṅgāpadmakeśaram |  ajākṣīrayutaṃdadyājjīrṇecapayasaudanam ||75||  durbalaṃpāyayitvāvātasyaivoparibhojayet |  prāgbhaktaṃnavanītaṃvādadyātsamadhuśarkaram ||76||
translation: After drinking sugarcane juice, sandalwood paste mixed with water, and rice washed in water, one is said to be freed from thirst and burning sensation.

sloka: prāśyakṣīrotthitaṃsarpiḥkapiñjalarasāśanaḥ |  tryahādārogyamāpnotipayasākṣīrabhuktathā ||77||  pītvāśatāvarīkalkaṃpayasākṣīrabhugjayet |  raktātisāraṃpītvāvātayāsiddhaṃghṛtaṃnaraḥ ||78||  ghṛtaṃyavāgūmaṇḍenakuṭajasyaphalaiḥśṛtam |  peyaṃtasyānupātavyāpeyāraktopaśāntaye ||79||
translation: For the one who is eaten away by pitta due to excessive rising of it, one should cool him down with cool liquids such as sweet water. One can also cleanse his cloth with the extracts of five types of woods, ghee, milk, curd, and waters mixed with powders made from various substances like bark, root of dhataki, lodhra, etc. The affected area should be smeared with these pastes. After washing it off with water, the area should be massaged with a mixture of oil, clarified butter, and taila processed one hundred times. The same process should be followed for cleansing the anus, thighs, knees, and other parts with ghee and other oils. (This is a procedure to treat someone suffering from pitta aggravation).

sloka: tvakcadāruharidrāyāḥkuṭajasyaphalānica |  pippalīśṛṅgaveraṃcadrākṣākaṭukarohiṇī ||80||  ṣaḍbhiretairghṛtaṃsiddhaṃpeyāmaṇḍāvacāritam |  atīsāraṃjayecchīghraṃtridoṣamapidāruṇam ||81||
translation: When someone, with a severely restricted breath, is lying down frequently due to exhaustion, then one should apply an ointment made of pure clarified butter, prepared as directed, to the abdomen. This is especially beneficial for those who are generally weak and suffering from a long-term ailment. Therefore, regularly massaging the abdomen with this ointment is recommended for such individuals.

sloka: kṛṣṇamṛnmadhukaṃśaṅkhaṃrudhiraṃtaṇḍulodakam |  pītamekatrasakṣaudraṃraktasaṅgrahaṇaṃparam ||82||
translation: When the wind is excessively active in its place, it gains strength particularly for accomplishing victory. Initially and subsequently, the red bile becomes aggravated due to this. A decoction of Shataavari with ghee should be prepared for such a person. Freshly churned butter mixed with half the amount of sugar should be given. Quickly procure a handful of Kshaudra (a type of bark) and make it into a powder. Make the person drink plenty of water boiled with ghee, followed by consuming an equal mixture of that and sugar. If the red bile moves downwards or rises upwards, this treatment should be administered.

sloka: pītaḥpriyaṅgukākalkaḥsakṣaudrastaṇḍulāmbhasā |  raktasrāvaṃjayecchīghraṃdhanvamāṃsarasāśinaḥ ||83||  kalkastilānāṃkṛṣṇānāṃśarkarāpañcabhāgikaḥ |  ājenapayasāpītaḥsadyoraktaṃniyacchati ||84||
translation: One who, due to lack of self-control, serves only his belly and bodily parts, quickly succumbs to a harsh, bitter fate.

sloka: palaṃvatsakabījasyaśrapayitvārasaṃpibet |  yorasāśījayecchīghraṃsapaittaṃjaṭharāmayam ||85||
translation: In the initial stage of digestion for abating diarrhea, the treatment that involves holding the breath should be applied as instructed; once implemented, it should not be reversed.

sloka: pītvāsaśarkarākṣaudraṃcandanaṃtaṇḍulāmbhasā |  dāhatṛṣṇāpramehebhyoraktasrāvāccamucyate ||86||
translation: For kapha-related disorders like anorexia, etc., one should prepare the following: Bilva, Karketaka, Vacha, Vidaanga, Bhootika, Dhanyaka, Devadaru, Kushtha, Sativisha, Pippali, Pippali Moola, Chitraka, Hastipippali, in equal parts. Of these, one-fourth should be used in the preparations. For increasing digestive fire and combating phlegm disorders, Ajaji, Masi, Sita, Naga, Rasanjana, Kutaja, Dhattura, Chandrakanti, Lodhra, Padma Kesara, Jambu, Tvak, Nimba, Madhu Yukta Katphala should be used. For treating Pitta disorders, Dhataki, Naga, Bilva, Lodhra, Padma Kesara, Jambu, Tvak, Nimba, and Madhu Yukta Katphala should be utilized. For Vata disorders, Katphala, Vidaanga, Maricha, Changeri, Kolakandra, Triphala, and Kshaudra Sharkara are recommended. For Kapha-Vata disorders, Kapittha, Vidaanga, Maricha, Changeri should be used. Sesame oil and rock salt should be added to the preparations for oral consumption.

sloka: gudobahubhirutthānairyasyapittenapacyate |  secayettaṃsuśītenapaṭolamadhukāmbunā ||87||  pañcavalkamadhūkānāṃrasairikṣurasairghṛtaiḥ |  chāgairgavyaiḥpayobhirvāśarkarākṣaudrasaṃyutaiḥ ||88|| prakṣālanānāṃkalkairvāsasarpiṣkaiḥpralepayet |  eṣāṃvāsukṛtaiścūrṇaistaṃgudaṃpratisārayet ||89||  dhātakīlodhracūrṇairvāsamāṃśaiḥpratisārayet |  tathāsravatinoraktaṃgudaṃtaiḥpratisāritam ||90||  pakvatāpraśamaṃyātivedanācopaśāmyati |  yathoktaiḥsecanaiḥśītaiḥśoṇite'tisravatyapi ||91||  gudavaṅkṣaṇakaṭyūrusecayedghṛtabhāvitam |  candanādyenatailenaśatadhautenasarpiṣā ||92||  kārpāsasaṅgṛhītenasecayedgudavaṅkṣaṇam |93|
translation: After drinking the decoction made from

sloka: alpālpaṃbahuśoraktaṃsaśūlamupaveśyate ||93||  yadāvāyurvibaddhaścakṛcchraṃcarativānavā |  piñchābastiṃtadātasyayathoktamupakalpayet ||94||  prapauṇḍarīkasiddhenasarpiṣācānuvāsayet |  prāyaśodurbalagudāścirakālātisāriṇaḥ ||95||  tasmādabhīkṣṇaśasteṣāṃgudesnehaṃprayojayet |96|
translation:
For alleviating an excess of wind, phlegm, or bile, or diarrhea, mix and apply
preparations made from a combination of powders of pippalI, bilva, and kuṣṭha.
On the day of their onset, after bathing and eating, one should massage
with warm bilva oil or with clarified butter processed with various decoctions.
Alternatively, massaging with oil processed with medicinal powders can also be done;
this will greatly benefit those suffering from ailments caused by phlegm and wind.

sloka: pavano'tipravṛttohisvesthānelabhate'dhikam ||96||  balaṃtasyasapittasyajayārthebastiruttamaḥ |  raktaṃviṭsahitaṃpūrvaṃpaścādvāyo'tisāryate ||97||  śatāvarīghṛtaṃtasyalehārthamupakalpayet |  śarkarārdhāṃśikaṃlīḍhaṃnavanītaṃnavoddhṛtam ||98||  kṣaudrapādaṃjayecchīghraṃtaṃvikāraṃhitāśinaḥ |  nyagrodhodumbarāśvatthaśuṅgānāpothyavāsayet ||99||  ahorātraṃjaletapteghṛtaṃtenāmbhasāpacet |  tadardhaśarkarāyuktaṃlihyātsakṣaudrapādikam ||100||  adhovāyadivā'pyūrdhvaṃyasyaraktaṃpravartate |101|
translation: The wind in its natural place certainly strengthens when kapha decreases

sloka: yastvevaṃdurbalomohātpittalānyevasevate ||101||  dāruṇaṃsavalīpākaṃprāpyaśīghraṃvipadyate |102|
translation: The one who first overcomes the wind's influence on bile, and then bile's influence on phlegm, becomes the strongest.

sloka: śleṣmātisāreprathamaṃhitaṃlaṅghanapācanam ||102||  yojyaścāmātisāraghnoyathoktodīpanogaṇaḥ |  laṅghitasyānupūrvyāṃcakṛtāyāṃnanivartate ||103||
translation: The symptoms of the agitating wind causing origination are described, as well as the established activities of the afflicted.

sloka: kaphajoyadyatīsāraḥkaphaghnaistamupācaret |bilvaṃkarkaṭikāmustamabhayāviśvabheṣajam ||104||  vacāviḍaṅgaṃbhūtīkaṃdhānyakaṃdevadāruca |  kuṣṭhaṃsātiviṣāpāṭhācavyaṃkaṭukarohiṇī ||105||  pippalīpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalī |  yogāñchlokārdhavihitāṃścaturastānprayojayet ||106|| śṛtāñchleṣmātisāreṣukāyāgnibalavardhanān |  ajājīmasitāṃpāṭhāṃnāgaraṃmaricānica ||107||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyānmātuluṅgarasāplutam |rasāñjanaṃsātiviṣaṃkuṭajasyaphalānica ||108||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyātpātuṃsakṣaudranāgaram |  dhātakīnāgaraṃbilvaṃlodhraṃpadmasyakeśaram ||109||  jambūtvaṅnāgaraṃdhānyaṃpāṭhāmocarasobalā |  samaṅgādhātakībilvamadhyaṃjambvāmrayostvacaḥ ||110||  kapitthāniviḍaṅgānināgaraṃmaricānica |  cāṅgerīkolatakrāmlāṃścaturastānkaphottare ||111||  ślokārdhavihitāndadyātsasnehalavaṇānkhaḍān |  kapitthamadhyaṃlīḍhvātusavyoṣakṣaudraśarkaram ||112||  kaṭphalaṃmadhuyuktaṃvāmucyatejaṭharāmayāt |113|
translation: This is the nineteenth chapter of the treatise on the arrangement of fire rituals, titled "Ekona-vimsha," which deals with the treatment of severe diarrhea in moving and non-moving beings in the medical facility.

sloka: kaṇāṃmadhuyutāṃpītvātakraṃpītvāsacitrakam ||113||  jagdhvāvābālabilvānimucyatejaṭharāmayāt |  bālabilvaṃguḍaṃtailaṃpippalīṃviśvabheṣajam |  lihyādvātepratihatesaśūlaḥsapravāhikaḥ ||114||  bhojyaṃmūlakaṣāyeṇavātaghnaiścopasevanaiḥ |  vātātisāravihitairyūṣairmāṃsarasaiḥkhaḍaiḥ ||115||  pūrvoktamamlasarpirvāṣaṭpalaṃvāyathābalam |  purāṇaṃvāghṛtaṃdadyādyavāgūmaṇḍamiśritam ||116||
translation: Now, I shall explain the treatment for leprosy. So said Lord Atreya. The cause, means, form, habitat, and pacification of leprosy – listen carefully, O AgniVesh, in detail.

sloka: vātaśleṣmavibandhevākaphevā'tisravatyapi |  śūlepravāhikāyāṃvāpicchābastiṃprayojayet ||117||  pippalībilvakuṣṭhānāṃśatāhvāvacayorapi |  kalkaiḥsalavaṇairyuktaṃpūrvoktaṃsannidhāpayet ||118||  pratyāgatesukhaṃsnātaṃkṛtāhāraṃdinātyaye |  bilvatailenamatimānsukhoṣṇenānuvāsayet ||119||  vacāntairathavākalkaistailaṃpaktvā'nuvāsayet |  bahuśaḥkaphavātārtastathāsalabhatesukham ||120||
translation: Those who partake in incompatible foods and heavy, unctuous substances; those who restrain the onset of vomiting and other natural urges; those who engage in excessive exercise and exertion while afflicted by overeating; and those who abandon the proper order of consuming hot and cold food and drink - all such persons are subject to disease.

sloka: svesthānemāruto'vaśyaṃvardhatekaphasaṅkṣaye |  savṛddhaḥsahasāhanyāttasmāttaṃtvarayājayet ||121||
translation: Those who are afflicted by the heat, quickly resort to cool water; those who have not digested their food, to starving; those who are engaged in the five gross actions, to new grains, curd, fish, salt, sour foods, and jaggery; those who engage in sexual intercourse with undigested food and those who sleep during the day, insult brahmins and gurus, and commit sinful acts.

sloka: vātasyānujayetpittaṃ pittasyānujayetkapham |  trayāṇāṃvājayetpūrvaṃyobhavedbalavattamaḥ ||122||
translation: The three impurities, wind, flesh, and water, pollute; they are responsible for the seven or eleven types of diseases in those with impure bodies. No single cause can be identified as the source of all skin diseases; instead, they arise from a combination of factors.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  prāgutpattinimittānilakṣaṇaṃsādhyatānaca |  kriyācāvasthikīsiddhānirdiṣṭāhyatisāriṇām ||123||
translation: The symptoms of kushtha (a skin disease) are: lack of knowledge of the touch, excessive sweating, not becoming pale, swelling, hair standing on end in a lesion, itching, pain, rapid and prolonged occurrence, inflammation, and unconsciousness of the affected limb.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛtetantrecarakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthāne'tisāracikitsitaṃnāmaikonaviṃśo'dhyāyaḥ ||19||
translation: The knotty, rough, and dark-reddish bark is considered to be a type of kushtha (a medicinal plant).

sloka: athātaḥ kuṣṭhacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2|| hetuṃ dravyaṃ liṅgaṃ kuṣṭhānāmāśrayaṃ praśamanaṃ ca|  śṛṇvagniveśa! samyagviśeṣataḥ sparśanaghnānām||3||
translation: They know it as Kushtha, resembling the Udumbara fruit in appearance, covered in hair follicles, reddish, scabby, and rough.

sloka: virodhīnyannapānāni dravasnigdhagurūṇi ca|  bhajatāmāgatāṃ chardiṃ vegāṃścānyānpratighnatām||4||  vyāyāmamatisantāpamatibhuktvopasevinām|  śītoṣṇalaṅghanāhārān kramaṃ muktvā niṣeviṇām||5||
translation: A circular formation that is white, red, firm, smooth, elevated, and pressed together; and is causing difficulty to others, is called a "kushtha" (tumor or chronic skin disease).

sloka: gharmaśramabhayārtānāṃ drutaṃ śītāmbusevinām|  ajīrṇādhyaśināṃ caiva pañcakarmāpacāriṇām||6||  navānnadadhimatsyātilavaṇāmlaniṣeviṇām|  māṣamūlakapiṣṭānnatilakṣīraguḍāśinām||7||  vyavāyaṃ cāpyajīrṇe'nne nidrāṃ ca bhajatāṃ divā|  viprān gurūn dharṣayatāṃ pāpaṃ karma ca kurvatām||8||
translation: The place on the tongue where a hair-like structure is present is called the ṛṣyajihvā.

sloka: vātādayastrayo duṣṭāstvagraktaṃ māṃsamambu ca|  dūṣayanti sa kuṣṭhānāṃ saptako dravyasaṅgrahaḥ||9||  ataḥ kuṣṭhāni jāyante sapta caikādaśaiva ca|  na caikadoṣajaṃ kiñcit kuṣṭhaṃ samupalabhyate||10||
translation: A white-colored (sashvetam) lotus, extending up to the red color (raktaparyantam), having the shape of a full-blown open-eye (pundarikadalopamam), and having a height equivalent to a span (otsedham) and always remaining fresh (sadaaham), is called a pundarika.

sloka: sparśājñatvamatisvedo na vā vaivarṇyamunnatiḥ|  koṭhānāṃ lomaharṣaśca kaṇḍūstodaḥ śramaḥ klamaḥ||11||  vraṇānāmadhikaṃ śūlaṃ śīghrotpattiścirasthitiḥ|  dāhaḥ [1] suptāṅgatā ceti kuṣṭhalakṣaṇamagrajam||12||
translation: That which releases pale, copper-colored, and oily substances and is mostly found in the armpits has a smell resembling that of the alabu flower.

sloka: kṛṣṇāruṇakapālābhaṃ yadrūkṣaṃ paruṣaṃ tanu|  kāpālaṃ todabahulaṃ tatkuṣṭhaṃ viṣamaṃ smṛtam||14||
translation: That which is the color of a crow's eye, causes intense pain, and bears the three signs of dosha, that is called kushtha; it does not get cured by kakanam (a type of plant).

sloka: dāhakaṇḍūrujārāgaparītaṃ lomapiñjaram|  udumbaraphalābhāsaṃ kuṣṭhamaudumbaraṃ viduḥ||15||
translation: These are the seven principal mallow plants (used in medical treatments).

sloka: śvetaṃ raktaṃ sthiraṃ styānaṃ snigdhamutsannamaṇḍalam|  kṛcchramanyonyasaṃsaktaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ maṇḍalamucyate||16||
translation: A mass of sweat resembling fish scales is a single dose of cow's urine (for medicinal use).

sloka: karkaśaṃ raktaparyantamantaḥ śyāvaṃ savedanam|  yadṛṣyajihvāsaṃsthānamṛṣyajihvaṃ taducyate||17||
translation: The named skin is thick, like an elephant's hide.

sloka: saśvetaṃ raktaparyantaṃ puṇḍarīkadalopamam|  sotsedhaṃ ca sadāhaṃ ca puṇḍarīkaṃ taducyate||18||
translation: Recalled as black, rough, and touching the ground, and resembling a camel's hump.

sloka: śvetaṃ tāmraṃ tanu ca yadrajo [1] ghṛṣṭaṃ vimuñcati|  alābūpuṣpavarṇaṃ tat sidhmaṃ prāyeṇa corasi||19||
translation: Featuring a clearly defined form, located in the Vaipadika division, and causing intense sensations.

sloka: yat kākaṇantikāvarṇamapākaṃ tīvravedanam|  tridoṣaliṅgaṃ tat kuṣṭhaṃ kākaṇaṃ naiva sidhyati||20||
translation: With a face charmingly decorated with glistening sweat and smeared with sandalwood paste.

sloka: iti saptamahākuṣṭhāni
translation: A circle of elephants with upraised trunks. (This is a reference to a group of elephants standing together with their trunks raised in either greeting, excitement, or aggression.)

sloka: asvedanaṃ mahāvāstu yanmatsyaśakalopamam|  tadekakuṣṭha
translation: That which is red, covered in pustules and makes a popping sound, and sheds serous fluid is called a "carmathala" (boil) and is intolerable to touch.

sloka: carmākhyaṃ bahalaṃ hasticarmavat||21||
translation:
Stained with dust, white, red, and black, as well as patches; extremely.

The verse describes the various colors and marks that might be seen on something, possibly a creature or an object, using four different words for color (dust-stained, white, red, and black) and the word "patches" (pidaka). The word "extremely" (bhirsham) is used to emphasize the intensity of the marks. However, without additional context, it is difficult to provide a more specific translation.

sloka: śyāvaṃ kiṇakharasparśaṃ paruṣaṃ kiṭibhaṃ smṛtam|
translation: Flashes of bright red color will emit from their bodies.

sloka: vaipādikaṃ pāṇipādasphuṭanaṃ tīvravedanam||22||
translation: Always being red, black, constantly eating (or consuming), having a hundred wounds.

sloka: kaṇḍūmadbhiḥ sarāgaiśca gaṇḍairalasakaṃ citam|
translation: A long-billed bird, brown in color, with much body hair and that moves about. (Referring to a species of bird)

sloka: sakaṇḍūrāgapiḍakaṃ dadrumaṇḍalamudgatam||23||
translation: These are the eleven minor ailments known as Kshudrakushthani.

sloka: raktaṃ [1] sakaṇḍu sasphoṭaṃ sarugdalati cāpi yat|  taccarmadalamākhyātaṃ saṃsparśāsahamucyate||24||
translation: In excessive wind, there arises the kushtha disease in the skull region; in bile, audumbara (a type of tree) should be known as its cause; kaakanam is the cause of the disease in all three doshas (humors); rishyajihva and pundarika are born in wind-bile, bile-phlegm, and excessive wind-phlegm. Ekakushtham, kitima with swollen limbs, alasaka kushtha are mostly caused by a vitiation of wind and bile; paama, shataaru, visphotanam, and dardura are generally caused by an excess of phlegm and bile.

sloka: pāmāśvetāruṇaśyāvāḥ kaṇḍūlāḥ piḍakā bhṛśam|
translation: One should identify the specific mark of a particular dosha (defect) in the kushthas (lesions), and treat that very dosha. Only then can one also address the subsequent ramifications.

sloka: sphoṭāḥ śvetāruṇābhāso visphoṭāḥ syustanutvacaḥ||25||
translation: The causes of the kushtha afflictions are understood to be those special flaws, as well as kushtha itself. The reason for these is also made clear.

sloka: raktaṃ śyāvaṃ sadāhārti śatāruḥ syādbahuvraṇam|
translation: Roughness, emaciation, swelling, pain, spasm, harshness, and anger are symptoms of vata dosha. Burning sensation, excessive thirst, coloration, and wasting away are symptoms of pitta dosha. Whitening, cooling, itching, firmness, increase in height, heaviness, and symptoms caused by Kapha-predominant organisms are symptoms of kapha dosha.

sloka: sakaṇḍūḥ piḍakā śyāvā bahusrāvā vicarcikā||26||
translation: A wise person should avoid a feeble body that is afflicted by thirst, indigestion, and is overpowered by the imbalances of wind, phlegm, or bile. Such a condition can be difficult to cure. However, a body overwhelmed by the combined powerful influence of all three - phlegm, bile, and wind, is invariably challenging to rectify.

sloka: ityekādaśa kṣudrakuṣṭhāni
translation: In cases of excess wind, emesis; in those of bile, release; in cases of phlegm and skin diseases, application of ghee is recommended; for blood-related disorders, phlebotomy is advised as the first resort.

sloka: vāte'dhikatare kuṣṭhaṃ kāpālaṃ maṇḍalaṃ kaphe|  pitte tvaudumbaraṃ vidyāt kākaṇaṃ tu tradoṣajam||27|| vātapitte śleṣmapitte vātaśleṣmaṇi cādhike|  ṛṣyajihvaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ sidhmakuṣṭhaṃ ca jāyate||28||  carmākhyamekakuṣṭhaṃ ca kiṭimaṃ savipādikam|  kuṣṭhaṃ cālasakaṃ jñeyaṃ prāyo vātakaphādhikam||29||  pāmā śatārurvisphoṭaṃ dadruścarmadalaṃ tathā|  pittaśleṣmādhikaṃ prāyaḥ kaphaprāyā vicarcikā||30||
translation: Vamana and virecana therapies, as described in the calendrical texts, should be employed for those afflicted with kushtha (skin diseases). In both cases of mild and severe kushtha, bloodletting through veins is considered beneficial.

sloka: sarvaṃ tridoṣajaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ doṣāṇāṃ tu balābalam|  yathāsvairlakṣaṇairbuddhvā kuṣṭhānāṃ kriyate kriyā||31||  doṣasya yasya paśyet kuṣṭheṣu viśeṣaliṅgamadriktam|  tasyaiva śamaṃ kuryāttataḥ paraṃ cānubandhasya||32||
translation: A person with many faults needs to be purified, diseased with many ailments, and requires constant protection of life. For, even a slight reduction in the fault causes the wind to quickly take away strength.

sloka: kuṣṭhaviśeṣairdoṣā doṣaviśeṣaiḥ punaśca kuṣṭhāni|  jñāyante tairheturhetustāṃśca [1] prakāśayati||33||
translation: Drinking of pure liquid (medicine) is beneficial when flowed through a clean intestine; for, air swiftly enters a weak and unclean intestine.

sloka: raukṣyaṃ śoṣastodaḥ śūlaṃ saṅkocanaṃ tathā''yāmaḥ|  pāruṣyaṃ kharabhāvo harṣaḥ śyāvāruṇatvaṃ ca||34||  kuṣṭheṣu vātaliṅgaṃ dāho rāgaḥ parisravaḥ pākaḥ|  visro gandhaḥ kledastathā'ṅgapatanaṃ ca pittakṛtam||35||  śvaityaṃ śaityaṃ kaṇḍūḥ sthairyaṃ cotsedhagauravasnehāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu tu kaphaliṅgaṃ jantubhirabhibhakṣaṇaṃ kledaḥ||36||
translation: In a heart afflicted by doshas, and in the upper parts of the kushta eruptions, pimples filled with the extracts of kutaja fruits, patola, and nimba, as well as honey, should be used for therapeutic vomiting.

sloka: sarvairliṅgairyuktaṃ matimān vivarjayedabalam|  tṛṣṇādāhaparītaṃ śāntāgniṃ jantubhirjagdham||37||  vātakaphaprabalaṃ yadyadekadoṣolbaṇaṃ na tat kṛcchram|  kaphapittavātapittaprabalāni tu kṛcchrasādhyāni||38||
translation: The powder of three kinds of costus, a toothbrush with three branches, and triphala are recommended for evacuation. Sauviraka, the water of tusohara, and the extracts of sidhu fruits are praised by those who know the proper order for evacuation.

sloka: vātottareṣu sarpirvamanaṃ śleṣmottareṣu kuṣṭheṣu|  pittottareṣu mokṣo raktasya virecanaṃ cāgre||39||
translation: The afflicted with kushtha (a skin disease) should be established, after anointing with a paste made of darvi, brihati, patola, pichumarda, madanakritamala, along with other ingredients like ushira, mushti, yava, nimba, and kutaja, combined with sesame oil. This treatment is recommended for the disease that is aggravated by wind, dry, and is deeply seated, and should be continued until the symptoms subside.

sloka: vamanavirecanayogāḥ kalpoktāḥ kuṣṭhināṃ prayoktavyāḥ|  pracchanamalpe kuṣṭhe mahati ca śastaṃ sirāvyadhanam||40||
translation: A pippalī plant with a sandalwood-like scent, the fruit of karṇjaphala, and a serpent-shaped root can be a cure for diseases caused by krimi, kuṣṭha, vairecanika, and other ailments when used with Vairechanika's fumigants. The harmful parasites and skin diseases located in the body are pacified by it.

sloka: बहुदोषः संशोध्यः कुष्ठी बहुशोऽनुरक्षता प्राणान्।  दोषे ह्यतिमात्रहृते वायुर्हन्यादबलमाशु॥४१॥
translation: The red distress caused by the piercing of stable, broken earthen vessels needs to be prevented.

sloka: snehasya pānamiṣṭaṃ śuddhe koṣṭhe pravāhite rakte|  vāyurhi śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhinamabalaṃ viśati śīghram||42||
translation: For cleansing pustules on fleshy, warm parts of the body, one should scrape off the burst pustule with a sharp instrument. Alternatively, for the purpose of releasing blood, small twigs may be used to puncture the pustule. A mild and reduced quantity of pustule can be expelled using lukewarm water. The application of these therapeutic procedures on properly cleaned and prepared body parts will result in immediate success.

sloka: doṣotkliṣṭe hṛdaye vāmyaḥ kuṣṭheṣu cordhvabhāgeṣu|  kuṭajaphalamadanamadhukaiḥ sapaṭolairnimbarasayuktaiḥ||43|| śītarasaḥ pakvaraso madhūni madhukaṃ ca vamanāni|
translation: In those who do not traverse with weapons, the destroyers of the sense organs are the saline, blood, and fault; these should be drained out. The lump of piles, hardened scab, ancient kushtha (a kind of skin disease), and agada's (poison's) work should be done with poisons and agadas (antidotes). Stiffened, sleeping sweat glands, and kushthas should be treated with kurchas (purgatives), danti (three myrobalan fruits), trivrita (a kind of plant), vrikakarnja (a kind of plant), kutaja (a kind of plant), jatyarka (a kind of tree), nimba (neem) leaves, or samudrafeni (sea salt). They should be treated with cow dung and then with purifying agents.

sloka: kuṣṭheṣu trivṛtā dantī triphalā ca virecane śastā||44||  sauvīrakaṃ tuṣodakamāloḍanamāsavāśca sīdhūni|  śaṃsantyadhoharāṇāṃ yathāvirekaṃ kramaśceṣṭaḥ||45||
translation: For kapha-kushthi patients, the prescribed action is to consume bitter and astringent tastes to eliminate Kapha and Pitta, use pittahara herbs, and manage sarpishtha (advanced stage of kushtha) through specific measures. This is the best treatment for Pitta-kushtha.

sloka: dārvībṛhatīsevyaiḥ paṭolapicumardamadanakṛtamālaiḥ|  sasnehairāsthāpyaḥ kuṣṭhī sakaliṅgayavamustaiḥ||46||  vātolbaṇaṃ viriktaṃ nirūḍhamanuvāsanārhamālakṣya|  phalamadhukanimbakuṭajaiḥ sapaṭolaiḥ sādhayetsneham||47||
translation: This action (of treating leprosy) is declared to be predominantly for the removal of the excess of doshas (impurities), and I will explain a generally applicable treatment for leprosy, due to the similarity of its causes.

sloka: saindhavadantīmaricaṃ phaṇijjhakaḥ pippalī karañjaphalam|  nasyaṃ syātsaviḍaṅgaṃ krimikuṣṭhakaphaprakopaghnam [1] ||48||  vairecanikairdhūmaiḥ ślokasthāneritaiḥ praśāmyanti|  kṛmayaḥ kuṣṭhakilāsāḥ prayojitairuttamāṅgasthāḥ||49||
translation: The resounding bark of the darvi (a kind of tree) or the sap of rasanjana, or cow's urine, when used along with abhaya (a type of plant), or sesame oil from a woman in her fertile period, can cure skin diseases in a month.

sloka: sthirakaṭhinamaṇḍalānāṃ svinnānāṃ prastarapraṇāḍībhiḥ|  kūrcairvighaṭṭitānāṃ raktotkleśo'panetavyaḥ||50||
translation: The root of patola and gawakshya, a triphala leaf, and a quarter portion of the outer skin of nagarapada, when separately made into a powder and mixed with water, makes for an excellent remedy to remove impurities. One should consume this mixture when their strength is depleted, or when afflicted by diseases such as kushtha, shoph, grahani dosha, arsha, krishrana, and visha jwara. This concoction can eliminate heart and abdominal pains, as well as irregular fevers, through the use of this six-ingredient mixture over a period of three days.

sloka: ānūpavārijānāṃ māṃsānāṃ poṭṭalaiḥ sukhoṣṇaiśca|  svinnotsannaṃ [1] vilikhet kuṣṭhaṃ tīkṣṇena śastreṇa||51||  rudhirāgamārthamathavā śṛṅgālābūni [2] yojayet kuṣṭhe|  pracchitamalpaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ virecayedvā jalaukobhiḥ||52||  ye lepāḥ kuṣṭhānāṃ yujyante nirhṛtāsradoṣāṇām|  saṃśodhitāśayānāṃ sadyaḥ siddhirbhavetteṣām||53||
translation: The powder, when prepared with nine portions of the offered portion, consisting of musta, vyosa, tripala, manjishtha, five-leafed plant,

sloka: yeṣu na śastraṃ kramate sparśendriyanāśanāni yāni syuḥ|  teṣu nipātyaḥ kṣāro raktaṃ doṣaṃ ca visrāvya||54||  pāṣāṇakaṭhinaparuṣe supte kuṣṭhe sthire purāṇe ca|  pītāgadasya kāryo viṣaiḥ pradeho'gadaiścānu||55||  stabdhāni suptasuptānyasvedanakaṇḍulāni kuṣṭhāni|  kūrcairdantītrivṛtākaravīrakarañjakuṭajānām||56||  jātyarkanimbajairvā patraiḥ śastraiḥ samudraphenairvā|  ghṛṣṭāni gomayairvā tataḥ pradehaiḥ pradehyāni||57||
translation: Of the Triphala, Visha, Katukanimbaka, Kalinga, Kavacha, Patola, Magadhi, Jani, Dvaya, Padma, Kamala, Bhuinimba, and Palasha, one should give a Vipala fruit after making it twice the size of a Trirud. Its Brahmi then, when made into powder, is an excellent sleep inducer.

sloka: mārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnaṃ karmoktaṃ pittakuṣṭhināṃ kāryam|  kaphapittaraktaharaṇaṃ tiktakaṣāyaiḥ praśamanaṃ ca||58||  sarpīṃṣi tiktakāni ca yaccānyadraktapittanut [1] karma|  bāhyābhyantaramagryaṃ tat kāryaṃ pittakuṣṭheṣu||59||
translation: The finest of substances, produced by the repeated use of lelīta (a type of plant), is distinguished by its taste and is recognized as such by experts. It is also known as sapta-dasha kuṣṭha-ghāti and mākṣika-dhātu in the form of urine.

sloka: doṣādhikyavibhāgādityetat karma kuṣṭhanut proktam|  vakṣyāmi kuṣṭhaśamanaṃ prāyastvagdoṣasāmānyāt||60||
translation: The best of all remedies for arthritis is either gold treated with Gandhaka (sulfur), or the use of copper with sulfur, which eliminates all diseases and has kept arthritis in check. Alternatively, a combination of vajra-shila (probably a type of stone) and jatu (possibly a type of plant) along with yogaraja, when used daily after isolating arthritis, can cure all diseases.

sloka: dārvī rasāñjanaṃ vā gomūtreṇa prabādhate kuṣṭham|  abhayā prayojitā vā māsaṃ savyoṣaguḍatailā||61||
translation: After boiling khadira and suradaru woods, when their essence is extracted, one should prepare a decoction in a prastha of water. To this, eight palas each of previously ground turmeric, black pepper, and gold-moistened camphor should be added. Placing this mixture in an iron vessel similar to the size of a fish's eye and ageing it for a month with madhu-asava (fermented preparation) will cure kushtha-kilasa (a skin disease). This is known as Madhva-asava.

sloka: mūlaṃ paṭolasya tathā gavākṣyāḥ pṛthak palāṃśaṃ triphalātvacaśca [1] |  syāttrāyamāṇā kaṭurohiṇī ca bhāgārdhikā nāgarapādayuktā||62||  palaṃ tathaiṣāṃ saha cūrṇitānāṃ jale śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  jīrṇe rasairdhanvamṛgadvijānāṃ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta||63||  kuṣṭhāni śophaṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi kṛcchrāṇi halīmakaṃ ca|  ṣaḍrātrayogena nihanti caiṣa hṛdbastiśūlaṃ viṣamajvaraṃ ca||64||
translation: Having filled a pot with clarified butter and a Kadiraka tree's bark, and also having ground six Palasa (type of tree) leaves and other materials into a powder, one should put them in the pot.

sloka: mustaṃ vyoṣaṃ triphalā mañjiṣṭhā dāru pañcamūlyau dve|  saptacchadanimbatvak saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||65||  cūrṇaṃ tarpaṇabhāgairnavabhiḥ saṃyojitaṃ samadhvājyam [1] |  siddhaṃ kuṣṭhanibarhaṇametat prāyogikaṃ bhakṣyam||66||  śvayathuṃ sapāṇḍurogaṃ śvitraṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi|  braghnabhagandarapiḍakākaṇḍūkoṭhāṃśca vinihanti||67||  iti mustādicūrṇa
translation: Consisting of three ingredients, a concoction made from Amla, Vidanga, and the best of Mushṭa, along with turmeric and peeled off bark; this is to be used for a month.

sloka: triphalāphalātiviṣākaṭukānimbakaliṅgakavacāpaṭolānām|  māgadhikārajanīdvayapadmakamūrvāviśālānām||68||  bhūnimbapalāśānāṃ dadyādvipalaṃ tatastrivṛddviguṇā|  tasyāśca punarbrāhmī taccūrṇaṃ suptinut paramam||69||
translation: In the morning, one should consume sesame seeds stored in a vessel. This, when done regularly for a month, will eliminate all diseases caused by vata, kapha, pitta, and mucus, as well as their accompanying symptoms such as cough, fatigue, and fever. As a result, one's complexion will not become pale, and instead, one will gain the golden hue of health.

sloka: lelītakaprayogo [1] rasena jātyāḥ samākṣikaḥ paramaḥ|  saptadaśakuṣṭhaghātī mākṣikadhātuśca mūtreṇa||70||
translation: Even in mustard seeds that have been treated with a mixture containing turmeric and salt, this special procedure is applicable only to those affected by phlegm-related disorders; it is not for those with other types of imbalances. (80)

sloka: śreṣṭhaṃ [2] gandhakayogāt suvarṇamākṣikaprayogādvā|  sarvavyādhinibarhaṇamadyāt kuṣṭhī rasaṃ ca nigṛhītam||71||  vajraśilājatusahitaṃ sahitaṃ vā yogarājena|  sarvavyādhipraśamanamadyātkuṣṭhī nigṛhya nityaṃ ca||72||
translation: The three-phala fruit juice, from Gauda region, with attractive label, that removes kushtha diseases, and combined with honey and the extract of dashamula, is praised for its excellence.

sloka: khadirasuradārusāraṃ śrapayitvā tadrasena toyārthaḥ|  kṣaudraprasthe kāryaḥ kārye te cāṣṭapalike ca||73||  tatrāścūrṇānāmaṣṭapalaṃ prakṣipettathā'mūni|  triphalaile tvaṅmaricaṃ patraṃ kanakaṃ ca karṣāṃśam||74||  matsyaṇḍikā madhusamā tanmāsaṃ jātamāyase bhāṇḍe|  madhvāsavamācarataḥ kuṣṭhakilāse śamaṃ yātaḥ||75||  iti madhvāsavaḥ
translation: Light, beneficial foods such as bitter plants like neem and those with astringent tastes like bhallataka, along with nimba, triphala, and ghee-infused dishes are recommended for leprosy patients. Traditional grains, wild fruits, meat, mudga lentils, and patola gourds should be avoided, as well as salty seafood, sugar, and sesame seeds. (82-83)

sloka: khadirakaṣāyadroṇaṃ kumbhe ghṛtabhāvite samāvāpya|  dravyāṇi cūrṇitāni ca ṣaṭpalikānyatra deyāni||76||
translation: The bark of the tree called Elā, Kusṭha, Dārvi, Śatapuṣpā, Citraka, and Vidaṇga are recommended for making a paste to apply in cases of Kusṭha (a skin disease).

sloka: triphalāvyoṣaviḍaṅgarajanīmustāṭarūṣakendrayavāḥ|  sauvarṇī ca tathā tvak chinnaruhā ceti tanmāsam||77||
translation: The gold-spotted, round emblic myrobalan fruit, three leaved fig, and the serpentine rock be reduced to a powder and mixed with Palasha tree's bark, to be applied on the body. With cow urine and salt water, this mixture will quickly dissolve and eliminate the impurities burned by the sun.

sloka: nidadhīta dhānyamadhye prātaḥ prātaḥ pibettato yuktyā|  māsena mahākuṣṭhaṃ hantyevālpaṃ tu pakṣeṇa||78||  arśaḥśvāsabhagandarakāsakilāsapramehaśoṣāṃśca|  nā bhavati kanakavarṇaḥ pītvā'riṣṭaṃ kanakabindum||79||
translation: Flesh, pepper, salt, night, tagara, sugar, smoke from the home, urine, excrement, lye, palaasha, and lepa for skin disease.

sloka: iti kanakabindvariṣṭam  kuṣṭheṣvanilakaphakṛteṣvevaṃ peyastathā'pi paitteṣu|  kṛtamālakvāthaścāpyeṣa viśeṣāt kaphakṛteṣu||80||
translation: The powder of Trapu and green leaves, the beautifully decorated and large-sized mandala, goat's milk, salted butter, wood-apple juice, and urine are all used in the ritual.

sloka: triphalāsavaśca gauḍaḥ sacitrakaḥ kuṣṭharogavinihantā|  kramukadaśamūladantīvarāṅgamadhuyogasaṃyuktaḥ||81||
translation: The mixing of lime, the dust of Palasa leaves, and the powder of Kshaara in water is recommended for use on meat; similarly, when these are mixed with husked rice, they become an excellent paste for destroying skin diseases, causing sweating, and killing germs.

sloka: laghūni cānnāni hitāni vidyāt kuṣṭheṣu śākani ca tiktakāni|  bhallātakaiḥ satriphalaiḥ sanimbairyuktāni cānnāni ghṛtāni caiva||82||  purāṇadhānyānyatha jāṅgalāni māṃsāni mudgāśca paṭolayuktāḥ|  śastā na gurvamlapayodadhīni nānūpamatsyā na guḍastilāśca||83||
translation: This is named "siddhārthaka" purification, consisting of emesis and purgation; mustard, datura, triphala, karanja, aragvadha, kalinga, yava; darvi, saptaparna; it removes impurities of the skin, blemishes, and disorders such as leprosy, fever, and poisoning.

sloka: elā kuṣṭhaṃ dārvī śatapuṣpā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhālepanamiṣṭaṃ rasāñjanaṃ cābhayā caiva||84||
translation: A treatment for leprosy is the application of a paste made from the seeds of karanja tree, a type of clay called sindhava, haridra, lodhra, and the roots of white karavi tree. The fruit of kutaja and karanja trees, along with manjishtha, sumana, and pravalaprvala, when made into a paste, is also an effective treatment for leprosy.

sloka: citrakamelāṃ bimbīṃ [1] vṛṣakaṃ trivṛdarkanāgarakam|  cūrṇīkṛtamaṣṭāhaṃ bhāvayitavyaṃ palāśasya||85||  kṣāreṇa gavāṃ mūtrasrutena tenāsya maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhidyante vilayanti ca liptānyarkābhitaptāni||86||
translation: The seed-born embryo of the Dhataki tree, the night-blossoming Jasmine, and the resin from Kushtha plants; as well as the paste and application made from Malati flowers.

sloka: māṃsī maricaṃ lavaṇaṃ rajanī tagaraṃ sudhā gṛhāddhūmaḥ|  mūtraṃ pittaṃ [2] kṣāraḥ pālāśaḥ kuṣṭhahā lepaḥ||87||
translation: The four types of pastes are Kushtanullepa, made from Kasha, Pistaka, Kaakamachi, and Rajavrksapatrani.

sloka: trapu sīsamayaścūrṇaṃ maṇḍalanut phalgucitrakau bṛhatī|  godhārasaḥ salavaṇo dāru ca mūtraṃ ca maṇḍalanut||88||
translation: The decoctions of the bark of aragvadha tree, barley, nimba, patala, khadira, and the root of saptaparna, when used in seven ways - as a snuff, for washing, drinking, anointing, gargling, and smearing, and also when used in the preparation of oil and ghee, are beneficial in treating skin diseases.

sloka: kadalīpalāśapāṭaliniculakṣārāmbhasā prasannena|  māṃseṣu toyakāryaṃ kāryaṃ piṣṭe ca kiṇve [3] ca||89||  tairmedakaḥ sujātaḥ kiṇvairjanitaṃ pralepanaṃ śastam|  maṇḍalakuṣṭhavināśanamātapasaṃsthaṃ kṛmighnaṃ ca||90||
translation: The concoction of triphala, nimba, patola, manjishtha, Rohini, and vaca, when consumed regularly, eliminates kapha-pitta caused kushthaa. When ghee is added to these same ingredients, it becomes effective in treating kushthaa caused by vata. This is a proven remedy using khadira, asana, daruharidra, and nimba.

sloka: mustaṃ madanaṃ triphalā karañja āragvadhakaliṅgayavāḥ|  dārvī sasaptaparṇā snānaṃ siddhārthakaṃ nāma||91||  eṣa kaṣāyo vamanaṃ virecanaṃ varṇakastathodgharṣaḥ|  tvagdoṣakuṣṭhaśophaprabādhanaḥ pāṇḍurogaghnaḥ||92||
translation: The myrobalan fruits, the root of kabijaki, katphala, haritaki, bakuchi, and the seeds of Rohini, citraka, durralabha, viddanga; the bitter aalabu, kampillaka, sarshapa, vasaca, dervi - with these, a potent oil is prepared that counteracts kushtha. This application, which includes rubbing and cleansing, is deemed appropriate.

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ karañjabījānyeḍagajaḥ kuṣṭhasūdano lepaḥ|  prapunnāḍabījasaindhavarasāñjanakapitthalodhrāśca||93||  śvetakaravīramūlaṃ kuṭajakarañjayoḥ phalaṃ tvaco dārvyāḥ|  sumanaḥpravālayukto lepaḥ kuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||94||
translation: This oil, made from the seeds of the White Karanji tree and castor beans, mixed with sesame oil and applied to skin diseases, is approved by physicians.

sloka: lodhrasya dhātakīnāṃ vatsakabījasya naktamālasya|  kalkaśca mālatīnāṃ kuṣṭheṣūnmardanālepau||95||
translation: The oil made from the roots of white karaveer, vidaanga, kushtha, arka, musta, and sigru, mixed with appropriate auxiliary materials and processed with cow's urine, when applied four times in increasing quantity after being mixed with kushtha, is known as swetakaraveeradi taila.

sloka: śairīṣī tvak puṣpaṃ kārpāsyā rājavṛkṣapatrāṇi|  piṣṭā ca kākamācī caturvidhaḥ kuṣṭhanullepaḥ||96||  iti lepāḥ
translation: The two roots of turmeric and haridra, the fruit of the large-sized citraka plant, munja grass, kutaja, tvaak, ku Shahasta, sura, daru, tumburu, vida, and arka, langalaka, the resin of kapikachhu, and Rohini - when mixed with mustard oil and applied four times in quantity to the affected area, can cure skin diseases like kustha, and alleviate vata and kapha doshas. This is known as the recipe for tiktakeshavadi tailam.

sloka: dārvyā rasāñjanasya ca nimbapaṭolasya khadirasārasya|  āragvadhavṛkṣakayostriphalāyāḥ saptaparṇasya||97||  iti ṣaṭ kaṣāyayogāḥ kuṣṭhaghnāḥ saptamaśca tiniśasya|  snāne pāne ca hitāstathā'ṣṭamaścāśvamārasya||98||  ālepanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameta eva ca kaṣāyāḥ|  tailaghṛtapākayoge ceṣyante kuṣṭhaśāntyartham||99||

triphalā nimbapaṭolaṃ mañjiṣṭhā rohiṇī vacā rajanī|  eṣa kaṣāyo'bhyasto nihanti kaphapittajaṃ kuṣṭham||100||  etaireva ca sarpiḥ siddhaṃ vātolbaṇaṃ jayati kuṣṭham|  eṣa ca kalpo diṣṭaḥ khadirāsanadārunimbānām||101||
translation: The properly prepared Katuka-alabu paste should be applied

sloka: kuṣṭhārkatutthakaṭphalamūlakabījāni rohiṇī kaṭukā|  kuṭajaphalotpalamustaṃ bṛhatīkaravīrakāsīsam||102||  eḍagajanimbapāṭhā durālabhā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  tiktālābukabījaṃ kampillakasarṣapau vacā dārvī||103||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kuṣṭhaghnaṃ yoga eṣa cālepaḥ|  udvartanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameṣa eveṣṭaḥ||104||
translation: The procedure is as follows: Apply a mixture of licorice, mustard seed, sulfur, and arsenic trioxide, mixed with oil, to the affected area once a day for seven days. After one month, free from impurities, one should bathe and discard this paste. This is the method for applying paste to the afflicted area.

sloka: śvetakaravīrakaraso gomūtraṃ citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭheṣu tailayogaḥ siddho'yaṃ sammato bhiṣajām||105||  iti śvetakaravīrādyaṃ tailam
translation: The oil extracted from black sesame seeds, flaxseeds, and radish seeds is considered beneficial for Kushtha (a skin disease). Also, the juice of Khadira (a type of tree) is recommended.

sloka: śvetakaravīrapallavamūlatvagvatsako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhārkamūlasarṣapaśigrutvagrohiṇī kaṭukā||106||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kalkaiḥ pādāṃśikairgavāṃ mūtram|  dattvā tailacaturguṇamabhyaṅgāt kuṣṭhakaṇḍūghnam||107||  iti śvetakaravīrapallavādyaṃ tailam
translation: The root of manjistha, darvi, and kampillaka, when cooked in ghee and mixed with the residue of samathu, can be used to treat an inflamed foot and a leg affected by kushtha. Even a stubborn kushtha on the skin is cured by this application. This is described as the treatment for vipadika (inflammation of feet) using ghee-cooked herbs.

sloka: tiktālābukabījaṃ dve tutthe rocanā haridre dve|  bṛhatīphalameraṇḍaḥ saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||108||  kāsīsahiṅguśigrutryūṣaṇasuradārutumburuviḍaṅgam|  lāṅgālakaṃ kuṭajatvak kaṭukākhyā rohiṇī caiva||109|| sarṣapatailaṃ kalkairetairmūtre caturguṇe sādhyam|  kaṇḍūkuṣṭhavināśanamabhyaṅgānmārutakaphahantṛ||110|| iti tiktekṣvākvāditailam
translation: Let varāharrudhiram (the mud of a pig wallowing place) and saindhavam (rock salt) be mixed in equal proportions as a paste for application to kustumburuṇi (ringworms or similar skin disorders); also, apply the powder of kaṭuka (a type of plant) to them.

sloka: kanakakṣīrī śailā bhārgī dantyāḥ phalāni mūlaṃ ca|  jātīpravālasarṣapalaśunaviḍaṅgaṃ karañjatvak||111||  saptacchadārkapallavamūlatvaṅnimbacitrakāsphotāḥ|  guñjairaṇḍaṃ bṛhatīmūlakasurasārjakaphalāni||112||  kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhā mustaṃ tumburumūrvāvacāḥ saṣaḍgranthāḥ [1] |  eḍagajakuṭajaśigrutryūṣaṇabhallātakakṣavakāḥ||113||  haritālamavākpuṣpī tutthaṃ kampillako'mṛtāsañjñaḥ|  saurāṣṭrī kāsīsaṃ dārvītvak sarjikālavaṇam||114||  kalkairetaistailaṃ karavīrakamūlapallavakaṣāye|  sārṣapamathavā tailaṃ gomūtracaturguṇaṃ sādhyam||115||
translation: Made pure by lime, with hair made of kusa grass, having consumed an offering of fermented liquor, smeared with cowdung and barley, and capable of cleansing moles and skin disorders.

sloka: sthāpyaṃ kaṭukālābuni tatsiddhaṃ tena maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhindyādbhiṣagabhyaṅgātkṛmīṃśca kaṇḍūṃ ca vinihanyāt||116||  iti kanakakṣīrītailam
translation: The pastes of belleric myrobalan, Indian barberry, deodar tree, khadira wood, and black myrobalan are, for those suffering from skin diseases, to be applied again and again, all mixed with licorice extract and milk, as they are destroyers of wind, phlegm, and bile.

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ tamālapatraṃ maricaṃ samanaḥśilaṃ sakāsīsam|  tailena yuktamuṣitaṃ saptāhaṃ bhājane tāmre||117||  tenāliptaṃ sidhmaṃ saptāhāhyeti [1] tiṣṭhato gharme|  māsānnavaṃ kilāsaṃ snānaṃ muktvā viśuddhatanoḥ||118||  iti sidhme lepaḥ
translation: By using the Kushtha (an herb), rock salt, Sauvira salt, black mustard seeds, and other antiparasitic substances, one can appease the itching caused by worms and the skin disease known as "Krimikushthamandala."

sloka: sarṣapakarañjakoṣātakīnāṃ tailānyatheṅgudīnāṃ ca|  kuṣṭheṣu hitānyāhustailaṃ yaccāpi khadirasārasya||119||
translation: The root of drugs, the cause of intoxication, and the sap of edaga and gaja plants; this preparation, when mixed with kanjika, is called udvartana lepa.

sloka: jīvantī mañjiṣṭhā dārvī kampillakaḥ payastuttham|  eṣa ghṛtatailapākaḥ siddhaḥ siddhe ca sarjarasaḥ||120||  deyaḥ samadhūcchiṣṭo vipādikā tena śāmyate'bhyaktā|  carmaikakuṣṭhakiṭimaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ śāmyatyalasakaṃ ca||121||  iti vipādikāharaghṛtataile
translation: Triphala garments, for drinking and bathing, as well as for massaging and anointing; also Rohini, Bṛhatī, Sevyapatraka, Khadira, Vaghātaka, Kubhara, Ohtika, Karavīra, Śasya, Dhavanimba - these seven are beneficial when used in bathing and drinking.

sloka: kiṇvaṃ [1] varāharudhiraṃ pṛthvīkā saindhavaṃ ca lepaḥ syāt|  lepo yojyaḥ kustumburūṇi kuṣṭhaṃ ca maṇḍalanut||122||
translation: A perfectly made paste of arka, lodhra, patala, candana, and the outer layers of plants like jala, loha, and keshara, for treating the symptoms of excess pitta, kapha, and kushtha.

sloka: pūtīkadārujaṭilāḥ pakvasurā kṣaudramudgaparṇyau ca|  lepaḥ sakākanāso maṇḍalakuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||123||
translation: The paste of turmeric, agaru, kapittha, lodhra, padma-kasthuri, pichumarda, and cooling sandalwood powder are beneficial for use in bathing and drinking, alleviating Pitta and Kushtha diseases.

sloka: citrakaśobhāñjanakau guḍūcyapāmārgadevadārūṇi|  khadiro dhavaśca lepaḥ śyāmā dantī dravantī ca||124||  lākṣārasāñjanailāḥ punarnavā ceti kuṣṭhino lepāḥ|  dadhimaṇḍayutāḥ sarve deyāḥ ṣaṇmārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnāḥ||125||
translation: The application of musk, the fruits of the Pangrum tree, and the leaves of a Chandan tree, served by an antidote, and the bitter juice of the Rohini plant.

sloka: eḍagajakuṣṭhasaindhavasauvīrakasarṣapaiḥ kṛmighnaiśca|  kṛmikuṣṭhamaṇḍalākhyaṃ dadrūkuṣṭhaṃ ca śamamupaiti||126||
translation: Anointed with sesame oil washed in a bitter taste, and smeared with a paste of sandalwood, honey, and various other oils and powders, on burninating pitta (inflamed skin lesions).

sloka: eḍagajaḥ sarjaraso mūlakabījaṃ ca sidhmakuṣṭhānām|  kāñjikayuktaṃ tu pṛthaṅmatamidamudvartanaṃ lepāḥ||127||
translation: When wet, one slips; when burning, one jumps; in the midday sun, the shadow disappears; in cold, the body becomes shivery; during hunger, even ghee tastes bitter.

sloka: vāsā triphalā pāne snāne codvartane pralepe ca|  bṛhatīsevyapaṭolāḥ sasārivā rohiṇī caiva||128||  khadirāvaghātakakubharohītakalodhrakuṭajadhavanimbāḥ|  saptacchadakaravīrāḥ śasyante snānapāneṣu||129||
