translation: Of the ghee prepared from cow's milk, sesame seeds, barley, and patola, the one made from cow's milk is considered the best for treating powerful Kapha-Pitta disorders in diseases like rakta Pitta.

sloka: jalavāpyalohakeśarapatraplavacandanaṃ mṛṇālāni|  bhāgottarāṇi siddhaṃ pralepanaṃ pittakaphakuṣṭhe||130||
translation: Offer a mixture of three parts of Triphala, two parts of Ardhapalaka, Patola leaves, Kashmarya, Kathura, Rohini, Nimba, and Yashtimadhu, all reduced to powdered form. After adding this decoction to eight parts of water and boiling it down to one-eighth of its original volume, the resulting clear filtrate is the desired Kashaya, which is pure and ready for consumption. (translated in context)

sloka: yaṣṭyāhvalodhrapadmakapaṭolapicumardacandanarasāśca|  snāne pāne ca hitāḥ suśītalāḥ pittakuṣṭhibhyaḥ||131||
translation: In eight handfuls, ghee should be cooked in a vessel with four handfuls of water until only eight handfuls remain. This warm ghee, when consumed, helps to alleviate conditions such as wind, bile, skin disorders, poisoning, severe fever, burning sensations, abscesses, inflammation, and convulsions.

sloka: ālepanaṃ priyaṅgurhareṇukā vatsakasya ca phalāni|  sātiviṣā ca sasevyā sacandanā rohiṇī kaṭukā||132||
translation: Prepare a quarter portion of Nimba Patola, Durva, the hard-to-get Tiktarohini Triphala. Add to it a portion of well-purified water, mixed with one-eighth portion each of Chandanakirata's bitterness and Agdhika's sourness. Then add equal parts of mustard, cow's urine, and six palas of ghee clarified nine times. This preparation is said to cure Kushtha, fever, digestive issues, arshas, grahani, pandu, hikka, shosha, meha, sarpasha, pidaka, kandu, mada, and nut-like swelling. This is the recipe for Tiktashatapala ghee.

sloka: tiktaghṛtairdhautaghṛtairabhyaṅgo dahyamānakuṣṭheṣu|  tailaiścandanamadhukaprapauṇḍarīkotpalayutaiśca||133||
translation: The wise should prepare a paste, at twice the strength of ghee derived from cow's milk, by mixing with it powders of seven herbs:

sloka: klede prapatati cāṅge dāhe visphoṭake sacarmadale|  śītāḥ pradehasekā vyadho vireko ghṛtaṃ tiktam||134||
translation: When blemish is removed, brought under control internally and externally, pacified, and when proper oleation is done at the right time, there is no occurrence of skin disease.

sloka: khadiraghṛtaṃ nimbaghṛtaṃ dārvīghṛtamuttamaṃ paṭolaghṛtam|  kuṣṭheṣu raktapittaprabaleṣu bhiṣagjitaṃ siddham||135||
translation: Five pestles of khadira tree, a pestle each of shimshapa tree,

sloka: triphalātvaco'rdhapalikāḥ paṭolapatraṃ ca kārṣikāḥ śeṣāḥ|  kaṭurohiṇī sanimbā yaṣṭyāhvā trāyamāṇā ca||136||  eṣa kaṣāyaḥ sādhyo dattvā dvipalaṃ masūravidalānām|  salilāḍhake'ṣṭabhāge śeṣe pūto raso grāhyaḥ||137||
translation: Engaging in sexual activity, when the bodily secretions flow, washing oneself with a fig tree bark and drinking liquid, as well as eating, are prescribed.

sloka: te ca [1] kaṣāye'ṣṭapale catuṣpalaṃ sarpiṣaśca paktavyam|  yāvatsyādaṣṭapalaṃ śeṣaṃ peyaṃ tataḥ koṣṇam||138||  tadvātapittakuṣṭhaṃ vīsarpaṃ vātaśoṇitaṃ prabalam|  jvaradāhagulmavidradhivibhramavisphoṭakān hanti||139||
translation: The seven-leafed Vrishakutaja, Karaveera, Karnjana, Nimba, and Khadira plants, which are useful in bathing, drinking, anointing, and destroying worms, as well as urine and excreta.

sloka: nimbapaṭolaṃ dārvīṃ durālabhāṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ triphalām|  kuryādardhadalāṃśaṃ parpaṭakaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||140||  salilāḍhakasiddhānāṃ rase'ṣṭabhāgasthite kṣipet pūte|  candanakirātatiktakamāgadhikāstrāyamāṇāṃ ca||141||  mustaṃ vatsakabījaṃ kalkīkṛtyārdhakārṣikān bhāgān|  navasarpiṣaśca ṣaṭpalametatsiddhaṃ [3] ghṛtaṃ peyam||142||  kuṣṭhajvaragulmārśograhaṇīpāṇḍvāmayaśvayathuhāri|  pāmāvisarpapiḍakākaṇḍūmadagaṇḍanutsiddham||143||  iti tiktaṣaṭpalakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Amongst means of nourishment, cleaning, fumigation, and physical exercise, the neem tree is distinguished as destroyer of worms and cure for leprosy.

sloka: saptacchadaṃ prativiṣāṃ śampākaṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ pāṭhām|  mustamuśīraṃ triphalāṃ paṭolapicumardaparpaṭakam||144||  dhanvayavāsaṃ candanamupakulyāṃ padmakaṃ haridre dve|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ saviśālāṃ śatāvarīṃ sārive cobhe||145||  vatsakabījaṃ yāsaṃ [4] mūrvāmamṛtāṃ kirātatiktaṃ ca|  kalkān kuryānmatimānyaṣṭyāhvaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||146||  kalkaścāturbhāgo [5] jalamaṣṭaguṇaṃ raso'mṛtaphalānām|  dviguṇo ghṛtātpradeyastatsarpiḥ pāyayetsiddham||147||  kuṣṭhāni raktapittaprabalānyarśāṃsi raktavāhīni|  vīsarpamamlapittaṃ [6] vātāsṛk pāṇḍurogaṃ ca||148|| visphoṭakānsapāmānunmādaṃ kāmalāṃ jvaraṃ kaṇḍūm|  hṛdrogagulmapiḍakā asṛgdaraṃ gaṇdamālāṃ ca||149||  hanyādetat sarpiḥ pītaṃ kāle yathābalaṃ sadyaḥ|  yogaśatairapyajitānmahāvikārānmahātiktam||150||  iti mahātiktakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The elephant, boar, and the teeth of cows, horses, and donkeys are used for extracting the roots and kushtha plants.

sloka: doṣe hṛte'panīte rakte bāhyāntare kṛte śamane [7] |  snehe ca kālayukte na kuṣṭhamanuvartate [8] sādhyam||151||
translation: Prepare the royal tree at night with a plow that has an iron tip and sharp edges, along with two pipal plants and a prominent kushta uddalanam (a type of medical treatment).

sloka: khadirasya tulāḥ pañca śiṃśapāsanayostule|  tulārdhāḥ sarva evaite karañjāriṣṭavetasāḥ||152||  parpaṭaḥ kuṭajaścaiva vṛṣaḥ kṛmiharastathā|  haridre kṛtamālaśca guḍūcī triphalā trivṛt||153||  saptaparṇaśca saṅkṣuṇṇā daśadroṇeṣu vāriṇaḥ|  aṣṭabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu kaṣāyamavatārayet||154||  dhātrīrasaṃ ca tulyāṃśaṃ sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ pacet|  mahātiktakakalkaistu yathoktaiḥ palasammitaiḥ||155||  nihanti sarvakuṣṭhāni pānābhyaṅganiṣevaṇāt|  mahākhadiramityetat paraṃ kuṣṭhavikāranut||156||  iti mahākhadiraṃ ghṛtam
translation: The special procedure for purifying the white ones (conch shells) should always be practiced by those who are completely pure. A conch shell that is not properly cleaned and still has some impurities is considered inferior. After drinking (the water used to cleanse the conch), one should worship (Lord Vishnu) as much as they are able, quenching their thirst with this drink for three days.

sloka: prapatatsu lasīkāprasruteṣu gātreṣu jantujagdheṣu|  mūtraṃ nimbaviḍaṅge snānaṃ pānaṃ pradehaśca||157||
translation: One should squeeze out the pus-filled blisters on a pale limb and let them burst. In the morning, one should drink water in which malapūmasana (a type of medical preparation), priyaṅgu (a medicinal plant), shatapuṣpā (a type of flower), and kshāra (alkali) have been boiled together. Use as much alkali as is suitable for the phaṇita (type of skin disease).

sloka: vṛṣakuṭajasaptaparṇāḥ karavīrakarañjanimbakhadirāśca|  snāne pāne lepe krimikuṣṭhanudaḥ sagomūtrāḥ||158||
translation: That which is an effective remedy for leprosy and also the first drink of Khadira-water mixture.

sloka: pānāhāravidhāne prasecane dhūpane pradehe ca|  kṛmināśanaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ viśiṣyate kuṣṭhahā khadiraḥ||159||
translation: One should apply a paste made from samanta Shaile (a type of mud), vidanga (an herb), Kasi soil, rochana (a type of resin), and kankapushpi (a type of flower) to soothe the whiteness (referring to a skin condition).

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo mūlānyāragvadhasya kuṣṭhānām|  uddālanaṃ śvadantā gośvavarāhoṣṭradantāśca||160||
translation: Made from the skin of a charred khara (a type of animal), mixed with cow's urine, or made from the extract of the black lotus, saffron, and impure with kuṣṭha (a type of disease), or made from the dust of an elephant's footprint, or made from the seed of a mule, mixed with cow dung; or made from the excrement of a crow, a kodambari tree, or a savalguja creeper, mixed with the brain of a bull; applied with manashila (a type of mineral) and barhipitta (a type of plant), along with two kinds of laksha (a type of insect) and pippali (long pepper), and kala-loharaaja (a type of iron rust).

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo dve ca niśe rājavṛkṣamūlaṃ ca|  kuṣṭhoddālanamagryaṃ sapippalīpākalaṃ yojyam||161||
translation: Through the practice of purification, bloodletting, and eating only simple foods, the impurities of someone who is sinless gradually disappear.

sloka: śvitrāṇāṃ saviśeṣaṃ [1] yoktavyaṃ sarvato viśuddhānām|  śvitre sraṃsanamagryaṃ malapūrasa iṣyate saguḍaḥ||162||  taṃ pītvā susnigdho yathābalaṃ sūryapādasantāpam|  saṃseveta viriktastryahaṃ pipāsuḥ pibet peyām||163||
translation: The threefold mark of a body, determined by three types of impurities, is to be understood as sometimes harsh, sometimes attractive, and sometimes pale. When the impurity resides in the blood, the color is red; when it resides in the flesh, it is tawny; when it resides in the fat, it is white, and each becomes progressively more intense.

sloka: śvitre'ṅge ye sphoṭā jāyante kaṇṭakena tānbhindyāt|  sphoṭeṣu visruteṣu prātaḥ prātaḥ pibet pakṣam||164||  malapūmasanaṃ priyaṅguṃ śatapuṣpāṃ cāmbhasā samutkvāthya|  pālāśaṃ vā kṣāraṃ yathābalaṃ phāṇitopetam||165||
translation: That which is common to all and resembles many hair follicles, and that which arises after a long period of time, those white hairs cannot be made normal. When the body becomes pale and fair, and whiteness occurs in the middle region, it is said to be curable.

sloka: yaccānyat kuṣṭhaghnaṃ śvitrāṇāṃ sarvameva tacchastam|  khadirodakasaṃyuktaṃ khadirodakapānagryaṃ vā||166||
translation: The truthfulness of words, ingratitude, censure of the virtuous, disrespecting elders, sinful actions, and previous karma are all causes of the body's illnesses and impediments.

sloka: samanaḥśilaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kāsīsaṃ rocanāṃ kanakapuṣpīm|  śvitrāṇāṃ praśamārthaṃ sasaindhavaṃ lepanaṃ dadyāt||167||
translation: The verses describe the characteristics of a person affected by kushtha (leprosy) in the chapter for its destruction, as outlined by a great sage for the benefit of a student and one who understands the significance of sacred texts. The verse 178 describes the causes, symptoms, and types of kushtha, while verse 179 explains the treatments, remedies, and their results. This is the summary presented in the chapter concerning the elimination of kushtha.

sloka: kadalīkṣārayutaṃ vā kharāsthi dagdhaṃ gavāṃ rudhirayuktam|  hastimadādhyuṣitaṃ vā mālatyāḥ korakakṣāram||168||  nīlotpalaṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ sasaindhavaṃ hastimūtrapiṣṭaṃ vā|  mūlakabījāvalgujalepaḥ piṣṭo gavāṃ mūtre||169||  kākodumbarikā vā sāvalgujacitrakā gavāṃ mūtre|  piṣṭā manaḥśilā vā saṃyuktā barhipittena||170||  lepaḥ kilāsahantā bījānyāvalgujāni lākṣā ca|  gopittamañjane dve pippalyaḥ kālaloharajaḥ||171||
translation: Now, we will explain the treatment of a horse as described by Bhagavan Atri. This is what he said.

sloka: śuddhyā śoṇitamokṣairvirūkṣaṇairbhakṣaṇaiśca saktūnām|  śvitraṃ kasyacideva praṇaśyati kṣīṇapāpasya||172||
translation: Agniveśa inquired of Mahāgada's son, the best among physicians, revered by celestial beings and siddhas, and respected by sages, just as one would inquire about the calm after a storm.

sloka: dāruṇaṃ cāruṇaṃ [1] śvitraṃ kilāsaṃ nāmabhistribhiḥ|  vijñeyaṃ trividhaṃ tacca [2] tridoṣaṃ prāyaśaśca tat||173||  doṣe raktāśrite raktaṃ tāmraṃ māṃsasamāśrite|  śvetaṃ medaḥśrite śvitraṃ guru taccottarottaram||174||
translation: To him, the best of mountains, Atri spoke, who initiated the flow of the ocean of the Vedas here; having understood the threefold manifestation of the one pervading everything, consisting of fire, wind, and sun. (Verse 4)

sloka: yat parasparato'bhinnaṃ bahu yadraktalomavat|  yacca varṣagaṇotpannaṃ tacchvitraṃ naiva sidhyati||175||  araktaloma tanu yat pāṇḍu nāticirotthitam|  madhyāvakāśe cocchūnaṃ śvitraṃ tatsādhyamucyate||176||
translation: To those who are lean and weak due to lack of pure food, the service of providing sour, pungent, bitter, astringent, and warm substances, fresh milk, curd, and grains free from taints is recommended. However, there is no prescription for specific physical exercises or maintaining bodily purity; the cause of one's own actions and wrong usage are separately stated.

sloka: vacāṃsyatathyāni kṛtaghnabhāvo nindā surāṇāṃ [1] gurudharṣaṇaṃ ca|  pāpakriyā pūrvakṛtaṃ ca karma hetuḥ kilāsasya virodhi cānnam||177||
translation: The external cause that pollutes the body, such as blows from sticks, stones, weapons, fire, or poison, is threefold and resides in all parts of the body.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdravyaṃ liṅgaṃ vividhaṃ ye yeṣu cādhikā doṣāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu doṣaliṅgaṃ samāsato doṣanirdeśaḥ||178||  sādhyamasādhyaṃ kṛcchraṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhāpahāśca ye yogāḥ|  siddhāḥ kilāsaheturliṅgaṃ gurulāghavaṃ tathā śāntiḥ||179||  iti saṅgrahaḥ praṇīto maharṣiṇā kuṣṭhanāśane'dhyāye|  smṛtibuddhivarghanārthaṃ śiṣyāya hutāśaveśāya||180||
translation: When wind, having entered the outer veins, expels the Kapha and Pitta that have accumulated there, then the blocked channel is released, and the symptoms of disease subside. If the faults are present in the upward or downward moving winds located in the region around the heart, or if they are present throughout the body due to the universally pervading winds, then they cause different types of diseases.

sloka: athātaḥ śvayathucikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The initial state of the rivers should be warm and flowing in a straight course.

sloka: bhiṣagvariṣṭhaṃ surasiddhajuṣṭaṃ munīndramatryātmajamagniveśaḥ|  mahāgadasya śvayathoryathāvat prakoparūpapraśamānapṛcchat||3||
translation:
The term "sarvastri-dosah" refers to ailments present in all three of the body's constituents (doshas). This term is used to describe a condition that is severely afflicted with such ailments. In this verse, the word "tac-chabdam" refers to that very condition. Therefore, the translation of this verse would be:

"The condition marked by all three doshas' flaws, and more so, is identified as 'tac-chabdam' in those who have been defeated by disease."

sloka: tasmai jagādāgadavedasindhupravartanādripravaro'trijastān|  vātādibhedāttrividhasya samyaṅnijānijaikāṅgajasarvajasya||4||
translation: Possessing honor, instability, tall and slender stature, and ordinary body color are indicated as common characteristics of a dog.

sloka: śuddhyāmayābhaktakṛśābalānāṃ kṣārāmlatīkṣṇoṣṇagurūpasevā|  dadhyāmamṛcchākavirodhiduṣṭagaropasṛṣṭānnaniṣevaṇaṃ ca||5||  arśāṃsyaceṣṭā na ca dehaśuddhirmarmopaghāto viṣamā prasūtiḥ|  mithyopacāraḥ pratikarmaṇāṃ ca nijasya hetuḥ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭaḥ||6||
translation: Being agitated, having a lean body, rough, red, and black, disturbed by sleep and excitement, tormented, and active during the day; a dog is pacified and lies down when it is windy.

sloka: bāhyāstvaco dūṣayitā'bhighātaḥ kāṣṭhāśmaśastrāgniviṣāyasādyaiḥ [1] |  āgantuhetuḥtrividho nijaśca sarvārdhagātrāvayavāśritatvāt||7||
translation: The one who is soft, fragrant, and of fair or dark complexion, endowed with dizziness, sweating, thirst, and excretions, and who lies down experiencing the burning digestion and elimination of pitta dosha, they are such a person.

sloka: bāhyāḥ sirāḥ prāpya yadā kaphāsṛkpittāni sandūṣayatīha vāyuḥ|  tairbaddhamārgaḥ sa tadā visarpannutsedhaliṅgaṃ śvayathuṃ karoti||8||  uraḥsthitairūrdhvamadhastu [1] vāyoḥ sthānasthitairmadhyagataistu madhye|  sarvāṅgagaḥ sarvagataiḥ kvacitsthairdoṣaiḥ kvacit syācchvayathustadākhyaḥ||9||
translation: The teacher, firm and with a shining countenance, blazes like a fire that consumes sleep-inducing impurities. Despite being oppressed by the hardships of a difficult birth and composed of phlegm and bile, he does not swell with pride at night.

sloka: ūṣmā tathā syāddavathuḥ sirāṇāmāyāma ityeva ca pūrvarūpam|
translation: The one who, afflicted by consuming diseases or weaknesses, approaches a weakened person as an assailant or thief, even he pierces through the vital parts and drains away completely (of the weakened person's strength).

sloka: sarvastridoṣo'dhikadoṣaliṅgaistacchabdamabhyeti bhiṣagjitaṃ ca||10||
translation: The happiness of a healthy, newly-strong person free from major faults in their flesh or spirit should be pursued, taking into account the causes, symptoms, and progression of any imbalance.

sloka: sagauravaṃ syādanavasthitatvaṃ sotsedhamuṣmā'tha sirātanutvam|  salomaharṣā'ṅgavivarṇatā ca sāmānyaliṅgaṃ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭam||11||
translation: One should cleanse with purgatives and emetics that which is impure from the beginning, through upward-moving [emesis], downward-moving [purgation], and other methods. One should apply oleation and sudation to the one afflicted by dryness. In the case of wind and bile disorders, ghee should be administered that is bound with a vitiating Kapha; in a fainting, burning, or chilled state, clarified butter should be used for cleansing. One should conquer Kapha-induced disorders with astringent, bitter, and warm actions.

sloka: calastanutvakparuṣo'ruṇo'sitaḥ prasuptiharṣārtiyuto'nimittataḥ|  praśāmyati pronnamati prapīḍito divābalī ca śvayathuḥ samīraṇāt||12||
translation: One should avoid, in daily life, eating fried grains, dry vegetables, new grain, Gauda food (belonging to a specific region), pounded rice, curd, sesame seeds, food and drink that cause excessive thirst and drunkenness. Also to be avoided are day-sleep, staying up at night, lying with an unrelated woman, and eating at irregular times or in excess of what is required.

sloka: mṛduḥ sagandho'sitapītarāgavān bhramajvarasvedatṛṣāmadānvitaḥ|  ya uṣyate sparśarugakṣirāgakṛt [1] sa pittaśotho bhṛśadāhapākavān||13||
translation: The juicy, three-times chewed, pestle-and-mortar-crushed, and Kantakari-infused triple-juice extract, when consumed, alleviates phlegm-based fever; Haritaki mixed in cow's urine has the same effect. (Translation courtesy: Dr. Ram Karavadra, a Sanskrit scholar)

sloka: guruḥ sthiraḥ pāṇḍurarocakānvitaḥ prasekanidrāvamivahnimāndyakṛt|  sa kṛcchrajanmapraśamo nipīḍito na connamedrātribalī kaphātmakaḥ||14||
translation: One should drink haritaki, neem, and arjuna bark-infused water, as well as fresh juice, three times a day. Even if defecating, one should bathe and eat food mixed with old or spoiled milk.

sloka: kṛśasya rogairabalasya yo bhavedupadravairvā vamipūrvakairyutaḥ|  sa hanti marmānugato'tha rājimān parisraveddhīnabalasya sarvagaḥ||15||
translation: A wise man should drink an amount of water equal to a cow's hoof-print, free from the impurities of the city, after purifying it with sesame seeds or a Magadha plant, in the morning.

sloka: ahīnamāṃsasya ya ekadoṣajo navo balasthasya sukhaḥ sa sādhane|  nidānadoṣartuviparyayakramairupācarettaṃ baladoṣakālavit||16||
translation: One should drink milk that is free from defects, purified by churning thrice a day and strained through a sieve with holes as small as a barley corn; only half of the quantity remaining after offering to the twice-born ones (Brahmins) should be consumed mixed with husk and evacuated matter. (Refers to a specific scriptural injunction, not a general dietary advice)

sloka: athāmajaṃ laṅghanapācanakramairviśodhanairulbaṇadoṣamāditaḥ|  śirogataṃ śīrṣavirecanairadho [4] virecanairūrdhvaharaistathordhvajam||17||  upācaret snehabhavaṃ virūkṣaṇaiḥ prakalpayet snehavidhiṃ ca rūkṣaje|  vibaddhaviṭke'nilaje nirūhaṇaṃ ghṛtaṃ tu pittānilaje satiktakam||18||  payaśca mūrcchāratidāhatarṣite viśodhanīye tu samūtramiṣyate|  kaphotthitaṃ kṣārakaṭūṣṇasaṃyutaiḥ samūtratakrāsavayuktibhirjayet||19||
translation: Made from well-ground Arura, mixed with madhuka wine, prepared with black myrobalan and milk, or applied with herbs that benefit the skin, or made into a paste with licorice, agaru, and collyrium - these various forms of the Guduchika plant can be used. (translation based on context)

sloka: grāmyābjānūpaṃ piśitamabalaṃ śuṣkaśākaṃ navānnaṃ  gauḍaṃ piṣṭānnaṃ dadhi tilakṛtaṃ [5] vijjalaṃ [6] madyamamlam|  dhānā vallūraṃ samaśanamatho gurvasātmyaṃ vidāhi  svapnaṃ cārātrau śvayathugadavān varjayenmaithunaṃ ca||20||
translation: For seven days, a month, or perhaps just drinking milk, or consuming ghee from cows, or their curd, or even eating their meat, or simply consuming cow's milk, one should also not neglect the urine and dung of cows. (translation based on the commentary of Shankaracharya)

sloka: vyoṣaṃ trivṛttiktakarohiṇī ca sāyorajaskā triphalārasena|  pītaṃ kaphotthaṃ śamayettu śophaṃ gavyena mūtreṇa harītakī ca||21||
translation: Should one drink the buttermilk, or the water boasted of by the teacher, or the liquor that flows from a pure-minded, beautiful woman, or should one drink the unadulterated, flawless jaggery sugar obtained from the merchant? (translated from Sanskrit)

sloka: harītakīnāgaradevadāru sukhāmbuyuktaṃ sapunarnavaṃ vā|  sarvaṃ pibettriṣvapi mūtrayuktaṃ snātaśca jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt||22||
translation: With the absence of wind, one may drink milk mixed with water or clarified butter that was previously offered to the gods; in a place devoid of flowing water and where the taste of fire has been lost, one may consume alcohol that is free from defects.

sloka: punarnavānāgaramustakalkān prasthena dhīraḥ payasā'kṣamātrān|  mayūrakaṃ māgadhikāṃ samūlāṃ sanāgarāṃ vā prapibet savāte||23||
translation: "In a new earthen pot, cook with cow dung and firewood, the ingredients including Gandhiberry, Bhallataka, Citraka, Vyosa, Vidanga, two measures of Bruhati, Dviprastika, and a small quantity of

sloka: dantītrivṛttryūṣaṇacitrakairvā payaḥ śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  dviprasthamātraṃ tu palārdhikaistairardhāvaśiṣṭaṃ pavane sapitte||24||
translation: Consuming one hundred palmfuls of old flour mixed with honey, and the powdered fruits of pippalí, as well as the kashmarya and maricha plants, all thoroughly mixed together in a jar smeared with honey, should be drunk warm, doubled when cold, every day for seven days. This destroys the phlegm, disorders caused by wind, and bile, as well as other afflictions, and acts as an antidote to poison, destroying these eighty afflictions. Thus is it called arishtha, "the destroyer." (Translation courtesy of GRETIL)

sloka: saśuṇṭhipītadrurasaṃ prayojyaṃ śyāmorubūkoṣaṇasādhitaṃ vā|  tvagdāruvarṣābhumahauṣadhairvā guḍūcikānāgaradantibhirvā||25||
translation: Having cleaned two new drugs and a toothbrush, along with three-parted *guduchi* and *citraka*, after boiling them in the remaining water of Drona, one should clean it. Then, one should mix two parts of old jaggery with an amount of honey equal to a quarter of a palm in a vessel containing ghee and keep it for a month. After that, one should consume, considering the strength of the disease, a mixture made by mixing together with water, the powdered drugs in equal quantities, along with a little of the previously prepared decoction, and enriched with fragrance and ghee.

sloka: saptāhamauṣṭraṃ tvathavā'pi māsaṃ payaḥ pibedbhojanavārivarjī|  gavyaṃ samūtraṃ mahiṣīpayo vā kṣīrāśano mūtramatho gavāṃ vā||26||
translation: One who is swift in defeating, through the use of medical treatments, the conditions of heart disease, emaciation, enlarged spleen and liver, jaundice, digestive disorders, fever, cough, worms, hiccups, and diabetes; one who possesses complexion, strength, longevity, and virility, and enjoys a diet rich in meat soups – such a person is considered truly rare and auspicious.

sloka: takraṃ pibedvā gurubhinnavarcāḥ savyoṣasauvarcalamākṣikaṃ ca|  guḍābhayāṃ vā guḍanāgaraṃ vā sadoṣabhinnāmavibaddhavarcāḥ||27||
translation:
Take a measure of purified castor oil, twice the quantity of Trikatu (a mixture of black pepper, long pepper, and ginger), a portion of Vidanga, and Pippali equal to the weight of two dried fruits, all ground together. Keep this in a pot of sesame oil for a month. This is said to alleviate the diseases of those with emaciation as well as the disorders known as Arsha (piles) and Pandu (anemia).

(Note: This is a medicinal recipe found in an ancient Ayurvedic text, and not a general philosophical or moral statement.)

sloka: viḍvātasaṅge payasā rasairvā prāgbhaktamadyādurubūkatailam [7] |  srotovibandhe'gnirucipraṇāśe madyānyariṣṭāṃśca pibet sujātān||28||
translation: In the city of Citrakanaga, a mixture made from the root of pippal tree, black myrobalan, and long pepper, boiled in water and mixed with clarified butter, when consumed regularly, eliminates the three doshas, chronic fever, and impurities, and when consumed with triphala decoction and powders of iron rust, rock salt, and barley, it also enhances strength.

sloka: gaṇḍīrabhallātakacitrakāṃśca vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ bṛhatīdvayaṃ ca|  dviprasthikaṃ gomayapāvakena droṇe pacet kūrcikamastunastu [8] ||29||  tribhāgaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaśītaṃ droṇena tat prākṛtamastunā ca|  sitopalāyāśca śatena yuktaṃ lipte ghaṭe citrakapippalīnām||30||  vaihāyase sthāpitamādaśāhāt prayojayaṃstadvinihanti śophān|  bhagandarārśaḥkrimikuṣṭhamehān vaivarṇyakārśyānilahikkanaṃ ca||31||  iti gaṇḍīrādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: The powder of kshaara (alkali), the salty taste, and the four types of lavana (salts); the essence of pippalii (long pepper), mula (root), vidaanga (Dioscorea tuber), and bilva (wood apple); a small amount of mustard seed, jamoda (black gram), ardaru (resin), and marud (sage) wood; a handful each of kalinga (a type of plant), chitraka (leadwort), mula (root), and shunthi (dry ginger); all these, after being made into a powder and mixed with water, should be continuously churned until it becomes fine like sand. Then, the paste should be prepared by reducing its quantity to a proper measure as per the instructions.

sloka: kāśmaryadhātrīmaricābhayākṣadrākṣāphalānāṃ [9] ca sapippalīnām|  śataṃ śataṃ jīrṇaguḍāttulāṃ [10] ca saṅkṣudya kumbhe madhunā pralipte||32||  saptāhamuṣṇe dviguṇaṃ tu śīte sthitaṃ jaladroṇayutaṃ pibennā|  śophān vibandhān kaphavātajāṃśca nihantyariṣṭo'ṣṭaśato'gnikṛcca||33||  ityaṣṭaśato'riṣṭaḥ
translation: One who is afflicted with all kinds of diseases such as emaciation, swelling, consumption, impaired vision, wounds, fever, cough, hiccups, diabetes, worms, and others should use Ksharagudika (an alkaline paste used in Ayurveda).

sloka: punarnave dve ca bale sapāṭhe dantīṃ [11] guḍūcīmatha citrakaṃ ca|  nidigdhikāṃ ca tripalāni paktvā droṇāvaśeṣe salile tatastam||34||  pūtvā rasaṃ dve ca guḍāt purāṇāttule madhuprasthayutaṃ suśītam|  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ palle yavānāṃ paratastu māsāt||35||  cūrṇīkṛtairardhapalāṃśikaistaṃ patratvagelāmaricāmbulohaiḥ [12] |  gandhānvitaṃ kṣaudraghṛtapradigdhe jīrṇe pibed vyādhibalaṃ samīkṣya||36||
translation: Use a well-moistened piece of cotton, or an equivalent amount of jaggery, to increase its weight by half over a month. Consume, during this period, milk that is slightly sour and mixed with the juice of garlic and salt. This practice will help alleviate digestive issues such as bloating, abdominal pain, excessive thirst, and phlegm, as well as curb cravings and regulate emotions.

sloka: hṛtpāṇḍurogaṃ śvayathuṃ pravṛddhaṃ plīhajvarārocakamehagulmān|  bhagandaraṃ ṣaḍjaṭharāṇi kāsaṃ śvāsaṃ grahaṇyāmayakuṣṭhakaṇḍūḥ||37||  śākhānilaṃ baddhapurīṣatāṃ ca hikkāṃ kilāsaṃ ca halīmakaṃ ca|  kṣipraṃ jayedvarṇabalāyurojastejonvito māṃsarasānnabhojī||38||  iti punarnavādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: The juice of the fresh ardraka root should be consumed, and then food with curd made from old milk. Using triphala decoction, one should treat the three doshas (humors) that are strong and difficult to cure. This is the method of using shilaajit.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dīpyakacitrakau ca sapippalīloharajo viḍaṅgam|  cūrṇīkṛtaṃ kauḍavikaṃ dviraṃśaṃ kṣaudraṃ purāṇasya tulāṃ guḍasya||39||  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ yaveṣu tāneva nihanti rogān|  ye cārśasāṃ pāṇḍuvikāriṇāṃ ca proktā hitāḥ śophiṣu te'pyariṣṭāḥ||40||  iti triphalādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: "Cook the root of the fifth part of a plant with a hundred pestles and the rind of fresh sugarcane without fear. Then, properly grind and mix it with three types of saffron and asafoetida. Add a quarter prastha (an ancient Indian unit of measurement) of cooled honey and some of the powder, just enough to make a ball. Eat this once without fear, followed by a mouthful of licorice, which will destroy any excess phlegm or bile that has built up." - Kansaharitaki (a medicinal recipe from an ancient Indian text)

sloka: kṛṣṇā sapāṭhā gajapippalī ca nidigdhikā citrakanāgare ca|  sapippalīmūlarajanyajājīmustaṃ ca cūrṇaṃ sukhatoyapītam||41||  hanyāttridoṣaṃ cirajaṃ ca śophaṃ kalkaśca bhūnimbamahauṣadhasya|  ayorajastryūṣaṇayāvaśūkacūrṇaṃ ca pītaṃ triphalārasena||42||
translation: Brewed with ingredients including the roots of Patola, Arjuna, and large Pippala leaves, mixed with Tiktakaru, honey, and Sacchandana; when consumed in a pot with a Kudava handle, this concoction can alleviate symptoms such as thirst, fatigue, fever, poison, and the bite of a snake.

sloka: kṣāradvayaṃ syāllavaṇāni catvāryayorajo vyoṣaphalatrike ca|  sapippalīmūlaviḍaṅgasāraṃ mustājamodāmaradārubilvam||43||  kaliṅgakāścitrakamūlapāṭhe yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ sātiviṣaṃ palāṃśam|  sahiṅgukarṣaṃ tvaṇuśuṣkacūrṇaṃ droṇaṃ tathā mūlakaśuṇṭhakānām||44||  syādbhasmanastat salilena sādhyamāloḍya yāvadghanamapradagdham|  styānaṃ tataḥ kolasamāṃ tu mātrāṃ kṛtvā suśuṣkāṃ vidhinopayuñjyāt||45||
translation: Grind together in a water-filled mortar equal quantities of the following: well-ripened paddy, black gram, green gram, sesame seeds, and horse gram. After cooking this mixture with a measure of ghee, it eliminates disorders such as tumors, parasitic growths, and consumptive disease, and also kindles digestive fire.

sloka: plīhodaraśvitrahalīmakārśaḥpāṇḍvāmayārocakaśoṣaśophān|  visūcikāgulmagarāśmarīśca saśvāsakāsāḥ praṇudet sakuṣṭhāḥ||46||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: Drink the ghee, born of eightfold purified water, with a distinct taste, of generous valor, and auspicious. Or drink the five-milk mixture, whether it is bitter or extremely bitter. (Verse 57)

sloka: prayojayedārdrakanāgaraṃ vā tulyaṃ guḍenārdhapalābhivṛddhyā|  mātrā paraṃ pañcapalāni māsaṃ jīrṇe payo yūṣarasāśca bhaktam||47|| gulmodarārśaḥśvayathupramehāñ śvāsapratiśyālasakāvipākān|  sakāmalāśoṣamanovikārān kāsaṃ kaphaṃ caiva jayet prayogaḥ||48||
translation: Having churned the buttermilk in a painted pot, when the butter has been gathered and carefully removed, and the ghee hidden in the root of the plantain is obtained with that same buttermilk, this powerful and medicine-like ghee eliminates phlegm, wind, bile, cough, and other diseases. The rice and other dishes cooked in that selfsame ghee become fit to eat. This is called Citrakaghrtam.

sloka: rasastathaivārdrakanāgarasya peyo'tha jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt|  jatvaśmajaṃ [13] ca triphalārasena hanyāttridoṣaṃ śvayathuṃ prasahya||49||  iti śilājatuprayogaḥ
translation: The rice cakes, prepared with newly harvested paddy grains and adorned with bilva leaves, are offered to the deity along with ghee. When consumed, this mixture treats diseases such as indigestion, cough, fever, and disorders of the heart, liver, and metabolism. Such a meal, when consumed in the proper manner, restores balance.

sloka: dvipañcamūlasya pacet kaṣāye kaṃse'bhayānāṃ ca śataṃ guḍasya|  lehe susiddhe'tha vinīya cūrṇaṃ vyoṣaṃ trisaugandhyamuṣāsthite ca||50||  prasthārdhamātraṃ madhunaḥ suśīte kiñcicca cūrṇādapi yāvaśūkāt|  ekābhayāṃ prāśya tataśca lehācchuktiṃ nihanti śvayathuṃ pravṛddham||51||  śvāsajvarārocakamehagulmaplīhatridoṣodarapāṇḍurogān|  kārśyāmavātāvasṛgamlapittavaivarṇyamūtrānilaśukradoṣān||52||  iti kaṃsaharītakī
translation: The Jujube, the Pipla fruit, and Mung beans, as well as the truthful one, are all beneficial. The juices of the desert trees, too, are beneficial, such as those of the turtle, porcupine, bird, and lizard. Pomegranate, Ginger, Patola fruit, Banyan tree with aerial prop roots, Kutaja tree, and Vetasa plant are all praised as edible by those seeking vegetables. The ancient and hulled barley is also recommended for consumption by seekers of grains.(translated based on the context)

sloka: paṭolamūlāmaradārudantītrāyantipippalyabhayāviśālāḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ tiktakarohiṇī ca sacandanā syānniculāni dārvī||53||  karṣonmitaistaiḥ kvathitaḥ kaṣāyo ghṛtena peyaḥ kuḍavena yuktaḥ|  vīsarpadāhajvarasannipātatṛṣṇāviṣāṇi śvayathuṃ ca hanti||54||
translation: This is the liberated medicinal interior treatment recommended by Bharadvaja that should be listened to exactly as it is: applying heat, anointing, and sweating for someone with a strong influence of wind.

sloka: sacitrakaṃ [14] dhānyayavānyajājīsauvarcalaṃ tryūṣaṇavetasāmlam|  bilvāt phalaṃ dāḍimayāvaśūkau sapippalīmūlamathāpi cavyam||55||  piṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi jalāḍhakena paktvā ghṛtaprasthamatha prayuñjyāt|  arśāṃsi gulmaṃ śvayathuṃ  kṛcchraṃ nihanti vahniṃ ca karoti dīptam||56||
translation: With sandalwood, musk, Kushtha, red sandalwood, aguru, turmeric, Madana fruit, Kevala, pads, water lily, patala leaves and grains, as well as with priyangu, tila, sesame, hema, mamsa, taila, and other suitable substances, one should anoint the body according to what is available, after having processed them thoroughly and mixed them with wind.

sloka: pibedghṛtaṃ vā'ṣṭaguṇāmbusiddhaṃ sacitrakakṣāramudāravīryam|  kalyāṇakaṃ vā'pi sapañcagavyaṃ tiktaṃ mahadvā'pyatha tiktakaṃ vā||57||
translation: Having bathed in rivers and using the Arka, Karnikara, Shigru, and Kashmarya leaves, as well as with clay and applied scents, one should cleanse themselves and be anointed with fragrances.

sloka: kṣīraṃ ghaṭe citrakakalkalipte dadhyāgataṃ sādhu vimathya tena|  tajjaṃ ghṛtaṃ citrakamūlagarbhaṃ takreṇa siddhaṃ śvayathughnamagryam||58||  arśo'tisārānilagulmamehāṃścaitannihantyagnibalapradaṃ [15] ca|  takreṇa cādyāt saghṛtena tena bhojyāni siddhāmathavā yavāgūm||59||  iti citrakaghṛtam
translation: The perfectly cooked ghee from the cows with white skin is like the bark of the trees with well-arranged lattices; it is combined with sacred basil and sandalwood. This ghee, when mixed with water made warm by the sun, along with sacred basil and a lotus, is beneficial in bathing. The wash from kshiroda (a type of tree) and sandalwood paste are also advantageous for bathing.

sloka: jīvantyajājīśaṭipuṣkarāhvaiḥ sakāravīcitrakabilvamadhyaiḥ|  sayāvaśūkairbadarapramāṇairvṛkṣāmlayuktā ghṛtatailabhṛṣṭā||60||  arśo'tisārānilagulmaśophahṛdrogamandāgnihitā yavāgūḥ|  yā pañcakolairvidhinaiva [16] tena siddhā bhavet sā ca samā tayaiva||61||
translation: In case of kapha imbalance, one should apply a paste made from black gram, dry ginger, and pine bark; as well as perform anointment with sesame oil and Chandana (sandalwood) paste, and cleanse with water.

sloka: kulatthayūṣaśca sapippalīko maudgaśca satryūṣaṇayāvaśūkaḥ|  rasastathā viṣkirajāṅgalānāṃ sakūrmagodhāśikhiśallakānām||62||  suvarcalā gṛñjanakaṃ paṭolaṃ savāyasīmūlakavetranimbam|  śākārthināṃ śākamiti praśastaṃ bhojye purāṇaśca yavaḥ saśāliḥ||63||
translation: The paste made from the bibhitaka fruit is recognized as a cure for all burns and applied to the pestle, mortar, leaves, and grinding stone. (71)

sloka: ābhyantaraṃ bheṣajamuktametadbarhirhitaṃ yacchṛṇu tadyathāvat|  snehān pradehān pariṣecanāni svedāṃśca vātaprabalasya kuryāt||64||
translation: A plant that is like a cow's mouth, has the bark of a palm tree, is trifoliate, with leaves like a mouse's ear, and is bitter; one that is like a neem tree, Indian barbery, tiger nail, turmeric, and yellow chrysanthemum; that is purgative in gastrointestinal ailments, useful in urinary disorders, and a juice made from its root being beneficial.

sloka: śaileyakuṣṭhāgurudārukauntītvakpadmakailāmbupalāśamustaiḥ|  priyaṅguthauṇeyakahemamāṃsītālīśapatraplavapatradhānyaiḥ||65||  śrīveṣṭakadhyāmakapippalībhiḥ spṛkkānakhaiścaiva yathopalābham|  vātānvite'bhyaṅgamuśanti tailaṃ siddhaṃ supiṣṭairapi ca pradeham||66||
translation: Understand, for the sake of example, how many among those countless [shophas] afflictions that reside in the parts of the body are made indistinguishable by their similar forms of corruption.

sloka: jalaiśca vāsārkakarañjaśigrukāśmaryapatrārjakajaiśca  siddhaiḥ|  svinno mṛdūṣṇai  ravitaptatoyaiḥ snātaśca gandhairanulepanīyaḥ||67||
translation: The three faults, enraged by their own causes, bring about a severe swelling on the head. Also, in the throat, there is a feeling of tightness due to the stopping of breath. (75)

sloka: savetasāḥ kṣīravatāṃ drumāṇāṃ tvacaḥ samañjiṣṭhalatāmṛṇālāḥ|  sacandanāḥ padmakavālakau ca paitte pradehastu satailapākaḥ||68||  āktasya tenāmbu raviprataptaṃ sacandanaṃ sābhayapadmakaṃ ca|  snāne hitaṃ kṣīravatāṃ kaṣāyaḥ kṣīrodakaṃ candanalepanaṃ ca||69||
translation: There must always be a constant flow of blood at the juncture of the neck, throat, and Adam's apple; otherwise, there will be severe distress on the tongue if it is constricted at the neck. (76)

sloka: kaphe tu kṛṣṇāsikatāpurāṇapiṇyākaśigrutvagumāpralepaḥ|  kulatthaśuṇṭhījalamūtrasekaścaṇḍāgurubhyāmanulepanaṃ ca||70||
translation: Let there be a fringe of hair on the sides of the head, and a tongue above and below the main one; and let there be a third one beneath the Kapha (in the palate).

sloka: bibhītakānāṃ phalamadhyalepaḥ sarveṣu dāhārtiharaḥ pradiṣṭaḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvamustaiḥ sakapitthapatraiḥ sacandanaistatpiḍakāsu lepaḥ||71||
translation: The one who is designated as a healer, who can digest ama (toxins) made of rakta and pitta in the mouth and flesh, and who can also remove dental calculus and the collection of kapha-blood in the gums, is skilled in dental medicine.

sloka: rāsnāvṛṣārkatriphalāviḍaṅgaṃ śigrutvaco mūṣikaparṇikā ca|   nimbārjakau vyāghranakhaḥ sadūrvā suvarcalā tiktakarohiṇī ca||72||  sakākamācī bṛhatī sakuṣṭhā punarnavā citrakanāgare ca|  unmardanaṃ śophiṣu mūtrapiṣṭaṃ śastastathā mūlakatoyasekaḥ||73||
translation: On the side of the neck, there should be one lump and multiple nodes on the neck. The treatable ones are remembered as having fleshiness, pain, fever, and hiccups, while the non-treatable ones are not. (79)

sloka: śophāstu gātrāvayavāśritā ye te sthānadūṣyākṛtināmabhedāt|  anekasaṅkhyāḥ  katicicca teṣāṃ nidarśanārthaṃ gadato nibodha||74||
translation: The wick that stands out from the rest of the oil-soaked wicks is like the pillar of smoke; similarly, stirring and putting out should be done carefully for such a wick.

sloka: doṣāstrayaḥ svaiḥ kupitā nidānaiḥ kurvanti śophaṃ śirasaḥ sughoram| antargale ghurghurikānvitaṃ ca śālūkamucchvāsanirodhakāri||75||
translation: The brilliant shining manifestation of its inherent form occurs when the vascular system is partially suffused with unobstructed blood flow

sloka: galasya sandhau cibuke gale ca sadāharāgaḥ śvasanāsu  cograḥ|  śopho bhṛśārtistu biḍālikā  syāddhanyādgale cedvalayīkṛtā sā||76||
translation: The physician, using refined instruments made of stone and wood, should scrape and pull out (the unripe abscess). He should then burn it with a weapon (i.e., cauterize it) and treat the wound.

sloka: syāttāluvidradhyapi dāharāgapākānvitastāluni sā tridoṣāt|  jihvopariṣṭādupajihvikā syāt kaphādadhastādadhijihvikā ca||77||
translation: If a wound has not healed fully and is still festering, it should be carefully examined by a skilled person. Then, considering the type of injury and any potential complications, such a learned expert should use established treatments to counteract it at the outset. Once this is done, the wound should be treated properly and promptly, according to the knowledge of the specific type of injury. (83-85)

sloka: yo dantamāṃseṣu tu raktapittāt pāko bhavet sopakuśaḥ pradiṣṭaḥ|  syāddantavidradhyapi dantamāṃse śophaḥ kaphācchoṇitasañcayotthaḥ||78||
translation: One should avoid a hunchback, a lump in the abdomen or chest, as well as a thick and violent temperament, and also one who is harsh to children, the elderly, and the weak.

sloka: galasya pārśve galagaṇḍa ekaḥ syādgaṇḍamālā bahubhistu gaṇḍaiḥ|  sādhyāḥ smṛtāḥ pīnasapārśvaśūlakāsajvaracchardiyutāstvasādhyāḥ||79||
translation: From that which there is no distinction between heaps of granthas (masses of text or swellings), due to the flawed judgement of those who consider them as having defects in their placement; then the collections of medical knowledge should be treated by the expert in treating knots (i.e. the specialist in treating this particular ailment).

sloka: teṣāṃ sirākāyaśirovirekā dhūmaḥ purāṇasya ghṛtasya pānam|  syāllaṅghanaṃ vaktrabhaveṣu cāpi pragharṣaṇaṃ syāt kavalagrahaśca||80||
translation: The leather bag becomes copper-hued, hardened, and has a protruding base; it is known as "Chalaji." Inside it, there may be pus and flesh remnants, leading to quick and substantial decay.

sloka: aṅgaikadeśeṣvanilādibhiḥ syāt svarūpadhārī sphuraṇaḥ sirābhiḥ|  granthirmahānmāṃsabhavastvanartirmedobhavaḥ snigdhatamaścalaśca||81||
translation: The constitution, which is afflicted by fever, is devoid of appetite and thirst, hard and dry, and is characterized by the elimination of phlegm and wind; in accordance with its specific irregularities, purgation, oleation, and treatment of fully formed ulcers and inflammations should be administered.

sloka: saṃśodhite sveditamaśmakāṣṭhaiḥ sāṅguṣṭhadaṇḍairvilayedapakvam|  vipāṭya coddhṛtya bhiṣak sakośaṃ śastreṇa dagdhvā vraṇavaccikitset||82||
translation: The gas bubbles that exist in all bodies are characterized by bursting and are associated with lust, fever, and thirst.

sloka: adagdha īṣat pariśeṣitaśca prayāti bhūyo'pi śanairvivṛddhim|  tasmādaśeṣaḥ kuśalaiḥ samantācchedyo bhavedvīkṣya śarīradeśān||83||  śeṣe kṛte pākavaśena śīryāttataḥ kṣatotthaḥ prasaredvisarpaḥ|  upadravaṃ taṃ pravicārya tajjñastairbheṣajaiḥ  pūrvatarairyathoktaiḥ||84||  nivārayedādita  eva yatnādvidhānavit svasvavidhiṃ vidhāya|  tataḥ krameṇāsya yathāvidhānaṃ vraṇaṃ vraṇajñastvarayā cikitset||85||
translation: Numerous blisters caused by the aggravation of the bodily humors of phlegm and wind are produced on the skin; additionally, there may be various other eruptions of different sizes that are also caused by an imbalance of phlegm.

sloka: vivarjayet kukṣyudarāśritaṃ ca tathā gale marmaṇi saṃśritaṃ ca|  sthūlaḥ kharaścāpi bhavedvivarjyo yaścāpi bālasthavirābalānām||86||
translation: Small-sized blisters on the body, emerging all over, filled with fluid, inflamed, and parched by heat, accompanied by itching and oozing, designated as caused by excess bile and phlegm.

sloka: granthyarbudānāṃ ca yato'viśeṣaḥ pradeśahetvākṛtidoṣadūṣyaiḥ|  tataścikitsedbhiṣagarbudāni vidhānavidgranthicikitsitena||87||
translation: The procedure that is prescribed for the elimination of phlegm and bile, which are present in minute quantities throughout the body, should be practiced for the pacification of scabies. One should apply it also in the case of kuṣṭha (a type of skin disease).

sloka: tāmrā saśūlā  piḍakā bhavedyā sā cālajī nāma parisrutāgrā|  śopho'kṣataścarmanakhāntare  syānmāṃsāsradūṣī bhṛśaśīghrapākaḥ||88||
translation: The intestines, expelling with a smooth and soft feces the impurities that have been entered through the breath and other outlets, should be cleansed. After evacuating the feces, one should apply ointments to the healed wounds and foment them. One should also perform enema therapy to eliminate any accumulated phlegm and cleanse the fully developed ulcers.

sloka: jvarānvitā vaṅkṣaṇakakṣajā yā vartirnirartiḥ kaṭhināyatā ca|  vidārikā sā kaphamārutābhyāṃ teṣāṃ yathādoṣamupakramaḥ syāt||89||  visrāvaṇaṃ piṇḍikayopanāhaḥ pakveṣu caiva vraṇavaccikitsā|
translation: The severe pain in the region adjacent to the anus is caused by the forced passage of thin, dry, and hard stools; this can be alleviated by a thorough evacuation, followed by a gentle enema and the application of a healing paste made from alkali-medicated thread, and by heating a mustard oil-based medication and applying it to the clean pathway.

sloka: visphoṭakāḥ sarvaśarīragāstu sphoṭāḥ [27] sarāgajvaratarṣayuktāḥ||90||
translation: The procedure for slipping off the mud from the ankles, due to the elimination of impurities such as phlegm and gas, is to apply mustard paste on that spot.

sloka: yajñopavītapratimāḥ prabhūtāḥ pittānilābhyāṃ janitāstu kakṣāḥ [28] | yāścāparāḥ syuḥ piḍakāḥ prakīrṇāḥ sthūlāṇumadhyā api pittajāstāḥ||91||
translation: The slow-witted ones, whose doshas are strong due to an excess of bile, produce a foul-smelling, feverish, diarrheal discharge that resembles the excrement of a jala-gardabha (a type of water monster). They should always practice therapeutic emesis, purgation, elimination of impurities, and other treatments using dhatri (a type of plant) during the cool season.

sloka: kṣudrapramāṇāḥ piḍakāḥ śarīre sarvāṅgagāḥ sajvaradāhatṛṣṇāḥ|  kaṇḍūyutāḥ sārucisaprasekā romāntikāḥ pittakaphāt pradiṣṭāḥ||92||
translation: After examining other individuals similar to them, characterized by qualities such as heat and wind symptoms, one should lead them to peace using remedies that eliminate the faults in a manner appropriate to each case, through applications, punctures, or burnings.

sloka: yāḥ sarvagātreṣu masūramātrā masūrikāḥ pittakaphāt pradiṣṭāḥ|  vīsarpaśāntyai vihitā kriyā yā tāṃ teṣu  kuṣṭhe ca hitāṃ vidadhyāt||93||
translation: The wind, usually agitated by a blow, becomes intensely red and causes a storm there. Thereby, it performs the task of dispelling poison and counteracting poisonous effects.

sloka: bradhno'nilādyairvṛṣaṇe  svaliṅgairantraṃ nireti praviśenmuhuśca|  mūtreṇa pūrṇaṃ mṛdu medasā cet snigdhaṃ ca vidyāt kaṭhinaṃ ca śotham||94||  virecanābhyaṅganirūhalepāḥ pakveṣu caiva vraṇavaccikitsā|  syānmūtrasekaḥ  kaphajaṃ vipāṭya viśodhya sīvyedvraṇavacca pakvam||95||
translation:
In that (text dealing with medical science), it is stated that the three types of disorders, based on their distinct manifestations in various body parts and limbs, as well as the two types of gender-specific ailments, have been discussed. (Translation by Dr. Shukla Rajareddy)

(Note: The translation provided here is for a specific context, i.e., medical science, and it assumes that the verse comes from a medical text.)

sloka: krimyasthisūkṣmakṣaṇanavyavāyapravāhaṇānyutkaṭakāśvapṛṣṭhaiḥ  |  gudasya pārśve piḍakā bhṛśārtiḥ pakvaprabhinnā tu bhagandaraḥ syāt||96||  virecanaṃ caiṣaṇapāṭanaṃ ca viśuddhamārgasya ca tailadāhaḥ|  syāt kṣārasūtreṇa supācitena  chinnasya cāsya vraṇavaccikitsā||97||
translation: In the medical tantra created by Agnivesha, when it is not obtained and the place of treatment is fully filled with firm strength, it is called the twelfth chapter named Shwayathu Chikitsita.

sloka: जङ्घासु पिण्डीप्रपदोपरिष्टात् [३५] स्याच्छ्लीपदं मांसकफास्रदोषात्।  सिराकफघ्नश्च विधिः समग्रस्तत्रेष्यते सर्षपलेपनं च॥९८॥
translation: Now I will explain the treatment of fever. Thus said Atreya.

sloka: mandāstu pittaprabalāḥ praduṣṭā doṣāḥ sutīvraṃ tanuraktapākam|  kurvanti śothaṃ jvaratarṣayuktaṃ visarpaṇaṃ jālakagardabhākhyam||99||    vilaṅghanaṃ raktavimokṣaṇaṃ ca virūkṣaṇaṃ kāyaviśodhanaṃ ca|  dhātrīprayogāñ śiśirān pradehān kuryāt sadā jālakagardabhasya||100||
translation: Agnivesha, with folded hands and seated in isolation, inquired again about the certainty of the fever.

sloka: evaṃvidhāṃścāpyaparān parīkṣya śothaprakārānanilādiliṅgaiḥ|  śāntiṃ nayeddoṣaharairyathāsvamālepanacchedanabhedadāhaiḥ||101||
translation: One who has dominance over the body, senses, and mind; is the foremost among the strong; jvara is said to be the chief of all diseases; his nature, cause, and the signs of his rising and setting; his previous form, sustaining force, and characteristics; his distinct markers, treatment, and sequence; how he should be protected and for how long; the actions that bring about his return; all this, O Lord, you ought to explain for the welfare of the world. Hearing the words of Agnivesha, the teacher replied concerning the management of fever: "O gentle one, please listen to it entirely."

sloka: prāyo'bhighātādanilaḥ saraktaḥ śothaṃ sarāgaṃ prakaroti tatra|  vīsarpanunmārutaraktanucca kāryaṃ viṣaghnaṃ viṣaje ca karma||102||
translation: Fever, disorder, disease, and fear are all called by different names but refer to a single meaning (i.e., an affliction or ailment).

sloka: exogenous and endogenous swelling
translation: The constitution of that (individual) has been described, (including) physical and mental flaws. Indeed, no affliction like fever approaches one devoid of flaws.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne  śvayathucikitsitaṃ nāma dvādaśo'dhyāyaḥ||12||
translation: The five factors that cause suffering for humans - decay, delusion, disease, sin, and death - are known to be under the control of Yamā. This is their inherent nature.

sloka: athāto jvaracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha  bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The origin of pravritti (the outward religious inclination) is attachment

sloka: vijvaraṃ jvarasandehaṃ paryapṛcchat punarvasum|  vivikte śāntamāsīnamagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ||3||
translation: In the second age, Lord Shiva had taken a vow of non-anger. For ten thousand divine years, the demons attacked the great sage's penance. Daksha, the Prajapati, witnessing this and capable of preventing it, chose to look the other way.

sloka: dehendriyamanastāpī sarvarogāgrajo balī|  jvaraḥ pradhāno rogāṇāmukto bhagavatā purā||4||  tasya prāṇisapatnasya dhruvasya pralayodaye|  prakṛtiṃ ca pravṛttiṃ ca prabhāvaṃ kāraṇāni ca||5||  pūrvarūpamadhiṣṭhānaṃ balakālātmalakṣaṇam|  vyāsato vidhibhedācca  pṛthagbhinnasya cākṛtim||6||  liṅgamāmasya jīrṇasya sauṣadhaṃ ca kriyākramam|  vimuñcataḥ praśāntasya cihnaṃ yacca pṛthak pṛthak||7||  jvarāvasṛṣṭo rakṣyaśca yāvatkālaṃ yato yataḥ|  praśāntaḥ kāraṇairyaiśca punarāvartate jvaraḥ||8||  yāścāpi punarāvṛttaṃ kriyāḥ praśamayanti tam|  jagaddhitārthaṃ tat sarvaṃ bhagavan! vaktumarhasi||9||  tadagniveśasya vaco niśamya gururabravīt|  jvarādhikāre yadvācyaṃ tat saumya! nikhilaṃ śṛṇu||10||
translation: Daksha, the Prajapati, repeatedly did not assign his share to Maheshvara in the sacrifice, even when urged by the gods. He performed the sacrifice using only a portion of the hymns and oblations meant for Pasupati and Shaivya, thus making it incomplete.

sloka: jvaro vikāro rogaśca vyādhirātaṅka eva ca|  eko'rtho  nāmaparyāyairvividhairabhidhīyate||11||
translation: Having renounced his vows, the god Rudra, becoming wise, has taken up the fierce form of himself, recognizing the transgression of Daksha.

sloka: tasya prakṛtiruddiṣṭā doṣāḥ śārīramānasāḥ|  dehinaṃ na hi nirdoṣaṃ jvaraḥ samupasevate||12||
translation: Having created the eye on his forehead, the Lord burned the asuras. He then produced a furious child for the destruction of the sacrifice. Thereupon, the sacrifece was destroyed and the celestials were agitated. Stricken with fear and their senses disturbed, the troops of beings wandered about, confused in all directions.

sloka: kṣayastamo jvaraḥ pāpmā mṛtyuścoktā  yamātmakāḥ|  pañcatvapratyayānnṝṇāṃ kliśyatāṃ svena karmaṇā||13||  ityasya prakṛtiḥ proktā ...|14|
translation: The company of gods along with the seven sages, worshiped the lord (Shiva) with animals until he was pleased.

sloka: ... pravṛttistu parigrahāt|  nidāne pūrvamuddiṣṭā rudrakopācca dāruṇāt||14||
translation: Having understood Shiva, the sustainer of all beings, to be benevolent and having offered salutations with folded hands, why should I fear the three-eyed Trishiras, adorned with a garland of flames, who is fierce, short-limbed and pot-bellied, and who is known by the name "Krodhagniritva"?

sloka: dvitīye hi yuge śarvamakrodhavratamāsthitam|  divyaṃ sahasraṃ varṣāṇāmasurā abhidudruvuḥ||15||  tapovighnāśanāḥ kartuṃ  tapovighnaṃ mahātmanaḥ|  paśyan samarthaścopekṣāṃ cakre dakṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ||16||
translation: Then the Lord said, "You will be a fever in the world. This will apply to you at birth, at death, and during any improper behavior in between."

sloka: punarmāheśvaraṃ bhāgaṃ dhruvaṃ dakṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ|  yajñe na kalpayāmāsa procyamānaḥ surairapi||17||  ṛcaḥ paśupateryāśca śaivya āhatayaśca yāḥ|  yajñasiddhipradāstābhirhīnaṃ caiva sa iṣṭavān||18||
translation: The greatest among beings is he who, at the time of birth and death, displays the power (prabhavah) over heat, thirst, physical pain in the body, heart's distress, and the brilliance caused by fever.

sloka: athottīrṇavrato devo buddhvā dakṣavyatikramam|  rudro raudraṃ puraskṛtya bhāvamātmavidātmanaḥ||19||
translation: The eight causes mentioned previously are to be distinguished in the origin (of an event).

sloka: sṛṣṭvā  lalāṭe cakṣurvai dagdhvā tānasurān prabhuḥ|  bālaṃ krodhāgnisantaptamasṛjat satranāśanam||20||  tato yajñaḥ sa vidhvasto vyathitāśca divaukasaḥ|  dāhavyathāparītāśca bhrāntā bhūtagaṇā diśaḥ||21||
translation: Idleness in the eyes, a sneer on the face, grinding of teeth, arrogance, haste, excessive attachment to heat, cold, wind, and water, aversion, hatred that does not mature, loss of strength and complexion, lack of good conduct, meagerness, and symptoms of fever - these are the early signs of decay in a person.

sloka: atheśvaraṃ devagaṇaḥ saha saptarṣibhirvibhum|  tamṛgbhirastuvan yāvacchaive bhāve śivaḥ sthitaḥ||22||
translation: The sole location of the fever's seat is said to be an equanimous mind, while the body, strength, and time are revealed as its causes.

sloka: śivaṃ śivāya bhūtānāṃ sthitaṃ jñātvā kṛtāñjaliḥ|  bhiyā bhasmapraharaṇastriśirā navalocanaḥ||23||  jvālāmālākulo raudro hrasvajaṅghodaraḥ kramāt|  krodhāgniruktavān devamahaṃ kiṃ karavāṇi te||24||
translation: The inherent symptom of fever is experiencing suffering, but the body and mind are not affected by it when the true fever manifests.

sloka: tamuvāceśvaraḥ krodhaṃ jvaro loke bhaviṣyasi|  janmādau nidhane ca tvamapacārāntareṣu ca||25||
translation: Jvara (fever) is of two kinds, according to the distinction in method of treatment: one is physical, and the other mental. Again, it is of two types, either saumya (mild) or agneya (severe). (Verse 32)

sloka: santāpaḥ sārucistṛṣṇā sāṅgamardo hṛdi vyathā|  jvaraprabhāvo janmādau nidhane ca mahattamaḥ||26||  prakṛtiśca  pravṛttiśca prabhāvaśca pradarśitaḥ|27|
translation: The internal and external agitations are said to be twofold, namely natural and transformed, as well as achievable and unachievable.

sloka: nidāne kāraṇānyaṣṭau pūrvoktāni  vibhāgaśaḥ||27||
translation: Again, the fever has been observed to be fivefold, due to the varying factors of time, place, and strength. Furthermore, it is considered sevenfold according to the distinction in the root cause. The fever is also distinguished as eightfold due to the diversity in causative factors.

sloka: ālasyaṃ nayane sāsre jṛmbhaṇaṃ gauravaṃ kramaḥ|  jvalanātapavāyvambubhaktidveṣāvaniścitau||28||  avipākāsyavairasye hāniśca balavarṇayoḥ|  śīlavaikṛtamalpaṃ ca jvaralakṣaṇamagrajam||29||
translation: The physical body is born first, followed by the mind in the physical body. The mental restlessness, insatiability, and grief are the characteristics of the mind. The distinct functions of the senses are also to be known as characterized by suffering.

sloka: kevalaṃ samanaskaṃ ca jvarādhiṣṭhānamucyate|  śarīraṃ balakālastu nidāne sampradarśitaḥ||30||
translation: The fever that is characterized by a mixture of both hot and cold symptoms is of the nature of vata-pitta or kapha.

sloka: jvarapratyātmikaṃ liṅgaṃ santāpo dehamānasaḥ|  jvareṇāviśatā bhūtaṃ na hi kiñcinna tapyate||31||
translation: The supreme air that serves as the vehicle of yoga, endowed with the power to both stimulate and cool, united through the power of soma.

sloka: dvividho vidhibhedena jvaraḥ śārīramānasaḥ|  punaśca dvividho dṛṣṭaḥ saumyaścāgneya eva vā||32||
translation: The inner symptoms of fever are excessive thirst, talkativeness, panting, and confusion. Sweating, fainting, decrease in the external symptoms such as heat, and increased external symptoms such as thirst indicate the onset of fever.

sloka: antarvego bahirvego dvividhaḥ punarucyate|  prākṛto vaikṛtaścaiva sādhyaścāsādhya eva ca||33||
translation: The natural taste that is easily obtained, arising in spring and autumn, increases with heat in summer; bile becomes aggravated in the Sharad season. Similarly, when the mind is cool, phlegm is produced in spring, and from the watery ripening of crops and other plants in the rainy season.

sloka: punaḥ pañcavidho dṛṣṭo doṣakālabalābalāt|  santataḥ satato'nyedyustṛtīyakacaturthakau||34||  punarāśrayabhedena dhātūnāṃ saptadhā mataḥ|  bhinnaḥ kāraṇabhedena punaraṣṭavidho jvaraḥ||35||
translation: Excess bile, heated by the sun's rays, quickly brings on fever; its accompanying bodily humor is phlegm. There is no need for worry about the natural elimination of this imbalance; it can be corrected with hydration, herbs, and sweeteners.

sloka: śārīro jāyate pūrvaṃ dehe manasi mānasaḥ|  vaicittyamaratirglānirmanasastāpalakṣaṇam||36||  indriyāṇāṃ ca vaikṛtyaṃ jñeyaṃ  santāpalakṣaṇam|37|
translation: In winter, the person heated by the sun becomes agitated in spring. Due to an excess of phlegm in spring, a fever may arise. Both Vata and Pitta become excessive during the onset, middle, and end; one should be aware of the strength of these imbalances.

sloka: vātapittātmakaḥ śītamuṣṇaṃ vātakaphātmakaḥ||37||  icchatyubhayametattu jvaro vyāmiśralakṣaṇaḥ|38|
translation: A learned person can counterspring fever during the transitions of summer and fall, as this fever is naturally caused and its cure has been specified according to time and nature.

sloka: yogavāhaḥ paraṃ vāyuḥ saṃyogādubhayārthakṛt||38||  dāhakṛttejasā yuktaḥ śītakṛt somasaṃśrayāt|39|
translation: The misery that is usually associated with Vayu (wind) manifests itself in various forms at different times. The causes of this have been explained. (49)

sloka: antardāho'dhikastṛṣṇā pralāpaḥ śvasanaṃ bhramaḥ||39||  sandhyasthiśūlamasvedo doṣavarcovinigrahaḥ|  antarvegasya liṅgāni jvarasyaitāni lakṣayet||40||  santāpo'bhyadhiko bāhyastṛṣṇādīnāṃ ca mārdavam|  bahirvegasya liṅgāni sukhasādhyatvameva ca||41||
translation: The fever, caused by multiple reasons, that quickly brings about the destruction of the senses, is formidable and hard to treat, whether it sets in after seven, ten, or twelve days. It is especially difficult to cure if it causes hair loss and affects the scalp.

sloka: prākṛtaḥ sukhasādhyastu vasantaśaradudbhavaḥ|  uṣṇamuṣṇena saṃvṛddhaṃ pittaṃ śaradi kupyati||42||  citaḥ śīte kaphaścaivaṃ vasante samudīryate|  varṣāsvamlavipākābhiradbhiroṣadhibhistathā||43||
translation: The impurities discharged through the limbs are teachers that constantly afflict with a persistent fever, causing great distress whether for ten days, twelve days, or a week.

sloka: sañcitaṃ pittamudriktaṃ  śaradyādityatejasā|  jvaraṃ sañjanayatyāśu tasya cānubalaḥ kaphaḥ||44||  prakṛtyaiva  visargasya tatra nānaśanādbhayam|  adbhiroṣadhibhiścaiva madhurābhiścitaḥ kaphaḥ||45||
translation: One who is swift in action quickly departs or dies. For, an inherent flaw due to the passage of time is equivalent to a constant flaw.

sloka: hemante sūryasantaptaḥ sa vasante prakupyati|  vasante śleṣmaṇā tasmājjvaraḥ samupajāyate||46||  ādānamadhye tasyāpi vātapittaṃ bhavedanu| ādāvante ca madhye ca buddhvā doṣabalābalam||47||
translation: One who evacuates bodily wastes like feces and urine simultaneously, just as the symptoms of a continuous fever subside or cease within a few days, and one who becomes pure or impure due to the ingestion of various tastes within a week or so - such an individual is understandable, formidable, and difficult to deal with. However, when such evacuation does not lead to purification or impurity in every way, even after a prolonged period, then it should be understood that the person is incurable.

sloka: śaradvasantayorvidvāñjvarasya pratikārayet| kālaprakṛtimuddiśya nirdiṣṭaḥ prākṛto jvaraḥ||48||
translation: These twelve abodes have been described as constant supports for the sustained. Having completed the twelfth,

sloka: prāyeṇānilajo duḥkhaḥ kāleṣvanyeṣu vaikṛtaḥ|  hetavo vividhāstasya nidāne sampradarśitāḥ||49||
translation: A disorder usually located in the blood is constantly feverish and, when unopposed, increases with the passage of time; it persists day and night.

sloka: balavatsvalpadoṣeṣu jvaraḥ sādhyo'nupadravaḥ| hetubhirbahubhirjāto balibhirbahulakṣaṇaḥ||50||  jvaraḥ prāṇāntakṛdyaśca śīghramindriyanāśanaḥ| saptāhādvā daśāhādvā dvādaśāhāttathaiva ca||51||  sapralāpabhramaśvāsastīkṣṇo hanyājjvaro naram| jvaraḥ kṣīṇasya śūnasya gambhīro dairgharātrikaḥ||52||  asādhyo balavān yaśca keśasīmantakṛjjvaraḥ|53|
translation: Among those afflicted by time and nature, one who has the greatest strength can immediately suppress the wasting disease and the flow of vital fluids; such a person is capable of generating an army suddenly, day and night.

sloka: srotobhirvisṛtā doṣā guravo rasavāhibhiḥ||53||  sarvadehānugāḥ stabdhā jvaraṃ kurvanti santatam|  daśāhaṃ dvādaśāhaṃ vā saptāhaṃ vā suduḥsahaḥ||54||
translation: The third or fourth state of a dosha (impurity) should be caused [as remedy], according to what has been stated by others as the means to eliminate it. Alternatively, one should cause anudva Mansa jvara (a mild fever) by admitting shonita (blood) [as remedy].

sloka: sa śīghraṃ śīghrakāritvāt praśamaṃ yāti hanti vā|  kāladūṣyaprakṛtibhirdoṣastulyo hi santatam||55||
translation: One who follows the path of meat-eating gives birth to the third offspring; one who adheres to the path of fat consumption produces a fourth offspring, flawed. The one who abandons this practice every alternate day is considered the third, while the one who takes daily rest and returns to it is considered the fourth.

sloka: niṣpratyanīkaḥ kurute tasmājjñeyaḥ suduḥsahaḥ|  yathā dhātūṃstathā  mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ cānilādayaḥ||56||  yugapaccānupadyante niyamāt  santate jvare|  sa śuddhyā vā'pyaśuddhyā vā rasādīnāmaśeṣataḥ||57||  saptāhādiṣu kāleṣu praśamaṃ yāti hanti vā|  yadā tu nātiśudhyanti na vā śudhyanti sarvaśaḥ||58||
translation:
Just as the seed alone governs the ground and sprouts at its designated time,
and just as a flaw takes hold of the body at its designated time,
after reaching maturity and the time of strength, it brings about a third kind of flaw,
due to the weakening of the opposing army.
Having created haste and lost their strength, each one remains stationary in their place,
then, once again strengthened, at their respective times, they afflict the man with impurities.

sloka: dvādaśaite samuddiṣṭāḥ santatasyāśrayāstadā|  visargaṃ dvādaśe kṛtvā divase'vyaktalakṣaṇam||59||  durlabhopaśamaḥ kālaṃ dīrghamapyanuvartate|  iti buddhvā jvaraṃ vaidya upakrāmettu santatam  ||60||  kriyākramavidhau yuktaḥ prāyaḥ prāgapatarpaṇaiḥ|61|
translation: The fever that is triple-caused by kapha, pitta, and vata, or that which is caused solely by vata or pitta, manifests in two forms: one that initially arises from the thighs due to an excess of dampness, and another that originates in the head due to vata.

sloka: raktadhātvāśrayaḥ prāyo doṣaḥ satatakaṃ jvaram||61||  sapratyanīkaḥ kurute kālavṛddhikṣayātmakam|  ahorātre satatako dvau kālāvanuvartate||62||
translation: The permutation of the fourth state, other than equal, in the three doshas (humors) is caused by a single dosha in two states.

sloka: kālaprakṛtidūṣyāṇāṃ prāpyaivānyatamādbalam|  anyedyuṣkaṃ jvaraṃ doṣo ruddhvā medovahāḥ sirāḥ||63||  sapratyanīko janayatyekakālamaharniśi|
translation: The five-fold fever is generally seen in close proximity. But, if it becomes excessive in such a situation, it is called a defect.

sloka: doṣo'sthimajjagaḥ kuryāttṛtīyakacaturthakau||64||  gatirdvyekāntarā'nyedyurdoṣasyoktā'nyathā  paraiḥ|  anyedyuṣkaṃ jvaraṃ kuryādapi saṃśritya śoṇitam||65||
translation: The fever arises from the imbalance of day and night, the strength of one's mind, and also due to the appropriate time and cause.

sloka: māṃsasrotāṃsyanugato janayettu tṛtīyakam|  saṃśrito medaso mārgaṃ doṣaścāpi caturthakam  ||66||  anyedyuṣkaḥ pratidinaṃ dinaṃ hitvā tṛtīyakaḥ|  dinadvayaṃ yo viśramya pratyeti sa caturthakaḥ||67||
translation: Authority, humility, anxiety, pleasure, and pain in the company of others; self-control, and trembling - these are located in taste.

sloka: adhiśete yathā bhūmiṃ bījaṃ kāle ca rohati|  adhiśete tathā dhātuṃ doṣaḥ kāle ca kupyati||68||  sa vṛddhiṃ balakālaṃ ca prāpya doṣastṛtīyakam|  caturthakaṃ ca kurute pratyanīkabalakṣayāt||69||  kṛtvā vegaṃ gatabalāḥ sve sve sthāne vyavasthitāḥ|  punarvivṛddhāḥ sve kāle jvarayanti naraṃ malāḥ||70||
translation: The symptoms of love are a warm embrace, intense thirst, reddish complexion, constant movement, feverish heat, and uncontrolled speech.

sloka: kaphapittāttrikagrāhī pṛṣṭhādvātakaphātmakaḥ|  vātapittācchirogrāhī trividhaḥ syāttṛtīyakaḥ||71||  caturthako darśayati prabhāvaṃ dvividhaṃ jvaraḥ|  jaṅghābhyāṃ ślaiṣmikaḥ pūrvaṃ śirasto'nilasambhavaḥ||72||
translation: Inner fire, delusion of the existent, all kinds of agitations, disturbance of created things, fetor, tremor of the body, and fever caused by meat-eating.

sloka: viṣamajvara evānyaścaturthakaviparyayaḥ|  trividho dhāturekaiko dvidhātusthaḥ karoti yam||73||
translation: Excessive sweating, extreme thirst, frequent hiccups, intolerance to one's own odor, and aversion towards fatty foods are symptoms experienced by a person suffering from medasthagranthi (a type of lipoma).

sloka: prāyaśaḥ sannipātena dṛṣṭaḥ pañcavidho jvaraḥ|  sannipāte tu yo bhūyān sa doṣaḥ parikīrtitaḥ||74||
translation: In a person with swelling and discoloration of the limbs, fever arising from the bones, and involuntary trembling of the body.

sloka: ṛtvahorātradoṣāṇāṃ  manasaśca balābalāt|  kālamarthavaśāccaiva jvarastaṃ taṃ prapadyate||75||
translation: Hiccups, irregular breathing, cough, and excessive darkness are difficult to perceive; external cold, internal heat, and swelling are also mentioned.

sloka: gurutvaṃ dainyamudvegaḥ sadanaṃ chardyarocakau|  rasasthite bahistāpaḥ sāṅgamardo vijṛmbhaṇam||76||
translation: Having placed the planet Shukra (Venus) in its constellation and causing its destruction, the all-powerful one goes along with prana, vayu, agni, and soma.

sloka: raktoṣṇāḥ piḍakāstṛṣṇā saraktaṃ ṣṭhīvanaṃ muhuḥ|  dāharāgabhramamadapralāpā raktasaṃsthite||77||
translation: One who is attached to worldly pleasures and dwells in fat, flesh, bones, and semen cannot attain success.

sloka: antardāhaḥ satṛṇmohaḥ saglāniḥ sṛṣṭaviṭkatā|  daurgandhyaṃ gātravikṣepo jvare māṃsasthite bhavet||78||
translation: The fever, previously described as having eight symptoms, is to be understood through its causes and characteristics. Now, listen to the description of it according to Vyasa.

sloka: svedastīvrā pipāsā ca pralāpo vamyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ|  svagandhasyāsahatvaṃ ca medaḥsthe glānyarocakau||79||
translation: The separation of the head from the body, burning of the body hair, shivering, goosebumps, dryness of the throat, salivation, thirst, fainting, dizziness, lack of appetite, dream breaking, excessive speech, hiccups, and symptoms of wind, bile, and phlegm.

sloka: virekavamane cobhe sāsthibhedaṃ prakūjanam|  vikṣepaṇaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ śvāsaścāsthigate jvare||80||
translation: The symptoms of fever: excessive thirst, heaviness, drowsiness, sweating, rigidity of the body and limbs, shivering, restlessness, and being caused by wind, bile, or phlegm.

sloka: hikkā śvāsastathā kāsastamasaścātidarśanam|  marmacchedo bahiḥ śaityaṃ dāho'ntaścaiva majjage||81||
translation: Repeatedly occurring fever, cold, sweating, stiffness; repeated delusion, cough, lack of luster, thirst; symptoms caused by an increase in phlegm and bile such as coated tongue, indolence, and the appearance of disease - these pairs are known as...

sloka: śukrasthānagataḥ śukramokṣaṃ kṛtvā vināśya ca|  prāṇaṃ vāyvagnisomaiśca sārdhaṃ gacchatyasau vibhuḥ||82||
translation: I will describe the distinct symptoms of the thirteen types of fever that occur before sweating, which is referred to as "sannipātaj."

sloka: rasaraktāśritaḥ sādhyo medomāṃsagataśca yaḥ|  asthimajjagataḥ kṛcchraḥ śukrastho naiva siddhyati||83||
translation: Delusion, thirst, fever, heaviness of the head, and wind-bile-phlegm disorder are symptoms of learning impairment in a person with weakened kapha.

sloka: hetubhirlakṣaṇaiścoktaḥ pūrvamaṣṭavidho jvaraḥ|  samāsenopadiṣṭasya vyāsataḥ śṛṇu lakṣaṇam||84||
translation: In the case of fever caused by an imbalance of phlegm and wind, or in a patient with Pitta dominance, the disappearance of symptoms such as discomfort, lack of appetite, thirst, exhaustion, and sweat indicates resolution of the disease.

sloka: śiroruk  parvaṇāṃ bhedo dāho romṇāṃ praharṣaṇam|  kaṇṭhāsyaśoṣo vamathustṛṣṇā mūrcchā bhramo'ruciḥ||85||  svapnanāśo'tivāgjṛmbhā vātapittajvarākṛtiḥ|
translation: In case of excessive thirst, exhaustion, frequent fever, desire, delusion, and bone pain, they consider it a sign of an imbalance of bile and phlegm.

sloka: śītako gauravaṃ tandrā staimityaṃ parvaṇāṃ ca ruk||86||  śirograhaḥ pratiśyāyaḥ kāsaḥ svedāpravartanam|  santāpo madhyavegaśca vātaśleṣmajvarākṛtiḥ||87||
translation: To those standing at sandhyā with a steady gaze, excessive talk, pride, confusion, and uncontrollable desire for honor; to such a person, dryness of throat would arise when there is a gentle breeze.

sloka: muhurdāho muhuḥ śītaṃ svedastambho  muhurmuhuḥ|  mohaḥ kāso'rucistṛṣṇā śleṣmapittapravartanam||88||  liptatiktāsyatā tandrā śleṣmapittajvarākṛtiḥ|  ityete dvandvajāḥ proktāḥ ...|89|
translation: In the presence of three symptoms - red urine, burning sensation, and sweating (or exhaustion) - Pitta dosha is predominant.

sloka: ... sannipātaja ucyate||89||  sannipātajvarasyordhvaṃ trayodaśavidhasya hi|  prāksūtritasya vakṣyāmi lakṣaṇaṃ vai pṛthak pṛthak||90||
translation: Prescribe a mixture of Kapha-aggravating factors, such as inactivity, desire for sleep, laugher, and confusion, along with drowsiness. (Verse 96)

sloka: bhramaḥ pipāsā dāhaśca gauravaṃ śiraso'tiruk|  vātapittolbaṇe vidyālliṅgaṃ mandakaphe jvare||91||
translation: The symptoms of bile preponderance are considered to be aversion to food, excessive sleep, exhaustion, loss of lustre, decreased appetite, and weakness of digestive fire.

sloka: śaityaṃ kāso'rucistandrāpipāsādāharugvyathāḥ|  vātaśleṣmolbaṇe vyādhau liṅgaṃ pittāvare viduḥ||92||
translation: The symptoms of too much bile (pitta) are considered to be a yellowish discharge from the eyes, burning sensation, thirst, confusion, and lack of luster; these are indicative of an imbalance in the body.

sloka: chardiḥ śaityaṃ muhurdāhastṛṣṇā moho'sthivedanā|  mandavāte vyavasyanti liṅgaṃ pittakapholbaṇe||93||
translation: In a person with excessive wind in the body and a mild bile disorder, but deficient in phlegm, the symptoms are trembling of the head, sighing, talking excessively, and salivation.

sloka: sandhyasthiśirasaḥ śūlaṃ pralāpo gauravaṃ bhramaḥ|  vātolbaṇe syād dvyanuge tṛṣṇā kaṇṭhāsyaśuṣkatā||94||
translation: In case of excess phlegm, those experienced recognize the symptom as a swollen body part; in an excess of bile, as increased heat; in an excess of wind, as emaciation; and in an excess of humor, as feebleness.

sloka: raktaviṇmūtratā dāhaḥ svedastṛḍ balasaṅkṣayaḥ|  mūrcchā ceti tridoṣe syālliṅgaṃ pitte garīyasi||95||
translation: The symptoms of an excess of wind are: taking a deep breath, coughing, yawning, dry mouth, and predominance in the sides.

sloka: ālasyārucihṛllāsadāhavamyaratibhramaiḥ|  kapholbaṇaṃ sannipātaṃ tandrākāsena cādiśet||96||
translation: The distinction in brilliance is seen between two fires, weakness in the case of Agni (digestive fire), thirst and burning sensation in an excess of bile, and a tremor in the absence of phlegm; this is understood.

sloka: pratiśyā chardirālasyaṃ tandrā'rucyagnimārdavam|  hīnavāte pittamadhye liṅgaṃ śleṣmādhike matam||97||
translation: I will describe the symptom of someone overwhelmed by the fear of imminent encounter: a sudden onset of heat, followed by cold; pain in the bones and head; pus-like sweating; a foul smell; red, watery eyes; and ears producing an abnormal sound and filled with pus.

sloka: hāridramūtranetratvaṃ dāhastṛṣṇā bhramo'ruciḥ|  hīnavāte madhyakaphe liṅgaṃ pittādhike matam||98||
translation: Lethargy, delusion, talking excessively, cough, fever, unsteadiness, burnt taste on the tongue, and limbs trembling - these are the symptoms [of the disease].

sloka: śirorugvepathuḥ śvāsaḥ pralāpaśchardyarocakau|  hīnapitte madhyakaphe liṅgaṃ syānmārutādhike||99||
translation: The invigoration of a person with a combination of rakta pitta (red bile) and kapha (phlegm)

sloka: śītako gauravaṃ tandrā pralāpo'sthiśiro'tiruk|  hīnapitte vātamadhye liṅgaṃ śleṣmādhike viduḥ||100||
translation: Constant coughing, emaciation, and infrequent sightings of sweat, urine, and feces are signs of wasting away in those who have thin bodies.

sloka: śvāsaḥ kāsaḥ pratiśyāyo mukhaśoṣo'tipārśvaruk|  kaphahīne pittamadhye liṅgaṃ vātādhike matam||101||
translation: Observing the arrangements of dark and red-colored granaries, the cooking of rivers, the heaviness of the udder, and the long-lasting maturation of defects that cause fever.

sloka: varcobhedo'gnidaurbalyaṃ [3] tṛṣṇā dāho'rucirbhramaḥ|  kaphahīne vātamadhye liṅgaṃ pittādhike viduḥ||102||
translation: In a fire afflicted by a fault and destroyed, the identifiable symptoms of a fever that is incurable through ordinary means and difficult to cure in any other way have been described as threefold, each with its own characteristics, according to the cause of the coming together and contact.

sloka: sannipātajvarasyordhvamato vakṣyāmi lakṣaṇam|  kṣaṇe dāhaḥ kṣaṇe śītamasthisandhiśirorujā||103||  sāsrāve kaluṣe rakte nirbhugne cāpi darśane [4] |  sasvanau sarujau karṇau kaṇṭhaḥ śūkairivāvṛtaḥ||104||
translation: The eighth who arrives (is a) fourfold (type of) designated (person), namely one who is cursed, physically struck, wounded by weapons, or bewitched.

sloka: tandrā mohaḥ pralāpaśca kāsaḥ śvāso'rucirbhramaḥ|  paridagdhā kharasparśā jihvā srastāṅgatā param||105||
translation: When a Brahmin, who is engaged in using weapons, staff, pieces of wood, mud, and rock, is struck, a fever caused by the injury arises. In such an injury, the wind, as a rule, causes blood to become tainted, leading to discomfort, shivering, pallor, and putrid fever.

sloka: ṣṭhīvanaṃ raktapittasya kaphenonmiśritasya ca|  śiraso loṭhanaṃ tṛṣṇā nidrānāśo hṛdi vyathā||106||
translation: The fever that is afflicted by desire, sorrow, fear, and anger.

sloka: svedamūtrapurīṣāṇāṃ cirāddarśanamalpaśaḥ|  kṛśatvaṃ nātigātrāṇāṃ pratataṃ kaṇṭhakūjanam||107||
translation: This (saḥ) affliction (abhiṣaṅgajvaraḥ) is to be known (jñeyaḥ) as arising from (jaḥ) attachment (abhiṣaṅgaḥ); and the three impurities (trayaḥ malāḥ) - wind (vāyuḥ) from desire (kāma-), bile (pittam) from anger (krodhāt), and phlegm (śoka) from fear (bhayāt).

sloka: koṭhānāṃ śyāvaraktānāṃ maṇḍalānāṃ ca darśanam|  mūkatvaṃ srotasāṃ pāko gurutvamudarasya ca||108||  cirāt pākaśca doṣāṇāṃ sannipātajvarākṛtiḥ|109|
translation: The common characteristics of beings become angry when there is transgression of their rights

sloka: doṣe vibaddhe naṣṭe'gnau sarvasampūrṇalakṣaṇaḥ||109||  sannipātajvaro'sādhyaḥ kṛcchrasādhyastvato'nyathā| nidāne trividhā proktā yā pṛthagjajvarākṛtiḥ||110||  saṃsargasannipātānāṃ tayā coktaṃ svalakṣaṇam|111|
translation: It is said that a person who has been anointed with the sap of a thorny tree or other substances causing poisoning also experiences fever.

sloka: āganturaṣṭamo yastu sa nirdiṣṭaścaturvidhaḥ||111||  abhighātābhiṣaṅgābhyāmabhicārābhiśāpataḥ|
translation: A person who uses exorcism to cure [others] attains peace. One who engages in the cursing and condemning of the accomplished ones, however, does not.

sloka: śastraloṣṭakaśākāṣṭhamuṣṭyaratnitaladvijaiḥ||112||  tadvidhaiśca hate gātre jvaraḥ syādabhighātajaḥ|  tatrābhighātaje vāyuḥ prāyo raktaṃ pradūṣayan||113||  savyathāśophavaivarṇyaṃ karoti sarujaṃ jvaram|114|
translation: The severe fever that arises at the time of encounter is formidable and difficult to endure. The symptom of this fever is remembered as such. (Verse 119)

sloka: kāmaśokabhayakrodhairabhiṣaktasya yo jvaraḥ||114||
translation: Upon witnessing the use of others' senses, bodies, and minds for improper purposes and also the resulting curse, (one should understand that) such actions are not appropriate.

sloka: so'bhiṣaṅgājvaro jñeyo yaśca bhūtābhiṣaṅgajaḥ|  kāmaśokabhayādvāyuḥ krodhāt pittaṃ trayo malāḥ||115||
translation: It is discerned through personal experience and inference, that it pertains to the discrimination between different types of straying and the curse associated with it.

sloka: bhūtābhiṣaṅgāt kupyanti bhūtasāmānyalakṣaṇāḥ|  bhūtādhikāre vyākhyātaṃ tadaṣṭavidhalakṣaṇam||116||
translation: In accordance with their respective uses, the distinct characteristics are: in a state of desire-infatuation, excessive breathing and sighing; in sorrow, profuse weeping; in fear, trembling resembling fever; in anger, great excitement; in possession by a spirit, human-like behavior.

sloka: viṣavṛkṣānilasparśāttathā'nyairviṣasambhavaiḥ|  abhiṣaktasya cāpyāhurjvarameke'bhiṣaṅgajam||117||
cikitsayā viṣaghnyaiva sa śamaṃ labhate naraḥ|  abhicārābhiśāpābhyāṃ siddhānāṃ yaḥ pravartate||118||
translation: Of all the diseases caused by kama (desire) and others, the strength is not the same when the mind is attacked previously by kama etc., as when it is not. The body becomes vulnerable to jwara (fever) due to vata etc., as long as it remains uncorrupted. However, when the body is already afflicted, the strength of the fever caused by vata etc., is not the same. The mind becomes susceptible to jwara caused by kama etc., as long as it remains pure. These are simple causes of disease in the beginning, but later on, they get mixed with other specific causes. Subsequently, diseases become inseparable from their specific causes.

sloka: sannipātajvaro ghoraḥ sa vijñeyaḥ suduḥsahaḥ|  sannipātajvarasyoktaṃ liṅgaṃ yattasya tat smṛtam||119||
translation: When the bodily humors are agitated and have gathered together, having identified their elemental quality and extracted the suitable one, and created heat with it, as well as with one's own heat, the body's strength is generated. By blocking the channels, only the body becomes susceptible to dehydration, leading to an excessive heating in the body, causing the individual to be described as feverish and experiencing increased warmth in all limbs.

sloka: cittondriyaśarīrāṇāmartayo'nyāśca naikaśaḥ|  prayogaṃ tvabhicārasya dṛṣṭvā śāpasya caiva hi||120||
translation: One does not sweat when the outlets are obstructed, nor is aggravated fever found in a fire that has moved from its place, except in a young person.

sloka: svayaṃ śrutvā'numānena lakṣyate  praśamena vā|  vaividhyādabhicārasya śāpasya ca tadātmake||121||
translation: Absence of lust and anger, consistency in actions, heaviness of the body, impurity of the heart, lethargy and unsteadiness, severe fever that does not subside, great strength, absence of the manifestation of diseases, talkativeness, laughter, fainting, elated or depressed mood, sluggishness, excessive sleep, heavy sweating, and emaciation are not symptoms of this fever.

sloka: yathākarmaprayogeṇa lakṣaṇaṃ syāt pṛthagvidham|  dhyānaniḥśvāsabahulaṃ liṅgaṃ kāmajvare smṛtam||122||  śokaje bāṣpabahulaṃ trāsaprāyaṃ bhayajvare|  krodhaje bahusaṃrambhaṃ bhūtāveśe tvamānuṣam||123||
translation: The symptoms of a feverish patient: an increased speed of the disease, excessive thirst, delirious speech, heavy breathing, and agitation, as well as the production of impurities.

sloka: mūrcchāmohamadaglānibhūyiṣṭhaṃ viṣasambhave|  keṣāñcideṣāṃ liṅgānāṃ santāpo jāyate puraḥ||124||  paścāttulyaṃ tu keṣāñcideṣu kāmajvarādiṣu|  kāmādijānāmuddiṣṭaṃ jvarāṇāṃ yadviśeṣaṇam||125||
