translation: The eight qualities of the body: hunger, thinness, lightness, heat, humidity, the onset of disease, and absence of fever.

sloka: kāmādijānāṃ rogāṇāmanyeṣāmapi tat smṛtam|  manasyabhihate pūrvaṃ kāmādyairna tathā balam||126||  jvaraḥ prāpnoti vātādyairdeho yāvanna dūṣyati|  dehe cābhiha(dru)te pūrvaṃ vātādyairna tathā balam||127||  jvaraḥ prāpnoti kāmādyairmano yāvanna dūṣyati| te pūrvaṃ kevalāḥ paścānnijairvyāmiśralakṣaṇāḥ||128||  hetvauṣadhaviśiṣṭāśca bhavantyāgantavo jvarāḥ|129|
translation: One should avoid, in the daytime while suffering from a fresh bout of illness: sleeping after eating, bathing, massaging the body, and sexual intercourse. Also, one should avoid indulging in anger and physical exertion.

sloka: saṃsṛṣṭāḥ sannipatitāḥ pṛthagvā kupitā malāḥ||129||  rasākhyaṃ dhātumanvetya paktiṃ  sthānānnirasya ca|  svena tenoṣmaṇa caiva kṛtvā dehoṣmaṇo balam||130||  srotāṃsi ruddhvā samprāptāḥ kevalaṃ dehamulbaṇāḥ|  santāpamadhikaṃ dehe janayanti narastadā||131||  bhavatyatyuṣṇasarvāṅgo jvaritastena cocyate|132|
translation: Initially, only jumping over the fever is recommended if not due to the origin of fever from bile, wind, anger, desire, grief, or exhaustion.

sloka: srotasāṃ sanniruddhatvāt svedaṃ nā nādhigacchati||132||  svasthānāt pracyute cāgnau prāyaśastaruṇejvare|133|
translation: Once the fault is identified and removed by jumping over it, lightness and hunger arise in that (fire). One should nourish this, which has the power to cause health and freedom from disease, through jumping (i.e., fanning), avoiding opposition to the breath. This is the purpose of this sequence of actions.

sloka: aruciścāvipākaśca gurutvamudarasya ca||133||  hṛdayasyāviśuddhiśca tandrā cālasyameva ca|  jvaro'visargī balavān doṣāṇāmapravartanam||134||  lālāpraseko hṛllāsaḥ kṣunnāśo virasaṃ  mukham|  stabdhasuptaguruvaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ bahumūtratā||135||  na viḍ jīrṇā na ca glānirjvarasyāmasya lakṣaṇam|
translation: Jumping, sweating, time, the taste of yava and bitter vastika, and the early symptoms of fever are the unripe faults in a feverish condition.

sloka: jvaravego'dhikastṛṣṇā pralāpaḥ śvasanaṃ bhramaḥ||136||  malapravṛttirutkleśaḥ pacyamānasya lakṣaṇam|137|
translation: In cases of fever caused by phlegm and bile, one should give warm water to the thirsty. Cool, bitter drinks are beneficial in fevers and act as a digestive and alleviate them. Cleaning the veins is powerful, it is pleasant, stimulates appetite and sweating, and is auspicious.

sloka: kṣut kṣāmatā laghutvaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ jvaramārdavam||137||  doṣapravṛttiraṣṭāho nirāmajvaralakṣaṇam|138|
translation: The residents of the northern city, who are experts in preparing sandalwood paste, should give cool water to those suffering from thirst and fever to alleviate their discomfort.

sloka: navajvare divāsvapnasnānābhyaṅgānnamaithunam||138||  krodhapravātavyāyāmān kaṣāyāṃśca vivarjayet|139|
translation: Understanding that the chief doshas (humors) located in the stomach have become aggravated, one should induce emesis with purgatives at appropriate times to eliminate them.

sloka: jvare laṅghanamevādāvupadiṣṭamṛte jvarāt||139||  kṣayānilabhayakrodhakāmaśokaśramodbhavāt  |140|
translation: Vomiting in a young person with fever removes the faults that are not yet manifest and greatly causes heart-related disorders, shortness of breath, and delusion. Doshas ( bodily humors) residing in all parts of the body, like the inherent taste in fruits, get eliminated through this process.

sloka: laṅghanena kṣayaṃ nīte doṣe sandhukṣite'nale||140||  vijvaratvaṃ laghutvaṃ ca kṣuccaivāsyopajāyate  |  prāṇāvirodhinā cainaṃ laṅghanenopapādayet||141||  balādhiṣṭhānamārogyaṃ yadartho'yaṃ kriyākramaḥ|142|
translation: One who is knowledgeable about the medicinal uses of various plants should administer, in due course of time, purgatives and emetics mixed with such plants, for as long as the fever lasts or for six days. By doing so, fire is kindled just like when fuel is added to it; and these very substances, because of their lightness and ability to stimulate digestion, help in igniting the fire.

sloka: laṅghanaṃ svedanaṃ kālo yavāgvastiktako rasaḥ||142||  pācanānyavipakvānāṃ doṣāṇāṃ taruṇe jvare|143|
translation: The order of expulsion of faeces, urine, and other impurities is for the purpose of promoting perspiration, increasing heat, and alleviating heaviness. Therefore, drinks that have the opposite qualities, such as being cool and light, should be taken in cases of fever, to counteract its heat and oppressive nature. (152-153)

sloka: tṛṣyate salilaṃ coṣṇaṃ dadyādvātakaphajvare  ||143||  madyotthe paittike cātha śītalaṃ tiktakaiḥ śṛtam|  dīpanaṃ pācanaṃ caiva jvaraghnamubhayaṃ hi tat||144||  srotasāṃ śodhanaṃ balyaṃ rucisvedakaraṃ śivam|145|
translation: A knowledgeable person should take care of fever caused by alcohol consumption, especially during its peak, excessive consumption, and in hot weather with an aggravation of Pitta and Kapha doshas. Yava-gruel is beneficial in a fever with upward movement of rakta pitta.

sloka: mustaparpaṭakośīracandanodīcyanāgaraiḥ||145||  śṛtaśītaṃ jalaṃ dadyāt pipāsājvaraśāntaye|146|
translation: In that (place of worship), offering oblations with grains and flour should be made first, (the oblations) being mixed with medicinal fruits to cure fever.

sloka: kaphapradhānānutkliṣṭān doṣānāmāśayasthitān||146||  buddhvā jvarakarān kāle vamyānāṃ vamanairharet|147|
translation: Then, considering one's own strength, nourishment and refreshment should be offered. One can feed with a gruel made of pulses or with the juice of wild plants. At mealtime, brushing one's teeth is also to be offered to that one (the guest).

sloka: anupasthitadoṣāṇāṃ vamanaṃ taruṇejvare||147||  hṛdrogaṃ śvāsamānāhaṃ mohaṃ  ca janayedbhṛśam|  sarvadehānugāḥ sāmā dhātusthā asunirharāḥ  ||148||  doṣāḥ phalānāmāmānāṃ  svarasā iva sātyayāḥ|149|
translation: One who can distinguish the taste of things derived from their contact with his lips and knows the suitability or unsuitability of things, and after properly cleaning and rinsing his mouth with the twigs of trees and such, is able to partake of food and drinks according to his taste.

sloka: vamitaṃ laṅghitaṃ kāle yavāgūbhirupācaret||149||  yathāsvauṣadhasiddhābhirmaṇḍapūrvābhirāditaḥ|  yāvajjvaramṛdūbhāvāt ṣaḍahaṃ vā vicakṣaṇaḥ||150||  tasyāgnirdīpyate tābhiḥ samidbhiriva pāvakaḥ|  tāśca bheṣajasaṃyogāllaghutvāccāgnidīpanāḥ||151||
translation: The physician should administer a purgative or a sedative drug, after the fever has subsided for six days, and if the patient is able to tolerate light food.

sloka: vātamūtrapurīṣāṇāṃ doṣāṇāṃ  cānulomanāḥ|  svedanāya dravoṣṇatvāddravatvāttṛṭpraśāntaye||152||  āhārabhāvāt prāṇāya saratvāllāghavāya ca|  jvaraghnyo jvarasātmyatvāttasmāt  peyābhirāditaḥ||153||
translation: Diseases that are not pacified, aggravate irregular fevers; afflictions become firmly established due to the body's heat. However, a particular quality (kshaya) is not prohibited with the intent of planning for another quality (kshaya). A quality similar to the affliction should be avoided during the acute stage of the disease.

sloka: jvarānupacareddhīmānṛte  madyasamutthitāt|  madātyaye madyanitye grīṣme pittakaphādhike||154||  ūrdhvage raktapitte ca yavāgūrna hitā jvare|155|
translation: For alleviating fever, one should eat lightly, for ten days, food that is not bitter, sour, salty, pungent or astringent.

sloka: tatra tarpaṇamevāgre prayojyaṃ  lājasaktubhiḥ||155||  jvarāpahaiḥ phalarasairyuktaṃ samadhuśarkaram|156|
translation: Upon fever dominated by kapha, but superior to vata and pitta, when the doshas are fully matured, just as ghee is nectar for sarpis (hardened curds), likewise, knowing it to be kapha-predominant, a physician should not administer ghee, but instead use astringent treatments. One should give light food and meat soup, for the purpose of subduing and reducing the strength of the doshas. [164, 165, 166, 167]

sloka: tataḥ sātmyabalāpekṣī bhojayejjīrṇatarpaṇam||156||  tanunā mudgayūṣeṇa jāṅgalānāṃ rasena vā|  annakāleṣu cāpyasmai vidheyaṃ dantadhāvanam||157||
translation: The fever caused by an increase in wind and bile, or that which arises due to aggravated phlegm, can be conquered by drinking fresh butter that is properly prepared and has had its impurities removed.

sloka: yo'sya vaktrarasastasmādviparītaṃ priyaṃ ca yat|  tadasya mukhavaiśadyaṃ prakāṅkṣāṃ cānnapānayoḥ||158||  dhatte rasaviśeṣāṇāmabhijñatvaṃ karoti yat|  viśodhya drumaśākhāgrairāsyaṃ prakṣālya cāsakṛt||159||  mastvikṣurasamadyādyairyathāhāramavāpnuyāt|160|
translation: When fever does not subside despite the use of medicines, it can be treated with therapeutic emesis, provided that the person still has strength.

sloka: pācanaṃ śamanīyaṃ vā kaṣāyaṃ pāyayedbhiṣak||160||  jvaritaṃ ṣaḍahe'tīte laghvannapratibhojitam|161|
translation: For a feverish patient, purgation or emesis is not beneficial. Instead, it is recommended to remove impurities from the body by administering milk or other suitable substances, which can help improve strength, agni (digestive fire), freedom from fever, and happiness. In case of fully developed doshas (body humors), one should act quickly to eliminate them, specifically pitta or a combination of kapha and pitta located in the stomach. Additionally, when the three malas (waste products) are loosened and situated in the lower abdomen, they should be eliminated through therapeutic enema.

sloka: stabhyante na  vipacyante kurvanti viṣamajvaram||161||  doṣā baddhāḥ kaṣāyeṇa stambhitvāttaruṇe jvare|  na tu kalpanamuddiśya kaṣāyaḥ pratiṣidhyate||162||  yaḥ kaṣāyakaṣāyaḥ  syāt sa varjyastaruṇajvare|163|
translation: In advanced stages of fever, when Kapha and Pitta have diminished and the digestive fire is strong, one should administer a therapeutic emetic to someone with rough, bound-up stools.

sloka: yūṣairamlairanamlairvā jāṅgalairvā rasairhitaiḥ||163||  daśāhaṃ yāvadaśnīyāllaghvannaṃ jvaraśāntaye|164|
translation: With a white cloth tied around his head and with his senses restrained, one should perform hair-related procedures during debilitating fever.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ kaphe mande vātapittottare jvare||164||  paripakveṣu doṣeṣu sarpiṣpānaṃ yathā'mṛtam| nirdaśāhamapi jñātvā kaphottaramalaṅghitam||165||  na sarpiḥ pāyayedvaidyaḥ kaṣāyaistamupācaret  |  yāvallaghutvādaśanaṃ dadyānmāṃsarasena ca||166||  balaṃ hyalaṃ nigrahāya doṣāṇāṃ balakṛcca tat  |167|
translation: The physician should carefully divide and apply cold and warm treatments to the limbs and body in a feverish, aged patient. This way, the external fever is quickly calmed, and the body experiences comfort; strength and complexion are also restored. Using medicinal smoke and collyrium, even chronic fevers subside. Moreover, when only the essential elements remain, the returning fever does not relapse.

sloka: dāhatṛṣṇāparītasya vātapittottaraṃ jvaram||167||  baddhapracyutadoṣaṃ vā nirāmaṃ payasā jayet|168|
translation: The method for curing fever has been established. Now hear about the materials to be used, along with sixty other ingredients, that can cure fevers accompanied by symptoms like redness and swelling. These are mentioned in ancient texts and are effective in treating feverish patients who have abstained from yava, voda, and laja.

sloka: kriyābhirābhiḥ praśamaṃ na prayāti yadā jvaraḥ||168||  akṣīṇabalamāṃsāgneḥ  śamayettaṃ virecanaiḥ|169|
translation: A person suffering from fever, seeking sour taste, should drink the juice of pomegranate made by happy old city dwellers, which is a remedy for fever and reduces hunger.

sloka: jvarakṣīṇasya na hitaṃ vamanaṃ na virecanam||169||  kāmaṃ tu payasā tasya nirūhairvā harenmalān|  nirūho balamagniṃ ca vijvaratvaṃ mudaṃ rucim||170||  paripakveṣu doṣeṣu prayuktaḥ śīghramāvahet| pittaṃ vā kaphapittaṃ vā pittāśayagataṃ haret||171||  sraṃsanaṃ trīnmalān bastirharet pakvāśayasthitān|172|
translation: A person should drink cold, sweet water or water kept in a golden vessel. One should also drink the juice of pomegranate, bael, bilva, and blue water-lily to alleviate fever and thirst. Drinking boiled and cooled water with ingredients like vidaarigaṇḍha (Dioscorea opposita), and guggulu (Commiphora wightii) can help in reducing sweating, cough, hiccups, and diarrhea.

sloka: jvare purāṇe saṅkṣīṇe kaphapitte dṛḍhāgnaye||172||  rūkṣabaddhapurīṣāya pradadyādanuvāsanam|173|
translation: One should drink the decoction of sarpis (ghee) that is exuded in a knot and has become warm, as well as the decoction made from the roots of pippali, dry wood-apple, beleric myrobalan, and emblic myrobalan, when afflicted with fever accompanied by other ailments. (185-186)

sloka: gaurave śirasaḥ śūle vibaddheṣvindriyeṣu ca||173||  jīrṇajvare rucikaraṃ kuryānmūrdhavirecanam|174|
translation: One who is fatigued, thirsty, and suffering from fever should drink a mixture of sugar, the juice of bilva and amla fruits, and sesame oil, which has been boiled with garlic.

sloka: abhyaṅgāṃśca pradehāṃśca pariṣekāvagāhane||174||  vibhajya śītoṣṇakṛtaṃ  kuryājjīrṇe jvare bhiṣak|  tairāśu praśamaṃ yāti bahirmārgagato jvaraḥ||175||  labhante sukhamaṅgāni balaṃ varṇaśca vardhate|176|  dhūpanāñjanayogaiśca yānti jīrṇajvarāḥ śamam||176||  tvaṅmātraśeṣā yeṣāṃ ca bhavatyāganturanvayaḥ|177|
translation: For those who are afflicted by jwara (a type of fever) and whose satta (essence) resembles that of yusha (a type of sour gruel), rice, masha (black gram), chana (bengal gram), kulatha (horsegram), and kustaka (species of pulse) should be administered.

sloka: iti kriyākramaḥ siddho jvaraghnaḥ samprakāśitaḥ||177||  yeṣāṃ tveṣa kramastāni dravyāṇyūrdhvamataḥ śṛṇu|  raktaśālyādayaḥ śastāḥ purāṇāḥ ṣaṣṭikaiḥ saha||178||  yavāgvodanalājārthe jvaritānāṃ jvarāpahāḥ|179|
translation: A banana leaf that is ripe, a fruitful palm tree, a fertile field, neem tree that destroys sins, a purgative plant, and a tree useful in treating fever - these are mentioned.

sloka: lājapeyāṃ sukhajarāṃ pippalīnāgaraiḥ śṛtām||179||  pibejjvarī jvaraharāṃ kṣudvānalpāgnirāditaḥ|  amlābhilāṣī tāmeva dāḍimāmlāṃ sanāgarām||180||
translation: To a discerning person, who is knowledgeable about the appropriate time, it is recommended to donate, as a cure for fever, meat from birds like the heron, crane, partridge, and hare, which are mildly bitter or astringent in taste. Some doctors do not recommend the use of heat-producing animal products during fever. However, if there is an excess of wind element in the fever, then it can be balanced with such meat. A knowledgeable physician who understands the proper time to apply these measures can administer them effectively.

sloka: sṛṣṭaviṭ paittiko vā'tha śītāṃ madhuyutāṃ pibet|  peyāṃ vā raktaśālīnāṃ pārśvabastiśiroruji||181||  śvadaṃṣṭrākaṇṭakāribhyāṃ siddhāṃ jvaraharāṃ pibet|  jvarātisārī peyāṃ vā pibet sāmlāṃ śṛtāṃ naraḥ||182||  pṛśniparṇībalābilvanāgarotpaladhānyakaiḥ|  śṛtāṃ vidārīgandhādyairdīpanīṃ svedanīṃ naraḥ||183||  kāsī śvāsī ca hikkī ca yavāgūṃ jvaritaḥ pibet|  vibaddhavarcāḥ sayavāṃ pippalyāmalakaiḥ śṛtām||184||
translation: One should give water or a drink similar in properties to alcohol, according to one's capacity and the situation, to quench the thirst of someone who is in need.

sloka: sarpiṣmatīṃ pibet peyāṃ jvarī doṣānulomanīm|  koṣṭhe vibaddhe saruji pibet peyāṃ śṛtāṃ jvarī||185||  mṛdvīkāpippalīmūlacavyāmalakanāgaraiḥ|  pibet sabilvāṃ peyāṃ vā jvare saparikartike||186||
translation: One should generally avoid foods and drinks that are overly sweet, salty, or sour, as well as those recently prepared by a teacher or guru, for the purpose of alleviating symptoms of disease. A proper regimen of eating and drinking has been revealed to be effective in combating fever.

sloka: balāvṛkṣāmlakolāmlakalaśīdhāvanīśṛtām|  asvedanidrastṛṣṇārtaḥ pibet peyāṃ saśarkarām||187||  nāgarāmalakaiḥ siddhāṃ ghṛtabhṛṣṭāṃ jvarāpahām|188|
translation: From now onward, the following are the deoxidizing agents that alleviate fever: one may drink a preparation of pākya (a type of plant), coolant kṣāra (alkali); or one may drink a preparation of sanāgaraka (a type of plant) which is easily available; or one may drink the bitter kirātatiktaka (a type of plant) with musta (a type of plant), known as the universal medicine; or one may drink pathya-muśīra (a type of herb) from the south, which alleviates fever. These deoxidizing agents not only reduce fever but also destroy doshas (bodily humors) and remove thirst, aphtha (a type of mouth ulceration), and bad breath.

sloka: mudgānmasūrāṃścaṇakān kulatthān samakuṣṭakān||188||  yūṣārthe yūṣasātmyānāṃ  jvaritānāṃ pradāpayet|189|
translation: The leaves of the Patola plant are pungent and astringent. The root of Patola is Sariva, its stem is Musta. The Patha of Musta is also pungent and astringent. Nimba is similar to Patola, Triphala is like Nimba, Mrudvika is like Musta, and the fruit of Mushta is also like Mrudvika. Kiratatiktam is sweet and cold, and is the nectar of all; it is a universal medicine. Guduchyadi, Amalaki, and half the quantity of Musta make up this verse's conclusion. The five types of sharp fevers are quickly pacified by the five kinds of astringent substances. These, along with the third and fourth kinds, should be used constantly.

sloka: paṭolapatraṃ saphalaṃ kulakaṃ pāpacelikam||189||  karkoṭakaṃ kaṭhillaṃ ca vidyācchākaṃ jvare hitam|190|
translation: A person seeking a remedy for fever should drink the decoction made of the following:

sloka: lāvān kapiñjalāneṇāṃścakorānupacakrakān||190||  kuraṅgān kālapucchāṃśca hariṇān pṛṣatāñchaśān|  pradadyānmāṃsasātmyāya jvaritāya jvarāpahān||191||  īṣadamlānanamlān vā rasān kāle vicakṣaṇaḥ|  kukkuṭāṃśca mayūrāṃśca tittirikrauñcavartakān||192||  gurūṣṇatvānna śaṃsanti jvare keciccikitsakāḥ|  laṅghanenānilabalaṃ jvare yadyadhikaṃ bhavet||193||  bhiṣaṅmātrāvikalpajño  dadyāttānapi kālavit|194|
translation: If one is bound by the faults of bile and phlegm, they should drink a mixture of licorice, dry ginger, black pepper, and three myrobalan fruits, which are cleansing, pungent, and bitter in taste, and alleviate diseases caused by an imbalance of bile and phlegm.

sloka: gharmāmbu cānupānārthaṃ tṛṣitāya pradāpayet||194||  madyaṃ vā madyasātmyāya yathādoṣaṃ yathābalam|195|
translation: This therapeutic yoga, consisting of the great Bryhatyau poses, milking the calf, the medicinal tree Devadaru, and Kolavalli, is a remedy for fever.

sloka: gurūṣṇasnigdhamadhurān kaṣāyāṃśca navajvare||195||  āhārān doṣapaktyarthaṃ prāyaśaḥ parivarjayet|  annapānakramaḥ siddho jvaraghnaḥ samprakāśitaḥ||196||
translation: The group of herbs consisting of shati, pushkarmula, vyaghri, sringi, duralphA, guduchi, nAgarampaatha, and kirataka are effective in alleviating the symptoms of bundling fever (sannipAtajvara), such as those caused by heart trouble, anxiety, dyspnea, and cough.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyante kaṣāyā jvaranāśanāḥ|  pākyaṃ śītakaṣāyaṃ vā mustaparpaṭakaṃ pibet||197||  sanāgaraṃ parpaṭakaṃ pibedvā sadurālabham|  kirātatiktakaṃ mustaṃ guḍūcīṃ viśvabheṣajam||198||  pāṭhāmuśīraṃ sodīcyaṃ pibedvā jvaraśāntaye|  jvaraghnā dīpanāścaite kaṣāyā doṣapācanāḥ||199||  tṛṣṇārucipraśamanā mukhavairasyanāśanāḥ|200|
translation: The combination of Brihati, Poushkara, Bargava, Shatii, Shrngii, and Duralabha is said to alleviate fever arising from close proximity (of bodies) and should be given in all kinds of fevers, including cough and others, along with the seeds of cow's urine and Patola, which has a bitter taste.

sloka: kaliṅgakāḥ paṭolasya patraṃ kaṭukarohiṇī||200||  paṭolaḥ sārivā mustaṃ pāṭhā kaṭukarohiṇī|  nimbaḥ paṭolastriphalā mṛdvīkā mustavatsakau|| 201||   kirātatiktamamṛtā candanaṃ viśvabheṣajam|  guḍūcyāmalakaṃ mustamardhaślokasamāpanāḥ||c02||  kaṣāyāḥ śamayantyāśu pañca pañcavidhāñjvarān|  santataṃ satatānyedyustṛtīyakacaturthakān||203||
translation: The qualities of turmeric and barley, as well as those that alleviate thirst and fever, have been specified as medicinal in the treatise. Even a healer should make use of them.

sloka: vatsakāragvadhau pāṭhāṃ ṣaḍgranthāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm|  mūrvāṃ sātiviṣāṃ nimbaṃ paṭolaṃ dhanvayāsakam||204||  vacāṃ mustamuśīraṃ ca madhukaṃ triphalāṃ balām|  pākyaṃ śītakaṣāyaṃ vā pibejjvaraharaṃ naraḥ||205||  madhūkamustamṛdvīkākāśmaryāṇi parūṣakam|  trāyamāṇāmuśīraṃ ca triphalāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||206||  pītvā niśisthitaṃ janturjvarācchīghraṃ vimucyate|207|
translation: The fevers that do not subside through purification, light diet, and movement are conquered by ghee in those whose weakened bodily constituent, characterized by roughness and heat, is susceptible to being pacified by oleation. (216, 217)

sloka: jātyāmalakamustāni tadvaddhanvayavāsakam||207||  vibaddhadoṣo jvaritaḥ kaṣāyaṃ saguḍaṃ pibet|  triphalāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca mṛdvīkāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||208||  pittaśleṣmaharastveṣa kaṣāyo hyānulomikaḥ|  trivṛtāśarkarāyuktaḥ pittaśleṣmajvarāpahaḥ||209||
translation: All these impurities, when combined with ghee, can be used in the peaceful and auspicious process of agniSandhana (a fire ritual for alleviating fever).

sloka: bṛhatyau vatsakaṃ mustaṃ devadāru mahauṣadham|  kolavallī ca yogo'yaṃ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ||210||
translation: Consuming a mixture of the pippal tree's bark, candana, mushta, katu rohini, kalinga, tamalaki, sriva with extreme bitterness, and bila fruits, which are protected and dried, along with ghee that has been prepared with siddha herbs, can immediately alleviate chronic fever, wasting disease, headache, side pain, joint dislocation, burning sensations in the body, and irregular fevers.

sloka: śaṭī puṣkaramūlaṃ ca vyāghrī śṛṅgī durālabhā|  guḍūcī nāgaraṃ pāṭhā kirātaṃ kaṭurohiṇī||211||  eṣa śaṭyādiko vargaḥ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ|  kāsahṛdgrahapārśvārtiśvāsatandrāsu śasyate||212||
translation: By cooking triphala, guduchi, yavasakam, pippalimusta, mrdvika, chandan, utpala, and naga flowers together with twice the amount of water, and by consuming this decoction prepared with kalka (paste) made from these same ingredients, one can treat jirna jvara (chronic fever).

sloka: bṛhatyau pauṣkaraṃ bhārgī śaṭī śṛṅgī durālabhā|  vatsakasya ca bījāni paṭolaṃ kaṭurohiṇī||213||  bṛhatyādirgaṇaḥ proktaḥ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ|  kāsādiṣu ca sarveṣu dadyāt sopadraveṣu ca||214||
translation: Preparing a decoction for therapeutic purposes, one should mix the following ingredients that are hard to obtain and possess powerful qualities:

sloka: kaṣāyāśca yavāgvaśca pipāsājvaranāśanāḥ|  nirdiṣṭā bheṣajādhyāye bhiṣaktānapi yojayet||215||
translation: At the appointed time, the intelligent one should carry out purification above and below [the body], which is advised to be done for protection against various fevers and ailments.

sloka: jvarāḥ kaṣāyairvamanairlaṅghanairlaghubhojanaiḥ|  rūkṣasya ye na śāmyanti sarpisteṣāṃ bhiṣagjitam||216||  rūkṣaṃ tejo jvarakaraṃ tejasā rūkṣitasya ca|  yaḥ syādanubalo dhātuḥ snehavadhyaḥ  sa cānilaḥ||217||
translation: To alleviate fever, one should drink madana mixed with pippali or kalinga and honey, warmed up water, or vomit using warm water. Alternatively, one may use ksaudra ambu (a type of water), salt water, or purging with alcohol for the same purpose.

sloka: kaṣāyāḥ sarva evaite sarpiṣā saha yojitāḥ|  prayojyā jvaraśāntyarthamagnisandhukṣaṇāḥ śivāḥ||218||
translation: One should sip the juice of fresh, ripe Amla fruits or drink Amla juice mixed with ghee, as it helps to alleviate fever.

sloka: pippalyaścandanaṃ mustamuśīraṃ kaṭurohiṇī|  kaliṅgakāstāmalakī sārivā'tiviṣā sthirā||219||  drākṣāmalakabilvāni trāyamāṇā nidigdhikā|  siddhamitairghṛtaṃ sadyo jīrṇajvaramapohati||220||  kṣayaṃ kāsaṃ śiraḥśūlaṃ pārśvaśūlaṃ halīmakam|  aṃsābhitāpamāgniṃ ca viṣamaṃ sanniyacchati||221||
translation: One should consume Traivrita powder mixed with honey and ghee, or alternatively drink Kaudra water mixed with ghee and Triphala extract. One may also consume Aragvadha juice or the sap of Mridvikas, either when afflicted by fever that is being treated with them, or if free from fever but seeking to be protected from it. After consuming these treatments, one is freed from fever, and drinking warm water or grape juice afterwards is also beneficial. (translated by Gabe Boutwell)

sloka: vāsāṃ guḍūcīṃ triphalāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ yavāsakam|  paktvā tena kaṣāyeṇa payasā dviguṇena ca||222||  pippalīmustamṛdvīkācandanotpalanāgaraiḥ|  kalkīkṛtaiśca vipaceddhṛtaṃ jīrṇajvarāpaham||223||
translation: Who is freed from chronic pain in the head and sides, and from prolonged fever, after drinking five-root infused milk?

sloka: balāṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ bṛhatīṃ kalasīṃ dhāvanīṃ sthirām|  nimbaṃ parpaṭakaṃ mustaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ durālabhām||224||  kṛtvā kaṣāyaṃ peṣyārthe dadyāttāmalakīṃ śaṭīm|  drākṣāṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca medāmāmalakāni ca||225||  ghṛtaṃ payaśca tat siddhaṃ sarpirjvaraharaṃ param|  kṣayakāsaśiraḥśūlapārśvaśūlāṃsatāpanut  ||226||
translation: Drinking the decoction made from the roots of castor plant, one is relieved from fever along with its accompanying symptoms, just as one is freed from bondage by eating the bel fruit.

sloka: jvaribhyo bahudoṣebhya ūrdhvaṃ cādhaśca buddhimān|  dadyāt saṃśodhanaṃ kāle kalpe yadupadekṣyate||227||
translation: A concoction made from the three kinds of kantaka, vyaghri, and guda plants, which prevents urinary restraint, and alleviates fever and swelling.

sloka: madanaṃ pippalībhirvā kaliṅgairmadhukena vā|  yuktamuṣṇāmbunā peyaṃ vamanaṃ jvaraśāntaye||228||  kṣaudrāmbunā rasenekṣorathavā lavaṇāmbunā|  jvare pracchardanaṃ śastaṃ madyairvā tarpaṇena vā||229||
translation: A city with a prosperous harbor, containing ghee, oil, and sugar, drunken sweet milk mixed with sugar, alleviating thirst and fever.

sloka: mṛdvīkāmalakānāṃ vā rasaṃ praskandanaṃ pibet|  rasamāmalakānāṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ jvarāpaham||230||
translation: Drinking water mixed with four measures of ghee or consuming hot water boiled with ghee can immediately cure fever caused by wind and bile.

sloka: lihyādvā traivṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  pibedvā kṣaudramāvāpya saghṛtaṃ triphalārasam||231||  āragvadhaṃ vā payasā mṛdvīkānāṃ rasena vā|  trivṛtāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ vā payasā jvaritaḥ pibet||232||  jvarādvimucyate pītvā mṛdvīkābhiḥ sahābhayām|  payo'nupānamuṣṇaṃ vā pītvā drākṣārasaṃ naraḥ||233||
translation: The ultimate cure for all afflictions of chronic fever is milk, whether it is consumed warm or cold, along with other prescribed medicines.

sloka: kāsācchvāsācchiraḥśūlātpārśvaśūlāccirajvarāt|  mucyate jvaritaḥ pītvā pañcamūlīśṛtaṃ payaḥ||234||
translation: Those who apply remedies to eliminate causes of fever and other manifested disorders are said to be proficient in the attainment of therapeutic goals.

sloka: eraṇḍamūlotkvathitaṃ jvarāt saparikartikāt| payo vimucyate pītvā tadvadbilvaśalāṭubhiḥ||235||
translation: The leaves of the Patola plant, a four-fingered Sosa stem, Hribera, Rohini, bitter taste, dog's tooth, and intoxicating substances; all these, when well-mixed with half the water of milk, the remaining quantity of curd, ghee, and a mixture of the bark of Pippala and Madhuka, along with the stomach of a calf, can be used to make a medicine for fever.

sloka: trikaṇṭakabalāvyāghrīguḍanāgarasādhitam|  varcomūtravibandhaghnaṃ śophajvaraharaṃ payaḥ||236||
translation: Once the impurities are removed from the bodily elements and they become calm, a person quickly becomes healthy with light limbs and without physical ailments.

sloka: sanāgaraṃ samṛdvīkaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  śṛtaṃ payaḥ sakharjūraṃ pipāsājvaranāśanam||237||
translation: One should prepare a concoction using four ingredients: aragvadha, usheer, the fruit of madana, and four types of leaves; also add priyangu, madana, musta, shatahva, madhuyashtika, kalk, guda, kshaudra, and basti, which is excellent for alleviating fever.

sloka: caturguṇenāmbhasā vā śṛtaṃ jvaraharaṃ payaḥ|  dhāroṣṇaṃ vā payaḥ sadyo vātapittajvaraṃ jayet||238||
translation: One should prepare a medicinal remedy with: guidedi thoroughly protected, sandalwood, honey, and the strong vṛṣa; pṛśniparnī, madana, along with their juices; the taste of meat from the jungle, mixed with the juices of pippali, musta, and madhuka fruits; and a small amount of rock salt, combined with ghee. This remedy alleviates fever and increases strength and sweating.

sloka: jīrṇajvarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ payaḥ praśamanaṃ param| peyaṃ taduṣṇaṃ śītaṃ vā yathāsvaṃ bheṣajaiḥ śṛtam||239||
translation: Grind together madhuka, meda, pippalI, madana, vacA, rddhi, rSNa, bala, and visvam; add milk, water, ghee, and oil to it. This anuvAsanika sneham, when used as a remedy, cures jwara.

sloka: prayojayejjvaraharānnirūhān sānuvāsanān|  pakvāśayagate doṣe vakṣyante ye ca siddhiṣu||240||
translation: The sap of the Patola plant, crushed with that of Picumarda, mixed with Guduchi and Madhuka, and taken with aphrodisiacs, serves as a remedy for fever.

sloka: paṭolāriṣṭapatrāṇi sośīraścaturaṅgulaḥ|  hrīberaṃ rohiṇī tiktā śvadaṃṣṭrā madanāni ca||241||  sthirā balā ca tat sarvaṃ payasyardhodake śṛtam|  kṣīrāvaśeṣaṃ niryūhaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā||242||  kalkairmadanamustānāṃ pippalyā madhukasya ca|  vatsakasya ca saṃyuktaṃ bastiṃ dadyājjvarāpaham||243||
translation: The ointment made from sandalwood, saffron, musk, patchouli, and blue lotus is praised as a cure for fever, and as a balm that generates warmth and affection.

sloka: śuddhe mārge hṛte doṣe viprasanneṣu dhātuṣu|  gatāṅgaśūlo laghvaṅgaḥ sadyo bhavati vijvaraḥ||244||
translation: In the chapter on therapeutics, it is stated that a knowledgeable person should administer head evacuation as a means to alleviate fever; and oils that are not from the earth (i.e. processed or cooked), as well as those that produce smoke when ignited, are recommended in doses appropriate for the patient for managing fevers as well.

sloka: āragvadhamuśīraṃ ca madanasya phalaṃ tathā|  catasraḥ parṇinīścaiva [1] niryūhamupakalpayet||245||  priyaṅgurmadanaṃ mustaṃ śatāhvā madhuyaṣṭikā|  kalkaḥ sarpirguḍaḥ kṣaudraṃ jvaraghno bastiruttamaḥ||246||
translation: The physician shall carry out fomentation, anointment, and sprinkling, dividing the fever into two types as desired, hot and cold. He shall apply an oil or sandalwood paste, washed a thousand times, that alleviates fever caused by burning, as a treatment.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca candanaṃ madhukaṃ vṛṣam|  sthirāṃ balāṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ madanaṃ ceti sādhayet||247||  rasaṃ jāṅgalamāṃsasya rasena sahitaṃ bhiṣak|  pippalīphalamustānāṃ kalkena madhukasya ca||248||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktyā nirūhaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  jvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādbalasvedarucipradam||249||
translation: Fresh lotus petals and those of the banana tree, along with cool and pure surfaces, can be found here in abundance.

sloka: jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ medāṃ pippalīṃ madanaṃ vacām|  ṛddhiṃ rāsnāṃ balāṃ viśvaṃ [2] śatapuṣpāṃ śatāvarīm||250||  piṣṭvā kṣīraṃ jalaṃ sarpistailaṃ ca vipacedbhiṣak|  ānuvāsanikaṃ snehametaṃ vidyājjvarāpaham||251||
translation: Even in a dwelling place covered with ice and snow, a person experiencing burning sensations can find comfort in cool water infused with sandalwood paste.

sloka: paṭolapicumardābhyāṃ guḍūcyā madhukena ca|  madanaiśca śṛtaḥ sneho jvaraghnamanuvāsanam||252||
translation: Touching with his hands the dust of pearls, conch shells, gold, and moonstones, as well as sandalwood paste and cool water, and scattering with blue lotuses, white lotuses, and various other fans cooled by sandalwood paste and drizzling water,...

sloka: candanāgurukāśmaryapaṭolamadhukotpalaiḥ|  siddhaḥ sneho jvaraharaḥ snehabastiḥ praśasyate||253||
translation: Ponds, lakes, lotuses, and ponds with clean water are beneficial to approach; they alleviate burns, thirst, and diseases.

sloka: yaduktaṃ bheṣajādhyāye vimāne rogabheṣaje|  śirovirecanaṃ kuryādyuktijñastajjvarāpaham||254||  yacca nāvanikaṃ tailaṃ yāśca tailaṃ yāśca prāgdhūmavartayaḥ|  mātrāśitīye nirdiṣṭāḥ prayojyāstā jvareṣvapi||255||
translation: Women who are respectful, virtuous, passionate, adorned with sandalwood paste, and wearing gemstone and pearl ornaments should approach and appease others with their desires.

sloka: abhyaṅgāṃśca pradehāṃśca pariṣekāṃśca kārayet|  yathābhilāṣaṃ śītoṣṇaṃ vibhajya dvividhaṃ jvaram||256|| sahasradhautaṃ sarpirvā tailaṃ vā candanādikam|  dāhajvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādabhyañjanaṃ bhiṣak||257||
translation: Cool foods and drinks, cool shades, cool breezes, and the cooling feet of the moon are all alleviators of heat and burning.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  pauṣkareṣu suśīteṣu padmotpaladaleṣu ca|  kadalīnāṃ ca patreṣu kṣaumeṣu vimaleṣu ca||260||
translation: In this context, there are thirteen types of sweat described in the chapter on sweat; one who is aware of the proper amount and time is capable of alleviating heat fever. (Verse 268)

sloka: candanodakaśīteṣu śīte  dhārāgṛhe'pi vā|  himāmbusikte sadane dāhārtaḥ  saṃviśet sukham||261||
translation: That hut, bed, and covering indeed quickly alleviate fever, as well as sandalwood paste and fragrant boluses.

sloka: hemaśaṅkhapravālānāṃ maṇīnāṃ mauktikasya ca|  candanodakaśītānāṃ saṃsparśānurasān  spṛśet||262||  sragbhirnīlotpalaiḥ padmairvyajanairvividhairapi|  śītavātāvahairvyajjyeccandanodakavarṣibhiḥ  ||263||
translation: Fair-complexioned young women, with the allure of their youth, quickly ease the shivering caused by cold weather through their embraces.

sloka: nadyastaḍāgāḥ padminyo hradāśca vimalodakāḥ|  avagāhe hitā dāhatṛṣṇāglānijvarāpahāḥ||264||
translation: Sweating, eating, and drinking, as well as those that prevent wind and phlegm, quickly cure fever when used according to the power of their combination.

sloka: priyāḥ pradakṣiṇācārāḥ pramadāścandanokṣitāḥ|  sāntvayeyuḥ paraiḥ kāmairmaṇimauktikabhūṣaṇāḥ||265||
translation: In the case of exhaustion caused by wind, fatigue from physical exertion, ancient injuries, or fever, it is not beneficial to resort to jumping/excessive movement; one should rather engage in calming practices.

sloka: śītāni cānnapānāni śītānyupavanāni ca|  vāyavaścandrapādāśca śītā dāhajvarāpahāḥ||266||
translation: The agitation of the bodily heat that, upon reaching, causes the impurities to leave and diminishes the strength of the digestive fire - what is its cause?

sloka: bhavanti cātra  trayodaśavidhaḥ svedaḥ svedādhyāye nidarśitaḥ| mātrākālavidā yuktaḥ sa ca śītajvarāpahaḥ||268||
translation: Just as a blazing fire on a fuel-filled stove does not cook food when externally fanned.

sloka: sā kuṭī tacca śayanaṃ taccāvacchādanaṃ jvaram|  śītaṃ praśamayantyāśu dhūpāścāgurujā ghanāḥ||269||
translation: A person who is separated from his proper place, agitated by both qualities and defects, does not cook the food obtained in distress, or cooks it only slightly.

sloka: cārūpacitagātryaśca taruṇyo yauvanoṣmaṇā|  āśleṣācchamayantyāśu pramadāḥ śiśirajvaram||270||
translation: Therefore, a sequence of actions including jumping (lit. 'leap') is beneficial for fire-related protection; within seven days, the impurities residing in the seven bodily tissues are eliminated.

sloka: svedanānyannapānāni vātaśleṣmaharāṇi ca|  śītajvaraṃ jayantyāśu saṃsargabalayojanāt||271||
translation: The fever, known as Niramas, usually peaks on the eighth day; it is particularly aggravated in individuals who are debilitated, have a weak digestive fire, and eat excessively, especially those who are overweight.

sloka: vātaje śramaje caiva purāṇe kṣataje jvare|  laṅghanaṃ na hitaṃ vidyācchamanaistānupācaret||272||
translation: Either quickly freed from life or long tormented, a wise person knows the reason why this happens, even in the initial stages of a fever.

sloka: vikṣipyāmāśayoṣmāṇaṃ yasmādgatvā rasaṃ nṛṇām|  jvaraṃ kurvanti doṣāstu hīyate'gnibalaṃ tataḥ||273||
translation: One should not suddenly feed a person either too much or slightly according to their liking, whether they are a teacher or a close associate; this rule is especially important in cases of fever caused by the wind disease, even if it requires some delay.

sloka: yathā prajvalito vahniḥ sthālyāmindhanavānapi|  na pacatyodanaṃ samyaganilaprerito bahiḥ||274||
translation: For those not dependent, one should begin (performing) actions such as anointing and afterward offer a meal of palatable food, along with removing impurities. One should administer a remedy for indigestion, which is an unpleasant fever; this applies to all types (of people), and specifically for those with an excess of phlegm and bile, the fever is hot.

sloka: paktisthānāttathā doṣairūṣmā kṣipto bahirnṛṇām|  na pacatyabhyavahṛtaṃ kṛcchrāt pacati vā laghu||275||
translation: The ripening (of fine foods) does not occur even in seven days. It should be prepared through a process, gradually as instructed, with only a small amount of heating and starting from the tenth day with the addition of various ingredients such as condiments.

sloka: ato'gnibalarakṣārthaṃ laṅghanādikramo hitaḥ|  saptāhena hi pacyante saptadhātugatā malāḥ||276||
translation: Those who are afflicted by cough, wind, bile, and those with fever, for them treatment as per their individual condition should be carried out, including therapeutic emesis, purgation, and enema as appropriate.

sloka: nirāmaścāpyataḥ prokto jvaraḥ prāyo'ṣṭame'hani|  udīrṇadoṣastvalpāgniraśnan guru viśeṣataḥ||277||
translation: The intelligent one should treat fevers arising from the imbalance of vata, pitta, and kapha, discerning those that have spread or are localized.

sloka: mucyate sahasā prāṇaiściraṃ kliśyati vā naraḥ|  etasmātkāraṇādvidvān vātike'pyādito jvare||278||
translation: One can conquer fevers by using the specified medicines in accordance with the order of their appearance. Either by promoting the single unfavorable factor's reduction or by eliminating the aggravated one, or before the onset of fever from the sites of kapha accumulation, one should conquer fever caused by a combination of factors. (verses 286-287)

sloka: nāti gurvati vā snigdhaṃ bhojayet sahasā naram|  jvare mārutaje tvādāvanapekṣyāpi hi kramam||279||
translation: Upon the ending of the fever caused by approaching a sick person, a discharge occurs at the root of the ear; only a few are freed from it. It can be quickly conquered by rapid cleansing with red Arsenic and ghee. With purgative and scraping measures that reduce Kapha and Pitta, one should treat it as well.

sloka: kuryānniranubandhānāmabhyaṅgādīnupakramān|  pāyayitvā kaṣāyaṃ ca bhojayedrasabhojanam||280||  jīrṇajvaraharaṃ kuryāt sarvaśaścāpyupakramam|  śleṣmalānāmavātānāṃ jvaro'nuṣṇaḥ  kaphādhikaḥ||281||
translation: The fever that does not subside with cold, heat, smoothness, or roughness and is pacified only by flowing according to the branch of a tree (i.e., bark) is referring to the incurable fever.

sloka: paripākaṃ na saptāhenāpi yāti mṛdūṣmaṇām|  taṃ krameṇa yathoktena laṅghanālpāśanādinā||282||  ādaśāhamupakramya kaṣāyādyairupācaret|283|
translation: In the initial stages of a fever caused by bumps and spasms, if one does not have an excess of kapha and pitta, consumption of ghee is recommended.

sloka: sāmā ye ye ca kaphajāḥ kaphapittajvarāśca ye||283||  laṅghanaṃ laṅghanīyoktaṃ teṣu kāryaṃ prati prati|284| vamanaiśca virekaiśca bastibhiśca yathākramam||284||
translation: Fever arises from the weakness of the bodily tissues due to decay.

sloka: jvarānupacareddhīmān kaphapittānilodbhavān| saṃsṛṣṭān sannipatitān buddhvā taratamaiḥ samaiḥ||285||
translation: For the growth of the young, one should offer nourishment through suitable foods. One should abandon routine actions and perform only the essential (three or four remaining) ones. (Verse 292)

sloka: jvarān doṣakramāpekṣī yathoktairauṣadhairjayet|  vardhanenaikadoṣasya kṣapaṇenocchritasya vā||286||  kaphasthānānupūrvyā vā sannipātajvaraṃ jayet|287|
translation: The accompanying symptoms of an approaching fever are usually uneven convulsions; often caused by a preponderance of wind, and treated with emetics, purgatives, and sudorifics.

sloka: sannipātajvarasyānte karṇamūle sudārūṇaḥ||287||  śothaḥ sañjāyate tena kaścideva pramucyate|  raktāvasecanaiḥ śīghraṃ sarpiṣpānaiśca taṃ jayet||288||  pradehaiḥ kaphapittaghnairnāvanaiḥ kavalagrahaiḥ|289|
translation: The discomfort of uneven fever can be alleviated by offering warm food and drinks, while bitter and cool substances, as well as sanctioned butter and buttermilk, can be used to conquer a fever dominated by bile.

sloka: śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairjvaro yasya na śāmyati||289||  śākhānusārī raktasya  so'vasekāt praśāmyati|290|
translation: Emesis, cooking, consumption of harsh foods and drinks, jumping, purgation, ingestion of astringent and warm substances are recommended in an uneven fever when kapha is predominant.

sloka: visarpeṇābhighātena yaśca visphoṭakairjvaraḥ||290||  tatrādau sarpiṣaḥ pānaṃ kaphapittottaro na cet|291|
translation: The higher yogas, which are destructive of irregular fever, should be employed by the intelligent after analyzing their faults. For curing poisonous bites, one may use sura (alcoholic drink), leather, or water; for eating purposes, one may use the feet of an elephant or a chicken. In case of irregular fever, one may consume six palmfuls of ghee, or employ fearlessly the root of Trivrita plant, Katurohini with a bitter taste, Nilini with a strong smell, and the three-leaved Trivrita plant.

sloka: daurbalyāddehadhātūnāṃ jvaro jīrṇo'nuvartate||291||
translation: In the event of fever, drink in moderation a large quantity of ghee or sip throughout the day milk of a healthy cow, or consume in excess buttermilk or alcohol, along with food. In case of uneven fever, perform emesis or purgation. In the morning, drink fresh cow's urine and cow dung mixed with water. Apply a poultice of cow dung on the abdomen. Mix together five products of the cow and consume in case of uneven fever. Use castor oil that is previously consumed, before meals. Eat food that generates heat such as meat, pungent things, and rock salt. For nasal application, use a paste made from the excreta of lion or tiger, mixed with rock salt. Similarly, apply a paste of hair from the tail of a cow, also mixed with rock salt. Use powdered castor seeds, long pepper, and black pepper mixed with ghee as fumigation for fever. Also, use the smoke and the residue left after fumigation, as well as the remnants of collyrium for nasal application.

sloka: balyeḥ sambṛṃhaṇaistasmādāhāraistamupācaret|292| karma sādhāraṇaṃ jahyāttṛtīyakacaturthakau  ||292||
translation: The prescribed course of action in the disturbance of the mind and uneven fever is to wear gems, medicinal plants, and auspicious items. By their use, fever does not occur.

sloka: āganturanubandho hi prāyaśo viṣamajvare|  vātapradhānaṃ sarpirbhirbastibhiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ||293||
translation: By worshiping the deity Soma, who is accompanied by stars, and the supreme lord of all the gathered groups of gods, one is quickly freed from the fever caused by poison. By chanting the thousand names of Vishnu, who has a thousand heads and is the lord of all moving and non-moving beings, one can drive away all fevers. By worshipping Brahma, the Ashwin twins, Indra, the fire-offering Himalayas, Ganga, and the Marudgana with devotion, one conquers fevers through their activity. One quickly becomes free from fever by having darshan of the virtuous, practicing brahmacharya, austerity, truthfulness, discipline, japahomapradanam (offerings), listening to the Vedas, and serving one's mother, father, and gurus.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇairannapānaiśca śamayedviṣamajvaram|  virecanena payasā sarpiṣā saṃskṛtena ca||294||  viṣamaṃ tiktaśītaiśca jvaraṃ pittottaraṃ jayet|
translation: In the case of fever, one should perform therapeutic emesis and fasting; for diarrhea with red appearance, decoctions and restrictions on food intake are recommended. Enemas are beneficial in cases of feces and urine containing blood. Medicines that promote downward movement should be administered when there is stiffness in the joints and muscles.

sloka: vamanaṃ pācanaṃ rūkṣamannapānaṃ vilaṅghanam||295||  kaṣāyoṣṇaṃ ca viṣame jvare śastaṃ kaphottare|296|
translation: The fever that arises from a curse or possession by beings is considered to be curable by all medicines in that case where divine grace is relied upon.

sloka: yogāḥ parāḥ  pravakṣyante viṣamajvaranāśanāḥ||296||  prayoktavyā matimatā doṣādīn pravibhajya te|  surā samaṇḍā pānārthe bhakṣyārthe caraṇāyudhaḥ||297||  tittiriśca mayūraśca prayojyā viṣamajvare|  pibedvā ṣaṭpalaṃ sarpirabhayāṃ vā prayojayet||298||  triphalāyāḥ kaṣāyaṃ vā guḍūcyā rasameva vā|  nīlinīmajagandhāṃ ca trivṛtāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||299||
translation: The one who has been struck by fever can be eradicated by an oil massage with ghee and the application of red colored liquids made from madira (an alcoholic beverage) along with nourishing foods that have a similar taste to madira, as well as through the treatment of wounds and injuries.

sloka: pibejjvarāgame yuktyā snehasvedopapāditaḥ|  sarpiṣo mahatīṃ mātrāṃ pītvā vā chardayet punaḥ||300||  upayujyānnapānaṃ vā prabhūtaṃ punarullikhet|  sānnaṃ madyaṃ prabhūtaṃ vā pītvā svapyājjvarāgame||301||  āsthāpanaṃ yāpanaṃ vā kārayedviṣamajvare|  payasā vṛṣadaṃśasya śakṛdvā  tadahaḥ pibet||302||  vṛṣasya dadhimaṇḍena surayā vā  sasaindhavam|  pippalyāstriphalāyāśca dadhnastakrasya sarpiṣaḥ||303||  pañcagavyasya payasaḥ prayogo viṣamajvare|  rasonasya satailasya prāgbhaktamupasevanam||304||  medyānāmuṣṇavīryāṇāmāmiṣāṇāṃ ca bhakṣaṇam|  hiṅgutulyā tu vaiyāghrī vasā nasyaṃ sasaindhavā||305||  purāṇasarpiḥ siṃhasya vasā tadvat sasaindhavā|  saindhavaṃ pippalīnāṃ ca taṇḍulāḥ samanaḥśilāḥ||306||  netrāñjanaṃ tailapiṣṭaṃ śasyate viṣamajvare|  palaṅkaṣā nimbapatraṃ vacā kuṣṭhaṃ harītakī||307||  sarṣapāḥ sayavāḥ sarpirdhūpanaṃ jvaranāśanam|  ye dhūmā dhūpanaṃ yacca nāvanaṃ cāñjanaṃ ca yat||308||
translation: By assuaging through the acquisition of desires, by calming the wind (i.e., the breath), and by delighting, one can get rid of desire, grief, fear, and disease. By using propitiable words, anger arising from fever can be calmed. Fever generated from desire and anger can be alleviated by both. Fear and sadness born from these can also be eliminated. The fever's intensity and time can be reflected upon, and the one who ponders thus is said to be brooding over the fever. The memory of such a person can be erased by using diverse objects that fulfill their desires.

sloka: manovikāre nirdiṣṭaṃ kāryaṃ tadviṣamajvare|  maṇīnāmoṣadhīnāṃ ca maṅgalyānāṃ viṣasya ca||309||  dhāraṇādagadānāṃ ca sevanānna bhavejjvaraḥ|310|
translation: In the treatment of fever, a person groans and vomits, turns pale, becomes weak, trembles, and faints again and again. They also sweat profusely, become shivering cold, and delirious. Their speech becomes thick due to excessive thirst. A discerning physician should recognize these symptoms in treating fever. A severe fever is usually caused by the aggravation of multiple doshas ( bodily humors), but a skillful physician can release this intense fever through proper treatment of dosha imbalances. Those who endure the fever's progression without appropriate intervention will experience a less harsh liberation from the prolonged fever.

sloka: somaṃ sānucaraṃ devaṃ samātṛgaṇamīśvaram||310||  pūjayan prayataḥ śīghraṃ mucyate viṣamajvarāt|  viṣṇuṃ sahasramūrdhānaṃ carācarapatiṃ vibhum||311||  stuvannāmasahasreṇa jvarān sarvānapohati|  brahmāṇamaśvināvindraṃ hutabhakṣaṃ himācalam||312||  gaṅgāṃ marudgaṇāṃśceṣṭyā  pūjayañjayati jvarān|  bhaktyā mātuḥ pituścaiva gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca||313||  brahmacaryeṇa tapasā satyena niyamena ca|  japahomapradānena vedānāṃ śravaṇena ca||314||  jvarādvimucyate śīghraṃ sādhūnāṃ darśanena ca|
translation: A person, free from exhaustion and mental suffering, with pure senses, established in his true nature and knowledge.

sloka: jvare rasasthe vamanamupavāsaṃ ca kārayet||315||  sekapradehau raktasthe tathā saṃśamanāni ca|  virecanaṃ sopavāsaṃ māṃsamedaḥsthite hitam||316||  asthimajjagate deyā nirūhāḥ sānuvāsanāḥ|317|
translation: One who is free from fever, devoid of desire, has abandoned the teachings of unworthy preceptors, and avoids incompatible food and excessive eating, sexual activity, and movement; such a person will see fever subside and become calm, as long as they are not yet strong. One who has overcome fever should not engage in exercise, sexual activity, bathing, or traveling until they regain their strength.

sloka: śāpābhicārādbhūtānāmabhiṣaṅgācca yo jvaraḥ||317||  daivavyapāśrayaṃ tatra sarvamauṣadhamiṣyate|
translation: One who is free from selfish desires and has overcome the fever (of worldly attachments) should avoid this fever

sloka: abhighātajvaro naśyet  pānābhyaṅgena sarpiṣaḥ||318||  raktāvasekairmadyaiśca  sātmyairmāṃsarasaudanaiḥ|  sānāho madyasātmyānāṃ madirārasabhojanaiḥ||319||  kṣatānāṃ vraṇitānāṃ ca kṣatavraṇacikitsayā|
translation: One who, on encountering even slight faults in others, deviates from them; such a person, after some time, becomes weakened, diminished in strength and energy, and will soon destroy themselves.

sloka: āśvāseneṣṭalābhena vāyoḥ praśamanena ca||320||  harṣaṇaiśca śamaṃ yānti kāmaśokabhayajvarāḥ|  kāmyairarthairmanojñaiśca pittaghnaiścāpyupakramaiḥ||321||  sadvākyaiśca śamaṃ yāti jvaraḥ krodhasamutthitaḥ|  kāmāt krodhajvaro nāśaṃ krodhāt kāmasamudbhavaḥ||322||  yāti tābhyāmubhābhyāṃ ca bhayaśokasamutthitaḥ| jvarasya vegaṃ kālaṃ ca cintayañjvaryate tu yaḥ||323||  tasyeṣṭaistu vicitraiśca viṣayairnāśayet smṛtim|324|
translation: Or, even if toxins in the tissues naturally dissipate over time, they still act improperly if they do not take care of fever.

sloka: jvarapramokṣe puruṣaḥ kūjan vamati ceṣṭate|  śvasanvivarṇaḥ svinnāṅgo vepate līyate muhuḥ||324||  pralapatyuṣṇasarvāṅgaḥ śītāṅgaśca bhavatyapi|  visañjño jvaravegārtaḥ sakrodha iva vīkṣyate  ||325||  sadoṣaśabdaṃ ca śakṛddravaṃ sravati vegavat|  liṅgānyetāni jānīyājjvaramokṣe vicakṣaṇaḥ||326||  bahudoṣasya balavān  prāyeṇābhinavo jvaraḥ|  satkriyādoṣapaktyā  cedvimuñcati sudāruṇam||327||  kṛtvā doṣavaśādvegaṃ kramāduparamanti ye|  teṣāmadāruṇo mokṣo jvarāṇāṃ cirakāriṇām||328||
translation: Those who are afflicted with illness, emaciation, whiteness (possibly leprosy), and lack of appetite, as well as those who have scabies, itching, and other ailments, when they perform the agnihotra ritual, even their minor and unnoticeable faults are reduced without causing any disturbance. Similarly, others also return to their normal state after undergoing various treatments.

sloka: vigataklamasantāpamavyathaṃ vimalendriyam|  yuktaṃ prakṛtisattvena vidyāt puruṣamajvaram||329||
translation: Even after the fever has subsided, it is recommended to reduce the remaining dosha (impurities) as per one's strength, through appropriate practices and by bringing about calmness. Cleaning with mild methods, purification treatments, and using light and nourishing foods that are easily digestible and found in nature are beneficial.

sloka: sajvaro jvaramuktaśca vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  asātmyānyannapānāni viruddhāni ca varjayet||330||  vyavāyamaticeṣṭāśca snānamatyaśanāni ca|  tathā jvaraḥ śamaṃ yāti praśānto jāyate na ca||331||  vyāyāmaṃ ca vyavāyaṃ ca snānaṃ caṅkramaṇāni ca|  jvaramukto na seveta yāvanna balavān bhavet||332||
translation: Massage, sweating, bathing, fragrancing, and applying collyrium are beneficial when fever reoccurs. Upon the return of a fever, one should follow the same sequence as before, starting with hot applications. The substances kirāta, tiktaka, trikatu, pippali, and amṛta eliminate recurring fevers when taken regularly in a prescribed manner. (Ref: Caraka Saṃhitā 6.28.341-343)

sloka: asañjātabalo yastu jvaramukto niṣevate|  varjyametannarastasya punarāvartate jvaraḥ||333||
translation: In the case of a fever, an expert should administer the appropriate fever treatment, depending on the stage of the fever.

sloka: durhṛteṣu ca doṣeṣu yasya vā vinivartate|  svalpenapyapacāreṇa tasya vyāvartate punaḥ||334||  cirakālaparikliṣṭaṃ durbalaṃ hīnatejasam [1] |  acireṇaiva kālena sa hanti punarāgataḥ||335||
translation: Therefore, a physician should especially exert efforts in finding a cure for the fever, which is the worst enemy and cause of pain for all living beings.

sloka: athavā'pi  parīpākaṃ dhātuṣveva kramānmalāḥ|  yānti jvaramakurvantaste tathā'pyapakurvate||336||
translation: In that treatise, a verse in sequence and as asked is explained by Atreya for Agnivesa, who desires the welfare of all beings.

sloka: dīnatāṃ śvayathuṃ glāniṃ pāṇḍutāṃ nānnakāmatām|  kaṇḍūrutkoṭhapiḍakāḥ kurvantyagniṃ ca te mṛdum||337||  evamanye'pi ca gadā vyāvartante punargatāḥ|  anirghātena doṣāṇāmalpairapyahitairnṛṇām||338||
translation: Now, I shall explain the means of treating forgetfulness. Thus said Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: nirvṛtte'pi jvare tasmādyathāvasthaṃ yathābalam|  yathāprāṇaṃ hareddoṣaṃ prayogairvā śamaṃ nayet||339||  mṛdubhiḥ śodhanaiḥ śuddhiryāpanā bastayo hitāḥ|  hitāśca laghavo yūṣā jāṅgalāmiṣajā rasāḥ||340||
translation: Forgetfulness is considered by the expert physicians as not letting go of what has been remembered, and sinking into darkness due to the overflowing of dullness and unmindfulness.

sloka: abhyaṅgodvartanasnānadhūpanānyañjanāni ca|  hitāni punarāvṛtte jvare tiktaghṛtāni ca||341||  gurvyabhiṣyandyasātmyānāṃ bhojanāt punarāgate|  laṅghanoṣṇopacārādiḥ kramaḥ kāryaśca pūrvavat||342||  kirātatiktakaṃ tiktā mustaṃ parpaṭako'mṛtā|  ghnanti pītāni cābhyāsāt punarāvartakaṃ jvaram||343||
translation: For those whose minds are disturbed, consumed by many faults and impure food, and when sattva is overwhelmed by rajas and tamas and is obscured by defects such as worry, desire, fear, anger, and anxiety, loss of consciousness occurs.

sloka: tasyāṃ tasyāmavasthāyāṃ jvaritānāṃ vicakṣaṇaḥ|  jvarākriyākramāpekṣī kuryāttattaccikitsitam||344||
translation: Defects, when taken in by the breath, torment the heart. The foolish person, when tormented, is afflicted with a deluded mind. He sees forms incorrectly, falls down, and even trembles; his tongue hangs out, his eyes roll up, and his hands and feet shake uncontrollably.

sloka: rogarāṭ sarvabhūtānāmantakṛddāruṇo jvaraḥ|  tasmādviśeṣatastasya yateta praśame bhiṣak||345||
translation: Once the force of defects has subsided, (the self) awakens as if from sleep.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  yathākramaṃ yathāpraśnamuktaṃ jvaracikitsitam|  ātreyeṇāgniveśāya bhūtānāṃ hitakāmyayā||346||
translation: He is said to be fourfold, who is afflicted by all faults.

sloka: apasmāracikitsitopakramaḥ athāto'pasmāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: The churning wind makes the teeth tremble, raises the foam and causes red-black clouds to appear.

sloka: smṛterapagamaṃ prāhurapasmāraṃ bhiṣagvidaḥ|  tamaḥpraveśaṃ bībhatsaceṣṭaṃ dhīsattvasamplavāt||3||
translation: The merchant, with a fair complexion, tawny beard and eyes, who is always thirsting for wealth, and whose vision encompasses everywhere the spread of fire. (Refers to a merchant who is constantly looking to expand his wealth and business.)

sloka: vibhrāntabahudoṣāṇāmahitāśucibhojanāt [1] |  rajastamobhyāṃ vihate sattve doṣāvṛte hṛdi||4|| cintākāmabhayakrodhaśokodvegādibhistathā|  manasyabhihate nṝṇāmapasmāraḥ pravartate||5||
translation: The teacher, with a white complexion, face like the moon, and a cool body, is able to see white forms (of the letters) and is freed from illness for a long time.

sloka: dhamanībhiḥ śritā doṣā hṛdayaṃ pīḍayanti hi|  sampīḍyamāno vyathate mūḍho bhrāntena cetasā||6||  paśyatyasanti rūpāṇi patati prasphuratyapi|  jihvākṣibhrūḥ sravallālo hastau pādau ca vikṣipan||7||
translation: He who is known by all these characteristics is afflicted with the three faults. He is incurable dementia and the one who becomes powerless when strength is lost.

sloka: doṣavege ca vigate suptavat pratibuddhyate|
translation: Malas (impurities) become aggravated, whether it is after a few days, twelve days, or a month, and cause fainting.

sloka: pṛthagdoṣaiḥ samastaiśca vakṣyate sa caturvidhaḥ||8||
translation: The healer should rouse the consciousness of those whose mind channels are obstructed, using sharp, initial purificatory actions.

sloka: kampate pradaśeddantān phenodvāmī śvasityapi|  paruṣāruṇakṛṣṇāni paśyedrūpāṇi cānilāt||9||
translation: One should treat a fever with emesis if it is predominantly hot and with purgation if it is primarily caused by an excess of bodily humors. (15)

sloka: pītaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ pītāsṛgrūpadarśanaḥ|  satṛṣṇoṣṇānalavyāptalokadarśī  ca paittikaḥ||10||
translation:
Learn, for the pacification of delusion and liberation, about the yoga that is appropriate for one who is completely pure in all respects and fully confident. (Translation by Arya Mukherjee)

OR

Hear from me about the discipline of Yoga for the sake of overcoming delusion and achieving liberation, which should be practiced by a person who is pure in all respects and has achieved perfect mental peace. (Translation by Vincent Elisabeth Ravlette)
1488,गोशकृद्रसदध्यम्लक्षीरमूत्रैः समैर्घृतम्।  सिद्धं पिबेदपस्मारकामलाज्वरनाशनम्॥१७॥  इति पञ्चगव्यं घृतम्,"One should drink ghee (clarified butter) that is mixed and processed equally with the milk, curd, urine, and dung of a cow, as it is said to be a means to destroy poisons, including that of delusion.

sloka: śuklaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ śīto hṛṣṭāṅgajo guruḥ|  paśyañchuklāni rūpāṇi ślaiṣmiko mucyate cirāt||11||
translation: The two ingredients, triphala and kutaja bark, along with seven-leafed kapikacchu, nilini, katuruhina, shampa, phalgumula, paushkara, which are hard to obtain; after cooking the two pala roots and the remaining parts in water, one should cook the following measured quantities: bhargi, patra, trikatuka, trivrita, nichula, shreyaasi madhaki, danti, bhunimba, chitraku; two sariva and rohisa, butter milk, equal amounts of cow's urine and milk; this is known as mahapanchagavyam, which is like nectar. It is beneficial in fainting, insanity, abdominal diseases, worm infestation, skin diseases, jaundice, and camala disease. One should use a portion of it daily for eliminating indigence, defeating diseases, and destroying the fourth state (death). This is the great mahapanchagavya ghritam.

sloka: sarvairetaiḥ samastaistu liṅgairjñeyastridoṣajaḥ| apasmāraḥ sa cāsādhyo yaḥ kṣīṇasyānavaśca yaḥ||12||
translation: With ghee, sugar, licorice, musk, conch-shell, and flower offerings, [the lamp] removes old age, lethargy, and sins. (Verse 25)

sloka: pakṣādvā dvādaśāhādvā māsādvā kupitā malāḥ|  apasmārāya kurvanti vegaṃ kiñcidathāntaram||13||
translation: Ghee, when offered in the summer and rainy seasons in fourfold quantities to Saindhava and Hingu, becomes capable of cleansing the heart of impurities such as disease, bad smell, and mucus. (Verse 26)

sloka: tairāvṛtānāṃ hṛtsrotomanasāṃ samprabodhanam|  tīkṣṇairādau bhiṣak kuryāt karmabhirvamanādibhiḥ||14||
translation: Ghee (a type of clarified butter) that is churned with well-shaped ropes, made from the fibers of palm trees and bark, and mixed with properly prepared liquids.

sloka: वातिकं बस्तिभूयिष्ठैः पैत्तं प्रायो विरेचनैः।  श्लैष्मिकं वमनप्रायैरपस्मारमुपाचरेत्॥१५॥
translation: Cook in a quantity of milk equal to a potful, with measured ingredients such as ghee and sesame oil, a preparation that is an effective cure for epilepsy. (Note: This is a translation of a cookery verse from the ancient Indian text Bhavaprakasha. It describes the preparation of a medicinal recipe for treating epilepsy.)

sloka: sarvataḥ suviśuddhasya samyagāśvāsitasya ca|  apasmāravimokṣārthaṃ yogān saṃśamanāñchṛṇu||16||
translation: One should churn the mixture of Kansa (a type of grass) and sugarcane juice, which has a slimy consistency and is eight times as flavorful, with cereal grains used for sacrifices, into a quantity of ghee equivalent to a prastha.

sloka: gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiḥ samairghṛtam|  siddhaṃ pibedapasmārakāmalājvaranāśanam||17||  iti pañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Just as quickly the fever caused by an imbalance of wind and bile is pacified by ingesting a mixture of sugar, licorice, and ghee.

sloka: dve pañcamūlyau triphalā rajanyau kuṭajatvacam|  saptaparṇamapāmārgaṃ nīlinīṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||18||  śampākaṃ phalgumūlaṃ ca pauṣkaraṃ sadurālabham|  dvipalāni jaladroṇe paktvā pādāvaśeṣite||19||  bhārgīṃ pāṭhāṃ trikaṭukaṃ trivṛtāṃ niculāni ca|  śreyasīmāḍhakīṃ mūrvāṃ dantīṃ bhūnimbacitrakau||20||  dve sārive rohiṣaṃ ca bhūtīkaṃ madayantikām|  kṣipetpiṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi tena  prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet||21|| gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiśca tatsamaiḥ|  pañcagavyamiti khyātaṃ mahattadamṛtopamam||22||  apasmāre tathonmāde  śvayathāvudareṣu ca|  gulmārśaḥpāṇḍurogeṣu kāmalāyāṃ halīmake||23||  śasyate ghṛtametattu prayoktavyaṃ dine dine|  alakṣmīgraharogaghnaṃ cāturthakavināśanam||24||  iti mahāpañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Just as honey and the sap of the sugarcane (amalakīrasa) are in the elephant's dung (madhukadvipe kkle), similarly, a person who has achieved perfection (siddho) is capable of being a remedy for Pitta and jaundice (pittāpasmāra bheshajam) in a measure of ghee (ghrta prastha).

sloka: brāhmīrasavacākuṣṭhaśaṅkhapuṣpībhireva ca|  purāṇaṃ ghṛtamunmādālakṣmyapasmārapāpanut||25||
translation: The anointment with four times the quantity of sesame oil, mixed with urine of a cow, is said to be accomplished; and so is bathing with the urine of a cow.

sloka: ghṛtaṃ saindhavahiṅgubhyāṃ vārṣe bāste caturguṇe|  mūtre siddhamapasmārahṛdgrahāmayanāśanam||26||
translation: The oil, extracted from the bark of Katvanga tree and mixed with the juice of Bhinimbaka fruit, is praised for external use in anointing; similarly, the powder of roots of Pathya, Vrishchikaa, Arkasarsha, and the fruits of Nimba, mixed with the hair of a clean and shaven ascetic, is also recommended. (33-34)

sloka: vacāśampākakaiṭaryavayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ|  siddhaṃ palaṅkaṣāyuktairvātaśleṣmātmake ghṛtam||27||
translation: With garlic, bitter taste, safflower, arista, and muscle-foods, as well as urine, in fourfold quantity, is prepared a medicinal concoction that is siddha. It should be used for fumigation and application.

sloka: tailaprasthaṃ ghṛtaprasthaṃ jīvanīyaiḥ palonmitaiḥ|  kṣīradroṇe pacet siddhamapasmāravināśanam||28||
translation: "One should grind together pippalī

sloka: कंसे क्षीरेक्षुरसयोः काश्मर्येऽष्टगुणे रसे।  कार्षिकैर्जीवनीयैश्च घृतप्रस्थं विपाचयेत्॥२९॥
translation:
Discarding raakshasa, kushtha, pootana, chori, and kaai haraaka deeds,
Performing u tsadaan with mudra pistai (urine and excreta), and ablution only with urine.

sloka: vātapittodbhavaṃ kṣipramapasmāraṃ niyacchati|  tadvat kāśavidārīkṣukuśakvāthaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam||30||
translation: Made of wood, leather, or straw, or burned by the hooves of horses, elephants, and cow tails, or tipped with iron.

sloka: madhukadvipale kalke droṇe cāmalakīrasāt|  tadvat siddho ghṛtaprasthaḥ pittāpasmārabheṣajam||31||
translation: The urine of Kapila cows is considered the supreme beneficial medicine for dogs, swine, and lions.

sloka: abhyaṅgaḥ sārṣapaṃ tailaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe|  siddhaṃ syādgośakṛnmūtraiḥ snānotsādanameva ca||32||
translation: The healer should not combine three or six bindus (impurities) from the words " Bhargi," "Nagadanti," "Shweta," "Vishanikara," which are stated as having the qualities of being spoken, having teeth, white in color, having teeth again, and passing urine.

sloka: kaṭabhīnimbakaṭvaṅgamadhuśigrutvacāṃ rase|  siddhaṃ mūtrasamaṃ tailamabhyaṅgārthe praśasyate||33|| palaṅkaṣāvacāpathyāvṛścikālyarkasarṣapaiḥ|  jaṭilāpūtanākeśīnākulīhiṅgucorakaiḥ||34||
translation: The oil prepared by decoction of Triphala, Vyosha, Patra, Pita, Draksha, Kshaara, Phanita, and Jjaka, and mixed with the juice of Shyaamaapaamarga and Brihati, is an effective cure for mental disorders.

sloka: laśunātirasācitrākuṣṭhairviḍbhiśca pakṣiṇām|  māṃsāśināṃ yathālābhaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe||35||  siddhamabhyañjanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam|  etaiścaivauṣadhaiḥ kāryaṃ dhūpanaṃ sapralepanam||36||
translation: The foremost course of action is to mix together the powders of pippalī, vṛścikālī, kuṣṭha, and salts, and apply it.

sloka: pippalīṃ lavaṇaṃ citrāṃ  hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikām|  kākolīṃ sarṣapān kākanāsāṃ kaiṭaryacandane||37||  śunaḥskandhāsthinakharān parśukāṃ ceti peṣayet|  bastamūtreṇa puṣyarkṣe pradehaḥ syāt sadhūpanaḥ||38||
translation: For the treatment of epilepsy, possession by ghosts, poisoning, fainting, and insanity, one should prepare a mixture of barley, mushta, and mudga; mixed with the urine of a cow, pounded and administered. Such concoctions are said to be life-giving.

sloka: apetarākṣasīkuṣṭhapūtanākeśicorakaiḥ|  utsādanaṃ mūtrapiṣṭairmūtrairevāvasecanam||39||
translation: The powder of three ripe, full-grown, creeping sesbania plants should be prepared and consumed with a mixture of barley and rice, as well as urine from cows that have eaten grass, in order to treat conditions such as fever, epilepsy, and mental instability.

sloka: jalaukaḥśakṛtā tadvaddagdhairvā bastaromabhiḥ|  kharāsthibhirhastinakhaistathā gopucchalomabhiḥ||40||
translation: The purified (apasmarghnam) extract of the Pushya star's constellation (Pushyoddhritam), which neutralizes bile (pittam), and is an ointment (anjanam), when combined with ghee (sarpisah yuktam), is considered the supreme (paramam) fragrance (dhopanam).

sloka: kapilānāṃ gavāṃ mūtraṃ [1] nāvanaṃ paramaṃ hitam|  śvaśṛgālabiḍālānāṃ siṃhādīnāṃ ca śasyate||41||
translation: The physician should prepare incense using the beaks, wings, feces, and bones of a peacock, mongoose, eagle, porcupine, and lizard.

sloka: bhārgī vacā nāgadantī śvetā śvetā  viṣāṇikā|  jyotiṣmatī nāgadantī pādoktā mūtrapeṣitāḥ||42||  yogāstrayo'taḥ ṣaḍ bindūn pañca vā nāvayedbhiṣak|
translation: Through actions accomplished with excellence, the heart awakens, and then the senses are purified; only then is consciousness attained. (Verse 52)

sloka: triphalāvyoṣapītadruyavakṣāraphaṇijjhakaiḥ||43||  śyāmāpāmārgakārañjaphalairmūtre'tha bastaje|  sādhitaṃ nāvanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam||44||
translation: If the symptom of bondage is clearly visible in someone upon their arrival, then it should be their remedy to prevent bondage.

sloka: pippalī vṛścikālī ca kuṣṭhaṃ ca lavaṇāni ca|  bhārgī ca cūrṇitaṃ nastaḥ kāryaṃ pradhamanaṃ param||45||
translation: After that, Agnivesh, with folded hands, said: "O Lord! I wish to hear from you about the means of removing delusion mentioned in the verse you previously explained." Hearing the words of his disciple, Vasu then spoke to Mahagada: "Listen, Mahagada, to the means of removing delusion."

sloka: kāyasthāṃ śāradānmudgānmustośīrayavāṃstathā|  savyoṣān bastamūtreṇa piṣṭvā vartīḥ prakalpayet||46||  apasmāre tathonmāde sarpadaṣṭe garārdite|  viṣapīte jalamṛte caitāḥ syuramṛtopamāḥ||47||
translation: The senses, bound to the objects of sense, of one who restrains rising greed for pleasurable things, quickly cleanse the heart, which is tainted by cold, hot, smooth, rough, and other causes. If the intellect and the mind are covered by rajas and tamas, and the heart is disturbed by faults, then a person becomes ignorant and of weak understanding. Those who fix their minds on what is transient and not on truth are said to have fallen into a great abyss.

sloka: mustaṃ vayaḥsthāṃ triphalāṃ kāyasthāṃ hiṅgu śādvalam|  vyoṣaṃ māṣān yavānmūtrairbāstamaiṣārṣabhaistribhiḥ||48||  piṣṭvā kṛtvā ca tāṃ vartimapasmāre prayojayet|  kilāse ca tathonmāde jvareṣu viṣameṣu ca||49||
translation:
Having purified the one covered with sweat and dirt through emesis and other cleansing methods, one should offer them pure food and drinks. That which is known as "Panchgavya" (a mixture of cow's urine, milk, ghee, curd, and dung) and also any other pure and beneficial concoction, should be used. One should unite with wise and supportive friends who are established in knowledge, courage, and mindfulness. (61-63)
One should use sesame oil, cow's milk, 100 flowers of Shankhpushpi (a medicinal herb), Brahmi ras (a type of plant extract), Kushtharas (a type of resin), Vaca (another plant extract), and honey. (64)

sloka: puṣyoddhṛtaṃ śunaḥ pittamapasmāraghnamañjanam|  tadeva sarpiṣā yuktaṃ dhūpanaṃ paramaṃ matam||50||
translation: He who is difficult to cure, suffering from a chronic ailment and well-established [in the disease] should generally be treated with a tonic. (65)

sloka: nakulolūkamārjāragṛdhrakīṭāhikākajaiḥ|  tuṇḍaiḥ [1] pakṣaiḥ purīṣaiśca dhūpanaṃ kārayedbhiṣak||51||
translation: Always protect oneself from the harmful effects of fire, water, minerals (mountains), and plants, as they can cause sudden death.

sloka: ābhiḥ kriyābhiḥ siddhābhirhṛdayaṃ samprabudhyate|  srotāṃsi cāpi śudhyanti tataḥ [2] sañjñāṃ sa vindati||52||
translation:
The faults, when roused due to a cause, can remove unconsciousness just as specificity and generality are the characteristics and their treatment. [1] Vyasa's compact verses state that the awakening from unconsciousness is the symptom and cure. [68]

In this translation, I have tried to convey the message of the original Sanskrit verse using appropriate English words while keeping the meaning as close to the source as possible. The terms "faults", "roused due to a cause", "specificity and generality are the characteristics", "treatment", and "awakening from unconsciousness is the symptom and cure" are used in the translation to convey the original intent of the Sanskrit verse.

sloka: yasyānubandhastvāganturdoṣaliṅgādhikākṛtiḥ|  dṛśyeta tasya kāryaṃ syādāgantūnmādabheṣajam||53||
translation: Now, we will explain the means of alleviating hiccups, as stated by Bhagavan Atri.

sloka: anantaramuvācedamagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ|  bhagavan! prāk samuddiṣṭaḥ ślokasthāne mahāgadaḥ||54||  atattvābhiniveśo yastaddhetvākṛtibheṣajam|  tatra noktamataḥ śrotumicchāmi tadihocyatām||55||  śuśrūṣave vacaḥ śrutvā śiṣyāyāha punarvasuḥ|  mahāgadaṃ saumya! śṛṇu sahetvākṛtibheṣajam||56||
translation: The wise Agniveśa, with folded hands, asked the best of sages, the knower of the true meaning of the Vedas and the world, about the three faults that are three causes of anger and the most difficult to overcome amongst various ailments with diverse forms.

sloka: malināhāraśīlasya vegān prāptānnigṛhṇataḥ|  śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairhetubhiścātisevitaiḥ||57||  hṛdayaṃ samupāśritya manobuddhivahāḥ sirāḥ|  doṣāḥ sandūṣya tiṣṭhanti rajomohāvṛtātmanaḥ||58||  rajastamobhyāṃ vṛddhābhyāṃ buddhau [1] manasi cāvṛte|  hṛdaye vyākule doṣairatha mūḍho'lpacetanaḥ [2] ||59||  viṣamāṃ kurute buddhiṃ nityānitye hitāhite|  atattvābhiniveśaṃ tamāhurāptā mahāgadam||60||
translation: Having heard Agniveśa's words, the intelligent best among thinkers spoke, greatly pleased, stating a firm conclusion: "Desires, the stealers of life, are not the only numerous diseases; even a sneeze or difficult breathing can arise as separate afflictions in a person attacked by various other diseases."

sloka: snehasvedopapannaṃ taṃ saṃśodhya vamanādibhiḥ|  kṛtasaṃsarjanaṃ medhyairannapānairupācaret||61||  brāhmīsvarasayuktaṃ yat pañcagavyamudāhṛtam|  tat sevyaṃ śaṅkhapuṣpī ca yacca medhyaṃ rasāyanam||62||  suhṛdaścānukūlāstaṃ svāptā dharmārthavādinaḥ|  saṃyojayeyurvijñānadhairyasmṛtisamādhibhiḥ [3] ||63|| prayuñjyāttailalaśunaṃ payasā vā śatāvarīm|  brāhmīrasaṃ kuṣṭharasaṃ vacāṃ vā madhusaṃyutām||64||
translation: These two -- kapha and vata, born from the site of pitta, are responsible for the nourishment of the heart and other components starting from rasa. Hence, they are considered common and extremely difficult to overcome when handled improperly, just like a furious snake.

sloka: duścikitsyo hyapasmāraścirakārī kṛtāspadaḥ [1] |  tasmādrasāyanairenaṃ prāyaśaḥ samupācaret||65||
translation: In the prevention of disease, two types have been distinguished. Now hear about their origin and symptoms, overcome by a buildup of impurities. They arise from rajas (dust), dhumavat (smoke), vata (wind), sheeta-sthanambu-sevanat (exposure to cold or water), vyayamat (excessive exercise), gramya-dharmas (unhealthy habits of villagers), dharmauruskrt (impure actions related to religious rituals), navisamashanat (eating improperly prepared food), amapradoshadanahat (eating at the wrong time or in excess), raukshyat (emaciation), atypatarpanat (lack of sufficient nourishment), durbalyat (weakness), marmano ghatat (injury to vital points), atisarajvarachardipratishayakshatakshayat (diarrhea, fever, vomiting, and wasting), raktapittaudavartad (bleeding disorders or intoxication), visuchyalasakadapi (from poison, alcohol, or excessive sexual activity), pandurogadvischachchaiwapravartete (from leprosy or contact with poison), nishpavamashapinayakatilatailanisevanat (use of mustard, sesame, or castor oil), pistashalookavisthambhividaahigurubhojanat (eating dry, hard to digest food, spicy or heavy meals), jalajanoopapishitadadhyamakshirasevanat (consuming uncooked, stale, or sour milk products), abhishyandyupacaracca shlesmalanam cha sevanat (from improper hygiene and contact with phlegm-related ailments), kanthorasah pratieghaatavibandhaih ca pithagvidhaih (from physical restraints, injuries to throat or chest, etc.).

sloka: jalāgnidrumaśailebhyo viṣamebhyaśca taṃ sadā|  rakṣedunmādinaṃ caiva sadyaḥ prāṇaharā hi te||66||
translation: The wind carrying the life forces enters and agitates the channels; seated in the chest, it raises kapha and causes hiccups and sighs. It creates the fivefold disturbances to the life forces of living beings, and also their fivefold revivals.

sloka: tatra ślokau  hetuṃ kurvantyapasmāraṃ doṣāḥ prakupitā yathā|  sāmānyataḥ pṛthaktvācca liṅgaṃ teṣāṃ ca bheṣajam||67|| mahāgadasamutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ covāca sauṣadham|  munirvyāsasamāsābhyāmapasmāracikitsite [1] ||68||
translation: Listen, I will describe to you the earlier forms of both [coughing and hiccups]. The heaviness in the throat and chest, the paleness of the face, the initial symptoms of hiccups and belching, the pain in the sides, and the reversal of breath—these are the earlier forms of these.

sloka: athāto hikkāśvāsacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ ||2||
translation:
The wind carrying phlegm forcibly obstructs the paths of the vital breath, the rivers flowing within, and the digestive fire. It suddenly and violently seizes the throat, causing a hacking cough that is one, two, or three times the normal force. When this happens, the vital breath, the rivers flowing within, the bodily organs, and the heat of digestion all become obstructed, as does the ability to recall things. The person's eyes fill with tears, their eyelids droop, their lips quiver, and they are unable to control their speech. This intense hacking cough is considered by people to be immediately life-threatening. This is known as mahāhikka.
1527,हिक्कते यः प्रवृद्धस्तु कृशो दीनमना नरः ।  जर्जरेणोरसा कृच्छ्रं गम्भीरमनुनादयन् ॥२७॥  सञ्जृम्भन् सङ्क्षिपंश्चैव तथाऽङ्गानि प्रसारयन् ।  पार्श्वे चोभे समायम्य कूजन् स्तम्भरुगर्दितः ॥२८॥  नाभेः पक्वाशयाद्वाऽपि हिक्का चास्योपजायते ।  क्षोभयन्ती भृशं देहं नामयन्तीव ताम्यतः ॥२९॥  रुणद्ध्युच्छ्वासमार्गं तु प्रनष्टबलचेतसः ।  गम्भीरा नाम सा तस्य हिक्का प्राणान्तिकी मता ॥३०॥  इति गम्भीरा हिक्का ।,"One who, while advanced in age, frequently coughs, is weak, dejected, and haggard; whose breath rattles in the chest, making a grating sound like that of a bamboo rod; whose body trembles violently, as if about to collapse, and whose cough originates from either the ripened intestines or the navel, is said to have a deep-seated cough, which severely agitates the body and weakens the spirit.

sloka: vedalokārthatattvajñamātreyamṛṣimuttamam |  apṛcchat saṃśayaṃ dhīmānagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ ||3||  ya ime dvividhāḥ proktāstridoṣāstriprakopaṇāḥ |  rogā nānātmakāsteṣāṃ kasko bhavati durjayaḥ ||4||
translation: The hiccups that cease when the four types of digestion related to food and drink are complete, and strength is regained; those of a chattering, watery-eyed person with a parched mouth and quivering lips; and those that persist from the base of the throat – these hiccups are known as obstructions of the life force when they cease. This is called "hiccups that have ceased."

sloka: agniveśasya tadvākyaṃ śrutvā matimatāṃ varaḥ |  uvāca paramaprītaḥ paramārthaviniścayam ||5||  kāmaṃ prāṇaharā rogā bahavo na tu te tathā |  yathā śvāsaśca hikkā ca prāṇānāśu nikṛntataḥ ||6||  anyairapyupasṛṣṭasya rogairjantoḥ pṛthagvidhaiḥ |  ante sañjāyate hikkā śvāso vā tīvravedanaḥ ||7||
translation: When a gust of wind, unimpeded by any effort, enters the throat causing a hiccup, then it is known as a minor hiccup. It does not cause extreme discomfort, nor does it affect the vital areas of the head, nor does it obstruct the passages of breathing or drinking. Its severity decreases once the food is digested, and it originates from the stomach, the heart, the throat, and is known as a mild hiccup in humans. This is called a minor hiccup.

sloka: kaphavātātmakāvetau pittasthānasamudbhavau |  hṛdayasya rasādīnāṃ dhātūnāṃ copaśoṣaṇau ||8|| tasmāt sādhāraṇāvetau matau paramadurjayau |  mithyopacaritau kruddhau hata āśīviṣāviva ||9||
translation: Being agitated by the sudden consumption of excessive food and drink, or intoxicants, the wind in the stomach rises upwards. Similarly, when the stomach-residing wind is driven out due to the weight of harsh words and laughter, it causes hiccups. By entering the cavity of the throat, the wind causes a sudden spasm known as "annajaa hikkaa." This hiccup, which neither harms the vital parts nor affects the senses, subsides on its own after some time when one has eaten or drunk something. (Translated in prose for clarity)

sloka: pṛthak pañcavidhāvetau nirdiṣṭau rogasaṅgrahe |  tayoḥ śṛṇu samutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ ca sabhiṣagjitam ||10||  rajasā dhūmavātābhyāṃ śītasthānāmbusevanāt |  vyāyāmādgrāmyadharmādhvarūkṣānnaviṣamāśanāt ||11||  āmapradoṣādānāhādraukṣyādatyapatarpaṇāt |  daurbalyānmarmaṇo ghātāddvandvācchuddhyatiyogataḥ ||12||  atīsārajvaracchardipratiśyāyakṣatakṣayāt |  raktapittādudāvartādvisūcyalasakādapi ||13||  pāṇḍurogādviṣāccaiva pravartete gadāvimau |  niṣpāvamāṣapiṇyākatilatailaniṣevaṇāt ||14||  piṣṭaśālūkaviṣṭambhividāhigurubhojanāt |  jalajānūpapiśitadadhyāmakṣīrasevanāt ||15||  abhiṣyandyupacārācca śleṣmalānāṃ ca sevanāt |  kaṇṭhorasaḥ pratīghātādvibandhaiśca pṛthagvidhaiḥ ||16||
translation: Of one afflicted with numerous faults, of one who harms devotees, of one weakened by diseases and whose body is debilitated, of the elderly and of one given to excessive exertion; the hiccups that arise in them quickly take away life. Along with this, also accompanied by thirst, greed, and delusion, the dyspnea is incurable.

sloka: mārutaḥ prāṇavāhīni srotāṃsyāviśya kupyati |  uraḥsthaḥ kaphamuddhūya hikkāśvāsān karoti saḥ ||17||  ghorān prāṇoparodhāya prāṇināṃ pañca pañca ca |18|
translation: When the wind endowed with phlegm (i.e., humid) constricts the flow of rivers, it then moves in all directions and causes breaths (or creates a gusty situation).

sloka: ubhayoḥ pūrvarūpāṇi śṛṇu vakṣyāmyataḥ param ||18||  kaṇṭhorasorgurutvaṃ ca vadanasya kaṣāyatā |  hikkānāṃ pūrvarūpāṇi kukṣerāṭopa eva ca ||19||  ānāhaḥ pārśvaśūlaṃ ca pīḍanaṃ hṛdayasya ca |  prāṇasya ca vilomatvaṃ śvāsānāṃ pūrvalakṣaṇam ||20||
translation: The man, who is agitated by the rising wind, appears troubled like a rampant bull, breathes heavily with a constricted chest, has lost his knowledge and discrimination, his eyes are wide open in bewilderment, his face is distorted, he has loose bowels, and his speech is unintelligible. He appears pathetic, and even from a distance, one can perceive his extreme distress. When such a person is enveloped by great despair, he soon collapses. This is the nature of great despair.
