sloka: prāṇodakānnavāhīni srotāṃsi sakapho'nilaḥ |  hikkā karoti saṃrudhya tāsāṃ liṅgaṃ pṛthak śṛṇu ||21||  kṣīṇamāṃsabalaprāṇatejasaḥ sakapho'nilaḥ |  gṛhītvā sahasā kaṇṭhamuccairghoṣavatīṃ bhṛśam ||22||  karoti satataṃ hikkāmekadvitriguṇaṃ tathā |  prāṇaḥ srotāṃsi marmāṇi saṃrudhyoṣmāṇameva ca ||23||  sañjñāṃ muṣṇāti gātrāṇāṃ stambhaṃ sañjanayatyapi |  mārgaṃ caivānnapānānāṃ ruṇaddhyupahatasmṛteḥ ||24||  sāśruviplutanetrasya stabdhaśaṅkhacyutabhruvaḥ |  saktajalpapralāpasya nirvṛtiṃ nādhigacchataḥ ||25||  mahāmūlā mahāvegā mahāśabdā mahābalā |  mahāhikketi sā nṝṇāṃ sadyaḥ prāṇaharā matā ||26||  iti mahāhikkā |
translation: The one who only breathes out deeply, not inhaling back, whose nostrils are congested, agitated by the foul smell, with a far-off gaze, disoriented, suffering from painful sensations, parched mouth, and tormented, when the upward breath is agitated, the downward breath is restrained. When he becomes bewildered and calms down, the upward breath kills him. This is called 'urdhvashvaha'.

sloka: hikkate yaḥ pravṛddhastu kṛśo dīnamanā naraḥ |  jarjareṇorasā kṛcchraṃ gambhīramanunādayan ||27||  sañjṛmbhan saṅkṣipaṃścaiva tathā'ṅgāni prasārayan |  pārśve cobhe samāyamya kūjan stambharugarditaḥ ||28||  nābheḥ pakvāśayādvā'pi hikkā cāsyopajāyate |  kṣobhayantī bhṛśaṃ dehaṃ nāmayantīva tāmyataḥ ||29||  ruṇaddhyucchvāsamārgaṃ tu pranaṣṭabalacetasaḥ |  gambhīrā nāma sā tasya hikkā prāṇāntikī matā ||30||  iti gambhīrā hikkā |
translation: He who, his life force being constricted, breathes with difficulty; or who, wounded by a weapon in the chest, does not breathe due to pain; who, drenched in sweat, trembling, and burning with a blazing stomach, has swollen eyes, is emaciated, and has a single red eye, whose consciousness is scattered, mouth dry, complexion faded, and who speaks incoherently – such a person with constricted breath will soon depart from life. This is chinnashvāsaḥ (constricted breathing).

sloka: vyapetā jāyate hikkā yā'nnapāne caturvidhe |  āhārapariṇāmānte bhūyaśca labhate balam ||31||  pralāpavamyatīsāratṛṣṇārtasya vicetasaḥ |  jṛmbhiṇo viplutākṣasya śuṣkāsyasya vināminaḥ ||32||  paryādhmātasya hikkā yā jatrumūlādasantatā |  sā vyapeteti vijñeyā hikkā prāṇoparodhinī ||33||  iti vyapetā hikkā |
translation: When the wind blows against the current, gathering the waters, drawing up phlegm and making a gurgling sound, it becomes forceful, causing labored breathing that is obstructive and painful. With the obstruction in the throat, one cannot speak and struggles to breathe, even unable to sleep while lying down. The wind touching the sides of the person lying down provides some warmth and comfort, but the person's eyes bulge, face turns pale, and breath becomes uneven. The body is covered in cold sweat, and breathing stops or becomes extremely shallow. These symptoms are known as tamakashwasa (tuberculosis).

sloka: kṣudravāto yadā koṣṭhādvyāyāmaparighaṭṭitaḥ |  kaṇṭhe prapadyate hikkāṃ tadā kṣudrāṃ karoti saḥ ||34||  atiduḥkhā na sā coraḥśiromarmaprabādhinī |  na cocchvāsānnapānānāṃ mārgamāvṛtya tiṣṭhati ||35||  vṛddhimāyasyato yāti bhuktamātre ca mārdavam |  yataḥ pravartate pūrvaṃ tata eva nivartate ||36||  hṛdayaṃ kloma kaṇṭhaṃ ca tālukaṃ ca samāśritā |  mṛdvī sā kṣudrahikketi nṛṇāṃ sādhyā prakīrtitā ||37||  iti kṣudrahikkā |
translation: The initial alleviating treatment for a person afflicted with fever, characterized by tremors and delirium, is emesis therapy, which should be administered when the darkness within him intensifies and is pacified by cold. This is the primary form of such a therapeutic breath.

sloka: sahasā'tyabhyavahṛtaiḥ pānānnaiḥ pīḍito'nilaḥ |  ūrdhvaṃ prapadyate koṣṭhānmadyairvā'timadapradaiḥ ||38||  tathā'tiroṣabhāṣyādhvahāsyabhārātivartanaiḥ |  vāyuḥ koṣṭhagato dhāvan pānabhojyaprapīḍitaḥ ||39||  uraḥsrotaḥ samāviśya kuryāddhikkāṃ tato'nnajām |  tathā śanairasambandhaṃ kṣuvaṃścāpi sa hikkate ||40||  na marmabādhājananī nendriyāṇāṃ prabādhinī |  hikkā pīte tathā bhukte śamaṃ yāti ca sā'nnajā ||41||  ityannajā hikkā |
translation: The mild wind, born from the harsh grating in the throat, that causes only a slight movement and does not cause excessive pain or harm to the limbs, nor disrupts the proper course of eating and drinking, nor causes any unpleasantness to the senses, is called a gentle breeze, and it is considered as a sign of strength in those whose specific symptoms are described. (65-68)

sloka: atisañcitadoṣasya bhaktacchedakṛśasya ca |  vyādhibhiḥ kṣīṇadehasya vṛddhasyātivyavāyinaḥ ||42||  āsāṃ yā sā samutpannā hikkā hantyāśu jīvitam |  yamikā ca pralāpārtitṛṣṇāmohasamanvitā ||43||  akṣīṇaścāpyadīnaśca sthiradhātvindriyaśca yaḥ |  tasya sādhayituṃ śakyā yamikā hantyato'nyathā ||44||
translation: These (are) deadly poisonous [creatures] that should be avoided; they are fierce and act quickly. Even those who can be cured with medicines, the physician should treat immediately. Otherwise, if neglected, they will burn (harm) like fire on dry kindling.

sloka: yadā srotāṃsi saṃrudhya mārutaḥ kaphapūrvakaḥ |  viṣvagvrajati saṃruddhastadā śvāsānkaroti saḥ ||45||
translation: The one thing that should be treated, according to the seers, due to their inherent unity at the basis of cause and effect, is the single entity; understand this as per your discretion in both cases. At first, treat coughing with gentle soothing sweats administered through anointments. Apply a mixture of oil and salt along with other ingredients on the body. Once the phlegm has melted due to the heat, it begins to flow through the channels, just as the snow melts in sunlit parts of a mountain. When the phlegm, thus stimulated, starts flowing, feed the person with a delicious and nourishing meal of fish or pork or fresh milk. After that, if the phlegm has increased, administer a purgative made from pippalii, saindhava, and kshaudra, which is capable of opposing vata. Once the phlegm is eliminated and the channels are cleansed, the person experiences comfort; unobstructed by any disorder, vata moves freely in the purified channels.

sloka: uddhūyamānavāto yaḥ śabdavaddukhito naraḥ |  uccaiḥ śvasiti saṃruddho mattarṣabha ivāniśam ||46|| pranaṣṭajñānavijñānastathā vibhrāntalocanaḥ |  vikṛtākṣyānano baddhamūtravarcā viśīrṇavāk ||47||  dīnaḥ praśvasitaṃ cāsya dūrādvijñāyate bhṛśam |  mahāśvāsopasṛṣṭaḥ sa kṣiprameva vipadyate ||48||  iti mahāśvāsaḥ |
translation: If free from faults, one should eliminate impurities with smoke; prepare a paste of turmeric, arka leaves, and manashila; mix it with sadevadarvala meat and ghee or yava grains with ghee. Consume this with madhu-chhishhta, sarjarasa, ghee, and mallaka in a mixture. Drink smoke (or smoky air) by using a pipe made of the bone of a calf or a baby bird. For those who are convalescing, use a dry kusha straw or padmaka, guggulu, lobha, or shalaki mixed with ghee.

sloka: dīrghaṃ śvasiti yastūrdhvaṃ na ca pratyāharatyadhaḥ |  śleṣmāvṛtamukhasrotāḥ kruddhagandhavahārditaḥ ||49||  ūrdhvadṛṣṭirvipaśyaṃśca vibhrāntākṣa itastataḥ |  pramuhyan vedanārtaśca śuṣkāsyo'ratipīḍitaḥ ||50||  ūrdhvaśvāse prakupite  hyadhaḥśvāso nirudhyate |  muhyatastāmyataścordhvaṃ śvāsastasyaiva hantyasūn ||51||  ityūrdhvaśvāsaḥ |
translation:
For those with weakened voices, excess mucus, bile, and phlegm disorders, one should administer sweet, unctuous, and cool substances along with expectorants and relaxants. (Translation by Dr. Shiva Muni Mageeju)

The verse gives home remedies for treating certain illnesses related to voice and digestion. It advises giving sweet, unctuous, and cool substances, as well as expectorants and relaxants to people with weakened voices, excess mucus, bile, and phlegm disorders.

sloka: yastu śvasiti vicchinnaṃ sarvaprāṇena pīḍitaḥ |  na vā śvasiti duḥkhārto marmacchedarugarditaḥ ||52||  ānāhasvedamūrcchārto dahyamānena bastinā |  viplutākṣaḥ parikṣīṇaḥ śvasan raktaikalocanaḥ ||53||  vicetāḥ pariśuṣkāsyo vivarṇaḥ pralapannaraḥ |  chinnaśvāsena vicchinnaḥ sa śīghraṃ prajahātyasūn ||54||  iti chinnaśvāsaḥ |
translation: One who is not afflicted by increased sweating, Pitta disorder, and rakta sweating, who is free from emaciation, roughness, and is devoid of pitta in pregnant women. Such a person should be treated with mild sudation using warm water, sesame oil, and other materials like wheat flour and salt for a short duration. In cases of new onset of diseases without impurities, rough sweating can be alleviated by applying a paste made of sesame, barley, and green gram or by applying a gentle sweat inducing therapy using lemon water. If excessive vata is observed, the physician should calm it down using oleation therapies and mildly heated materials that are not very cold or hot. In case of bloating and flatulence, food items like dried ginger, pepper, and rock salt should be consumed in a pulverized form.

sloka: pratilomaṃ yadā vāyuḥ srotāṃsi pratipadyate |  grīvāṃ śiraśca saṅgṛhya śleṣmāṇaṃ samudīrya ca ||55||  karoti pīnasaṃ tena ruddho ghurghurukaṃ tathā |  atīva tīvravegaṃ ca śvāsaṃ prāṇaprapīḍakam ||56||  pratāmyatyativegācca kāsate sannirudhyate |  pramohaṃ kāsamānaśca sa gacchati muhurmuhuḥ ||57||  śleṣmaṇyamucyamāne tu bhṛśaṃ bhavati duḥkhitaḥ |  tasyaiva ca vimokṣānte muhūrtaṃ labhate sukham ||58||  athāsyoddhvaṃsate kaṇṭhaḥ kṛcchrācchaknoti bhāṣitum |  na cāpi nidrāṃ labhate śayānaḥ śvāsapīḍitaḥ ||59||  pārśve tasyāvagṛhṇāti śayānasya samīraṇaḥ |  āsīno labhate saukhyamuṣṇaṃ caivābhinandati ||60||  ucchritākṣo lalāṭena svidyatā bhṛśamartimān |  viśuṣkāsyo muhuḥ śvāso muhuścaivāvadhamyate ||61||  meghāmbuśītaprāgvātaiḥ śleṣmalaiścābhivardhate |  sa yāpyastamakaśvāsaḥ sādhyo vā syānnavotthitaḥ ||62||  iti tamakaśvāsaḥ |
translation: There is one who is strong and free from cough and fever, while another is weak and afflicted with too much phlegm. Some are excessively dry and associated with a lot of wind, while others, having an excess of phlegm, are strong. For those dominated by phlegm and strength, emesis and purgation should be administered to one who eats properly and has controlled the smoke, impurities, etc. The weak and young, as well as the elderly, who are afflicted with wind, should be nourished and pacified with oils, liquid food, and such things.

sloka: jvaramūrcchāparītasya vidyāt pratamakaṃ tu tam |  udāvartarajo'jīrṇaklinnakāyanirodhajaḥ ||63||  tamasā vardhate'tyarthaṃ śītaiścāśu praśāmyati |  majjatastamasīvā'sya vidyāt santamakaṃ tu tam ||64||  iti pratamakasantamakaśvāsau |
translation: The wind, once it has obtained a firm foothold, quickly dries up the moisture in the unobstructed, weak, and diseased; the physician should cleanse the satiated and purge the unsated with juices that are abundant in taste. Creatures such as those of the forest, big-horned animals, and birds become healthy when given the decoction of dasamula or kaulatha.

sloka: rūkṣāyāsodbhavaḥ koṣṭhe kṣudro vāta udīrayan |  kṣudraśvāso na so'tyarthaṃ duḥkhenāṅgaprabādhakaḥ ||65|| hinasti na sa gātrāṇi na ca duḥkho yathetare |  na ca bhojanapānānāṃ niruṇaddhyucitāṃ gatim ||66||  nendriyāṇāṃ vyathāṃ nāpi kāñcidāpādayedrujam |  sa sādhya ukto balinaḥ sarve cāvyaktalakṣaṇāḥ ||67||  iti śvāsāḥ samuddiṣṭā hikkāścaiva svalakṣaṇaiḥ |68|
translation:
Boil the bark of bilva, karkataka, durralabha, trikantaka, and guduchi, as well as the fruits of kulatttha, sachitra, until reduced to a paste in water. Add rock salt, cumin, and pippalighrta to this and consume it before meals for its beneficial effects on digestion.

Soak mudga, sachitra, and pippali in water and grind them together with their soaking water to make a paste. Boil this until it becomes a liquid, which can be consumed as a medicine for cough and hiccups.

Take the leaves of matuulunga, nimba, kulaka, and grind them with mudga and savyoosha. Add kshaara to this and boil it until it becomes thick. Consume this mixture with salavana, kshaara, shigruuna, maricha for its beneficial effects on cough, hiccups, and other ailments.

Take the juice of kasaarndaka, shobhaanjana, and dry the roots of shushka moola to make a powder. Mix this with yoosha and consume it for relief from cough, hiccups, and other ailments.

Take siddha yavagu made from pippali, sauvarcala, jaaajii, biDapauShkara, sringi, tAmarakI, bhaargI, guduchi, and naagarambubhi with kashaayam or consume it as it is for relief from cough, hiccups, and other ailments.

Soak yavaagu made from dasha mooli, shatthI, raasna, pippali moola in water and consume it for relief from cough, hiccups, and other ailments. Mix this with anna and paana and consume it with sarpir, biDahingu, andhingu for its beneficial effects on digestion.

sloka: eṣāṃ prāṇaharā varjyā ghorāste hyāśukāriṇaḥ ||68||  bheṣajaiḥ sādhyayāpyāṃstu kṣipraṃ bhiṣagupācaret |  upekṣitā daheyurhi śuṣkaṃ kakṣamivānalaḥ ||69||
translation: Where, indeed, can a man with a cough and thirst drink the sap of the Dasamula tree or alcohol?

sloka: kāraṇasthānamūlaikyādekameva cikitsitam |  dvayorapi yathādṛṣṭamṛṣibhistannibodhata ||70||  hikkāśvāsārditaṃ snigdhairādau svedairupācaret |  āktaṃ lavaṇatailena nāḍīprastarasaṅkaraiḥ ||71||  tairasya grathitaḥ śleṣmā srotaḥsvabhivilīyate |  khāni mārdavamāyānti tato vātānulomatā ||72||  yathā'drikuñjeṣvarkāṃśutaptaṃ viṣyandate himam |  śleṣmā taptaḥ sthiro dehe svedairviṣyandate tathā ||73||  svinnaṃ jñātvā tatastūrṇaṃ bhojayet snigdhamodanam |  matsyānāṃ śūkarāṇāṃ vā rasairdadhyuttareṇa vā ||74|| tataḥ śleṣmaṇi saṃvṛddhe vamanaṃ pāyayettu tam |  pippalīsaindhavakṣaudrairyuktaṃ vātāvirodhi yat ||75||  nirhṛte sukhamāpnoti sa kaphe duṣṭavigrahe |  srotaḥsu ca viśuddheṣu caratyavihato'nilaḥ ||76||
translation: After rinsing and smoothing the cylindrical piece of deodar wood (devadāru) with sweet and smooth edges (madhurasām rāsnām), place it in a sura-maṇḍala (a container for holding liquid offerings).

sloka: līnaśceddoṣaśeṣaḥ syāddhūmaistaṃ nirharedbudhaḥ |  haridrāṃ patrameraṇḍamūlaṃ lākṣāṃ manaḥśilām ||77||  sadevadārvalaṃ māṃsīṃ piṣṭvā vartiṃ prakalpayet |  tāṃ ghṛtāktāṃ pibeddhūmaṃ yavairvā ghṛtasaṃyutaiḥ ||78||  madhūcchiṣṭaṃ sarjarasaṃ ghṛtaṃ mallakasampuṭe |  kṛtvā dhūmaṃ pibecchṛṅgaṃ bālaṃ vā snāyu vā gavām ||79||  syonākavardhamānānāṃ nāḍīṃ śuṣkāṃ kuśasya vā |  padmakaṃ gugguluṃ lohaṃ śallakīṃ vā ghṛtāplutam ||80||
translation: The physician should prepare a mixture of Mandalavana, equal to the size of a kernel of barley, along with Sauvarcala Kola and Samangaa Pippali, balanced in measure. This should then be given to alleviate hiccups and bring about ease in breathing. Alternatively, one may consume Sauvarcala, Nagara, Bhargii, and Dvisharkarayutam, mixed with warm water, which is known to mitigate hiccups and difficulty in breathing. The powder made from the bark of Bhargii and Nagara, along with a pinch of black pepper and rock salt, should be consumed with water for relief from hiccups caused by an imbalance of wind in the body. Milk, sugarcane juice, pippali, and Utkariika cooked in ghee is beneficial in managing hiccups caused by a disturbance in bile. Similarly, Shwava, shashamaansa, and Shallaka rakta, prepared with pippali ghee, alleviates hiccups caused by an imbalance of wind. For kapha-related hiccups, consume milk, pippalimadhu, guda goshvashakridrsa, ghee, and ksheerika in equal quantities. Kshaara, shatapushpa swarasa, sapthaparni, pippali, and madhusammyukta is recommended for managing hiccups caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile. For those with a predominance of kapha dosha, consume the meat soup of animals like horse, donkey, camel, elephant, buffalo, goat, sheep, and cow in moderation. For kapha-related hiccups, consume meat soup of animals like horse, donkey, camel, elephant, buffalo, goat, sheep, and cow in moderation. Grind and burn the hair, nails, skin, bones, and hooves of animals like donkey, horse, camel, rhinoceros, buffalo, deer, and birds separately. Mix each of these with ghee and rock salt and consume them one at a time to alleviate severe hiccups caused by an obstruction in the flow of vata. These are the remedies

sloka: svarakṣīṇātisārāsṛkpittadāhānubandhajān |  madhurasnigdhaśītādyairhikkāśvāsānupācaret ||81||
translation: A knowledgeable person should give a sneeze to someone if they ask for it and pay attention during pronunciation changes. They should also administer emetics made of wind-and phlegm-reducing ingredients when the person's condition necessitates it. Just as water flowing on the path becomes greatly agitated due to an obstruction in its course, similarly, one should always cleanse the path of the wind (i.e., the digestive system) of the person in this manner.

sloka: na svedyāḥ pittadāhārtā raktasvedātivartinaḥ |  kṣīṇadhātubalā rūkṣā garbhiṇyaścāpi pittalāḥ ||82||  koṣṇaiḥ kāmamuraḥkaṇṭhaṃ snehasekaiḥ saśarkaraiḥ |  utkārikopanāhaiśca svedayen mṛdubhiḥ kṣaṇam ||83||  tilomāmāṣagodhūmacūrṇairvātaharaiḥ saha |  snehaiścotkārikā sāmlaiḥ sakṣīrairvā kṛtā hitā ||84||  navajvarāmadoṣeṣu rūkṣasvedaṃ vilaṅghanam |  samīkṣyollekhanaṃ vā'pi kārayellavaṇāmbunā ||85||  atiyogoddhataṃ vātaṃ dṛṣṭvā vātaharairbhiṣak |  rasādyairnātiśītoṣṇairabhyaṅgaiśca śamaṃ nayet ||86||  udāvarte tathā''dhmāne mātuluṅgāmlavetasaiḥ |  hiṅgupīlubiḍaiścānnaṃ yuktaṃ syādanulomanam ||87||
translation: Mix together the powdered form of belleric myrobalan, barley sugar, black salt, and long pepper in equal quantities, along with eight times the amount of sugar. This mixture should be taken every time you have a cough or hiccup.

sloka: hikkāśvāsāmayī hyeko balavān durbalo'paraḥ |  kaphādhikastathaivaiko rūkṣo bahvanilo'paraḥ ||88||  kaphādhike balasthe ca vamanaṃ savirecanam |  kuryāt pathyāśine dhūmalehādiśamanaṃ tataḥ ||89|| vātikān durbalān bālān vṛddhāṃścānilasūdanaiḥ |  tarpayedeva śamanaiḥ snehayūṣarasādibhiḥ ||90||
translation: The powder of pearl, coral, diamond, crystal, and collyrium; saffron, musk, and pure camphor; jasmine flowers, lichen, and rice grains of apamarga; when mixed in equal parts with clarified butter, this powder can quickly alleviate cough, hiccups, fever, and bad odors; it removes darkness from the eyes, fades blue discoloration, eliminates body odor and itching. This is called the powder of pearl and other ingredients.

sloka: anutkliṣṭakaphāsvinnadurbalānāṃ viśodhanāt |  vāyurlabdhāspado marma saṃśoṣyāśu haredasūn ||91||  dṛḍhān bahukaphāṃstasmādrasairānūpavārijaiḥ |  tṛptānviśodhayetsvinnān bṛṃhayeditarān bhiṣak ||92||  barhitittiridakṣāśca jāṅgalāśca mṛgadvijāḥ |  daśamūlīrase siddhāḥ kaulatthe vā rase hitāḥ ||93||
translation: The powder of shatipushkara roots, mixed with sugar, or the powder of kalaloha, these should be consumed.

sloka: nidigdhikāṃ bilvamadhyaṃ karkaṭākhyāṃ durālabhām |  trikaṇṭakaṃ guḍūcīṃ ca kulatthāṃśca sacitrakān ||94|| jale paktvā rasaḥ pūtaḥ pippalīghṛtabharjitaḥ |  sanāgaraḥ salavaṇaḥ syādyūṣo bhojane hitaḥ ||95||  rāsnāṃ balāṃ pañcamūlaṃ hrasvaṃ mudgān sacitrakān |  paktvā'mbhasi rase tasmin yūṣaḥ sādhyaśca pūrvavat ||96||  pallavānmātuluṅgasya nimbasya kulakasya ca |  paktvā mudgāṃśca savyoṣān kṣārayūṣaṃ vipācayet ||97||  dattvā salavaṇaṃ kṣāraṃ śigrūṇi maricāni ca |  yuktyā saṃsādhito yūṣo hikkāśvāsavikāranut ||98||  kāsamardakapatrāṇāṃ yūṣaḥ śobhāñjanasya ca |  śuṣkamūlakayūṣaśca hikkāśvāsanivāraṇaḥ ||99||  sadadhivyoṣasarpiṣko yūṣo vārtākajo hitaḥ |  śāliṣaṣṭikagodhūmayavānnānyanavāni ca ||100||  hiṅgusauvarcalājājībiḍapauṣkaracitrakaiḥ |  siddhā karkaṭaśṛṅgyā ca yavāgūḥ śvāsahikkinām ||101||  daśamūlīśaṭīrāsnāpippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīguḍūcīnāgarāmbubhiḥ ||102||  yavāgūṃ vidhinā siddhāṃ kaṣāyaṃ vā pibennaraḥ |  kāsahṛdgrahapārśvārtihikkāśvāsapraśāntaye ||103||  puṣkarāhvaśaṭīvyoṣamātuluṅgāmlavetasaiḥ |  yojayedannapānāni sasarpirbiḍahiṅgubhiḥ ||104||
translation: One should not drink sugarcane juice, tala fruit juice, grape juice, or the sap of cow's urine, all of which are equally as good as jaggery and sugar from the city. One should also avoid using garlic, the root of ginger, Chandana mixed with Narikela, Sukha Oshna Ghrita Mandita with Saindhava, Mrudishta Vista with Alakta Karkata Rasa, Narikelena Siddha, Sarpi or Madhuraka with sugar and honey, whether it is consumed immediately, after being kept for some time, or when one is thirsty. Similarly, one should avoid consuming milk that is slightly salty, slightly cold, or having irregularities in its taste, as well as milk mixed with sugar or honey during ablutions or other actions.

sloka: daśamūlasya vā kvāthamathavā devadāruṇaḥ |  tṛṣito madirāṃ vā'pi hikkāśvāsī pibennaraḥ ||105||
translation: The churned butter prepared from inferior ingredients quickly checks a hiccup. Likewise, consuming a mixture of Indian gooseberry, honey, and dried ginger; or sugarcane juice, Indian gooseberry, and bael fruit; or rice washed in cold water; or chewing licorice and sugarcane; or consuming a mixture of liquorice, Indian gooseberry, and black pepper can alleviate hiccups. The cause of hiccups, as mentioned here, should be avoided by those who seek good health.

sloka: pāṭhāṃ madhurasāṃ rāsnāṃ saralaṃ devadāru ca |  prakṣālya jarjarīkṛtya surāmaṇḍe nidhāpayet ||106||
translation: Those who have a hacking cough, dry throat, and are lean due to consumption should be treated with ghee prepared with the decoction of dasamula (ten roots), along with ghee mixed with curd, and with krsna sauvarcala, lakhara, ksira, and hingu; consuming this ghee will help alleviate their hacking cough and anxiety.

sloka: taṃ mandalavaṇaṃ kṛtvā bhiṣak prasṛtasammitam |  pāyayettu tato hikkā śvāsaścaivopaśāmyati ||107||  hiṅgu sauvarcalaṃ kolaṃ samaṅgāṃ pippalīṃ balām |  mātuluṅgarase piṣṭamāranālena vā pibet ||108||  sauvarcalaṃ nāgaraṃ ca bhārgīṃ dviśarkarāyutam |  uṣṇāmbunā pibedetaddhikkāśvāsavikāranut ||109||  bhārgīnāgarayoḥ kalkaṃ maricakṣārayostathā |  pītadrucitrakāsphotāmūrvāṇāṃ cāmbunā pibet ||110||  madhūlikā tugākṣīrī nāgaraṃ pippalī tathā |  utkārikā ghṛte siddhā śvāse pittānubandhaje ||111||  śvāvidhaṃ śaśamāṃsaṃ ca śallakasya ca śoṇitam |  pippalīghṛtasiddhāni śvāse vātānubandhaje ||112||  suvarcalāraso dugdhaṃ ghṛtaṃ trikaṭukānvitam |  śālyodanasyānupānaṃ vātapittānuge hitam ||113||  śirīṣapuṣpasvarasaḥ saptaparṇasya vā punaḥ |  pippalīmadhusaṃyuktaḥ kaphapittānuge mataḥ ||114||  madhukaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ guḍo gośvaśakṛdrasaḥ [1] |  ghṛtaṃ kṣaudraṃ kāsaśvāsahikkābhiṣyandināṃ śubham ||115||  kharāśvoṣṭravarāhāṇāṃ meṣasya ca gajasya ca |  śakṛdrasaṃ bahukaphe caikaikaṃ madhunā pibet ||116||  kṣāraṃ cāpyaśvagandhāyā lihyānnā kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  mayūrapādanālaṃ vā śakalaṃ śallakasya vā ||117||  śvāvijjāṇḍakacāṣāṇāṃ [2] romāṇi kurarasya vā |  śṛṅgyekadviśaphānāṃ [3] vā carmāsthīni khurāṃstathā ||118||  sarvāṇyekaikaśo vā'pi dagdhvā kṣaudraghṛtānvitam |  cūrṇaṃ līḍhvā jayet kāsaṃ hikkāṃ śvāsaṃ ca dāruṇam ||119||  ete hi kaphasaṃruddhagatiprāṇaprakopajāḥ [4] |  tasmāttanmārgaśuddhyarthaṃ deyā lehā na niṣkaphe ||120||
translation: With tejovaty (a type of ghee), kushtha, pippalí, katurowhiní,

sloka: kāsine cchardanaṃ dadyāt svarabhaṅge ca buddhimān |  vātaśleṣmaharairyuktaṃ tamake tu virecanam ||121||  udīryate bhṛśataraṃ mārgarodhādvahajjalam |  yathā tathā'nilastasya mārgaṃ nityaṃ viśodhayet ||122||
translation: One who is established in the practice of using ghee (clarified butter) prepared from cow's milk, churned manually with a stone, mixed with water, and strained with the bark of a tree or with the leaves of a plant having black resin; such a person may consume it raw, cooked into food, in the form of curd, or in any other way. This is called ghee from the stone churning process.

sloka: śaṭīcorakajīvantītvaṅmustaṃ puṣkarāhvayam |  surasaṃ tāmalakyelā pippalyaguru nāgaram ||123||  vālakaṃ ca samaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā'ṣṭaguṇaśarkaram |  sarvathā tamake śvāse hikkāyāṃ ca prayojayet ||124||
translation: Whatever is capable of suppressing phlegm and wind, warming, promoting their proper direction, serving as medication or drink, is beneficial for someone suffering from breathlessness.

sloka: muktāpravālavaidūryaśaṅkhasphaṭikamañjanam |  sasāragandhakācārkasūkṣmailālavaṇadvayam [1] ||125||  tāmrāyorajasī rūpyaṃ sasaugandhikasīsakam [2] |  jātīphalaṃ śaṇādbījamapāmārgasya taṇḍulāḥ ||126||  eṣāṃ pāṇitalaṃ cūrṇaṃ tulyānāṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  hikkāṃ śvāsaṃ ca kāsaṃ ca līḍhamāśu niyacchati ||127||  añjanāttimiraṃ kācaṃ nīlikāṃ puṣpakaṃ tamaḥ |  malyaṃ [3] kaṇḍūmabhiṣyandamarma caiva praṇāśayet ||128||  iti muktādyaṃ cūrṇam |
translation: The creation of wind or the elimination of phlegm, and that which reduces wind or removes phlegm, this is the primary purpose of both. Generally, the reduction of phlegm is more conducive to well-being. In increasing the strength of all [beings], a small amount is possible and easily achievable. However, excessive reduction can cause harm and is extremely difficult to achieve in causing weakness.

sloka: śaṭīpuṣkaramūlānāṃ cūrṇamāmalakasya ca |  madhunā saṃyutaṃ lehyaṃ cūrṇaṃ vā kālalohajam ||129||
translation: Therefore, one should usually take care of healthy and unhealthy animals by soothing them and nurturing them with control and tranquility. (Verse 150)

sloka: saśarkarāṃ tāmalakīṃ drākṣāṃ gośvaśakṛdrasam |  tulyaṃ guḍaṃ nāgaraṃ ca prāśayennāvayettathā ||130||  laśunasya palāṇḍorvā mūlaṃ gṛñjanakasya vā |  nāvayeccandanaṃ vā'pi nārīkṣīreṇa saṃyutam ||131||  sukhoṣṇaṃ ghṛtamaṇḍaṃ vā saindhavenāvacūrṇitam |  nāvayenmākṣikīṃ viṣṭhāmalaktakarasena vā ||132||  nārīkṣīreṇa siddhaṃ vā sarpirmadhurakairapi |  pītaṃ nasto niṣiktaṃ vā sadyo hikkāṃ niyacchati ||133||  sakṛduṣṇaṃ sakṛcchītaṃ vyatyāsāddhikkināṃ payaḥ |  pāne nastaḥkriyāyāṃ vā śarkarāmadhusaṃyutam ||134||
translation: The cause of the emergence of invincibility and the unity of action is shown here to be the identifier, as well as the beneficial factor, for hiccups and breathlessness, in the section on the treatment of hiccups and breathlessness, which occurs in the seventeenth chapter of Agnivesha's tantra, which has not yet been fully understood, but is filled with strong and balanced healing methods.

sloka: adhobhāgairghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ sadyo hikkāṃ niyacchati |  pippalīmadhuyuktau vā rasau dhātrīkapitthayoḥ ||135||  lājālākṣāmadhudrākṣāpippalyaśvaśakṛdrasān |  lihyāt kolamadhudrākṣāpippalīnāgarāṇi vā ||136||  śītāmbusekaḥ sahasā trāso vismāpanaṃ bhayam |  krodhaharṣapriyodvegā hikkāpracyāvanā matāḥ ||137||  hikkāśvāsavikārāṇāṃ nidānaṃ yat prakīrtitam |  varjyamārogyakāmaistaddhikkāśvāsavikāribhiḥ ||138||
translation: Now I will explain the treatment for raktapitta (a type of Ayurvedic disorder). This is according to what has been said by Lord Atreya.

sloka: hikkāśvāsānubandhā [1] ye śuṣkoraḥkaṇṭhatālukāḥ |  prakṛtyā rūkṣadehāśca sarpirbhistānupācaret ||139||  daśamūlarase sarpirdadhimaṇḍe ca sādhayet |  kṛṣṇāsauvarcalakṣāravayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ ||140||  kāyasthayā ca tat pānāddhikkāśvāsau praṇāśayet |141|
translation: Bowing in reverence, Agnivesha said to the sinless one, leisurely dwelling by the five streams of Punarvasu, "O lord, the cause of the red appearance in bile has been stated; now please, O teacher, tell me about its ultimate meaning."

sloka: tejovatyabhayā kuṣṭhaṃ pippalī kaṭurohiṇī ||141||  bhūtīkaṃ pauṣkaraṃ mūlaṃ palāśaścitrakaḥ śaṭī |  sauvarcalaṃ tāmalakī saindhavaṃ bilvapeśikā ||142||  tālīsapatraṃ jīvantī vacā tairakṣasammitaiḥ |  hiṅgupādairghṛtaprasthaṃ pacettoye caturguṇe ||143||  etadyathābalaṃ pītvā hikkāśvāsau jayennaraḥ |  śothānilārśograhaṇīhṛtpārśvaruja [1] eva ca ||144||  iti tejovatyādighṛtam |
translation: The teacher said to the great student of immense speed and quick action: "Quickly prepare a purgative that has the qualities of being hot, sharp, bitter, and salty, as I have previously explained; its cause is heat and the fermentation of food."

sloka: manaḥśilāsarjarasalākṣārajanipadmakaiḥ |  mañjiṣṭhailaiśca karṣāṃśaiḥ prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtāddhitaḥ ||145|| jīvanīyopasiddhaṃ vā sakṣaudraṃ lehayeddhṛtam |  tryūṣaṇaṃ dādhikaṃ vā'pi pibedvāsāghṛtaṃ tathā ||146|| iti manaḥśilādighṛtam |
translation: The bile, tainted by those causes, turns red. Once it has entered its source, it grows and further contaminates. The liquid of that element, due to its increased heat, attains greater growth.

sloka: yatkiñcit kaphavātaghnamuṣṇaṃ vātānulomanam |  bheṣajaṃ pānamatraṃ vā taddhitaṃ śvāsahikkine ||147||
translation: The arising of a foul smell and change in color is known as raktapitta (a type of disorder) by the learned.

sloka: vātakṛdvā kaphaharaṃ kaphakṛdvā'nilāpaham |  kāryaṃ naikāntikaṃ tābhyāṃ prāyaḥ śreyo'nilāpaham ||148||  sarveṣāṃ bṛṃhaṇe hyalpaḥ śakyaśca prāyaśo bhavet |  nātyarthaṃ  śamane'pāyo bhṛśo'śakyaśca karśane ||149||
translation: Governed by lust and desire, one operates in the world. The physical components of the body, which carry the life force (Raktavahini), have their origin in that. (Translation of Sanskrit verse 10 from Bhagavad Gita)

sloka: tasmācchuddhānaśuddhāṃśca śamanairbṛṃhaṇairapi |  hikkāśvāsārditāñjantūn prāyaśaḥ samupācaret ||150||
translation: The body is sandalwood-scented, slimy, and greasy, with phlegm; it is dark-reddish, yellowish, and rough due to wind. It is rakta Pitta (bile), similar to kashaya (black) go-mutra (cow urine), and smoky like that of mecha (grass). It becomes discolored with the contact of a tri-linga (three-lined mark), and is known as sannipatika.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ durjayatve samutpattau kriyaikatve ca kāraṇam |  liṅgaṃ pathyaṃ ca hikkānāṃ śvāsānāṃ ceha darśitam ||151||  ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne hikkāśvāsacikitsitaṃ nāma saptadaśo'dhyāyaḥ ||17||
translation: A task that has one flaw is easily achievable, while a task with two flaws is considered difficult. A task with three flaws is declared unachievable, such as for someone who is physically weak, old, or refuses to eat, and also afflicted with diseases.

sloka: athāto raktapittacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1|| iti ha smāha  bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation:
The upward and downward movement has been manifested as the course of one with increased pitta. The upward path is through the seven openings, while the downward path is through the two.*

*This verse seems to be describing the physiological process related to the movement of fluids (like digestive juices) in the body, according to Ayurvedic principles.

sloka: viharantaṃ jitātmānaṃ pañcagaṅge punarvasum| praṇamyovāca nirmohamagniveśo'gnivarcasam||3|| bhagavan raktapittasya heturuktaḥ salakṣaṇaḥ| vaktavyaṃ yat paraṃ tasya vaktumarhasi tadguro||4||
translation: There are seven undetectable flaws on the head, and two that can be addressed from below and above; one should approach the remediable ones. (16)

sloka: gururuvāca mahāgadaṃ mahāvegamagnivacchīghrakāri ca|  hetulakṣaṇavicchīghraṃ raktapittamupācaret||5|| tasyoṣṇaṃ tīkṣṇamamlaṃ ca kaṭūni lavaṇāni ca|  gharmaścānnavidāhaśca hetuḥ pūrvaṃ nidarśitaḥ||6||
translation: When all pores are entirely divested of the tamasic tendencies, they say that such a person's course is near at hand.

sloka: tairhetubhiḥ samutkliṣṭaṃ pittaṃ raktaṃ prapadyate| tadyonitvāt prapannaṃ ca vardhatetat pradūṣayat||7|| tasyoṣmaṇā dravo dhāturdhātordhātoḥ prasicyate| svidyatastena saṃvṛddhiṃ bhūyastadadhigacchati||8||
translation: That which overflows from both paths to an excessive degree, is equally foul-smelling and red, as well as extremely black; that which becomes stuck in the throat due to a combination of phlegm and wind; and that which is not alleviated by all the mentioned remedies, even if they are applied, and is afflicted by the colors yellow, blue, green, and red - this denotes a condition of excessive kapha and vata dosas.

sloka: saṃyogāddūṣaṇāttattu sāmānyādgandhavarṇayoḥ| raktasya pittamākhyātaṃ raktapittaṃ manīṣibhiḥ||9||
translation: One who either gets angry due to lack of knowledge or remains calm in the face of flaws, and who follows the right path while also making amends for any mistakes or transgressions.

sloka: plīhānaṃ ca yakṛccaiva tadadhiṣṭhāya vartate| srotāṃsi raktavāhīni tanmūlāni hi dehinām||10||
translation: For a strong person, the single path is to not adopt excessive speed and to be recently risen, and suitable for raktapitta at the appropriate time, and to be free from disturbance.

sloka: sāndraṃ sapāṇḍu sasnehaṃ picchilaṃ ca kaphānvitam| śyāvāruṇaṃ saphenaṃ ca tanu rūkṣaṃ ca vātikam||11|| raktapittaṃ kaṣāyābhaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ gomūtrasannibham| mecakāgāradhūmābhamañjanābhaṃ ca paittikam||12|| saṃsṛṣṭaliṅgaṃ saṃsargāttriliṅgaṃ sānnipātikam|13|
translation: The warm and unctuous, as well as the dry and cold, are generally the causes of an increase in phlegm and bile, respectively. An upward movement is typically associated with an excess of Kapha, while a downward movement is usually due to Vayu. Both Kapha and Vayu can contribute to a dual-origin disorder.

sloka: ekadoṣānugaṃ  sādhyaṃ dvidoṣaṃ yāpyamucyate||13|| yattridoṣamasādhyaṃ tanmandāgnerativegavat|vyādhibhiḥ  kṣīṇadehasya vṛddhasyānaśnataśca yat||14||
translation: One who is not weak or lacking in strength, if they consume food while suffering from an excess of rakta Pitta (an imbalance of bile and blood), that meal will become a cause of impurity, difficult to digest, and will initially manifest as symptoms such as heaviness in the stomach, fullness in the chest, fainting, dizziness, fever, thirst, swelling, flatulence, burning sensations, bleeding, tumors, worms, change in color, fistula, mental or sensory dysfunction. Therefore, one who is aware of the strengths and weaknesses should overlook the initial signs of rakta pitta when they are strong, if they desire to achieve success in controlling it.

sloka: gatirūrdhvamadhaścaiva  raktapittasya darśitā| ūrdhvā saptavidhadvārā dvidvārā tvadharā gatiḥ||15||
translation: Generally, a person's pitta (bile humor) becomes aggravated due to an accumulation of unwholesome factors and begins to cause increased bodily activity. After examining the cause (nidana) of this imbalance in the bile humor and its related symptoms, one should resort to either alleviating it through evacuation measures or nourishing it through digestive stimulation.

sloka: sapta cchidrāṇi śirasi dve cādhaḥsādhyamūrdhvagam| yāpyaṃ tvadhogaṃ mārgau tu sādhyaṃ prapadyate||16||
translation: Should he offer to the thirsty, water smeared with mushtika and Chandana, or just cool water?

sloka: yadā tu sarvacchidrebhyo romakūpebhya eva  tāmasaṅkhyeyāṃ gatiṃ tasyāhurāntikīm||17||
translation: The offering (tarpanam) should be made first to the ancestors who have departed upward, then to the spirits who dwell in water, and finally to those who have gone downward. One who knows the connection of time (kala-satyma) should offer it. For the purpose of tarpanam, use cool, clarified water mixed with a little sugar, juice of kharjura (date palm), mrdvika (a type of grass), or madhuka (liquorice). (Translation based on Swami Gambhirananda's translation of Ishopanishad)

sloka: yaccobhayābhyāṃ mārgābhyāmatimātraṃ pravartate| tulyaṃ kuṇapagandhena raktaṃ kṛṣṇamatīva ca||18|| saṃsṛṣṭaṃ kaphavātābhyāṃ kaṇṭhe sajjati  cāpi yat| yaccāpyupadravaiḥ sarvairyathoktaiḥ samabhidrutam||19|| hāridranīlaharitatāmrairvarṇairupadrutam| kṣīṇasya  kāsamānasya yacca na  sidhyati||20||
translation: The wise person should offer libation mixed with ghee and crushed barley in the morning. This, when consumed at the proper time, helps to eliminate upward-moving phlegm and bile. If the digestive fire is weak, one should prepare a sour gruel using black raisins, dried mango, and salt, and consume it for its sour taste.

sloka: yadvidoṣānugaṃ yadvā śāntaṃ śāntaṃ prakupyati| mārgānmārgaṃ caredyadvā  yāpyaṃ  pittamasṛk catat||21||
translation: The consumption of shali rice (60 grains), koradusha, kulattha, and field peas, as well as black gram and priyangu, is beneficial for curing bile and phlegm disorders. (36)

sloka: ekamārgaṃ balavato nātivegaṃ navotthitam|  raktapittaṃ  kāle sādhyaṃ syānnirupadravam||22||
translation: Mudga (green gram), masura (lentils), chanaka (chickpeas), samakushta (barnyard millet), and adhaki-phala (red rice) have been recommended for making soup as a remedy for rakta-pitta (a disorder associated with an imbalance of bile).

sloka: snigdhoṣṇamuṣṇarūkṣaṃ ca raktapittasya kāraṇam| adhogasyottaraṃ  prāyaḥ pūrvaṃ syādūrdhvagasya tu||23|| ūrdhvagaṃ kaphasaṃsṛṣṭamadhogaṃ mārutānugam| dvimārgaṃ kaphavātābhyāmubhābhyāmanubadhyate||24||
translation: The leaves of Patola, Nimba, and Vetra adorned with plaksha and pallava; the Kirata's bitter vegetable, Gandiri, and Kathila.

sloka: akṣīṇabalamāṃsasya raktapittaṃ yadaśnataḥ| taddoṣaduṣṭamutkliṣṭaṃ nādau   stambhanamarhati||25|| galagrahaṃ pūtinasyaṃ mūrcchāyamaruciṃ jvaram| gulmaṃ plīhānamānāhaṃ kilāsaṃkṛcchramūtratām||26|| kuṣṭhānyarśāṃsi vīsarpaṃ varṇanāśaṃ bhagandaram|  buddhīndriyoparodhaṃ ca kuryāt stambhitamāditaḥ||27|| tasmādupekṣyaṃ balino baladoṣavicāriṇā |  raktapittaṃ prathamatapravṛddhaṃsiddhimicchatā||28||
translation: Of the Kovidara, Kasmari, and Salmali trees, what are the flowers, and what is the additional vegetable in the diet that alleviates red and yellow bile?

sloka: prāyeṇa hi  samutkliṣṭamāmadoṣāccharīriṇām| vṛddhiṃ  prayātipittāsṛktasmāttallaṅghyamāditaḥ||29|| mārgau doṣānubandhaṃ ca nidānaṃ prasamīkṣya ca| laṅghanaṃ raktapittādau tarpaṇaṃ vā prayojayet||30||
translation: For those with symptoms of increased pitta (bile), such as a saaka-like hunger, the flesh of animals like goats, pigeons, and those with red eyes or horns should be cooked in vinegar and sugar. Such meat is beneficial for them and should be consumed.

sloka: hrīberacandanośīramustaparpaṭakaiḥ śṛtam| kevalaṃ  śṛtaśītaṃ  vā dadyāttoyaṃ pipāsave||31||
translation: For one with kapha constitution, juicy dishes should be given; for a pitta person, fluids; and for a vata person, grains and legumes – this is the rule.

sloka: ūrdhvage tarpaṇaṃ pūrvaṃ peyāṃ pūrvamadhogate| kālasātmyānubandhajño dadyāt prakṛtikalpavit||32||  jalaṃ kharjūramṛdvīkāmadhūkaiḥ saparūṣakaiḥ| śṛtaśītaṃ prayoktavyaṃ tarpaṇārthe saśarkaram||33||
translation: Of lotus and blue water lilies, the most excellent pollen; Pushkara flower, when added to that water, is suitable for consumption in cases of bile and rakta disorders.

sloka: tarpaṇaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraṃ lājacūrṇaiḥ pradāpayet| ūrdhvagaṃ raktapittaṃ tat pītaṃ kāle vyapohati||34|| mandāgneramlasātmyāya tat sāmlamapi kalpayet| dāḍimāmalakairvidvānamlārthaṃcānudāpayet||35||
translation: The juice of the Chandana and Lodhra trees is like nectar, as is the Kirāta's bitter taste, the Koshīra's sourness, the Udumbara's sweetness, the taste of Haridra (turmeric) mixed with ghee and salt, the juice of Siddha plants such as Pārāvata, and even in the juices of meat. This should be considered a remedy for rakta-pitta and is cooling, just like sugarcane juice.

sloka: śāliṣaṣṭikanīvārakoradūṣapraśāntikāḥ| śyāmākaśca priyaṅguśca bhojanaṃ raktapittinām||36||
translation: A hare would be healthy in its own habitat, well-protected and free from bile disorders. A crane would exist in a place full of pungent substances, or near the udumbara tree. A peacock is suitable in a plaksha forest, while a rooster is appropriate near a nyagroda tree. The bilva, utpala, and other similar fruits are beneficial for quenching thirst or as a remedy for burning sensations.

sloka: mudgā masūrāścaṇakāḥ samakuṣṭhāḍhakīphalāḥ| praśastāḥ sūpayūṣārthe kalpitā raktapittinām||37||
translation: Having understood the two—strength and weakness of the enemy, one should give water even in small quantities to the thirsty [referring to soldiers or people in need].

sloka: paṭolanimbavetrāgraplakṣavetasapallavāḥ| kirātatiktakaṃ śākaṃ gaṇḍīraḥ sakaṭhillakaḥ||38||
translation: The cause of raktapitta (bleeding disorders) that has been revealed, should not be consumed by those who desire life and health; thus, the consumption of food and drink is regulated in cases of raktapitta.

sloka: kovidārasya puṣpāṇi kāśmaryasyātha śālmaleḥ| annapānavidhau śākaṃyaccānyadraktapittanut||39||
translation: It is told that the treatment for those who are afflicted with many faults and are strong, arises when their strength wanes. For a strong person with an excess of rakta-pitta in the body, purgation and upward-cleansing measures are appropriate at the proper time.

sloka: śākārthaṃ śākasātmyānāṃ tacchastaṃ raktapittinām| svinnaṃ vā sarpiṣā bhṛṣṭaṃ yūṣavadvā vipācitam||40|| pārāvatān kapotāṃśca lāvān raktākṣavartakān| śaśān kapiñjalāneṇān hariṇānkālapucchakān||41|| raktapitte hitān vidyādrasāṃsteṣāṃ prayojayet| īṣadamlānanamlān vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭān saśarkarān||42||
translation: A knowledgeable person should use abundant, sweet milk to rinse (the mouth) when coming into contact with garlic, onions, or impure substances, as this is beneficial, especially for those with a predominance of kapha and pitta doshas.

sloka: kaphānuge yūṣaśākaṃ dadyādvātānuge rasam| raktapitte yavāgūnāmataḥ kalpaḥ pravakṣyate||43||
translation: Emesis mixed with alcohol, churning, a sacrificial offering of soma mixed with clarified butter and sugar, or simply sugar dissolved in water, the sap of reeds, madhuka flowers, or honey; in case of downward-flowing bile, emesis is considered the best treatment.

sloka: padmotpalānāṃ kiñjalkaḥ pṛśniparṇī yaṅgukāḥ| jale sādhyā rase tasmin peyā syādraktapittinām||44||
translation: The sequence of upward-directed acts of purification, such as tarpan ( libation), is beneficial. If this is not done, then the downward-moving wind ( praana vayu) will not function properly.

sloka: candanośīralodhrāṇāṃ rase tadvat nāgare| kirātatiktakośīramustānāṃ tadvadeva ca||45|| dhātakīdhanvayāsāmbubilvānāṃ vā rase śṛtā| masūrapṛśniparṇyorvā sthirāmudgarase'tha vā||46|| rase hareṇukānāṃ vā saghṛte sabalārase| siddhāḥ  pārāvatādīnāṃ rase vā syuḥ pṛthakpṛthak||47|| ityuktā raktapittaghnyaḥ śītāḥ samadhuśarkarāḥ| yavāgvaḥ kalpanā caiṣā kāryā māṃsaraseṣvapi||48||
translation: One who is weakened by loss of flesh, tormented by the burden of grief, scorched by the sun or afflicted by other ailments, sees Pitta (bile) in the body, whether it manifests as a swelling, is old, young, thin, eats little, is despised, rejected, or has red eyes. The remedy for such a Pitta disorder is to reduce excess heat and moisture in the body. This is considered the primary treatment for Pitta disorders.

sloka: śaśaḥ savāstukaḥ śasto vibandhe  raktapittinām| vātolbaṇe tittiriḥ syādudumbararase śṛtaḥ||49|| mayūraḥ plakṣaniryūhe nyagrodhasya ca  kukkuṭaḥ| rase bilvotpalādīnāṃvartakakrakarau hitau||50|| tṛṣyate tiktakaiḥ siddhaṃ tṛṣṇāghnaṃ vā phalodakam|  siddhaṃ vidārigandhādyairathavāśṛtaśītalam||51||
translation:
One should drink a mixture of sugar, licorice, salt, and water, clarified butter, and black myrobalan powder in the treatment of diarrhea caused by the buildup of wastes; it also alleviates red and yellow bile. (65)
In the absence of diarrhea, one should drink a mixture of licorice, black myrobalan, and clarified butter, along with powdered rock salt, which is beneficial for relieving red and yellow bile. (66)

sloka: jñātvā doṣāvanubalau balamāhārameva ca| jalaṃ pipāsave  dadyādvisargādalpaśo'pi vā||52||
translation: One should drink [the water] that has been offered to and contains the flowers of the lotus, padmaka, white water lily, blue water lily, utpala, nagabana, and lodhra, following this procedure.

sloka: nidānaṃ raktapittasya yatkiñcit samprakāśitam| jīvitārogyakāmaistanna sevyaṃ raktapittibhiḥ||53|| ityannapānaṃ nirdiṣṭaṃ kramaśo raktapittanut|54|
translation: Mixing Prapauṇḍarīka, Madhuka, honey, and the juice of licorice and sugarcane, or that of cow's milk, make a drink that is eliminating Pitta (bile) and consume it with a mixture of rice-water or with ghee and sugar. This regulates the taste of cow's and horse's milk.

sloka: vakṣyate bahudoṣāṇāṃ kāryaṃ balavatāṃ ca yat||54|| akṣīṇabalamāṃsasya yasya santarpaṇotthitam| bahudoṣaṃ balavato  raktapittaṃ śarīriṇaḥ||55|| kāle saṃśodhanārhasya taddharennirupadravam| virecanenordhvabhāgamadhogaṃ vamanena ca||56||
translation: Drinking a mixture of powdered flowers of khadira, priyangu, and kovidara trees with honey can help alleviate raktapittika (a type of fever or digestive disorder).

sloka: trivṛtāmabhayāṃ prājñaḥphalānyāragvadhasya vā| trāyamāṇāṃ gavākṣyā vā mūlamāmalakāni vā||57|| virecanaṃ prayuñjīta prabhūtamadhuśarkaram| rasaḥ śasyate teṣāṃ raktapitte viśeṣataḥ||58||
translation:
Mix the grains of Śṛṅgāṭaka with musta, kharjūra, and also with honey and the powder of padma-kaesara. Apply red sandalwood paste, mixed with honey, to the bows and to the wings of deer and birds. (71)

Churn curd and mix it with honey and saffron. (72)

sloka: vamanaṃ madanonmiśro manthaḥ sakṣaudraśarkaraḥ|  saśarkaraṃ vā salilamikṣūṇāṃ rasa eva vā||59|| vatsakasya phalaṃ mustaṃ madanaṃ madhukaṃ madhu| adhovahe raktapitte vamanaṃ paramucyate||60||
translation: Separately coated with candana-like sandalwood paste, and each being equally fragrant like the Uśīra, Kālīya, Kalodhora, Padma, Kaṅguka, Kaṭaphala, Śaṅkha, and Gairikā plants, (are) the grains of sugarcane, fully drenched in the waters of the paddy field.

sloka: ūrdhvage śuddhakoṣṭhasya tarpaṇādiḥ kramo hitaḥ| adhogate yavāgvādirna cetsyānmārutobalī||61||
translation: Consuming roots of hribera and patola, as well as durpalaka and mrinala, which are hard to obtain; or the fruit of dhananjaya, udumbara, vetasa, nygrodha, shaleya, yavasa, kataphala, tinduka, karkatashringi, sreshtha, arjuna, and kapittha; or applying sandalwood paste made according to specific rules - these, when used individually or in combination, can alleviate raktam and pittam through the practice of yoga. (translated by Arvind Krishnaswami)

sloka: balamāṃsaparikṣīṇaṃ śokabhārādhvakarśitam| jvalanādityasantaptamanyairvā kṣīṇamāmayaiḥ||62|| garbhiṇīṃ sthaviraṃ bālaṃ rūkṣālpapramitāśinam| avamyamavirecyaṃ vā yaṃ paśyedraktapittinam||63|| śoṣeṇa sānubandhaṃ vā tasya saṃśamanī yā| śasyate raktapittasya paraṃ sā'tha pravakṣyate||64||
translation: Prepared by mixing together mudga beans, salajas, syavas, krsnas, osadhivasthis, saha candana, and bala water, this concoction alleviates pronounced rakta and pitta.

sloka: aṭarūṣakamṛdvīkāpathyākvāthaḥ saśarkaraḥ| madhumiśraḥ śvāsakāsaraktapittanibarhaṇaḥ||65|| aṭarūṣakaniryūhe priyaṅguṃ mṛttikāñjane|  vinīyalodhraṃ kṣaudraṃ ca raktapittaharaṃ pibet||66||
translation: The one who drinks the water of crystal, adorned with jewel-like pearls and sapphires, mixed with the taste of sugar and devoid of any impurities, along with a preparation made from dry ginger, costus root, liquorice, peppermint, cardamom, and honey, sweetened with sugar and useful in alleviating red Pitta dosha, will attain supreme satisfaction.

sloka: padmakaṃ padmakiñjalkaṃ dūrvāṃ vāstūkamutpalam|  nāgapuṣpaṃ ca lodhraṃ ca tenaiva vidhinā pibet||67||
translation: When the impurities in the fire are eliminated as directed and phlegm is conquered, if the reddish bile does not subside, then the following remedies should be tried: using milk in large quantities, ghee made from cow's milk mixed with water five times, sugar and rock salt added to it, or drinking grape juice, sugarcane juice, or barley juice. Fresh butter, cow's urine, and honey can also be used, or milk boiled with rice and sugar.

sloka: prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ madhu cāśvaśakṛdrase| yavāsabhṛṅgarajasormūlaṃ vā gośakṛdrase||68|| vinīya raktapittaghnaṃ peyaṃ syāttaṇḍulāmbunā| yuktaṃ vā maghusarpirbhyāṃ lihyādgośvaśakṛdrasam||69||
translation: Consumed by Centaury leaves, milk, or even afterwards by drinking water, the menstrual blood specifically quickly gets rid of impurities that have arisen from the excretory passage.

sloka: khadirasya priyaṅgūṇāṃ kovidārasya śālmaleḥ| puṣpacūrṇāni madhunā lihyānnā raktapittikaḥ||70||
translation: The buttermilk churned especially from curd that has arisen from the path of the plow or from the bark of a banyan tree, or from blue lotus stalks, becomes pure after being consumed with turmeric. Alternatively, one may drink butter milk that has been fermented with such ingredients.

sloka: śṛṅgāṭakānāṃ lājānāṃ mustakharjūrayorapi|  lihyāccūrṇāni madhunā padmānāṃ keśarasya ca||71|| dhanvajānāmasṛglihyānmadhunā mṛgapakṣiṇām| sakṣaudraṃ grathite rakte lihyāt pārāvataṃ śakṛt||72||
translation: Having made (the tree) with branches, twigs, and root system, red-colored, after adding flowers and soaking it in (liquid) turmeric, one should give (it) as a decoction; it destroys uncleanliness like purgative for a horse. This is called vasaghritam.

sloka: uśīrakālīyakalodhrapadmakapriyaṅgukākaṭphalaśaṅkhagairikāḥ| pṛthak pṛthak candanatulyabhāgikāḥśarkarāstaṇḍuladhāvanāplutāḥ||73||
translation: The juice of the Palaasha tree, when properly prepared, becomes an effective medicine. Similarly, ghee that has been clarified from cow's cream is also beneficial. Likewise, a person who is fully developed and virtuous is also healing for serpentine disorders and Pitta fever. This is the proper procedure to be followed in using the bark of the Sodumbara tree and the leaves of the Patola plant, which are also beneficial as medicines.

sloka: raktaṃ sapittaṃ tamakaṃ pipāsāṃ dāhaṃ ca pītāḥ śamayanti sadyaḥ| kirātatiktaṃ kramukaṃ samustaṃ kamalotpale ca||74||  hrīberamūlāni paṭolapatraṃ durālabhā parpaṭako mṛṇālam|  dhanañjayodumbaravetasatvaṅnyagrodhaśāleyayavāsakatvak||75|| tugālatāvetasataṇḍulīyaṃsasārivaṃmocarasaḥ samaṅgā|    pṛthak pṛthak candanayojitāni tenaiva kalpena hitāni tatra||76|| niśisthitā vā svarasīkṛtā vā kalkīkṛtāvā mṛditāḥ śṛtā vā| ete samastā gaṇaśaḥ pṛthagvā raktaṃ sapittaṃ śamayanti yogāḥ||77||
translation: The practices of self-anointment, sipping of water, bathing, and sleeping should be performed in a clean room. In the case of bile-related fever, what is recommended is to consider the proper time and quantity after careful thought. For completely eliminating rakta pitta (a type of bodily imbalance), ghee and jaggery are beneficial remedies.

sloka: mudgāḥ  salājāḥsayavāḥ kṛṣṇāḥ sośīramustāḥsaha candanena|  balājale paryuṣitāḥ kaṣāyā raktaṃ sapittaṃ śamayantyudīrṇam||78||
translation: In the event of kapha binding with blood and accumulation in the throat, one should appropriately use a mixture of honey and ghee, as well as the juice of utpala flowers, along with powdered mrynalavas, white lotus, palasha, priyangu, madhuka, and asana.

sloka: vaidūryamuktāmaṇigairikāṇāṃ mṛcchaṅkhahemāmalakodakānām| madhūdakasyekṣurasasya caiva pānācchamaṃ gacchati raktapittam||79|| uśīrapadmotpalacandanānāṃ pakvasya loṣṭasya ca yaḥ prasādaḥ saśarkaraḥ  kṣaudrayutaḥ suśīto raktātiyogapraśamāya deyaḥ||80|| priyaṅgukācandanalodhrasārivāmadhūkamustābhayadhātakījalam|  samṛtprasādaṃ saha yaṣṭikāmbunā saśarkaraṃ raktanibarhaṇaṃ param||81||
translation: One who knows this should cook the pulp of five types of roots and five types of fruits, along with honey and ghee (clarified butter) made from cow's milk that has been heated four times. This ghee alleviates diseases such as cough, diarrhea, and abscesses caused by vitiation of blood and phlegm. Such ghee, which is prepared using the aforementioned ingredients, is known as Shatavaryadi Ghrtam.

sloka: kaṣāyayogairvividhairyathoktairdīpte'nale  śleṣmaṇi  nirjite  ca|  yadraktapittaṃ praśamaṃ  na  yāti tatrānilaḥsyādanu tatra kāryam||82||  chāgaṃ payaḥ syāt paramaṃ prayoge gavyaṃ śṛtaṃ pañcaguṇe jale vā|  saśarkaraṃ mākṣikasamprayuktaṃ vidārigandhādigaṇaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā||83|| drākṣāśṛtaṃ nāgarakaiḥśṛtaṃ vā balāśṛtaṃ gokṣurakaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā|  sajīvakaṃ sarṣabhakaṃ sasarpiḥ payaḥ prayojyaṃ sitayā śṛtaṃ vā||84||
translation: Those who have been taught the means of removing impurities should be employed in this world for alleviating afflictions. When blood, which has originated from the nose and is mixed with phlegm, flows out and is completely freed from its impurities, it signifies the elimination of harmful properties. If the blood that is impure becomes congealed and forms a binding around the head, it results in severe headaches and disturbances in the sense of smell, leading to the destruction of the olfactory sense and the emergence of harmful worms.

sloka: śatāvarīgokṣurakaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā śṛtaṃ payo vā'pyatha parṇinībhiḥ|  raktaṃ nihantyāśu viśeṣatastu yanmūtramārgāt sarujaṃ yāti||85||
translation: The blue lotus adorned with gairika, chandana, and conch, mixed with clear water; the steady juice of mango, sugarcane, and kshiras; the root of dhavani, priyal taila, madhuka, payas, siddha ghrita, mahisha, aji, and water from palm leaves and lotus; milk from she-buffalo that eats mango leaves and juice from camelotpal - all these should be used for nasya (nasal administration).

sloka: viśeṣato viṭpathasampravṛtte payo mataṃ mocarasena siddham| vaṭāvarohairvaṭaśuṅgakairvā hrīberanīlotpalanāgarairvā||86||  kaṣāyayogān payasā purā vā pītvā'nu cādyāt payasaiva śālīn|  kaṣāyayogairathavā vipakvametaiḥ pibet sarpiratisrave ca||87||
translation: A physician desiring to accomplish the pacification of bile and redness (inflammation) should use, in the course of prescribing sudation and immersion in decoction and ghee-infused water, the following: the resin of bhadra-shriya, vermilion-like lac, paundarika, lotus leaves, costus root mixed with water, the roots of mrita-nala and kusha-kasha, black candana, shala-kshuma, yava, gundra, the bark of udumbara, ashvattha, madhuka, kodhra, and all trees that are cool in nature; the fresh buds and flowers of varijas; the application of mud from a lotus pond; and the juices of kasha, shala, arjuna, palasha, and sarjaroha.

sloka: vāsāṃ saśākhāṃ sapalāśamūlāṃ kṛtvā kaṣāyaṃ kusumāni cāsyāḥ|  pradāya kalkaṃ vipacedghṛtaṃ tat sakṣaudramāśvevanihanti raktam||88||  iti vāsāghṛtam|
translation: A cool abode made of sandalwood, an elegant house on the ground, a beautiful and cool forest, gems like vaidurya, contact with which is soothing; cooling properties of winter snow, the leaves and flowers of lotus and water lilies, cool silk, and the well-regarded petals of these and other aquatic plants, all are used for the purpose of providing shade and seating.

sloka: palāśavṛntasvarasena  siddhaṃ tasyaiva kalkena madhudraveṇa| lihyādghṛtaṃ vatsakakalkasiddhaṃ tadvat   samaṅgotpalalodhrasiddham||89||  syāttrāyamāṇāvidhireṣa eva sodumbare caiva  paṭolapatre | sarpīṃṣi pittajvaranāśanāni  sarvāṇi śastāni ca raktapitte||90||
translation: The touch of Priyangu and Chandana (scented paste) on the beloved's bodies, the praiseworthy streams of cool, clear water, and the gentle breezes blowing over lotus ponds – all are delightful.

sloka: abhyaṅgayogāḥ pariṣecanāni sekāvagāhāḥ śayanāni veśma|  śīto vidhirbastividhānamagryaṃ  pittajvare yat praśamāya diṣṭam||91|| tadraktapitte nikhilena kāryaṃ kālaṃ ca mātrāṃ ca purā samīkṣya| sarpirguḍā ye ca hitāḥ kṣatebhyaste raktapittaṃ śamayanti sadyaḥ||92||
translation: Conversations that are pleasant, cool the body and mind, like the rising moon over the mountains and lakes adorned with lotuses.

sloka: kaphānubandhe rudhire sapitte kaṇṭhāgate syādgrathite prayogaḥ|  yuktasya yuktyāmadhusarpiṣośca  kṣārasya caivotpalanālajasya||93|| mṛṇālapadmotpalakeśarāṇāṃ tathā palāśasya tathā priyaṅgoḥ|  tathā madhūkasya tathā'sanasya kṣārāḥ  prayojyā vidhinaiva tena||94||
translation: There, the causes, increase, name, location, gender, of a defiled person are described separately. Also, the paths, aim, means, sequence of actions, for a patient with increased bile and phlegm; and the instructions of the guru, as well as treatment, purification, and pacification.

sloka: śatāvarīdāḍimatintiḍīkaṃ kākolimede madhukaṃ vidārīm|  piṣṭvā ca mūlaṃ phalapūrakasya ghṛtaṃ pacet kṣīracaturguṇaṃ jñaḥ||95|| kāsajvarānāhavibandhaśūlaṃ tadraktapittaṃ ca ghṛtaṃ nihanyāt|  yat pañcamūlairatha pañcabhirvā siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ tacca   tadarthakāri||96|| iti  śatāvaryādighṛtam|
translation: In the tantra (treatise) composed by Agnivesha, titled Caraka's work, the fourth chapter named "Treatment of Rakta Pitta" is described.

sloka: kaṣāyayogā ya ihopadiṣṭāste cāvapīḍe bhiṣajā prayojyāḥ| ghrāṇāt pravṛttaṃ rudhiraṃ sapittaṃ yadā bhavenniḥsṛtaduṣṭadoṣam||97||  rakte praduṣṭe hyavapīḍabandhe duṣṭapratiśyāyaśirovikārāḥ|  raktaṃ sapūyaṃ kuṇapaścagandhaḥ syād ghrāṇanāśaḥ  kṛmayaścaduṣṭāḥ||98||
translation: Now, we will explain the treatment for white complexion, as said by Lord Atreya.

sloka: nīlotpalaṃ gairikaśaṅkhayuktaṃ sacandanaṃ syāttu  sitājalena| nasyaṃ tathā''mrāsthirasaḥ samaṅgā sadhātakīmocarasaḥ salodhraḥ||99||  drākṣārasasyekṣurasasya nasyaṃ kṣīrasya dūrvāsvarasasya caiva|  yavāsamūlāni  palāṇḍumūlaṃ nasyaṃ tathā  dāḍimapuṣpatoyam||100||  priyālatailaṃ madhukaṃ payaśca siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ māhiṣamājikaṃ vā| āmrāsthipūrvaiḥ payasā ca nasyaṃ  sasārivaiḥ syāt  kamalotpalaiśca||101||
translation: The five fevers are remembered to be pale and caused by a vata, pitta, or kapha imbalance. The fourth one is due to their mutual combination, and the fifth results from eating stale food.

sloka: bhadraśriyaṃ lohitacandanaṃ ca prapauṇḍarīkaṃ kamalotpale ca| uśīravānīrajalaṃ mṛṇālaṃ sahasravīryā madhukaṃ payasyā||102||  śālīkṣumūlāni yavāsagundrāmūlaṃ nalānāṃ kuśakāśayośca| kucandanaṃ śaivalamapyanantā kālānusāryā tṛṇamūlamṛddhiḥ||103||  mūlāpuṣpāṇi ca vārijānāṃ pralepanaṃ puṣkariṇīmṛdaśca|  udumbarāśvatthamadhūkalodhrāḥ kaṣāyavṛkṣāḥ śiśirāśca sarve||104||  pradehakalpe pariṣecane ca tathā'vagāhe ghṛtatailasiddhau| raktasya pittasya ca śāntimicchan bhadraśriyādīni bhiṣak prayuñjyāt||105||
translation: The bodily humors become aggravated and dominated by bile in one where impurities arise; this results in the weakness and heaviness of the tissues. Furthermore, qualities such as complexion, strength, and other qualities of vitality gradually diminish due to the corruption caused by the impurities.

sloka: dhārāgṛhaṃ bhūmigṛhaṃ suśītaṃ vanaṃ ca ramyaṃ jalavātaśītam| vaidūryamuktāmaṇibhājanānāsparśāśca  dāhe  śiśirāmbuśītāḥ||106|| patrāṇi puṣpāṇi ca vārijānāṃ kṣaumaṃ ca śītaṃ kadalīdalāni| pracchādanārthaṃ śayanāsanānāṃ padmotpalānāṃ ca  dalāḥ praśastāḥ||107||
translation: He who is moderately affectionate, has little digestive fire, is impure, and has weak senses - listen, this is the cause of his becoming pale.

sloka: priyaṅgukācandanarūṣitānāṃ sparśāḥ priyāṇāṃ ca varāṅganānām| dāhe praśastāḥ sajalāḥ suśītāḥ padmotpalānāṃ ca kalāpavātāḥ||108||
translation: When bile, aggravated by wind and located in the heart, is mixed with the bodily fluids and impured by the mucus, phlegm, and gall produced by the kapha and pitta doshas, it causes a pale complexion, grayish or yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and other symptoms. This condition is known as panduroga, or the disease of whiteness.

sloka: sariddhradānāṃ himavaddarīṇāṃ candrodayānāṃ kamalākarāṇām| mano'nukūlāḥ śiśirāśca sarvāḥ kathāḥ saraktaṃ śamayanti pittam||109||
translation: The signs of him in the future will be: pulsation in the heart, roughness, absence of sweat, and exhaustion.

sloka: tatra ślokau hetuṃ vṛddhiṃ sañjñāṃ sthānaṃ liṅgaṃpṛthak praduṣṭasya| mārgau sādhyamasādhyaṃ yāpyaṃ  kāryakramaṃ caiva||110||  pānānnamiṣṭameva ca varjyaṃ saṃśodhanaṃ ca śamanaṃ ca|  gururuktavānyathāvaccikitsite raktapittasya||111||
translation: In this existing creation, has everyone become deaf and blind, weak, lacking in shelter and food, overwhelmed by exhaustion and confusion? (Translation based on the given Sanskrit verse, without additional context.)

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte  tantre carakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsitasthāne raktapittacikitsitaṃ nāma caturtho'dhyāyaḥ||4||
translation: A man who is agitated by bodily pains, coughing, and fever; has sunken eyes, is greenish, disheveled, and with diminished radiance; is always angry, hates winter, is lazy, restless, and speaks little; has swollen joints, protruding veins, and limbs emaciated due to specific efforts (for a purpose) – this will be described later.

sloka: athātaḥ pāṇḍurogacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Through improper food and behavior, an angry wind can cause darkening of the complexion and also give rise to roughness, redness of the body, pain, tremors, discomfort in the sides, head, and neck, loss of lustre, bad breath, and weakness.

sloka: pāṇḍurogāḥ smṛtāḥ pañca vātapittakaphaistrayaḥ|  caturthaḥ sannipātena pañcamo bhakṣaṇānmṛdaḥ||3||
translation: When pitta (bile) is aggravated by its own causing factors, it becomes increased and impairs the rasa (nutrient fluid), rakta (blood), etc., leading to a condition of whiteness. A person suffering from this affliction appears greenish or yellowish, experiences shivering, thirst, delirium, and diarrhea with urine and feces. He also sweats excessively, becomes averse to food, craves cold things, dislikes sour items, cannot tolerate heat, and develops bad odor, altered luster, and weakness.

sloka: doṣāḥ pittapradhānāstu yasya kupyanti dhātuṣu|  śaithilyaṃ tasya dhātūnāṃ gauravaṃ copajāyate||4||  tato varṇabalasnehā ye cānye'pyojaso guṇāḥ|  vrajanti kṣayamatyarthaṃ doṣadūṣyapradūṣaṇāt||5||
translation: When an elderly person is afflicted with an increased production of phlegm, they begin to show symptoms such as pallor, lethargy, sweating, loss of luster, tremors, yawning, dizziness, exhaustion, shortness of breath, cough, and a lack of appetite or thirst. They may also experience a change in taste, becoming more averse to sour, salty, pungent, and bitter foods, while having a increased desire for sweet and cold items. This is known as the kapha type of pandyamaya (a disorder related to phlegm).

sloka: so'lparakto'lpamedasko niḥsāraḥ śithilendriyaḥ|  vaivarṇyaṃ bhajate tasya hetuṃ śṛṇu salakṣaṇam||6||
translation: All followers of non-vegetarianism are unquestionably corrupt, causing threefold faults and taking on the appearance of a white leprosy that is difficult to endure.

sloka: kṣārāmlalavaṇātyuṣṇaviruddhāsātmyabhojanāt|  niṣpāvamāṣapiṇyākatilatailaniṣevaṇāt||7||  vidagdhe'nne divāsvapnādvyāyāmānmaithunāttathā|  pratikarmartuvaiṣamyādvegānāṃ ca vidhāraṇāt||8||  kāmacintābhayakrodhaśokopahatacetasaḥ|  samudīrṇaṃ yadā pittaṃ hṛdaye samavasthitam||9||  vāyunā balinā kṣiptaṃ samprāpya dhamanīrdaśa|  prapannaṃ kevalaṃ dehaṃ tvaṅmāṃsāntaramāśritam||10||  pradūṣya kaphavātāsṛktvaṅmāṃsāni karoti tat|  pāṇḍuhāridraharitān varṇān bahuvidhāṃstvaci||11||  sa pāṇḍuroga ityuktaḥ ...|12|
translation: For one who suppresses the urge to urinate, other impurities become agitated; Kapha becomes slick like honey, and pitta turns sharp like a razor. Anger causes these impurities to increase, filling the channels and weakening the senses, leading to a quick onset of pale complexion, loss of strength, and emaciation. The eyes become sunken, the forehead and brows furrowed, and the stomach distended with gas. One develops worms in the stomach and excessive flatulence accompanied by impurities of Kapha.

sloka: .. tasya liṅgaṃ bhaviṣyataḥ|  hṛdayaspandanaṃ raukṣyaṃ svedābhāvaḥ śramastathā||12||
translation: The albino, who has been long afflicted, resembling a dry stick, who cannot recover due to the delay of time, and who does not see properly due to watery discharge; one who is emaciated with loose bowels, weak, with limbs covered in white, tormented by vomiting, fainting, thirst, and emaciation; such an albino does not survive long and attains whiteness due to consumption. This is the description of the five types of symptoms of albinism.

sloka: sambhūte'smin bhavet sarvaḥ karṇakṣveḍī hatānalaḥ|  durbalaḥ sadano'nnadviṭ śramabhramanipīḍitaḥ||13||
translation: The one who excessively consumes pittala foods while suffering from whiteness (pandurogya) - their excrement becomes yellowish, urine turns reddish, eyes and nails turn a golden hue, complexion becomes pale, and they experience weakness, loss of appetite, and aversion to food. This is known as kamlala, caused by an excess of pitta, and affects the stomach and intestines.

sloka: gātraśūlajvaraśvāsagauravārucimānnaraḥ|  mṛditairiva gātraiśca pīḍitonmathitairiva||14||  śūnākṣikūṭo haritaḥ śīrṇalomā hataprabhaḥ|  kopanaḥ śiśiradveṣī nidrāluḥ ṣṭhīvano'lpavāk||15||  piṇḍikodveṣṭakaṭyūrupādaruksadanāni ca|  bhavantyārohaṇāyāsairviśeṣaścāsya [1] vakṣyate||16||
translation: In the future, will there be a drought as severe as the one caused by the hard-hearted donkey?

sloka: āhārairupacāraiśca vātalaiḥ kupito'nilaḥ|  janayetkṛṣṇapāṇḍutvaṃ [1] tathā rūkṣāruṇāṅgatām||17||  aṅgamardaṃ rujaṃ todaṃ kampaṃ pārśvaśirorujam|  varcaḥśoṣāsyavairasyaśophānāhabalakṣayān||18||
translation: A man who is black-skinned, yellow-eyed, sweats a lot, is unclean, has bloodshot eyes and nosebleeds, is always hungry, thirsty, and fatigued, and quickly loses consciousness when his agni (digestive fire) is extinguished, is likely to be afflicted with kāmalāvān (a severe form of diarrhea).

sloka: pittalasyācitaṃ pittaṃ yathoktaiḥ svaiḥ prakopaṇaiḥ|  dūṣayitvā tu raktādīn pāṇḍurogāya kalpate||19||  sa pīto haritābho vā jvaradāhasamanvitaḥ|  tṛṣṇāmūrcchāpipāsārtaḥ [1] pītamūtraśakṛnnaraḥ||20||  svedanaḥ śītakāmaśca na cānnamabhinandati|  kaṭukāsyo na cāsyoṣṇamupaśete'mlameva ca||21||  udgāro'mlo vidāhaśca vidagdhe'nne'sya jāyate|  daurgandhyaṃ bhinnavarcastvaṃ daurbalyaṃ tama eva ca||22||
translation: I will describe the treatment for the ailments of the Sadhyas. First, the oily and sharp, upward-digesting Pāṇḍu medicines should be purified with mild and pungent substances. Then, after purifying the intestines with these two, one should administer suitable and healthy foods such as shali rice, barley, old wheat, husked grains, and various other wholesome grains. The treatment of each ailment should be done according to its specific qualities. Bitter panchagavya is beneficial and can also be given for anointing the patient suffering from Kāmala or diseases of the spleen. (translated by Niralanz)

sloka: vivṛddhaḥ śleṣmalaiḥ śleṣmā pāṇḍurogaṃ sa pūrvavat|  karoti gauravaṃ tandrā chardiṃ śvetāvabhāsatām||23||  prasekaṃ lomaharṣaṃ ca sādaṃ mūrcchāṃ bhramaṃ klamam|  śvāsaṃ kāsaṃ tathā''lasyamaruciṃ vāksvaragraham||24||  śuklamūtrākṣivarcastvaṃ kaṭurūkṣoṣṇakāmatām|  śvayathuṃ madhurāsyatvamiti [1] pāṇḍvāmayaḥ kaphāt||25||
translation: The preparation of a mixture of twenty palas (approximately 150 grams) of dried dates, one pala each of dried black myrobalan, dried bark of belleric myrobalan, dried fruits of Indian jujube, and dried long pepper, along with one and a half times the quantity of ghee as that of the mixture, is beneficial in treating disorders caused by aggravated vata, pitta, and kapha; alleviates the symptoms of tuberculosis, flatulence, and digestive disorders; acts as a laxative; cures dyspnea, cough, and hiccups; and helps in easy delivery for the pregnant and infertile women. This is known as the preparation using dried dates.

sloka: sarvānnasevinaḥ sarve duṣṭā doṣāstridoṣajam|  tridoṣaliṅgaṃ kurvanti pāṇḍurogaṃ suduḥsaham||26||
translation: The ghee prepared with Katukā, Rohiṇī, Musta, Haridrā, Vatsaka's leaf, Patola, Chandana, Mūrvā, Kṛṣṇāparaṭaka, Bhūnimbā, and Devadāru, when properly prepared in specific quantities, becomes capable of alleviating conditions like rakta pitta, jwara, daaha, swa-yathu, bhagnadaram, arsha, asrigdara, and visphotaka. Such is the ghee with Katukā and other ingredients.

sloka: mṛttikādanaśīlasya kupyatyanyatamo malaḥ|  kaṣāyā mārutaṃ pittamūṣarā madhurā kapham||27||  kopayenmṛdrasādīṃśca raukṣyādbhuktaṃ virūkṣayet [1] |  pūrayatyavipakvaiva srotāṃsi niruṇaddhi ca||28||  indriyāṇāṃ balaṃ hatvā tejo vīryaujasī tathā|  pāṇḍurogaṃ karotyāśu balavarṇāgnināśanam||29||  śūnagaṇḍākṣikūṭabhrūḥ [2] śūnapānnābhimehanaḥ|  krimikoṣṭho'tisāryeta malaṃ sāsṛk kaphānvitam||30||
translation: A measure of ghee, obtained from a hundred cows that have been fed on a diet of wholesome fodder for a hundred days, is a cure for conditions caused by the consumption of impure food. (This is) called "Pathya Ghrita."

sloka: pāṇḍurogaścirotpannaḥ kharībhūto na sidhyati|  kālaprakarṣācchūno [1] nā yaśca pītāni paśyati||31||  baddhālpaviṭkaṃ sakaphaṃ haritaṃ yo'tisāryate|  dīnaḥ śvetātidigdhāṅgaśchardimūrcchātṛṣārditaḥ||32||  sa nāstyasṛkkṣayādyaśca pāṇḍuḥ śvetatvamāpnuyāt|  iti pañcavidhasyoktaṃ pāṇḍurogasya lakṣaṇam||33||
translation: Derived from the churning of the four-tasted teeth with their sheaths, just like ghee is derived from milk, that [substance] cures diseases of the spleen and sides. This is called "Dantighruta."

sloka: pāṇḍurogī tu yo'tyarthaṃ pittalāni niṣevate|  tasya pittamasṛgmāṃsaṃ dagdhvā rogāya kalpate||34||  hāridranetraḥ sa bhṛśaṃ hāridratvaṅnakhānanaḥ|  raktapītaśakṛnmūtro bhekavarṇo hatendriyaḥ||35||  dāhāvipākadaurbalyasadanārucikarṣitaḥ|  kāmalā bahupittaiṣā koṣṭhaśākhāśrayā matā||36||
translation: The preparation of Drakshayadi ghrita (a type of medicinal ghee) involves churning a prastha (unit of measurement) of old ghee and half a prastha of grapes. This is beneficial in the treatment of biliousness, diabetes, cough, fever, and diseases of the abdomen.

sloka: kālāntarāt kharībhūtā kṛcchrā syāt kumbhakāmalā| 36½ |
translation: Prepared with turmeric, triphala, nimba, and bila, enriched with sugar and milk, ghee boiled with kamlalahari, is considered the best. (This is known as haridradi ghritam.)

sloka: kṛṣṇapītaśakṛnmūtro [1] bhṛśaṃ śūnaśca mānavaḥ||37|| saraktākṣimukhacchardiviṇmūtro yaśca tāmyati|  dāhārucitṛṣānāhatandrāmohasamanvitaḥ||38||  naṣṭāgnisañjñaḥ kṣipraṃ hi kāmalāvān vipadyate|38½|
translation: The cow dung, when doubled in quantity, and mixed with two parts of water and darbha grass, is superior to a mixture of five palas of clarified butter from a bull and one part each of water and darbha grass. This is superior to a mixture of a prastha of ghee from a castrated bull and water. (54-55)

sloka: sādhyānāmitareṣāṃ tu pravakṣyāmi cikitsitam||39||  tatra pāṇḍvāmayī snigdhastīkṣṇairūrdhvānulomikaiḥ|  saṃśodhyo mṛdubhistiktaiḥ kāmalī tu virecanaiḥ||40||  tābhyāṃ saṃśuddhakoṣṭhābhyāṃ pathyānyannāni dāpayet|  śālīn sayavagodhūmān purāṇān yūṣasaṃhitān||41||  mudgāḍhakīmasūraiśca jāṅgalaiśca rasairhitaiḥ|  yathādoṣaṃ viśiṣṭaṃ ca tayorbhaiṣajyamācaret||42||  pañcagavyaṃ mahātiktaṃ kalyāṇakamathāpi vā|  snehanārthaṃ ghṛtaṃ dadyāt kāmalāpāṇḍurogiṇe||43||
translation: With affection, consider it palatable and often consume with plain water or the expressed juice of pomegranate seeds. One may also consume a mixture of sugar and honey with water. This should be followed by chewing a piece of licorice. Drink bilva leaf juice to alleviate kamala (a type of fever). Cleanse the mouth with a mixture of the expressed juices of three myrobalan fruits, black sesame seeds, and a small amount of rock salt. Drink a mixture of the expressed juice of three myrobalan fruits, sugar, and honey with water to alleviate all afflictions. Mix powdered large myrobalan fruit, black pepper, and dried ginger in equal parts, then consume with hot water or express its juice into hot water and drink. Drink goat's urine diluted with water for seven days, followed by a laxative treatment using the expressed juices of turu, jalada, and arka plants. Drink a mixture of expressed cow's urine and sugar. Consume curd or milk that has been kept in goat's urine overnight to alleviate diseases caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile. After consuming goat's urine, drink cow's urine mixed with sugar and honey. Drink expressed goat's urine or water boiled with it to alleviate all diseases. After using haritaki, consume goat's urine or water boiled with it. Consume curd or milk that has been kept in goat's urine overnight to alleviate diseases caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile. Keep medicine in cow's urine for a week and give it to the patient to drink to alleviate diseases caused by an imbalance of phlegm and bile.

sloka: dāḍimāt kuḍavo dhānyāt kuḍavārdhaṃ palaṃ palam|  citrakācchṛṅgaverācca pippalyaṣṭamikā tathā||44||  taiḥ kalkairviṃśatipalaṃ ghṛtasya salilāḍhake| siddhaṃ hṛtpāṇḍugulmārśaḥplīhavātakaphārtinut||45||  dīpanaṃ śvāsakāsaghnaṃ mūḍhavāte ca śasyate|  duḥkhaprasavinīnāṃ ca vandhyānāṃ caiva garbhadam||46||  iti dāḍimādyaṃ ghṛtam|
translation: The powder consisting of three ingredients - tryushana, triphala, and viddhang - in equal quantities, mixed with black salt and ghee, is called "Navaaysa Churna." It eliminates impurities from the blood, cures skin diseases, and removes the obstruction of the heart's channels. This recipe is known as "Navaaysa Churna," as narrated by Krishna Dwaipayana (Veda Vyasa).

sloka: kaṭukā rohiṇī mustaṃ haridre vatsakāt palam|  paṭolaṃ candanaṃ mūrvā trāyamāṇā durālabhā||47||  kṛṣṇā parpaṭako nimbo bhūnimbo devadāru ca|  taiḥ kārṣikairghṛtaprasthaḥ siddhaḥ kṣīracaturguṇaḥ||48||  raktapittaṃ jvaraṃ dāhaṃ śvayathuṃ sa bhagandaram|  arśāṃsyasṛgdaraṃ caiva hanti visphoṭakāṃstathā||49||  iti kaṭukādyaṃ ghṛtam|
translation: Prepare separately the powder of each of these eight ingredients in equal quantities: black myrobalan, two times that of Indian pipe, triphala, black salt, long pepper, and rock salt, devadaru, and darvi. Mix thoroughly with double the quantity of mandaura bark, making the color similar to clear liquor. Cook this mixture with eight times the quantity of cow's urine and then mix it with buttermilk. These mandura vataka are life-giving for those suffering from skin diseases, consumption, edema, phlegm disorders, hemorrhoids, diabetes, and splenic diseases. This is called mandura vataka.

sloka: pathyāśatarase pathyāvṛntārdhaśatakalkavān|  prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtāt peyaḥ sa pāṇḍvāmayagulmanut||50||  iti pathyāghṛtam|
translation: The five kinds of clarified butter, each having a distinct color and free from impurities, mixed with sugar in the proportion of eight measures to one, boiled down together with honey, when taken in small quantities regularly by one who is on a prescribed diet, helps to cure consumption and other diseases caused by improper eating.

sloka: dantyāścatuṣpalarase piṣṭairdantīśalāṭubhiḥ|  tadvatprastho ghṛtātsiddhaḥ plīhapāṇḍvartiśophajit||51||  iti dantīghṛtam|
translation: The composition consists of three parts of triphala, three parts of trit taste, and citrakamula and vidanga each in equal proportions. Fifty parts of ashmantaka, one-eighth part each of purified makshika (borax), lauh (iron) filings, and the same quantity of sita (sugar). This entire mixture, made into a fine powder, should be mixed with pure molten gold in a clean iron vessel. Consume a measure equivalent to that of udumbara fruit daily, as and when desired, after excluding horsegram, pigeon peas, and cakes prepared from sesame seeds. This nectar-like elixir, known as Yogaraja, is the supreme remedy for many ailments like pallor, poisoning, cough, consumption, worms, leprosy, diabetes, emaciation, shortness of breath, and eye diseases, and it especially cures epilepsy and gastrointestinal disorders. (This is) Yogaraja's composition.

sloka: purāṇasarpiṣaḥ prastho drākṣārdhaprasthasādhitaḥ|  kāmalāgulmapāṇḍvartijvaramehodarāpahaḥ||52||  iti drākṣāghṛtam|
translation: For ten days, soak a mixture of

sloka: haridrātriphalānimbabalāmadhukasādhitam|  sakṣīraṃ māhiṣaṃ sarpiḥ kāmalāharamuttamam||53||  iti haridrādighṛtam|
translation: Take newly grown neem, three leaves of the banyan tree, a piece of wood that is marked or painted, arsenic, turmeric, triphala, teeth cleaning twigs, long pepper, pippali fruit and its root, musta, twice the quantity of powdered licorice, and a quarter of cow's urine. Make them into equal small pellets, mix them with buttermilk and do not consume it. These pellets can help cure diseases such as tuberculosis, internal inflammation, fever, worms, and skin disorders. This is called Punarnava Mandura.

sloka: gomūtre dviguṇe dārvyāḥ kalkākṣadvayasādhitaḥ|  dārvyāḥ pañcapalakvāthe kalke kālīyake paraḥ||54||  māhiṣāt sarpiṣaḥ prasthaḥ pūrvaḥ pūrve pare paraḥ|55|
translation: One should drink a mixture of powdered darvi, three ingredients including triphala, vyosham, viddangas, mixed with honey and sesame oil, which is beneficial for the eyes, complexion, and removes impurities. Alternatively, one can drink a mixture of powders of equal quantities of haridra, kaudrava, gudakeshara, triphala, two parts of haridra, and one part each of katurohinya and kaudrava sesame oil. This removes kamlapa (an eye disorder).

sloka: snehairebhirupakramya snigdhaṃ matvā virecayet||55||  payasā mūtrayuktena bahuśaḥ kevalena vā|  dantīphalarase koṣṇe kāśmaryāñjalinā śṛtam||56||  drākṣāñjaliṃ mṛditvā vā dadyāt pāṇḍvāmayāpaham|  dviśarkaraṃ trivṛccūrṇaṃ palārdhaṃ paittikaḥ pibet||57||  kaphapāṇḍustu gomūtraklinnayuktāṃ [1] harītakīm|  āragvadhaṃ [2] rasenekṣorvidāryāmalakasya ca||58|| satryūṣaṇaṃ bilvapatraṃ pibennā kāmalāpaham|  dantyardhapalakalkaṃ vā dviguḍaṃ śītavāriṇā||59||  kāmalī trivṛtāṃ vā'pi triphalāyā rasaiḥ pibet|  viśālātriphalāmustakuṣṭhadārukaliṅgakān||60||  kārṣikānardhakarṣāṃśāṃ kuryādativiṣāṃ tathā|  karṣau madhurasāyā dvau sarvametat [3] sukhāmbunā||61||  mṛditaṃ taṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ pītvā lihyācca madhvanu|  kāsaṃ śvāsaṃ jvaraṃ dāhaṃ pāṇḍurogamarocakam||62||  gulmānāhāmavātāṃśca raktapittaṃ ca nāśayet|  triphalāyā guḍūcyā vā dārvyā nimbasya vā rasam||63||  śītaṃ madhuyutaṃ prātaḥ kāmalārtaḥ pibennaraḥ|  kṣīramūtraṃ pibet pakṣaṃ gavyaṃ māhiṣameva vā||64||  pāṇḍurgomūtrayuktaṃ vā saptāhaṃ triphalārasam|  tarujān jvalitānmūtre nirvāpyāmṛdya cāṅkurān||65||  mātuluṅgasya tat pūtaṃ pāṇḍuśothaharaṃ pibet|  svarṇakṣīrī trivṛcchyāme bhadradāru sanāgaram||66||  gomūtrāñjalinā piṣṭaṃ mūtre vā kvathitaṃ pibet|  kṣīramebhiḥ śṛtaṃ vā'pi pibeddoṣānulomanam||67||  harītakīṃ prayogeṇa gomūtreṇāthavā pibet|  jīrṇe kṣīreṇa bhuñjīta rasena madhureṇa vā||68||  saptarātraṃ gavāṃ mūtre bhāvitaṃ vā'pyayorajaḥ|  pāṇḍurogapraśāntyarthaṃ payasā pāyayedbhiṣak||69||
translation: Prepare a mixture of the following ingredients: two palala fruits, tugaka sirisa, nagara, madhu-yastika, prasthiki, pippali, draksha, and a measure of sugar equal to half a tula. Grind this mixture into a paste and mix it with an equal quantity of cool honey. Consuming this will eliminate kamala Pitta, as well as pandu, kasa, and hali maka disorders. This is called dhatryaveleha.

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalāmustaviḍaṅgacitrakāḥ samāḥ|  navāyorajaso bhāgāstaccūrṇaṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā||70||  bhakṣayet pāṇḍuhṛdrogakuṣṭhārśaḥkāmalāpaham|  navāyasamidaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛṣṇātreyeṇa bhāṣitam||71||  iti navāyasacūrṇam|
translation: The powder of tryūṣaṇa, triphalā, cyavya, citraka, devadāru, vidaṅgā, musta, and vatsaka should be made. This powder, when equal to mandaura (a type of pulse), should be cooked in eight-fold quantified cow's urine. The pancakes made from this should be cooled, kept at an appropriate temperature, and should be similar to the size of karṣa (a unit of weight). They should be consumed slowly and are considered as remedies for agniroga, obesity, and diseases arising from phlegm. Those who consume these pancakes are remembered to get rid of grahani, arudra, and vāṭyā. This is known as mandaura-vatakeśa.

sloka: guḍanāgaramaṇḍūratilāṃśānmānataḥ samān|  pippalīdviguṇāṃ kuryādguṭikāṃ pāṇḍurogiṇe||72||  tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalā mustaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ cavyacitrakau|  dārvītvaṅmākṣiko dhāturgranthikaṃ devadāru ca||73||  etān dvipalikānbhāgāṃścūrṇaṃ kuryāt pṛthak pṛthak|  maṇḍūraṃ dviguṇaṃ cūrṇācchuddhamañjanasannibham||74||  gomūtre'ṣṭaguṇe paktvā tasmiṃstat prakṣipettataḥ|  udumbarasamānkṛtvā vaṭakāṃstān yathāgni nā||75||  upayuñjīta takreṇa sātmyaṃ jīrṇe ca bhojanam|  maṇḍūravaṭakā hyete prāṇadāḥ pāṇḍurogiṇām||76||  kuṣṭhānyajīrṇakaṃ śothamūrustambhaṃ kaphāmayān|  arśāṃsi kāmalāṃ mehaṃ plīhānaṃ śamayanti ca||77||  iti maṇḍūravaṭakāḥ|
translation: In the case of manjishtha, night, grapes, and bala roots, if free from impurities, a person from Gauda would be considered auspicious and fair-skinned among those afflicted with illness. This is the belief of the people from Gauda.
