sloka: tāpyādrijaturūpyāyomalāḥ pañcapalāḥ pṛthak|  citrakatriphalāvyoṣaviḍaṅgaiḥ palikaiḥ saha||78||  śarkarāṣṭapalonmiśrāścūrṇitā madhunā''plutāḥ|  abhyasyāstvakṣamātrā hi jīrṇe hitamitāśinā||79||  kulatthakākamācyādikapotaparihāriṇā|80|
translation:
Take fourteen palas of bija, twenty of triphala, five of draksha, and seven of laksha. Mix them with a drona of water. After the residue becomes pure, consume it. Use a prastha of sharkara, a karsika of makshika, vyosha, vyaghranakhooshira, kramuka, sailavaluka, madhukam, and kushta, all ground into a powder and mixed in a ghrta bhajana. In yava for ten nights during the summer and twice that in winter, this is known as Bijakarishta, which cures grahani, arsha, shotha, gulma, mutrakrichchra, ashmari, meha, and malasancharya. 
1661,धात्रीफलसहस्रे द्वे पीडयित्वा रसं तु तम्॥१११॥  क्षौद्राष्टांशेन संयुक्तं कृष्णार्धकुडवेन च।  शर्करार्धतुलोन्मिश्रं पक्षं स्निग्धघटे स्थितम्॥११२॥  प्रपिबेन्मात्रया प्रातर्जीर्णे हितमिताशनः।  कामलापाण्डुहृद्रोगवातासृग्विषमज्वरान्॥११३॥ कासहिक्कारुचिश्वासांश्चैषोऽरिष्टः प्रणाशयेत्।  इति धात्र्यरिष्टः,"By squeezing the juice of two thousand Dhatri fruits, mixed with one-eighth of Kaudra, black Ardhakudava, and half as much sugar, a person who is committed to a healthy diet should consume this mixture in the morning. It will help to cure heart diseases, diabetes, disorders of the wind, bile, and phlegm, as well as cough, fever, hiccups, and other ailments. This is known as the Dhatryarista.

sloka: triphalāyāstrayo bhāgāstrayastrikaṭukasya ca||80||  bhāgaścitrakamūlasya viḍaṅgānāṃ tathaiva ca|  pañcāśmajatuno bhāgāstathā rūpyamalasya ca||81||  mākṣikasya ca śuddhasya lauhasya rajasastathā|  aṣṭau bhāgāḥ sitāyāśca tatsarvaṃ sūkṣmacūrṇitam||82||  mākṣikeṇāplutaṃ sthāpyamāyase bhājane śubhe|  udumbarasamāṃ mātrāṃ tataḥ khādedyathāgni nā||83||  dine dine prayuñjīta jīrṇe bhojyaṃ yathepsitam|  varjayitvā kulatthāni kākamācīṃ kapotakam||84|| yogarāja iti khyāto yogo'yamamṛtopamaḥ|  rasāyanamidaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ sarvarogaharaṃ śivam||85||  pāṇḍurogaṃ viṣaṃ kāsaṃ yakṣmāṇaṃ viṣamajvaram|  kuṣṭhānyajīrṇakaṃ mehaṃ śoṣaṃ śvāsamarocakam||86||  viśeṣāddhantyapasmāraṃ kāmalāṃ gudajāni ca|  iti yogarājaḥ|
translation: Drinking water that is stable (i.e., not moving) is recommended in the mealtime; it alleviates the desires of the PANDU family (i.e., those who are afflicted by desire). The water should be smooth and clear (mridvIka mala kIrasaḥ).

sloka: kauṭajatriphalānimbapaṭolaghananāgaraiḥ||87||  bhāvitāni daśāhāni rasairdvitriguṇāni vā|  śilājatupalānyaṣṭau tāvatī sitaśarkarā||88|| tvakkṣīrī pippalī dhātrī karkaṭākhyā palonmitā|  nidigdhyāḥ phalamūlābhyāṃ palaṃ yuktyā trigandhakam|  cūrṇitaṃ madhunaḥ kuryāt tripalenākṣikān guḍān|  dāḍimāmbupayaḥpakṣirasatoyasurāsavān||90||  tān bhakṣayitvā'nupibenniranno bhukta eva vā|  pāṇḍukuṣṭhajvaraplīhatamakārśobhagandarān||91||  pūtihṛcchukramūtrāgnidoṣaśoṣagarodarān [1] |  kāsāsṛgdarapittāsṛkśothagulmagalāmayān||92||  te ca sarvavraṇān hanyuḥ sarvarogaharāḥ śivāḥ|  iti śilājatuvaṭakāḥ|
translation: This has been stated by the great sage for the purpose of achieving lightness and calmness of the body (pāṇḍurogapraśāntyartham). Doctors should consider modifying this according to the predominant dosha, such as using more oily substances in vata-related disorders, cooling and astringent substances in pitta-related disorders, and spicy and astringent substances in kapha-related disorders. In close contact with infection, a mixture of these treatments can be used.

sloka: punarnavā trivṛdvyoṣaviḍaṅgaṃ dāru citrakam||93||  kuṣṭhaṃ haridre triphalā dantī cavyaṃ kaliṅgakāḥ|  pippalī [2] pippalīmūlaṃ mustaṃ ceti palonmitam||94||  maṇḍūraṃ dviguṇaṃ cūrṇādgomūtre dvyāḍhake pacet|  kolavadguṭikāḥ kṛtvā takreṇāloḍya nā pibet||95||  tāḥ pāṇḍurogān plīhānamarśāṃsi viṣamajvaram|  śvayathuṃ grahaṇīdoṣaṃ hanyuḥ kuṣṭhaṃ krimīṃstathā||96||  iti punarnavāmaṇḍūram|
translation: A knowledgeable physician should carefully examine the strength and weakness of the patient, then cause them to consume a paste made from purified earth, black gram, two measures each of vyosha, bilva, haridra, triphala, musta, and devadaru, one measure each of vrischikaali, bhaargi, with added ghee prepared in equal quantities. This is recommended for a person afflicted by impure clay-eating. Similarly, for someone who has an uncontrollable urge to eat clay, the physician should prepare a paste from keshara, rayashti, hvapippalii, kshara shaal, and vala and administer it with the purpose of eliminating this disorder. This can be done using nimba leaves, bitter neem fruit, kaoutaja, or moorva.

sloka: dārvītvak triphalā vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgamayaso rajaḥ|  madhusarpiryutaṃ lihyāt kāmalāpāṇḍurogavān||97||  tulyā ayorajaḥpathyāharidrāḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  cūrṇitāḥ kāmalī lihyādguḍakṣaudreṇa vā'bhayāḥ||98||  triphalā dve haridre ca kaṭurohiṇyayorajaḥ|  cūrṇitaṃ kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ sa lehaḥ kāmalāpahaḥ||99||
translation: The appropriate use of medicine is considered the means to cure the afflictions of those suffering from a pale disease (skin disease).

sloka: dvipalāṃśāṃ tugākṣīrīṃ nāgaraṃ madhuyaṣṭikām|  prāsthikīṃ pippalīṃ drākṣāṃ śarkarārdhatulāṃ śubhām||100||  dhātrīphalarasadroṇe cūrṇitaṃ lehavat pacet|  śītaṃ madhuprasthayutaṃ lihyāt pāṇitalaṃ tataḥ||101||  hantyeṣa kāmalāṃ pittaṃ pāṇḍuṃ kāsaṃ halīmakam|  iti dhātryavalehaḥ|
translation:
The one who emits a complexion like crushed sesame seeds possesses excess bile, which should be subdued by pitta-reducing measures such as cool, light, and dry foods, as well as physical restraint. When Vata is obstructed due to an excess of Kapha, it becomes located in the Pitta site, leading to symptoms including a yellowing of the eyes, white complexion, and brightness. This results in a condition called Sannipata, characterized by heaviness in the heart, weakness, reduced digestive fire, hiccups, cough, fever, and fainting. One should gradually counter this increase in Pitta that has taken root in its branch.*
1667,बर्हितित्तिरिदक्षाणां रूक्षाम्लैः कटुकै रसैः॥१२८॥  शुष्कमूलककौलत्थैर्यूषैश्चान्नानि भोजयेत्।  मातुलुङ्गरसं क्षौद्रपिप्पलीमरिचान्वितम्॥१२९॥  सनागरं पिबेत् पित्तं तथाऽस्यैति स्वमाशयम्।१३०।,"One should consume foods seasoned with bitter, astringent, and pungent tastes, such as dry root vegetables and soured liquids, that are beneficial for those suffering from kapha imbalances. Such a diet includes ingredients like sesame seeds, dried Indian berries, and spices like turmeric. This helps to balance one's bodily fluids.

sloka: tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalā cavyaṃ citrako devadāru ca||102||  viḍaṅgānyatha mustaṃ ca vatsakaṃ ceti cūrṇayet|  maṇḍūratulyaṃ taccūrṇaṃ gomūtre'ṣṭaguṇe pacet||103||  śanaiḥ siddhāstathā śītāḥ kāryāḥ karṣasamā guḍāḥ|  yathāgni bhakṣaṇīyāste plīhapāṇḍvāmayāpahāḥ||104|| grahaṇyarśonudaścaiva takravāṭyāśinaḥ smṛtāḥ|  iti maṇḍūravaṭakāḥ|
translation: Upon the onset of excessive pungency, heat, bitterness, and saltiness, one should adopt a regimen. Once the bile has returned to normal and the feces have eliminated the excess bile, prior practices should be resumed, as per the auspicious ritual for pacifying Kámaliká.

sloka: mañjiṣṭhā rajanī drākṣā balāmūlānyayorajaḥ||105||  lodhraṃ caiteṣu gauḍaḥ syādariṣṭaḥ pāṇḍurogiṇām|  iti gauḍo'riṣṭaḥ|
translation: When Pandu's complexion becomes as dark as a cloud and he is devoid of strength, enthusiasm, and thirst; when his agni (digestive fire) becomes low, body weak, and he avoids physical contact with women; when he develops shortness of breath, loss of appetite, and a tendency to stray from consciousness - then one should know that this is due to an imbalance of wind and bile.

sloka: bījakātṣoḍaśapalaṃ triphalāyāśca viṃśatiḥ||106||  drākṣāyāḥ pañca lākṣāyāḥ sapta droṇe jalasya tat|  sādhyaṃ pādāvaśeṣe tu pūtaśeṣe samāvapet||107||  śarkarāyāstulāṃ prasthaṃ mākṣikasya ca kārṣikam|  vyoṣaṃ vyāghranakhośīraṃ kramukaṃ sailavālukam||108||  madhukaṃ kuṣṭhamityetaccūrṇitaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  yaveṣu daśarātraṃ tadgrīṣme dviḥ śiśire sthitam||109||  pibettadgrahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥśothagulmanut|  mūtrakṛcchrāśmarīmehakāmalāsannipātajit||110||  bījakāriṣṭa ityeṣa ātreyeṇa prakīrtitaḥ|  iti bījakāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: The preparation made from the sap of Giloe, mixed with milk, should be consumed by one who is desirous of a smooth and unctuous body. One should consume it together with the clarified butter that is described as having a sweet taste and being capable of alleviating the imbalances of bile and wind. Previously mentioned drinks such as grape juice, sugarcane juice, and other sweet liquids should be consumed in moderation. Additionally, one should consume yogurt, curd, and other similar foods that have been fermented with a proper method to promote agni (digestive fire) and use kashayam, abhayaleha, pippali, madhuka, and bala in an appropriate manner, based on one's digestive strength.

sloka: dhātrīphalasahasre dve pīḍayitvā rasaṃ tu tam||111||  kṣaudrāṣṭāṃśena saṃyuktaṃ kṛṣṇārdhakuḍavena ca|  śarkarārdhatulonmiśraṃ pakṣaṃ snigdhaghaṭe sthitam||112||  prapibenmātrayā prātarjīrṇe hitamitāśanaḥ|  kāmalāpāṇḍuhṛdrogavātāsṛgviṣamajvarān||113|| kāsahikkāruciśvāsāṃścaiṣo'riṣṭaḥ praṇāśayet|  iti dhātryariṣṭaḥ
translation: The cause and cure of the five types of Kama (desire) for both achievable and unachievable objects are mentioned there. Any other option is a great illness known as "halimaka". Its detailed treatment has also been stated.

sloka: स्थिरादिभिः शृतं तोयं पानाहारे प्रशस्यते॥११४॥  पाण्डूनां कामलार्तानां मृद्वीकामलकीरसः।११५।
translation: In the treatise written by Agnivesha, when the section on strength and fortitude is not obtained, it is named the sixteenth chapter of the treatment for pandu disease.
